BIOC 202.name: Introductory Medical Biochemistry
BIOC 202.desc: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202 or 203 or BIOL 201. [3-0-0]
BIOC 202.prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233 or (c) all of CHEM 233, PHAR 220. For option (a), a corequisite of CHEM 213 is required. For option (b), a corequisite of CHEM 205 is required.

BIOC 203.name: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
BIOC 203.desc: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. [3-0-1]

BIOC 301.name: Biochemistry Laboratory
BIOC 301.desc: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied. [0-3-1]

BIOC 302.name: General Biochemistry
BIOC 302.desc: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 300 or 302 or 303. [3-0-1]
BIOC 302.prer: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and either (a) one of CHEM 204, CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233 or (c) all of PHAR 220, CHEM 233.

BIOC 303.name: Molecular Biochemistry
BIOC 303.desc: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences.  Credit is given for only one of BIOC 300 or 302 or 303. [3-0-0]
BIOC 303.prer: One of BIOC 203, BIOL 201 and either (a) one of CHEM 204, CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233.

BIOC 304.name: Contemporary Biochemical Research
BIOC 304.desc: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues. [3-0-0]

BIOC 398.name: Internship Work Placement I
BIOC 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
BIOC 398.prer: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required.
preq: Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major

BIOC 399.name: Internship Work Placement II
BIOC 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BIOC 402.name: Proteins: Structure and Function
BIOC 402.desc: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR. [3-0-0]
BIOC 402.prer: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.
preq: BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses

BIOC 403.name: Enzymology
BIOC 403.desc: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit given for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569. [3-0-0]
BIOC 403.prer: BIOC 402. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.
preq: BIOC 402. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended

BIOC 404.name: Biochemical Methods
BIOC 404.desc: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research.  Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor. [1-0; 2-0]

BIOC 410.name: Nucleic Acids-Structure and Function
BIOC 410.desc: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will not be given for both BIOC 410 and 510. [3-0-0]
BIOC 410.prer: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.
preq: BIOT 380. A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses

BIOC 420.name: Advanced Biochemical Techniques
BIOC 420.desc: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques.  Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor. [0-6-0]

BIOC 421.name: Recombinant DNA Techniques
BIOC 421.desc: Multi-week experiments involving contemporary nucleic acid research, cloning and recombinant protein engineering. Emphasis is on experimental design, critical analysis of data and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Major students in Biochemistry. [0-6-0]

BIOC 440.name: Concepts in Molecular Biology
BIOC 440.desc: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression. [3-0-0]
BIOC 440.prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

BIOC 448.name: Directed Studies in Biochemistry
BIOC 448.desc: A library (3 credits) or a laboratory project with written report (3 or 6 credits) allowing a student to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty and student.
BIOC 448.prer: Permission of the Department Head is required.
preq: Permission of the Department Head is required

BIOC 449.name: Honours Thesis
BIOC 449.desc: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

BIOC 450.name: Membrane Biochemistry
BIOC 450.desc: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development. [3-0-0]
BIOC 450.prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

BIOC 460.name: Advanced Techniques in Biochemistry
BIOC 460.desc: Theoretical basis and practical applications of a selection of advanced techniques currently used in biochemical research. Topics will vary. [3-0-0]
BIOC 460.prer: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

BIOC 490.name: Student Directed Seminars
BIOC 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Not given every year. [3-0-0]

BIOC 498.name: Internship Work Placement III
BIOC 498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BIOC 499.name: Internship Work Placement IV
BIOC 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

BIOT 306.name: Microbiology III
BIOT 306.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT BIOT 6201.

BIOT 307.name: Molecular Genetics I

BIOT 311.name: Biochemistry I

BIOT 312.name: Biochemistry II
BIOT 312.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT BIOT 6240.

BIOT 323.name: Analytical Chemistry I
BIOT 323.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT CHEM 5509.

BIOT 324.name: Analytical Chemistry II

BIOT 331.name: Critical Reading & Writing
BIOT 331.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT LIBS 7001.

BIOT 351.name: Management Skills and Applications
BIOT 351.desc: Enrolment limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT BUSA 7250.

BIOT 352.name: Management and Regulatory Affairs
BIOT 352.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT BIOT 6270.

BIOT 361.name: Applied Ethics
BIOT 361.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology. Same as BCIT LIBS 7002.

BIOT 380.name: Advanced Biotechnology
BIOT 380.desc: Block registration for the microbiology, molecular genetics, biochemistry, management and regulatory affairs, process systems, analytical chemistry and communication courses taken in the BCIT/UBC Joint Degree in Biotechnology.  Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

BIOT 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
BIOT 398.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology.

BIOT 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
BIOT 399.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biotechnology.

BMEG 101.name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
BMEG 101.desc: Core principles of biomedical engineering from a clinical perspective. Sensors and instrumentation, bioelectric phenomenon, biosignals, physiological modeling, biomechanics, biomaterials, tissue engineering, the principles of and design for medical imaging equipment, clinical engineering, moral and ethical issues.
BMEG 101.prer: All of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, MATH 100, MATH 101.

BMEG 102.name: Biomedical Engineering Lab
BMEG 102.desc: Rapid prototyping of mechanical, electrical and electromechanical systems. Building parts with state of the art software and 3-D printing. Use of laboratory equipment and instrumentation.

BMEG 150.name: The Fundamental Units of Life: From Cells To Systems
BMEG 150.desc: The structure and function of cells and how they are organized to generate tissues and organ systems [3-3*-0]

BMEG 201.name: Technical Communication for Biomedical Engineers
BMEG 201.desc: Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation in biomedical engineering specific cases and projects. Credit will not be granted for both BMEG 201 and APSC 201.

BMEG 210.name: Thermodynamics in Biomedical Engineering
BMEG 210.desc: Work, heat and energy; material and energy balances; the first law and second law of thermodynamics; entropy and process reversibility; availability (energy) analysis; Hess's Law; thermodynamic properties of fluids; and applications to biomedical systems.

BMEG 220.name: Circuits and Electromagnetics with Application to Biomedical Engineering
BMEG 220.desc: Electromagnetic phenomena in the  body; bioinstrumentation; electrostatic and electromagnetic fields, forces, capacitance and inductance; bio-effects of electromagnetic fields; and modelling electrical components of physiological and biomedical systems.
BMEG 220.prer: All of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, MATH 100, MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256.

BMEG 230.name: Biomechanics I
BMEG 230.desc: Integrating the study of two dimensional movement of animals and humans with the study of the manner in which forces on biomechanical structures such as bones, ligaments, tendons, muscles and joints cause motion. Techniques of solid mechanics and two dimensional rigid body dynamics.

BMEG 250.name: Cellular  Physiology  and Biophysics
BMEG 250.desc: Cellular structure and mechanisms of membrane transport, signal transduction, muscle mechanochemistry and neurotransmission. Structure and hierarchical organization up to the level of tissues. Light and electron microscopy.

BMEG 257.name: Biomedical Engineering Design I
BMEG 257.desc: Engineering design process for medical technologies. Clinical practice, the healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, use of statistics for evaluating medical technologies.

BMEG 310.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
BMEG 310.desc: Principles behind the methods of bioinformatics. The use of bioinformatics databases and tools for solving problems in genomics, proteomics, structural biology and evolutionary biology.

BMEG 320.name: Bioengineering Feedback Systems and Controls
BMEG 320.desc: Modeling, analysis and simulation of dynamic systems; system modeling by state space; linearization; feedback, stability and sensitivity; control system design. Examples from biological systems, assistive systems and biomedical equipment
BMEG 320.prer: All of PHYS 157, MATH 253, MATH 256, BMEG 220.

BMEG 330.name: Biomechanics II
BMEG 330.desc: Principles and common elements of sports-, orthopaedic-, injury- and cellular length-biomechanics. Improving sports performance and preventing overuse injuries through sports biomechanics, designing orthopaedic implants through orthopaedic biomechanics, preventing injuries through injury biomechanics and identifying and filtering cancerous blood cells through cellular biomechanics.

BMEG 350.name: Human Structure/Function from Cells to Systems
BMEG 350.desc: Human anatomy, histology and physiology with examples from biomedical engineering. Anatomical compartmentation and function regulation; homeostatic control systems, sensors and effectors; intercellular communication strategies; and cellular and organ function assessment.

BMEG 357.name: Biomedical  Engineering Design II
BMEG 357.desc: Creating innovations in medical technologies. Case studies in need clinical identification. Supervised design process, building and testing prototypes with potential users.

BMEG 370.name: Cellular  Responses  to Forces and Biomaterials
BMEG 370.desc: Mechanical forces and biomaterials regulating cellular functions critical to tissue development, regeneration and repair.

BMEG 371.name: Transport Phenomena within Cells and Tissues
BMEG 371.desc: Fluid flow and mass transport analysis within healthy and diseased cells and tissues using mathematics. Drug delivery and tissue engineering.
BMEG 371.prer: All of MATH 100, MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256.

BMEG 372.name: Biomedical Materials and Drug Delivery
BMEG 372.desc: Biomaterials science/engineering applied to design and synthesis of drug delivery systems. Biomaterial types, synthesis and testing; the use of biomaterials; biological response; biocompatibility and degradation; drug delivery systems; nanocarriers; modification of polymers; liposomes and micelles; nucleic acid, transdermal and oral delivery.

BMEG 373.name: Microfludics
BMEG 373.desc: Advantages and disadvantages of miniaturization of complex fluid flow processes. Manipulating liquid flow; electrophoretic velocity and mobility; serial dilution; capillary electrophoresis; integrated microfluidic platforms; and blood and the motility of bacteria.

BMEG 390.name: Medical Imaging
BMEG 390.desc: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, X-ray projection imaging and molecular imaging in medical imaging for diagnostics, therapeutics and interventions.

BMEG 410.name: Biomedical Equipment, Physiology, and Anatomy
BMEG 410.desc: Principles and operation of biomedical equipment for cardiovascular system, respiratory system, renal dialysis, endoscopy, surgery, and imaging. Functional relationships of biomedical equipment to physiology and anatomy of major body systems. Restricted to students in EECE and MECH Biomedical Engineering options. Credit will be given for only one of BMEG 410 or BMEG 510. [3-0-2*]

BMEG 430.name: Economics of Healthcare Solutions
BMEG 430.desc: Canadian and USA engineering economics in BME and healthcare systems.  Economic equivalence, cost estimation, risk assessment, regulatory frameworks, economic optimization, intangible factors, ethics, sustainability, financial tools, commercialization and regulator regimes.

BMEG 450.name: Biomedical Engineering Design Project
BMEG 450.desc: Capstone design and development of a practical biomedical device or system. Projects provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories.

BMEG 456.name: Clinical and Industrial Biomedical Engineering
BMEG 456.desc: Principles of clinical practice, Canadian healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, biostatistics. Restricted to students in EECE and MECH Biomedical Engineering options. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 456 or BMEG 556.

BMEG 474.name: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine
BMEG 474.desc: Biology and applications of stem cells in regenerative medicine. Modeling human biology and disease in vitro and in vivo. Regulatory and commercialization pathways for regenerative medicine innovations.

BIOL 111.name: Introduction to Modern Biology
BIOL 111.desc: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems.  Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB). [3-0-0]

BIOL 112.name: Biology of the Cell
BIOL 112.desc: The principles of cellular and molecular biology using bacterial and eukaryotic examples. [3-0-0]
BIOL 112.prer: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

BIOL 121.name: Genetics, Evolution and Ecology
BIOL 121.desc: Principles of storage and transmission of genetic variation; origin and evolution of species and their ecological interactions. [3-0-0]

BIOL 140.name: Laboratory Investigations in Life Science
BIOL 140.desc: Guided experimental investigations of biological questions. [1-2-0]

BIOL 153.name: Human Biology
BIOL 153.desc: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). Laboratories include selected experiments on organ physiology and general anatomy. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

BIOL 155.name: Human Biology
BIOL 155.desc: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology). [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

BIOL 200.name: Fundamentals of Cell Biology
BIOL 200.desc: Structure and function of plant and animal cells; membrane models, cytoplasmic organelles, biological information from gene to protein, the endomembrane system, secretion, intracellular digestion, endocytosis, transport processes, cytoskeleton and cell motility. [3-0-1]
BIOL 200.prer: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 113;  or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of CHEM 203.

BIOL 201.name: Introduction to Biochemistry
BIOL 201.desc: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-1]
BIOL 201.prer: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.

BIOL 203.name: Eukaryotic Microbiology
BIOL 203.desc: Introduction to the origin and diversity of protists (protozoa and algae) at both cellular and genomic levels, including the role of endosymbiosis in evolution. [3-3-0]
BIOL 203.prer: BIOL 140 and one of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. BIOL 200 recommended.

BIOL 204.name: Vertebrate Structure and Function
BIOL 204.desc: Introduction to the vertebrate phyla and their evolution; a comparative study of vertebrate structure and function, with dissection of representative forms. [3-3-0]
BIOL 204.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL 205.name: Comparative Invertebrate Zoology
BIOL 205.desc: An introduction to the unity, diversity and evolutionary history of invertebrates. [3-3-0]
BIOL 205.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL 209.name: Biodiversity of algae, fungi and bryophytes
BIOL 209.desc: Diversity, ecology, cell biology and evolutionary origins of multicellular eukaryotes, illustrated through mosses and liverworts; fungi and slime molds; and fresh water and marine algae. [3-3-0]
BIOL 209.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL 210.name: Vascular Plants
BIOL 210.desc: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function and ecology. [3-3]
BIOL 210.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.

BIOL 230.name: Fundamentals of Ecology
BIOL 230.desc: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-3*-0]

BIOL 233.name: Genetics for Life
BIOL 233.desc: How genetic differences determine individual characteristics, and how they are inherited, analyzed, and modified. Emphasis on genetic diversity, human ancestry, personal genomics, and cancer genetics. [3-0-2]
BIOL 233.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001; or (c) a corequisite of CHEM 203 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

BIOL 234.name: Fundamentals of Genetics
BIOL 234.desc: Genotype and phenotype, mechanisms of inheritance, genetic analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]
BIOL 234.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) a corequisite of CHEM 203 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.

BIOL 260.name: Fundamentals of Physiology
BIOL 260.desc: Principles of cellular and organismal physiology illustrated with examples from unicellular organisms, plants and animals, focusing on transport processes, water balance, nutrient acquisition and communication. [3-0-0]
BIOL 260.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001 or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.

BIOL 300.name: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
BIOL 300.desc: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]
BIOL 300.prer: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

BIOL 301.name: Biomathematics
BIOL 301.desc: Introduction to uses of mathematics in the biological sciences; experimental design and modelling of biological processes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]

BIOL 306.name: Advanced Ecology
BIOL 306.desc: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-3*-0]

BIOL 310.name: Introduction to Animal Behaviour
BIOL 310.desc: Animal behavior from an ecological and evolutionary perspective; the methods used to study behaviour and test its adaptive significance. [3-0-2]

BIOL 317.name: Weed Science
BIOL 317.desc: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventative, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0]

BIOL 320.name: Survey of Algae
BIOL 320.desc: A survey of the algae, considering their morphology, life history, classification, and ecology. [3-3-0]

BIOL 321.name: Morphology and Evolution of Bryophytes
BIOL 321.desc: A study of evolution, taxonomy and morphology of mosses, liverworts and hornworts with emphasis on living plants in their environment. [2-4-0]

BIOL 322.name: Structure and Evolution of Ferns and Fern-allies
BIOL 322.desc: Anatomy, morphology and relationships of the ferns and fern-allies, with assessment of both fossil and extant taxa. [2-4-0]

BIOL 323.name: Structure and Reproduction of Fungi
BIOL 323.desc: The evolutionary diversity of the fungi as shown by their morphology and reproductive biology. [2-3-0]

BIOL 324.name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
BIOL 324.desc: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0]

BIOL 325.name: Introduction to Animal Mechanics and Locomotion
BIOL 325.desc: Comparative aspects of the functional design of skeletal systems and the mechanics of swimming, flying and terrestrial locomotion, with particular reference to the vertebrates. [3-0-0]

BIOL 326.name: Experimental Biology of Invertebrates
BIOL 326.desc: Behaviour and ecology of invertebrates as revealed by hands-on experiments in the laboratory and field.  Marine emphasis. [1-4-0]

BIOL 327.name: Introduction to Entomology
BIOL 327.desc: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology, life-histories and insect-plant relations.

BIOL 328.name: Introductory Parasitology
BIOL 328.desc: Classification, morphology and life histories of animal parasites affecting humans and other animals. [2-3-0]

BIOL 331.name: Developmental Biology
BIOL 331.desc: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology. [3-3-0]
BIOL 331.prer: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

BIOL 332.name: Protistology
BIOL 332.desc: Cell biology, ecology, and evolution of protists; origins of multicellularity; the role of protists in micropaleontology, parasitology, and oceanography. [3-3-0]

BIOL 335.name: Molecular Genetics
BIOL 335.desc: Isolation and identification of genes, analysis of gene structure; gene expression and its regulation in prokaryotes and in eukaryotes; developmental genetics. [3-0-2]
BIOL 335.prer: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, MICB 322, FRST 302.

BIOL 336.name: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Biology
BIOL 336.desc: Natural selection; population genetics, quantitative genetics and systematics; classical and molecular approaches to the study of evolution. [3-0-2]

BIOL 337.name: Introductory Genetics Laboratory
BIOL 337.desc: A laboratory course demonstrating the fundamental principles of inheritance: Mendel's Laws, sex-linkage, mapping, mutagenesis, chromosome structure, developmental biology, biochemical and population genetics. [1-4-0]

BIOL 338.name: Introduction to Genomics
BIOL 338.desc: An introduction to genome biology and applications of genomics. [3-0-1.5]

BIOL 340.name: Introductory Cell Biology Laboratory
BIOL 340.desc: Experiments using unicellular eukaryotes or prokaryotes with emphasis on techniques in microscopy and cell biology. [1-3-0]
BIOL 340.prer: All of BIOL 140, BIOL 200. And at least third-year standing in Science.
preq: at least third-year standing in Science

BIOL 341.name: Introductory Molecular Biology Laboratory
BIOL 341.prer: BIOL 200. And at least third-year standing in Science.
preq: at least third-year standing in Science

BIOL 342.name: Integrative Biology Laboratory
BIOL 342.desc: Field-based and laboratory-based investigation of organisms. [1-3-0]
BIOL 342.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140 or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology; and third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science.
preq: higher in Combined Major in Science

BIOL 343.name: Plants and Peoples
BIOL 343.desc: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students. [2-2-1]

BIOL 344.name: Human Heredity and Evolution
BIOL 344.desc: Relates genetic and evolutionary concepts to humans. Primarily for upper-level students in the Faculty of Arts. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344. Not open to students in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

BIOL 345.name: Human Ecology
BIOL 345.desc: Basics of ecology are introduced, focussing on observations of the natural world. Assignments, including a group project, consider connections between research, awareness and practical uses of ecology. Not for credit in the Life Sciences. [3-0-2]

BIOL 346.name: Microbes and Society
BIOL 346.desc: An elementary course in molecular biology primarily for Arts students. The historical development of recent discoveries in molecular biology with emphasis on bacteria and viruses and their interaction with humans. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Not for credit in Life Sciences. [3-0-0]

BIOL 347.name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
BIOL 347.desc: Contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 449. [2-3-0]

BIOL 351.name: Plant Physiology I
BIOL 351.desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology. [3-3-0]
BIOL 351.prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. CHEM 233 is recommended.

BIOL 352.name: Plant Physiology II: Plant Development
BIOL 352.desc: Introduction to the processes involved in growth and development: cell division, tissue culture, meristems, differentiation, and the action of major growth regulators, and photomorphogenesis. Emphasis on experimental approaches. [2-3-1]
BIOL 352.prer: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) FRST 302. CHEM 233 is recommended.

BIOL 361.name: Physiology of Sensory, Nervous and Muscular Systems
BIOL 361.desc: Excitable membranes, neural signaling and transmission; transduction and coding of sensory information; muscle contraction. [3-0-0]
BIOL 361.prer: BIOL 200. One of BIOL 260 or BIOL 201 recommended.

BIOL 362.name: Cellular Physiology
BIOL 362.desc: The cytoskeleton, cell dynamics, and regulation of cellular activities. Preference will be given to Majors or Honours students in Biology and Honours Biophysics. [2-0-1]
BIOL 362.prer: Either (a) BIOL 361 or (b) all of BIOL 201, BIOL 351.

BIOL 363.name: Laboratory in Animal Physiology
BIOL 363.desc: Experimental studies in animal physiology. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology, Nutritional Sciences and Biophysics. [1-3-1]

BIOL 364.name: Animal Physiology
BIOL 364.desc: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and osmoregulatory physiology. Preference will be given to students who are in Biology, Nutritional Sciences, and Honours Biophysics. [3-0-0]
BIOL 364.prer: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

BIOL 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
BIOL 398.desc: Work experience in an industrial setting, taken during Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

BIOL 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
BIOL 399.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

BIOL 401.name: Theory of Evolutionary Dynamics
BIOL 401.desc: Evolution as a dynamical system based on ecological interactions. Adaptive dynamics and evolutionary game theory. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 401 and BIOL 560.
BIOL 401.prer: BIOL 301 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

BIOL 402.name: Aquatic Ecology
BIOL 402.desc: Theoretical and applied limnology; ecology of inland water organisms in relation to physical, chemical and biological factors. One weekend field trip required. [2-4-0]
BIOL 402.prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

BIOL 404.name: Ecological Methodology
BIOL 404.desc: Design, execution, and analysis of ecological surveys and experiments. Practical field methods for estimating population metrics and describing community structure. Computer techniques for the statistical analysis of ecological data. [2-4-0]
BIOL 404.prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

BIOL 406.name: Plant Ecology I
BIOL 406.desc: Plant community ecology including a consideration of the major approaches to sampling, analyzing and interpreting vegetation patterns. Instruction given in field work and computer analysis of field data. [3-3-0]

BIOL 408.name: Principles of Applied Ecology
BIOL 408.desc: Principles of animal and community ecology applicable to the management of animal resources; application of statistical and computer techniques for measuring, analyzing, modelling, and simulating resource systems; problems of multiple resource use. [2-2-0]

BIOL 409.name: Field Course in Ecology
BIOL 409.desc: A two-week intensive course in field methods used in ecology. Fieldwork for this course is normally in the summer. A fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration required.
BIOL 409.prer: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200. BIOL 306 is recommended.

BIOL 410.name: Current Topics in Animal Behaviour
BIOL 410.desc: Lectures and seminar discussions on selected topics in animal behaviour. [2-0-2]
BIOL 410.prer: BIOL 310. Permission of the head of Zoology is also acceptable.
preq: BIOL 310. Permission of the head of Zoology is also acceptable

BIOL 411.name: Insect Ecology
BIOL 411.desc: Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0-0]
BIOL 411.prer: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of AGRO 327, BIOL 327.

BIOL 412.name: Phytogeography
BIOL 412.desc: Description and interpretation of present and past floristic vegetational patterns; integration of evolutionary, ecological, and phytogeographical concepts. Terrestrial and aquatic plants are considered. Restricted to students of third and fourth years. [3-0-0]

BIOL 413.name: Zoogeography
BIOL 413.desc: The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year. [3-0-0]

BIOL 415.name: Evolutionary Processes in Plants
BIOL 415.desc: Experimental and comparative analysis of evolutionary processes, speciation, and phylogenetic patterns in plants. [2-0-0]

BIOL 416.name: Principles of Conservation Biology
BIOL 416.desc: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-0-2]

BIOL 417.name: Phylogenetic Biology
BIOL 417.desc: Biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective. The evolutionary (phylogenetic) tree of genetic descent that links all organisms: its reconstruction, interpretation, and implications for fields from ecology to molecular biology. [2-0-2]
BIOL 417.prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. BIOL 336 is recommended

BIOL 418.name: Evolutionary Ecology
BIOL 418.desc: Ecological adaptation and evolutionary processes in contemporary populations; natural selection, variation, optimization, foraging theory, coevolution, arms races; life history theory, evolution of sex, sexual selection, evolution in managed populations. [2-2-0]

BIOL 420.name: Ocean Conservation and Sustainability
BIOL 420.desc: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication.

BIOL 421.name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
BIOL 421.desc: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society. [3-0-2]
BIOL 421.prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260, BIOL 201.

BIOL 423.name: Plant Stress Ecophysiology
BIOL 423.desc: Molecular mechanisms of plant responses to extreme environments. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

BIOL 425.name: Biomechanics
BIOL 425.desc: An analytical approach to the study of skeletal mechanics and animal locomotion. Selected topics in the structure and properties of biological materials, the functional design of skeletons for locomotion, and the fluid mechanics of swimming and flight. [2-3-0]

BIOL 426.name: Mammalogy
BIOL 426.desc: Natural history, behavioral ecology and conservation of terrestrial mammals. The laboratory includes classification, life histories, and ecology, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0]

BIOL 427.name: Ornithology and Herpetology
BIOL 427.desc: Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles.  Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia. [2-3-0]

BIOL 428.name: Evolutionary Morphology of Marine Invertebrates
BIOL 428.desc: Comparative analysis of marine invertebrate morphology from a macroevolutionary perspective.  Origin and evolution of reoccurring adaptations in meiofaunal, benthic, pelagic, and deep-sea invertebrates, including their larval stages. [3-0-0]

BIOL 430.name: Genome Evolution
BIOL 430.desc: Integration of molecular genetics and genomics with evolutionary biology. Emphasis on the evolutionary dynamics of genomes and the evolutionary implications of recent discoveries in molecular genetics and genomics. [3-0-0]
BIOL 430.prer: One of BIOL 335, BIOL 338. Or with instructor permission BIOL 336.
preq: BIOL 338. Or with instructor permission BIOL 336

BIOL 431.name: Evolutionary Cell Biology
BIOL 431.desc: Ultrastructure, biogenesis, and evolution of eukaryotic cells and cell organelles, including their macromolecular basis. [3-0-0]

BIOL 432.name: Research Strategies and Techniques in Cell Biology
BIOL 432.desc: Major physiological mechanisms that define eukaryotic cells, explored through student visits to UBC research laboratories and discussion of recent scientific literature, with emphasis on the techniques and strategies that enable researchers to test hypotheses and advance new concepts. [3-0-0]
BIOL 432.prer: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. And fourth-year standing.

BIOL 433.name: Plant Genetics
BIOL 433.desc: Emphasis on molecular aspects. Systems and techniques for genetic analysis in plants; isolation and regulation of plant genes; genetic dissection of plant-specific processes; transposable elements; gene transfer in plants; cytoplasmic inheritance; genetic engineering. [3-0-2]

BIOL 434.name: Population Genetics
BIOL 434.desc: Theoretical and experimental aspects of population and quantitative genetics. [3-0-2]
BIOL 434.prer: BIOL 336 and either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234;  or (b) FRST 302.

BIOL 436.name: Integrated Functional Genomics
BIOL 436.desc: Global transcript, protein, and metabolite profiling technologies and their integration; applications focus on plant functions and plant interactions with pathogens and pests. [3-0-0]

BIOL 437.name: Laboratory in Animal Cell Molecular Biology
BIOL 437.desc: The use of recombinant DNA techniques to explore problems in animal developmental biology. [2-4-0]
BIOL 437.prer: All of BIOL 331, BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 302, BIOC 303. Permission of the department head is also required.
preq: BIOC 303. Permission of the department head is also required

BIOL 438.name: Zoological Physics
BIOL 438.desc: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0]
BIOL 438.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended.

BIOL 440.name: Plant Genomics
BIOL 440.desc: Concepts, principles, applications, and recent discoveries in genome structure, genetics, and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants. [3-0-0]

BIOL 441.name: Cell Biology of Intracellular Trafficking
BIOL 441.desc: Analysis of cellular organelles and the intracellular traffic between them, concentrating on mammalian cell systems. [3-0-0]
BIOL 441.prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 340, BIOL 341 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 362 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203.

BIOL 444.name: Techniques in Plant Molecular Biology
BIOL 444.desc: Purification and analysis of nucleic acids, electrophoresis and immunodetection of proteins. Restricted to Honours students with permission of the Head of Botany and the Biotechnology Teaching Laboratory. [0-7-0]

BIOL 445.name: Darwin's Fishes
BIOL 445.desc: A series of computer-assisted lectures using ichthyology and the work of Charles Darwin to illustrate basic principles of biology, and their practical implementation, i.e., how biologists select research programs, generate and test hypotheses, and present their case to peers and the public. [2-0-2]
BIOL 445.prer: Third-year standing in Science is required.
preq: Third-year standing in Science is required

BIOL 446.name: History and Philosophy of Biology
BIOL 446.desc: The nature of science, this history of evolutionary and molecular biology, philosophical questions about scientific methods and fundamental conclusions of biology. [3-0-0]
BIOL 446.prer: Fourth-year standing in any degree program is required.
preq: Fourth-year standing in any degree program is required

BIOL 447.name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
BIOL 447.desc: Seminars, debates, workshops and tutorials designed to produce competence in specific areas of Biology. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. [2-3-0]

BIOL 448.name: Directed Studies in Biology
BIOL 448.desc: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

BIOL 449.name: Directed Biological Research
BIOL 449.desc: A course designed to allow students to undertake a research project in selected fields. Open only to Honours students in Biology, with permission of the supervisor. Presentation of a thesis and an oral examination are required.

BIOL 450.name: Molecular Adaptation of Animals to the Environment
BIOL 450.desc: Physiological, biochemical, and molecular strategies of adaptation of animals to environmental challenges.  The evolution of genetic and biochemical systems, and their impact on animal structure and function. [3-0-0]
BIOL 450.prer: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. BIOL 457 is recommended.

BIOL 454.name: Comparative Animal Physiology
BIOL 454.desc: Selected topics in physiology emphasizing comparisons between diverse phylogenetic groups of animals. [3-0-0]

BIOL 455.name: Comparative Neurobiology
BIOL 455.desc: Current approaches in neurobiology, from the cellular to the behavioural level, are examined using representatives of vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems. [3-0-2*]
BIOL 455.prer: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, CAPS 301, PSYC 360.

BIOL 456.name: Comparative and Molecular Endocrinology
BIOL 456.desc: A comparative study of vertebrate and invertebrate endocrinology. [3-0-0]

BIOL 457.name: Comparative Environmental Physiology
BIOL 457.desc: A survey of physiological adaptions of animals to different environments. [3-0-0]

BIOL 458.name: Developmental Neurobiology
BIOL 458.desc: Cellular, molecular and physiological aspects of nervous system development with applications to understanding adult nervous system function and neurological disorders. [3-0-0]

BIOL 459.name: Neurobiology of Sensory and Motor Systems
BIOL 459.desc: Analysis of the mechanisms of sensory processing and motor orchestration using vertebrate and invertebrate model systems.  Neural circuit structure, specialization, information coding, integration, and behaviour. [3-0-0]

BIOL 462.name: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
BIOL 462.desc: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0]
BIOL 462.prer: All of BIOL 200, BIOL 201. BIOL 209 or BIOL 210 is recommended.

BIOL 463.name: Gene Regulation in Development
BIOL 463.desc: Control of gene expression in development; the genetic and physiological basis of epigenetic determination; inductive interactions. [3-0-0]
BIOL 463.prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 302, BIOC 303. BIOL 331 is recommended.

BIOL 464.name: Animal Developmental Genetics
BIOL 464.desc: Role of genes in embryonic development.  Emphasis on tissue specific expression patterns and the role of genetic networks in establishing cell types. [3-0-0]

BIOL 465.name: Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
BIOL 465.desc: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity. [2-3-0]

BIOL 466.name: Applied Biology of Fishes
BIOL 466.desc: Physiological ecology and exploitation biology of teleost fishes; computer-based analysis and modeling of fish populations.

BIOL 490.name: Student Directed Seminars
BIOL 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Normally not suitable as a specific BIOL program elective. [3-0]

BIOL 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
BIOL 498.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

BIOL 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
BIOL 499.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

SEAL 440.name: Supervised Study in Southeast Asian Languages

LAST 100.name: Introduction to Latin American Studies
LAST 100.desc: An overview of the culture and society of Latin America from ancient to contemporary times and from Argentina to Mexico.

LAST 201.name: Popular Culture in Latin America
LAST 201.desc: The culture of everyday life, both rural and urban: issues of identity, popular memory, resistance, negotiation, as expressed through ritual, crafts, the body, social movements, films, music, and literature.

LAST 205.name: Issues of Development in Modern Latin America
LAST 205.desc: Theory of development in the Latin American context: current problems and development alternatives.

LAST 301.name: Human and Civil Rights in Latin America
LAST 301.desc: Focuses on human rights movements; state violence and impunity; reform of criminal justice systems; rights of indigenous peoples, women, and minorities; international protection of human rights; the UN and inter-American systems.

LAST 303.name: Indigenous Peoples of Latin America
LAST 303.desc: Ethnohistory and contemporary cultures of the indigenous peoples of Mexico, Middle America, and South America. Different cultural areas or regions may be selected to illustrate the course's principal themes.

ECON 101.name: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON 101.desc: Elements of theory and of Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of markets and market behaviour, prices and costs, exchange and trade, competition and monopoly, distribution of income.

ECON 102.name: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON 102.desc: Elements of theory and of Canadian policy and institutions concerning the economics of growth and business cycles, national income accounting, interest and exchange rates, money and banking, the balance of trade.

ECON 204.name: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
ECON 204.desc: Mathematical and graphical models of individual, household, and firm behavior with applications to issues in international economics. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 204, 301, or 304.
ECON 204.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON 210.name: Microeconomic Policy
ECON 210.desc: A survey of policy issues, such as regulation, taxation, environmental and resource policy, health care, education and income distribution.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON 211.name: Macroeconomic Policy
ECON 211.desc: A survey of policy issues, such as the costs of inflation and unemployment, monetary and fiscal policy, the effects of government debt and exchange rate policy.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON 221.name: Introduction to Strategic Thinking
ECON 221.desc: An introduction to how people interact in strategic situations drawn from political science, history, psychology, law, biology, military history, economics, business, and anthropology. The focus will be on developing intuition.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 221 or ISCI 344.

ECON 226.name: Making Sense of Economic Data
ECON 226.desc: Formulation of a testable hypothesis, identification of relevant data, use of appropriate statistical tools.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing in ECON or COMM. Not available for credit to students already having credit for either of ECON 325 or ECON 326 (or equivalent).

ECON 234.name: Wealth and Poverty of Nations
ECON 234.desc: Historical approaches to long-run economic growth; international comparisons of income growth and inequality; colonialism; evolution of world capital markets; human migrations; rise of world trading empires; instability in the international economy.  Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 234 or former ECON 334 (6).  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON 255.name: Understanding Globalization
ECON 255.desc: Social and economic implications for both rich and poor countries of lowered barriers to the international flows of information, capital, labour and goods.  May not be taken for credit by students with fourth-year standing.

ECON 301.name: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis I
ECON 301.desc: Consumer behaviour, producer theory, exchange, monopoly, oligopoly, externalities, public goods, general equilibrium and welfare economics. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 201, ECON 301, or ECON 304.

ECON 302.name: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis I
ECON 302.desc: Income and employment theory, monetary theory, the open economy, economic fluctuations and growth. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 302, ECON 305.
ECON 302.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON 303.name: Intermediate Microeconomics II
ECON 303.desc: Risk and uncertainty, some concepts in game theory, adverse selection, moral hazard, bargaining, auctions. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 303 and 306.

ECON 304.name: Honours Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis I
ECON 304.desc: Consumer behaviour, producer theory, exchange, monopoly, oligopoly, externalities, public goods, general equilibrium and welfare economics. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 301 or 304 or COMM 295.
ECON 304.prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of ECON 101, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON 305.name: Honours Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis I
ECON 305.desc: Income and employment theory, monetary theory, the open economy, economic fluctuations and growth. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 302, ECON 305.
ECON 305.prer: A score of 68% or higher in all of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON 306.name: Honours Intermediate Microeconomics II
ECON 306.desc: Risk and uncertainty, some concepts in game theory, adverse selection, moral hazard, bargaining, auctions. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 303 and 306.
ECON 306.prer: A score of 68% or higher in ECON 304. Permission of the School is also acceptable.
preq: higher in ECON 304. Permission of the School is also acceptable

ECON 307.name: Honours Intermediate Macroeconomics II
ECON 307.desc: Theories of economic growth and the business cycle. Intended primarily for prospective honours and other qualified students.
ECON 307.prer: A score of 68% or higher in ECON 305. Or permission of the School.
preq: higher in ECON 305. Or permission of the School

ECON 308.name: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
ECON 308.desc: Mathematical and graphical models of individual, household, and firm behavior with applications to issues in international economics. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 301, 304, or 308.
ECON 308.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON 309.name: Intermediate Open Economy Macroeconomics
ECON 309.desc: The aggregate economy with emphasis on macroeconomic policy and international economic growth, money and inflation, unemployment, business cycles, and macroeconomic stabilization policy under fixed and flexible exchange rates. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 302, 305, or 309.
ECON 309.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON 310.name: Principles of Microeconomics
ECON 310.desc: The scope of this course is approximately the same as that of ECON101. The course is intended for upper-level students only. Credit will be given for only one of ECON 310 and ECON 101.

ECON 311.name: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON 311.desc: The scope of this course is approximately the same as that of ECON 102. The course is intended for upper-level students only. Credit will be given for only one of ECON 311 and ECON 102.

ECON 312.name: Political Economy of Capitalism
ECON 312.desc: An intellectual history of the evolution of the capitalist system and its institutions; a selection of defences and criticisms of capitalism and its alternatives in the writings of leading social and political philosophers from the 18th to the 20th centuries.

ECON 313.name: Marxist Economics
ECON 313.desc: Marxist critiques of capitalist systems and Marxian alternatives. The origin of exploitation; feudalism and capitalism; exploitation and profits; the morality of exploitation; the emergence of class; historical materialism; Marxist theories of imperialism; and public ownership of the means of production.

ECON 317.name: Poverty and Inequality
ECON 317.desc: Economic inequality in Canada and other countries; measurement and causes. Inequality in the distribution of wealth; redistribution of income and wealth; notions of distributive justice.

ECON 318.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith
ECON 318.desc: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.

ECON 319.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes
ECON 319.desc: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present including such figures as Malthus, Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

ECON 320.name: Introduction to Mathematical Economics
ECON 320.desc: Application of single and multivariable calculus to economics. Includes comparative static analysis of household and firm behaviour as well as simple dynamic models. ECON 320 cannot be counted as satisfying ECON requirements for the Combined Major in Economics/Mathematics.
ECON 320.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON 325.name: Introduction to Empirical Economics
ECON 325.desc: Essentials of probability and statistics for applied work in economics. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, and analysis of variance. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
ECON 325.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 104, MATH 105.

ECON 326.name: Methods of Empirical Research in Economics
ECON 326.desc: Techniques of empirical economic research. Topics include simple and multiple regression, time series analysis, and simultaneous equation estimation. Students will be required to undertake applied work. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

ECON 327.name: Introduction to Empirical Methods
ECON 327.desc: Basic tools for the statistical analysis of economic data. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 325, ECON 327,or STAT 200.
ECON 327.prer: All of ECON 101, ECON 102, MATH 105 and one of MATH 104, MATH 184.

ECON 328.name: Methods of Empirical Research
ECON 328.desc: Empirical tools used in applied research, with emphasis on the linear regression model. Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics program. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 326, ECON 328, or STAT 306.

ECON 334.name: Economic History of Modern Europe
ECON 334.desc: Background, causes and effects of economic change in Europe from the 18th century to recent times. Evolution of social and economic institutions; analysis of growth, structural change, the distribution of income, and the spread of industrialization.

ECON 335.name: Fertility, Families and Human Migration
ECON 335.desc: Traditional fertility and mortality patterns, demographic transition, catastrophes, well-being and nutrition, international and internal migration, epidemics and growth spurts.

ECON 336.name: Economic History of Canada
ECON 336.desc: The growth of the Canadian economy in relation to development of natural resources, changing markets, industrialism, communications, and technology.

ECON 337.name: Economic History of the United States
ECON 337.desc: The growth of the United States from the Colonial Era to the present: British colonialism, development of slave-based agriculture, the western expansion, the 'American system' of manufacturing, cyclical instability and depression, and the distribution of income.

ECON 339.name: Economics of Technological Change
ECON 339.desc: Application of economic analysis to technological change; the impact of technological change on the growth and distribution of income; economic influences on the invention and diffusion of technology; the interaction between technology, work, skills, and education; public policy toward technological change.

ECON 341.name: Economic Development of Asia
ECON 341.desc: Economic development under colonialism, the colonial legacy, population, trade and development, land reform, the Green Revolution, industrialization strategies, distribution of the gains from development. Each topic is discussed in the context of an Asian country.

ECON 342.name: The Economy of China since 1949
ECON 342.desc: The Maoist strategy of development, the commune system and rural development, the pace and pattern of industrialization, management and planning, incentive policy, economic lessons from China. Students who wish to contrast different approaches to development may find it useful to take ECON 341 and 342 as a sequence.

ECON 343.name: The Economic Development of Modern Japan
ECON 343.desc: An economic analysis of the growth and structural changes of the Japanese economy from the Meiji Restoration to the Second World War. Sources of growth, the development of new economic institutions, agricultural development, international trade and early industrialization, the emergence of a dual economic structure, war preparation, and the drive towards heavy industrialization.

ECON 345.name: Money and Banking
ECON 345.desc: Financial markets and financial institutions in theory and practice; structure and development of the Canadian financial system; development and theory of the regulation of the financial system; process of monetary control; theory and history of central banking and monetary policy.

ECON 350.name: Public Finance Policy Topics
ECON 350.desc: Examination of two or three selected policy problems from areas of taxation, income security, and public expenditures. Topics to be selected each year from areas of current or recent policy debate. Examples include public pension policy, privatization and public services, income tax or sales tax reform, federal-provincial cost sharing programs, tax incentives versus direct expenditures, welfare reform.

ECON 351.name: Women in the Economy
ECON 351.desc: Economic analysis of markets and policies particularly affecting women. Selected topics drawn from economic discrimination; educational, occupational, and work choices; pay and employment equity; allocation of work time and consumption within the household and in the market; economics of marriage and fertility; poverty; taxation; income security and pension policies; and historical perspectives.

ECON 352.name: Public Sector Economics
ECON 352.desc: Application of the tools of economic analysis to the study of important aspects of public policy in taxation, spending, borrowing, and regulation.

ECON 355.name: Introduction to International Trade
ECON 355.desc: The determinants of trade patterns, trade policy, tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade, political economy of protectionism, bilateral and multilateral trade disputes, trade liberalization, trade and development. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 355 and 455.

ECON 356.name: Introduction to International Finance
ECON 356.desc: Exchange rate policy regimes; international financial organizations; the interaction between monetary policy and exchange rate regimes; financial crises.

ECON 360.name: Labour Economics
ECON 360.desc: A study of the Canadian labour market. Labour supply, the allocation of the time among work and non-market activity, participation in the labour force, education and training. The demand for labour. The determination of wages and employment. The effect of unions on wages and employment. The wage structure, wage differentials by occupation, industry, race and sex. Unemployment. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 360 and 460.

ECON 361.name: Economics of Industrial Relations
ECON 361.desc: Economic aspects of industrial relations in Canada. Why workers join unions. The theory of trade union behaviour. The labour movement in Canada. Wage determination under collective bargaining. The causes of strikes and lockouts. Unions and the wage structure. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 361 and 461.

ECON 365.name: Topics in Canadian Industrial Organization and Regulation Policy
ECON 365.desc: Current topics in industrial organization and regulation with emphasis on Canadian federal and provincial policy. The content will differ from year to year. Possible subjects include the regulation of transportation and communications, environmental regulation, marketing boards and other forms of agricultural regulation, competition and anti-combines policy, industrial organization and trade policy, and issues in consumer protection.

ECON 367.name: Economic Analysis of Law
ECON 367.desc: The economics of market failure, equity and efficiency. Property rights, the economics of accident and contract law, economic theories of law enforcement.

ECON 370.name: Benefit-Cost Analysis and the Economics of Project Evaluation
ECON 370.desc: Techniques and problems in benefit-cost analysis of public projects. Examination of alternative approaches to public decision-making such as cost-effectiveness analysis and multiple-objective frameworks. Case studies of projects in the areas of natural resources, the environment, human resources, public services, and transportation.

ECON 371.name: Economics of the Environment
ECON 371.desc: Economic analysis applied to various environmental issues, including sustainable development, quality of life, and environmental impacts of specific industrial and consumption activities. The design and implementation of government policies. Global environmental effects of human economic activity.

ECON 374.name: Land Economics
ECON 374.desc: Economic analysis applied to problems of land use. Rent theory. Land valuation. Land conservation. Techniques for assessing economic efficiency of land use. Effects of institutions and public policies on land use.

ECON 384.name: Economic Analysis of Health Services
ECON 384.desc: Microeconomic theory of resource allocation with emphasis on the applications of optimizing models of health service markets. Analysis of Canadian problems in health service supply. Models of the consumer/patient, the physician/entrepreneur, the not-for-profit hospital/firm, and the third-party regulatory and payment agency.

ECON 387.name: Economic Reform and Transition
ECON 387.desc: Problems and processes of economic reform and of transition between different types of economic system, with emphasis on reform and transition in Communist and post-Communist economies. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 387 or ECON 487.

ECON 390.name: Introduction to Economic Research
ECON 390.desc: Selected topics in economic research.  Application of research methods to economic data.  Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 390, ECON 490, ECON 495, or ECON 499.

ECON 406.name: Topics in Microeconomics
ECON 406.desc: Selected topics in advanced microeconomic analysis.
ECON 406.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306.

ECON 407.name: Topics in Macroeconomics
ECON 407.desc: Selected topics in advanced macroeconomic analysis.
ECON 407.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306.

ECON 417.name: Welfare Economics
ECON 417.desc: The criteria for evaluating economic performance with special reference to the problems of justice in the distribution of income and economic efficiency. Topics include social evaluation functions, pareto-optimality, compensation criteria, and consistency of collective decision making.

ECON 420.name: Optimization and Economic Theory
ECON 420.desc: An introduction to static and dynamic optimization methods with economic applications.
ECON 420.prer: MATH 200 and one of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 303, ECON 306. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable.
preq: ECON 306. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable

ECON 421.name: Introduction to Game Theory and Applications
ECON 421.desc: Principles of rational behaviour in strategic situations and various notions of equilibrium useful in predicting outcomes. Applications from economics, business, politics, law and biology.

ECON 422.name: Mathematics for Economists
ECON 422.desc: Provides the required preparation in mathematics for the study of graduate economic theory. Solving systems of simultaneous equations; unconstrained and constrained maxima; elementary theory of difference and differential equations. Restricted to students taking graduate economic theory courses.

ECON 425.name: Introduction to Econometrics
ECON 425.desc: Theoretical and applied issues in statistics and econometrics. Statistical distributions, sampling theory, maximum likelihood methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, generalized least squares, measurement errors, non-normal errors, systems of equations, discrete-choice models, outliers, regression diagnostics, and model selection.

ECON 426.name: Econometric Analysis
ECON 426.desc: Further topics in econometrics including such areas as nonlinear estimation, distributed lag models, time-series analysis, time-varying parameters, multivariate analysis, simulation and forecasting models, Monte Carlo experiments, duration models, large econometric models, Bayesian statistics, asymptotic theory, and ergodic theory.

ECON 436.name: Historical Background to Contemporary Issues in Canadian Economy
ECON 436.desc: Demographic change, immigration, unemployment and labour markets, the inter-provincial transfer of resources, industrial and trade policy.
ECON 436.prer: One of ECON 304, ECON 301 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305.

ECON 441.name: The Process of Economic Development
ECON 441.desc: Industrialization of an agrarian economy; how the West grew rich; history of Japanese development; technical progress and growth; evolution of the patterns of income distribution; role of international trade in development; environment and development.

ECON 442.name: Issues in Economic Development
ECON 442.desc: Divergence in the world economy, poverty, consequences of initial inequality, institutions, the impact of history, recent developmental experience--some case studies, labour and credit markets, the trickle down process.

ECON 444.name: The Contemporary Japanese Economy
ECON 444.desc: An economic analysis of selected issues in contemporary Japan. The postwar growth record, economic management and planning, industrial policy, labour market and industrial relations, foreign trade and investment, rapid industrialization and its consequences, external economic relations.

ECON 447.name: Monetary Theory
ECON 447.desc: Theoretical analysis of economies that use money; the emergence of money; the roles of money in the economy; models of money demand; the optimal quantity of money seignorage and inflation; monetary policy and macroeconomic stability; monetary policy in an open economy.
ECON 447.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305.

ECON 450.name: Economics of Taxation
ECON 450.desc: The economic analysis of taxation. Equity and efficiency; optimal taxation theory; partial and general equilibrium analysis of incidence; analysis of taxes such as the personal and corporate income taxes, sales and excise taxes, payroll taxes and property tax.

ECON 451.name: Economics of Public Expenditures
ECON 451.desc: The role of government in the economy; efficiency and economic justice. Theory of public goods; applications to topics such as education, medical care and social services. Pricing and investment rules for public enterprises.

ECON 455.name: International Trade
ECON 455.desc: International trade theory and policy in general equilibrium; relative costs, factor proportions, imperfect competition and the pattern of trade; efficiency and distribution. Credit granted for only one of ECON355 and ECON455.

ECON 456.name: International Macroeconomics and Finance
ECON 456.desc: Balance of payments; market for foreign exchange; mechanism for adjusting the balance of payments; internal vs. external stability; current problems and issues.

ECON 457.name: Seminar in International Economic Relations
ECON 457.desc: Selected topics focusing upon various issues arising in international economic relations. Open only to fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

ECON 460.name: Economics of Labour Markets
ECON 460.desc: The theory of labour supply and demand for individuals, households, and firms. Policy implications for Canadian taxation and benefit programs. Employee selection, hiring and promotion. Credit may not be obtained for both ECON 360 and 460.
ECON 460.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305.

ECON 461.name: Economics of Trade Unions
ECON 461.desc: The microeconomic and macroeconomic effects of unions on wages, prices and employment. Industrial disputes and their resolution. Credit may not be obtained for both ECON 361 and 461.
ECON 461.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305.

ECON 465.name: Market Structure
ECON 465.desc: Market structure and social welfare, theory of price discrimination, equilibrium in oligopolistic markets, entry and exit decisions, product differentiation and spatial models, theories of hierarchical organization, agency problem in the modern corporation, vertical integration and control, market structure and technical progress.

ECON 466.name: The Economics of Government Regulation of Business
ECON 466.desc: Normative and positive theories of government regulation of business. Topics include natural monopoly, socially optimal monopoly pricing, regulation of multi-firm industries, competition policy. Selected empirical studies.

ECON 468.name: Economics of Intellectual Property: Patents, Drugs, and Rock 'n Roll
ECON 468.desc: Economic research into patents and copyrights, and policies regulating them. Analysis of the impact of stronger intellectual property rights on innovative activity, with applications to culture, the music industry, pharmaceuticals, consumer electronics, and the Internet.

ECON 471.name: Economics of Nonrenewable Resources
ECON 471.desc: Application of economic analysis to the management of nonrenewable natural resources. Emphasis is placed on the economics of alternative energy sources. Other topics include mineral economics, criteria for the optimal use of resources, and measurement of resources.

ECON 472.name: Economics of Renewable Resources
ECON 472.desc: Application of economic analysis to the management of renewable resources. Special attention is given to criteria for the optimal use of depleting resources such as forests and water. Other topics include public policy with regard to environmental quality, conservation, and outdoor recreation.

ECON 480.name: Transportation
ECON 480.desc: Economic characteristics of the provision of transportation services, both passenger and freight; the market structure of the industry and the economic impact of the varying degrees of public regulation and promotion within the industry; the role of economic analysis in resolving problems of Canadian policy.

ECON 482.name: The Economic Consequences of Religion
ECON 482.desc: Analysis of the economic aspects of religious behaviour, the structure of religious organizations, the effects of competition in the religious marketplace, the economic benefits of religion, and some of the ill-effects of religion (such as religious strife and terrorism).

ECON 485.name: Political Economy
ECON 485.desc: State and politics in economics. How states emerge, how dictators stay in power. Why groups engage in costly conflict, how countries turn into democracies and what its benefits are.
ECON 485.prer: One of ECON 301, ECON 304, ECON 308 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305, ECON 309 and all of ECON 325, ECON 326.

ECON 487.name: Comparative Economic Systems
ECON 487.desc: Economic analysis of non-market/non-price systems of resource allocation. Economic analysis of central planning, co-ordination problems in hierarchical organizations, and the role of quantity restrictions, quotas, standards, etc. in regulating economic behaviour. The Soviet system of economic planning is used throughout as an example of the issues discussed. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 387 or ECON 487.

ECON 490.name: Seminar in Applied Economics
ECON 490.desc: Selected problems and issues in the theory and practice of Economics. Each section will focus on a different field. Restricted to Economics Majors, and Combined Majors in Economics their final academic session.
ECON 490.prer: All of ECON 325, ECON 326 and one of ECON 301, ECON 304 and one of ECON 302, ECON 305. For additional possible prerequisites see individual course descriptions on the School's  website.
preq: ECON 305. For additional possible prerequisites see individual course descriptions on the School's website

ECON 493.name: Advanced Empirical Methods for International Economics
ECON 493.desc: Econometric methodologies necessary to conduct applied research, including time series analysis and panel data methods; review of empirical work in international economics.  Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program.

ECON 494.name: Seminar in Applied International Economics
ECON 494.desc: Focus on a particular aspect of applied international economics. Independent empirical research project required.  Registration restricted to students in the Bachelor of International Economics Program.

ECON 495.name: Honours Seminar
ECON 495.desc: Reports and group discussions of selected topics for fourth-year Honours students.

ECON 499.name: Honours Essay
ECON 499.desc: Essay on some theoretical, applied, or institutional problem. Open only to fourth-year Honours students.

RGLA 372.name: Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts
RGLA 372.desc: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.

RGLA 471.name: Advanced Seminar in Religion and Literature
RGLA 471.desc: Application of critical methods to one or more major authors.

SOWK 200.name: Introduction to Social Welfare
SOWK 200.desc: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

SOWK 201.name: Introduction to Social Work Practice
SOWK 201.desc: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems.

SOWK 305.name: Social Work Practice I
SOWK 305.desc: An examination of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program.

SOWK 310.name: Interviewing Skills
SOWK 310.desc: Communication theory and interviewing skills and their application to the Social Work interview.

SOWK 315.name: Practicum I
SOWK 315.desc: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

SOWK 316.name: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
SOWK 316.desc: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.
