SOWK 320.name: Introduction to Social Work Research
SOWK 320.desc: Introduction to theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. The focus is on development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school.

SOWK 335.name: Social Analysis for Social Work Practice
SOWK 335.desc: Theoretical considerations of relevance to social work practice.

SOWK 337.name: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
SOWK 337.desc: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

SOWK 400.name: Canadian Social Policy
SOWK 400.desc: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

SOWK 405.name: Social Work Practice II
SOWK 405.desc: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

SOWK 415.name: Practicum II
SOWK 415.desc: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

SOWK 416.name: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
SOWK 416.desc: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

SOWK 425.name: First Nations Social Issues
SOWK 425.desc: Contemporary social issues facing First Nations peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Euro-Canadian/First Nations relations; the impact of Euro-Canadian institutions upon First Nations peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice.

SOWK 430.name: Special Studies in Social Work
SOWK 430.desc: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.

SOWK 440.name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work
SOWK 440.desc: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

SOWK 441.name: Social Context of Child Development
SOWK 441.desc: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

SOWK 442.name: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
SOWK 442.desc: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.
SOWK 442.prer: SOWK 441 or another course in child development.

SOWK 450.name: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
SOWK 450.desc: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness.

SOWK 451.name: Health Care Team Development
SOWK 451.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400.

SOWK 452.name: HIV Prevention and Care
SOWK 452.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402.

SOWK 453.name: Disability and Justice
SOWK 453.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

SOWK 454.name: Interdisciplinary Practice with Children and Families
SOWK 454.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.

SOWK 455.name: Palliative Care
SOWK 455.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.

SOWK 456.name: Special Topics in Collaborative Healthcare
SOWK 456.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares students to practice patient-centred interprofessional collaboration in a specific area of healthcare. Offered as IHHS 480 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 456 or IHHS 480.

MEDG 410.name: Immunogenetics
MEDG 410.desc: Molecular basis of lymphocyte development, activation and adhesion; immunogenetics and the major histocompatibility complex. Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar. [3-0-1]
MEDG 410.prer: MICB 302 and one of BIOL 334, BIOL 335. A standing of "B" or better is recommended.

MEDG 419.name: Developmental Origin of Human Disorders
MEDG 419.desc: Genetic and epigenetic determinants of development from conception to birth. Topics include development of the neural tube, face, heart, endoderm, blastocyst, embryonic stem cells, gastrulation, genomic imprinting, placental complications, chromosomal abnormalities and prenatal diagnosis. Discussions based on published research articles. [3-0-1]
MEDG 419.prer: One of BIOL 234, BIOL 334 and one of BIOL 331, BIOL 335. A standing of 'B' or higher recommended.

MEDG 420.name: Human Genomics and Medical Genetics
MEDG 420.desc: Sequence and structure of the human genome. Human genetic evolution. Identification of genes affecting normal and pathological variation.  Molecular mechanisms of genetic diseases and disorders. Medical applications of human genetics. [3-0-0]
MEDG 420.prer: BIOL 335. A standing of 'B' or higher is recommended.

MEDG 421.name: Genetics and Cell Biology of Cancer
MEDG 421.desc: Molecular mechanisms of oncogenes and tumor suppressors and the effects of oncogenic mutations on the biology of cancer cells. [3-0-0]
MEDG 421.prer: BIOL 335 and one of BIOC 300, BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOL 350.

MEDG 448.name: Directed Studies
MEDG 448.desc: A supervised individual program of study of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of faculty and the student. Permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head is required.

PERS 100.name: Basic Persian I
PERS 100.desc: Basic vocabulary and the fundamentals of modern Persian grammar, structure, and pronunciation, as well as reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

PERS 104.name: Persian Reading and Writing for Persian-Speaking Students
PERS 104.desc: Reading and writing of standard Tehran Persian; lexical and syntactic differences between written and spoken Persian.  This course prepares students for PERS 300.
PERS 104.prer: Basic knowledge of spoken Persian and consent of instructor.

PERS 200.name: Intermediate Persian I
PERS 200.desc: Reading of simple texts with emphasis on reading and writing, conversation skills, grammar, and syntax.

PERS 300.name: Advanced Persian I
PERS 300.desc: Graded reading, writing, exposure to the writing system, textual history, newspaper reading, and translation. Cultural materials presented as appropriate. The art of calligraphy introduced.

PERS 400.name: Persian Short Story for Native and Heritage Speakers
PERS 400.desc: Literary works from mid-19th century to present. Restricted to native or heritage speakers of Persian.

RHSC 420.name: Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
RHSC 420.desc: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system. [2-3-0]

INDO 100.name: Introductory Indonesian I
INDO 100.desc: Spoken and written Indonesian. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100 or INDO 102.

INDO 101.name: Introductory Indonesian II
INDO 101.desc: Continuation of INDO 100. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 101 or INDO 102.

INDO 102.name: Introductory Indonesian
INDO 102.desc: Spoken and written Indonesian. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 100/101 or INDO 102.

INDO 200.name: Intermediate Indonesian
INDO 200.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201/202 or INDO 200.

INDO 201.name: Intermediate Indonesian I
INDO 201.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Indonesian literature. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 201 or INDO 200.

INDO 202.name: Intermediate Indonesian II
INDO 202.desc: Continuation of INDO 201. Credit will be granted for only one of INDO 202 or INDO 200.

PHTH 301.name: Physical Therapy Foundations
PHTH 301.desc: Builds on prerequisite concepts in anatomy, physiology, and physics taken at undergraduate and high school level to apply basic theories and principles of anatomy, human physiology, pathophysiology, biomechanics, and physics to essential rehabilitation concepts.

ASLA 300.name: Studies in an Asian Language (Basic Course)
ASLA 300.desc: Introduction to the fundamentals of an Asian language not normally taught in the Department. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details.

ASLA 400.name: Studies in an Asian Language (Intermediate Course)
ASLA 400.prer: ASLA 300. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable.
preq: ASLA 300. Permission of the instructor is also acceptable

JRNL 100.name: New Media and Society
JRNL 100.desc: Development of new media technologies, their applications, and their cultural, political, and social impacts.

LING 100.name: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
LING 100.desc: Study of language as a universal and uniquely human cognitive system: What universals do all languages share and how do languages differ? An investigation of sound systems, word-building, grammatical principles, language change, dialect variation, language acquisition, neurolinguistics. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.

LING 101.name: Languages of the World
LING 101.desc: A survey of the linguistic map of the world, examining how languages are genetically classified and how different languages evolve. Principles underlying different writing systems and the decipherment of historical documents. Issues of languages in contact, minority language endangerment, language death and the role of English as a world language. Recommended but not required for an honours, major, or minor in linquistics or speech sciences.

LING 140.name: Challenging Language Myths
LING 140.desc: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note. This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

LING 170.name: Introduction to How to Learn a Language
LING 170.desc: Skills and strategies for second language acquisition, through the foundations of pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and pragmatics, connected to the practical, social, and personal challenges of language learning.

LING 200.name: Linguistic Theory and Analysis I
LING 200.desc: Introduction to phonetics and phonology; training in the identification and production of speech sounds; principles and methods for describing and writing the sound system of a language; phonological theory with reference to selected languages; the interface between phonology and morphology. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

LING 201.name: Linguistic Theory and Analysis II
LING 201.desc: Introduction to grammatical analysis; morphology, syntax, semantics; synchronic analysis and description with illustrations from various languages. Analytical practice and seminar discussion.

LING 209.name: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
LING 209.desc: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences, with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

LING 222.name: Language Acquisition
LING 222.desc: Audition and speech perception, phonological organization, word learning, syntax, and pragmatics.

LING 270.name: Introduction to Studies in Second Language Acquisition
LING 270.desc: Linguistic systems that learners of an additional language develop as they approximate towards the target language, and key questions about what this 'interlanguage' system reveals about how we learn languages.
LING 270.prer: One of LING 100, LING 101, LING 140, LING 170.

LING 300.name: Studies in Grammar
LING 300.desc: Introduction to syntactic analysis and theory, with emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

LING 311.name: Studies in Phonology
LING 311.desc: Introduction to phonological analysis and theory, with a strong emphasis on description and analysis of data from a wide variety of languages.

LING 313.name: Introduction to Linguistic Phonetics and Speech Science
LING 313.desc: The articulatory and acoustic properties of speech production and perception, including practice in phonetic transcription, instrumental recording, and the analysis of normal speech.
LING 313.prer: LING 200. Recommended: All of LING 100,  PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.
preq: LING 200. Recommended: All of LING 100 PSYC 100 PSYC 217

LING 314.name: Instrumental Phonetics
LING 314.desc: Physiological and/or acoustic phonetics. Focus on experimental methods and analysis techniques. Topics may include: source-filter theory; spectral and temporal acoustic analysis, inter-articulator timing and motor coordination.
LING 314.prer: LING 313. Recommended: All of LING 100, PSYC 100 (or PSYC 101 and 102), PSYC 217 and 218, PHYS 341.
preq: LING 313. Recommended: All of LING 100 PSYC 100 PSYC 217

LING 319.name: Comparative and Historical Linguistics
LING 319.desc: The historical study of language.  Linguistic change.  Language families and evidence for genetic relationship.  Comparative method and internal reconstruction.  Emphasis on phonological and morphological reconstruction. Not offered every year.

LING 327.name: Introduction to Semantics
LING 327.desc: The analysis and theory of linguistic meaning with emphasis on formal techniques for semantic analysis and their application to empirical phenomena in language, including pragmatics.

LING 333.name: Research Methods for Linguistics
LING 333.desc: Research methods used in linguistics and speech science. Emphasis on scientific reasoning, critical thinking, experimental design, and the ethics and methods of linguistic data-collection.

LING 345.name: Pragmatics
LING 345.desc: Selected topics in pragmatics and information structure, including variations in their cross-linguistic expression and the corresponding influence of sentence form on context.

LING 405.name: Morphology
LING 405.desc: Analytic and theoretical consideration of the interrelation of word formation, sound patterning, and meaningful sentence structure. Not offered every year.
LING 405.prer: All of LING 300, LING 311. Recommended: LING 327

LING 420.name: Introduction to Linguistics
LING 420.desc: General background to linguistic studies; the different approaches to the analysis of languages; synchronic and diachronic linguistics; phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours program in Linguistics.

LING 430.name: Honours Seminar in Linguistics
LING 430.desc: Research papers on general linguistic topics to be read and discussed.

LING 431.name: Field Methods I
LING 431.desc: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied. Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

LING 432.name: Field Methods II
LING 432.desc: Elicitation, transcription, organization, and analysis of linguistic data from a native speaker of a language not commonly studied.  Practical experience in the use of fieldwork equipment.

LING 433.name: Native Languages of the Americas
LING 433.desc: Survey of the indigenous languages of the Americas. Study of the basis of genetic classification and areal similarities. The structure of representative languages will be presented and contrasted. The present status of American Indian languages will be considered. Note: this course is not necessarily offered every year.

LING 436.name: Community-based Language Research
LING 436.desc: Research methods and partnerships, ethical paradigms, the social, cultural and historical context of language research, and the relation of language research to pedagogy, policy and planning.

LING 445.name: Sociolinguistics
LING 445.desc: The systematic study of language as a social phenomenon.

LING 447.name: Topics in Linguistics
LING 447.desc: A capstone course for Linguistics and Speech Sciences majors, normally taken after three years of study.  Individual sections will differ substantially; see online Course List for detailed descriptions and prerequisites. May be repeated for credit when content is different.

LING 448.name: Directed Studies
LING 448.desc: Supervisor and topic chosen by mutual agreement between student and Linguistics faculty member. Department Advisor approval is required.

LING 451.name: Acquisition of Phonology
LING 451.desc: Development of the phonological system in typical first language acquisition from the perspective of diverse linguistic topics. Phonetic transcription of child speech.

LING 452.name: Acquisition of Syntax
LING 452.desc: Central issues in the first language acquisition of syntax, including early lexical and semantic development, acquisition of morphology, and syntactic development (e.g., word order, questions).

LING 469.name: Clinical Topics in Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
LING 469.desc: Introduction to speech and hearing sciences with emphasis on the clinical perspectives of audiology and speech pathology.

ASIA 100.name: Introduction to Traditional Asia
ASIA 100.desc: A survey of the histories and cultures of Asia before 1600 and the coming of the Europeans. Emphasis will be given to parallel themes in the development of the civilizations of South, Southeast and East Asia.

ASIA 101.name: Introduction to Modern Asia
ASIA 101.desc: A survey of the emergence of modern Asia. Aims at an understanding of how the various peoples of Asia have maintained distinctive cultural identities despite centuries of political, economic, social and cultural change.

ASIA 110.name: Introduction to the Major Eastern Religions
ASIA 110.desc: Introduction to the major Asian religious traditions (Islam, Hinduism, Sikhism, Jainism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, Christianity, Shintoism, and Shamanism); employs theoretical models drawn from religious studies.

ASIA 200.name: Cultural Foundations of East Asia
ASIA 200.desc: A comparative survey of the beliefs, assumptions and values which have shaped the civilizations of East Asia in both traditional and modern times.

ASIA 204.name: Introduction to Asian Religions
ASIA 204.desc: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.

ASIA 208.name: Cultural Foundations of South Asia
ASIA 208.desc: A survey of South Asian cultures, including language and literature, art, religion, polity and society, as they developed in the past and have been transformed in the modern period.

ASIA 209.name: Cultural Foundations of Southeast Asia
ASIA 209.desc: A comparative survey of the different cultures found in the communities of Southeast Asia. Focus will be on language and literature, arts, religion, society and polity, ideologies and belief systems in the past as well as in modern times.

ASIA 211.name: Sex, Sexual Ethics, and Asian Religions
ASIA 211.desc: Sex and sexual ethics in the scriptures, monastic rules, rituals, and narratives of Asian religions, such as Sikhism, Hinduism, Buddhism, and Confucianism.

ASIA 212.name: Writing About Japan
ASIA 212.desc: Literary, historiographic, religious, and feminist approaches to Japanese myths, legal tracts, religious tales, fiction, and poetry.

ASIA 213.name: Myth, Literature, and Film in North India
ASIA 213.desc: Indian literary and mythological texts, in genres from epic to lyric, as recast in contemporary Hindi film.

ASIA 222.name: Encountering Asia
ASIA 222.desc: Introduction to the literary, religious, and philosophical traditions of at least two Asian cultures using foundational texts. Students will learn about these traditions by encountering them historically as well as through the lenses of their own diverse identities and contexts.

ASIA 223.name: Writing Asia
ASIA 223.desc: This writing-intensive course is to be taken concurrently with ASIA 222. The seminar builds on the materials of ASIA 222. Students must have knowledge of or be enrolled in the study of one of the languages offered in Asian Studies.

ASIA 250.name: Introduction to Buddhism
ASIA 250.desc: Origins, basic teachings, development of Theravada, Mahayana, and Tantric traditions, historical spread first through Asia and later the world, and Buddhism in contemporary societies.

ASIA 254.name: Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in Japanese Literature and Film
ASIA 254.desc: The integral role that sex, gender, and sexuality play in literary and cinematic works from Japan. Literary works will be read in translation, movies will be subtitled.

ASIA 258.name: Religion in South Asia
ASIA 258.desc: The major religious traditions of South Asia, including Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, and Buddhism; the significance of religious thought and practice in premodern India, as well as the continuing impact of religion in today's globalized South Asia.

ASIA 270.name: China in World History
ASIA 270.desc: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

ASIA 300.name: Writing and Culture in East Asia
ASIA 300.desc: Practical, aesthetic, historical, technological and political issues pertaining to the use of Chinese characters - hanzi (Chinese), kanji (Japanese), or hanccha (Korean) - throughout the region.

ASIA 301.name: Buddhism in the Modern Era
ASIA 301.desc: Buddhism from the nineteenth century to present day with special emphasis on its history and character in local settings, including specific traditions such as Tibetan Nyingma and Japanese Zen, as well as the development of a modern and global "Buddhism."

ASIA 302.name: Theravada Buddhism
ASIA 302.desc: History, story, and culture of the major form of Buddhism primarily focused on the regions of Sri Lanka, and mainland Southeast Asia, including southern Vietnam, parts of southern China, spread to Nepal, and modern global diffusion.

ASIA 303.name: Mahayana Buddhism
ASIA 303.desc: Historical and philosophical development of Mahayana Buddhism.

ASIA 304.name: Survey of South and Southeast Asian Performing Arts
ASIA 304.desc: An historical perspective of the performing arts of South and Southeast Asia, highlighting the role of music, dance, and the dramatic arts in the lives of actors and audiences.  Option to complete a practicum performance.

ASIA 305.name: Asian Horror Cinema: National Nightmares and Specters of Trauma
ASIA 305.desc: Engaging with the ideologies, industrial histories, socio-cultural contexts, and aesthetics of horror films - and the genre itself - from various Asian cinemas.

ASIA 306.name: Esoteric Buddhism
ASIA 306.desc: Overview of Buddhism's rich and complex esoteric traditions in the Himalayan region and South, Southeast, and East Asia, with particular emphasis on texts, commentaries, and practices from a variety of traditions, locales and time periods.

ASIA 307.name: Korean Language and Writing in Culture and Society
ASIA 307.desc: An examination of Korean language and writing using approaches from sociolinguistics, the sociology of language, and linguistic anthropology.

ASIA 308.name: Myth, Ritual and Epic in Ancient India
ASIA 308.desc: Myths of creation Gods and goddesses of the Vedic pantheon. Connections with myths in other parts of the world, particularly in the Indo-European tradition. Literary representations of the myths.

ASIA 309.name: South Asian Beyond South Asia
ASIA 309.desc: A history of South Asian peoples and communities that emigrated overseas, including Indo-Canadians.

ASIA 310.name: Studies in the History of a Major Asian Civilization
ASIA 310.desc: Study of an Asian culture area different from those covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

ASIA 311.name: Tibetan Buddhism
ASIA 311.desc: Religious terrain of the Tibetan cultural realm, looking at the history and development of Tibetan Buddhism and key ideas of the four main Tibetan Buddhist traditions.

ASIA 313.name: Tibetan and Himalayan Culture and Society
ASIA 313.desc: History and culture of the Himalayan regions, including India, China, Tibet, Nepal, and Bhutan.

ASIA 314.name: Premodern Japan
ASIA 314.desc: Japanese history (political, economic, social and cultural) to 1600.

ASIA 315.name: Japan from Feudal to Modern State
ASIA 315.desc: Japanese history from 1600 to the Meiji Restoration. Political, economic, social and cultural forces which were involved in transforming Japan.

ASIA 316.name: Race and Ethnicity in Japanese Literature and Film
ASIA 316.desc: Examines relations between majority and minority groups in Japanese society and changing definitions of "Japan" through literature and film from Japan.

ASIA 317.name: The Rise of Korean Civilization
ASIA 317.desc: The evolution of a distinctive Korean civilization within the East Asian cultural sphere. Primary focus on cultural, social and political development from the earliest times to the sixteenth century.

ASIA 318.name: Premodern India
ASIA 318.desc: A survey of the history and culture of India from the earliest historic period to 1200 and the coming of Islam, with emphasis on the evolution of classical Hindu civilization.

ASIA 319.name: History of Indonesian Civilization
ASIA 319.desc: Survey of the archipelago from the 10th century to the present. Social organization, major religions, economic and political developments from the pre-modern period, through Dutch colonial rule to independence.

ASIA 320.name: History of Early China
ASIA 320.desc: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

ASIA 324.name: Literature of Hong Kong
ASIA 324.desc: A survey of the literature of Hong Kong, from classical times to the present. Important periods in literary history (imperial, colonial, post-colonial), major authors (locals, visitors, and writers elsewhere), and important genres, including poetry, essays, and fiction.

ASIA 325.name: Hong Kong Cinema
ASIA 325.desc: A survey of the cinema of Hong Kong from the post-war period to the present. The influence of Hong Kong on global cinema, and the forces (artists, studios, audiences, etc.) that have given rise to filmmaking styles and genres perceived as "distinctively Hong Kong."

ASIA 326.name: Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
ASIA 326.desc: A critical introduction to Japanese manga and anime in the 20th and 21st centuries.

ASIA 327.name: Korean Popular Music in Context
ASIA 327.desc: History, contexts, and the genres of Korean popular music. Students will analyze specific artists and songs using a range of approaches. While an understanding of basic concepts of music will be helpful, no previous exposure to ethnomusicology or music performance is required.

ASIA 328.name: Medieval India
ASIA 328.desc: The history, culture, and social and economic organization of South Asia from the decline of the classical Hindu empires through the Sultanate period.

ASIA 329.name: Gender in Southeast Asia
ASIA 329.desc: A critical examination of what it means to be a woman or a man within the social and cultural context of Southeast Asia. What "masculinity" and "femininity" signify in Indonesia's society; how these concepts are reaffirmed or challenged.

ASIA 330.name: Islam in South Asia
ASIA 330.desc: Islam as a transnational phenomenon with specific reference to its South Asian forms.

ASIA 331.name: Islam in Indonesia
ASIA 331.desc: Islam as a transnational phenomenon with specific reference to its Indonesian forms.

ASIA 332.name: Confucianism in China and Beyond: Reinventions of Tradition
ASIA 332.desc: Key ideas and trends in Confucian thought and practice from its origins to modern times through primary sources in translation and secondary scholarship.

ASIA 333.name: Contemporary South Asian Gender and Sexuality Studies
ASIA 333.desc: Main theories and key concepts with a particular focus on the changing status of women, and gender and sexual minorities.

ASIA 334.name: Indonesian Cinema
ASIA 334.desc: Representations of social and political relations, cultural traditions and regional differences, marriage, family and kinship ties, and gender politics in Indonesia as shown through Indonesian cinema.

ASIA 337.name: The Korean People in Modern Times (1600 to the present)
ASIA 337.desc: The transformation of Korea from a Confucian state into an industrial nation. The rise of nationalism and modern ideologies in Korea. Cultural, social and economic changes Korea has undergone as it has entered the modern world.

ASIA 338.name: Modern India: From Conquest to Raj
ASIA 338.desc: The history of India from the coming of the Europeans to the rise of the nationalist movement with emphasis on the social and economic impact of British imperialism.

ASIA 339.name: The Construction of South Asian Communities in the Diaspora
ASIA 339.desc: An examination of contemporary South Asian communities in the diaspora. Topics of particular importance are family life, religious life, notions of space, communal memory, literary and visual representation.

ASIA 340.name: History of Later Imperial China
ASIA 340.desc: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation.  Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

ASIA 341.name: Classical Chinese Literature in Translation
ASIA 341.desc: Poetry, historical and philosophic prose writings and the earliest genres of fiction in classical Chinese (ca. 1100 BC – ca. 750 AD).

ASIA 342.name: Chinese Literature in Translation: The Vernacular Tradition
ASIA 342.desc: Readings in drama and fiction, 800 to 1800 AD. The emergence of vernacular genres as distinct from and sometimes opposed to the existing classical genres.

ASIA 343.name: Film in South Asia
ASIA 343.desc: Social and cultural history of South Asian film.

ASIA 344.name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History I: Aristocrats and Warriors
ASIA 344.desc: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the courtly or warrior culture of Japan.

ASIA 346.name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History II: The Early Modern Age
ASIA 346.desc: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the culture of early modern Japan.

ASIA 347.name: Traditional Korean Literature in Translation
ASIA 347.desc: An introduction to Korean literature from ancient times to 1900.

ASIA 348.name: Great Literary Works of Classical India in Translation
ASIA 348.desc: Major Sanskrit and Prakrit literary genres as developed in the Brahmanical, Buddhist and Jaina traditions, including folktales of riddle, intrigue, etc. Ramayana, Mahabharata. Polished poems of the urbane. Plays. Learned novels and long poems.

ASIA 349.name: Southeast Asian Literature in Translation
ASIA 349.desc: Literary works from the Malay/Indonesian-speaking world (Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore) and some from other regions (mainland Southeast Asia, the Philippines). All readings in English translation.

ASIA 350.name: Asian Literature in Translation: A Comparative Approach
ASIA 350.desc: A comparative approach to the literatures of East, South and Southeast Asia focusing on a specific theme.

ASIA 351.name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation
ASIA 351.desc: Reading of selected novels and stories written between 1750 and the present.

ASIA 352.name: Topics in Traditional Chinese Vernacular Literature
ASIA 352.desc: Traditional Chinese culture as seen through reading and discussion of exemplary literary works in the vernacular language.

ASIA 353.name: Introduction to Hindi Film
ASIA 353.desc: History, aesthetics, politics, and social roles of Bollywood films. Seminar discussions in English; Hindi films with English subtitles.

ASIA 354.name: Introduction to Japanese Cinema
ASIA 354.desc: Students will be introduced to the work of the major directors (e.g., Ozu, Mizoguchi, Kurosawa, Itami, Oshima, Shinoda). Ideological uses of literary texts and period pieces (e.g., Ugetsu, Life of Oharu, Double Suicide). Impact of depiction of Japanese in American film.

ASIA 355.name: History of Chinese Cinema
ASIA 355.desc: Introduction to the work of major directors.

ASIA 356.name: Korean Cinema
ASIA 356.desc: Introduction to the work of the major film makers.

ASIA 357.name: Modern Korean Literature in Translation
ASIA 357.desc: Selected fiction and poetry written between 1917 and the present.

ASIA 358.name: Literature of Medieval India in Translation
ASIA 358.desc: Devotional, mystic, and erotic poetry of medieval Hinduism, Islam, and Sikhism.

ASIA 359.name: Gender Relations in Southeast Asian Literature and Cinema
ASIA 359.desc: Gender relations as portrayed in Southeast Asian films and writings in English translation by women and men from the Malay/Indonesian-speaking world, mainland Southeast Asia, and the Philippines.

ASIA 360.name: A Specific Asian Literature in Translation
ASIA 360.desc: Introduction to the literature of a linguistic area of Asia not covered in existing courses. Not given every year. Consult the Department for details. May be taken multiple times on different subjects for credit.

ASIA 361.name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation II
ASIA 361.desc: A thematic survey of modern Chinese fiction and film in translation.

ASIA 362.name: Pre-Modern Japanese Fiction (in translation)
ASIA 362.desc: The influential genre of early tales and fiction in pre-modern Japan.

ASIA 363.name: Fiction and Film from Modern Taiwan
ASIA 363.desc: A reading-intensive survey of literary and cinematic culture in Taiwan since the early 20th century: colonialism, the national divide, nativism, trauma, cosmopolitanism, and utopian imaginings. In English.

ASIA 364.name: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation
ASIA 364.desc: An introduction to the literature and cultural history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

ASIA 365.name: Punjabi Cinema
ASIA 365.desc: Punjabi culture, history, and social values through films.  The class includes film viewings and seminar discussions.  Films will be screened with English subtitles.

ASIA 366.name: Edo-Period Theatre
ASIA 366.desc: Edo-period puppet and kabuki theaters, with additional attention to the latter’s representation in woodblock prints and the construction of gender roles in theatre.

ASIA 367.name: Contemporary Korean Culture
ASIA 367.desc: An introduction to the literature, drama, music, and art of Korea today. Particular attention will be paid to the continuing influence of traditional themes and forms.

ASIA 368.name: Modern Literatures of South Asia in Translation
ASIA 368.desc: Fiction, drama, and poetry of modern India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka, including works in English translation and originally written in English.

ASIA 369.name: Asian Folklore
ASIA 369.desc: A survey of oral and expressive traditions in Asia, including jokes, superstitions, fairy tales, myths, music, and foodways; practical training in collecting and archiving folklore.

ASIA 370.name: The Sanskrit Cosmopolis: India and the World, 200-1500 CE
ASIA 370.desc: Languages, religions, art forms, and political structures of Asian societies shaped by creative encounters with Sanskrit.

ASIA 371.name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
ASIA 371.desc: Chinese thought from its beginnings until the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes, among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

ASIA 372.name: Development of Traditional Chinese Thought
ASIA 372.desc: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) to Wang Yangming (1472-1529) in its historical and cultural contexts.

ASIA 373.name: History of Hong Kong
ASIA 373.desc: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

ASIA 374.name: Imagining Punjab
ASIA 374.desc: The cultural and linguistic region of Punjab as it has been imagined in different times and places, in South Asia and beyond, in literature, scholarship, film, and popular culture.

ASIA 375.name: Global Chinese Cinemas
ASIA 375.desc: A survey of Chinese cinemas in global perspective, covering films, filmmakers, producers, audiences, markets, industries, and critical discourse since the early twentieth century. Covers both cinematic culture and filmmaking technique.

ASIA 376.name: The Sikhs: Formations, Contexts, and Historical Development
ASIA 376.desc: Introduction to the historical development of Sikh traditions in India and Diaspora, from the 15th century to the present, with attention to broader historical contexts.

ASIA 377.name: History of Korean Thought
ASIA 377.desc: An examination of Korean religious, philosophical, and scientific thought from the earliest written records to the present day, with particular focus on the interaction of Shamanism, Buddhism, Confucianism, and, in the present century, Christianity.

ASIA 378.name: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
ASIA 378.desc: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

ASIA 379.name: The Sikhs: History, Religion and Society
ASIA 379.desc: A historical study of the social and cultural forces that helped shape Sikh religious beliefs and ritual practices over the past four centuries. In dealing with the evolution of Sikh identity, due attention will be given to Sikh ideals, social organization, religious institutions and sacred literature.

ASIA 380.name: The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution
ASIA 380.desc: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.

ASIA 381.name: Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
ASIA 381.desc: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century CE in their cultural, intellectual and social contexts.

ASIA 382.name: Buddhism in China
ASIA 382.desc: History, thought, and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century.

ASIA 383.name: Common Religious Traditions in China
ASIA 383.desc: A study of the religious practices and beliefs shared by the great majority of people in traditional Chinese culture, including ancestor worship, seasonal festivals, offerings to deities, exorcism of harmful forces.

ASIA 384.name: The
ASIA 384.desc: Introduction to a foundational text of East Asian thought. Both the primary text and its reception in traditional and modern contexts will be examined.

ASIA 385.name: Chan/Zen Buddhism: Doctrine and Practice
ASIA 385.desc: The history, doctrines, and practices of Chan Buddhism, particularly the profound influence of Chan Buddhism on various aspects of East Asian culture.

ASIA 386.name: Chinese Grammar and Usage I
ASIA 386.desc: In-depth examination of modern Chinese grammar and its usage including word formation, syntactic constructions, discourse cohesions, semantics, and stylistic considerations.
ASIA 386.prer: All of CHIN 207, CHIN 337, CHIN 208, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 347, CHIN 218, CHIN 348 or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.
preq: higher level of Chinese language proficiency

ASIA 387.name: Japanese Religions
ASIA 387.desc: An introduction to traditional Japanese religions including Shinto, Buddhism, Shugendo, Confucianism, new religions and folklore, and their roles in Japanese history, culture and society.

ASIA 388.name: Buddhist, Brahamanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
ASIA 388.desc: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

ASIA 390.name: History of the Indian Ocean World
ASIA 390.desc: Societies and empires shaped by voyages of exploration, religious pilgrimages, trading diasporas and forced migration in the world of the Indian Ocean.

ASIA 391.name: An Introduction to the Indo-Persian Cosmopolis/Knowledge Systems
ASIA 391.desc: Cultural interactions between Delhi and the wider Dar al Islam with indigenous groups and local culture from the 13th to the 19th centuries.

ASIA 392.name: Classical Persian Literature in English Translation
ASIA 392.desc: Works of classical Persian literature dating from the tenth to the seventeenth century (in English translation).

ASIA 393.name: History of Iran from the Sasanians to the Safavids
ASIA 393.desc: Iranian history from the fall of the Sasanian empire and the Arab conquest of Iran to the rise of Iranian dynasties in the east, the reign of Turkic and Turko-Mongolian rulers, and the formation of a Shi‘ite Iran under the Safavids.

ASIA 394.name: Post-Revolutionary Iranian Cinema
ASIA 394.desc: Gender politics, family relationships, and women's social, economic, and political roles in post-revolutionary Iran as shown through Iranian cinema.

ASIA 396.name: Chinese Grammar and Usage II
ASIA 396.desc: In-depth examination of modern Chinese grammar and its usage including word formation, syntactic constructions, discourse cohesions, semantics, and stylistic considerations. Continuation of ASIA 386.
ASIA 396.prer: ASIA 386 or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.
preq: higher level of Chinese language proficiency

ASIA 397.name: The Idea of India
ASIA 397.desc: History of cultural ideas that led to India’s transformation from a traditional, colonial society tied to the British empire to a postcolonial, pluralistic, development oriented parliamentary democracy.

ASIA 398.name: Narrative Literature in Premodern India
ASIA 398.desc: Stories of gods, goddesses and religious heroes from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Puranas, Avadanas and in classical poetry and drama.

ASIA 400.name: Chinese Characters: Script, Languages, and Civilizations
ASIA 400.desc: Advanced study of the structure of the Chinese characters in their graphic, phonetic, and semantic aspects.
ASIA 400.prer: ASIA 300 and one of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348, JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361, KORN 300, KORN 301, KORN 302.

ASIA 402.name: Language, Writing, and Linguistic Thought in the History of the Sinographic Cosmopolis
ASIA 402.desc: History of language, writing and linguistic thought in China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam from a comparative perspective and focusing on the dissolution of this translocal cultural formation with the onset of modernity.
ASIA 402.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students.  At least 12 credits of any level of CHIN, JAPN, or KORN or placement approval.  Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. At least 12 credits of any level of CHIN
a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 405.name: The Interaction of Science, Religion, and Philosophy in East Asia
ASIA 405.desc: The influence of Confucianism, Buddhism, Daoism, and Christianity on the way peoples of East Asia understood and manipulated the natural world, focussing on the natural sciences.

ASIA 408.name: Religion, Society, and Secularism in Modern India
ASIA 408.desc: The postcolonial nation-state and the challenge of a multi-religious society.  Religious and secular discourse in colonial India, the partition, the modern constitution, secularism, Hindu and Muslim mobilization, and religious radicalism and communal violence.
ASIA 408.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 410.name: International Relations in Premodern East Asia
ASIA 410.desc: International relations, particularly between Korea and Japan in the premodern East Asian context, focusing on migration, trade, diplomacy, war, collective memory, mutual perceptions, and the context of the Sinocentric international order.

ASIA 411.name: Chinese Political Thought and Institutions
ASIA 411.desc: Chinese theories and practices of government and administration from earliest times to 1949.

ASIA 414.name: Architecture and Urbanism in Islamic South Asia
ASIA 414.desc: Historical factors shaping Indian architecture from the 13th to the 19th centuries.

ASIA 418.name: Social History of India
ASIA 418.desc: Fundamental institutions including family, caste and religious organizations, with emphasis on the early modern and British periods.

ASIA 428.name: Mughal India
ASIA 428.desc: History of the politics, economy, society, and culture of South Asia from the Great Mughals to the British conquest.

ASIA 430.name: International Relations in Modern East Asia: Korea and Japan
ASIA 430.desc: Trade, diplomacy, war, imperialism, militarism, colonialism, collective memory, mutual perceptions Korean-Japanese relations are examined as an exemplary case for exploring the dimensions of international conflict and partnership.

ASIA 433.name: The Cinematic Lives of Muslims in South Asia
ASIA 433.desc: Depictions of Muslims in South Asian cinema, with a particular focus on the Hindi film industry.

ASIA 440.name: Cultural History of Imperial China
ASIA 440.desc: An in-depth examination of the construction, transmission, and transformation of Chinese culture(s) prior to 1800. Completion of at least 9 credits of 300- or 400-level ASIA recommended prior to registration. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 440 or HIST 479.

ASIA 441.name: Masterworks of Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation
ASIA 441.desc: Reading of a classic novel or play, with attention to intellectual, social, and political subtexts as well as aesthetic dimensions and problems of interpretation.

ASIA 442.name: Lives of Chinese Books
ASIA 442.desc: Concepts and methods for understanding the lives of books across time, through an examination of both the material forms of a text and its cultural reception. Focus on one major work from pre-modern China.

ASIA 444.name: Topics in Modern Japanese Fiction and Cultural History
ASIA 444.desc: Focuses on a limited time period or particular aspect of modern Japanese literature.

ASIA 447.name: Korean Women's Literature
ASIA 447.desc: Women's voices and issues in the Korean literary tradition, from earliest times to the new millennium, in translation.
ASIA 447.prer: One of ASIA 347, ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable.
preq: ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable

ASIA 448.name: Narrative and Performance in South Asia
ASIA 448.desc: Key theoretical issues in the production and enactment of folk narratives in traditional and modern South Asian cultures. Intended for advanced undergraduates in Asian folklore studies. Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 448 and 547.

ASIA 450.name: Special Topics in Buddhist Studies
ASIA 450.desc: For upcoming offerings, including course descriptions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule at https://courses.students.ubc.ca/cs/main.

ASIA 451.name: Modern Chinese Authors in Translation
ASIA 451.desc: Study of one influential modern Chinese author, such as Lu Xun, Shen Congwen, Eileen Chang, Yu Hua, Mo Yan, or Wang Anyi.
ASIA 451.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 452.name: Literature of the Korean Diaspora
ASIA 452.desc: A survey of literature, in translation, from the Korean diaspora, focusing on writing by ethnic Koreans in North America, Europe, and Japan.
ASIA 452.prer: One of ASIA 347, ASIA 357, ASIA 447, ASIA 457.

ASIA 453.name: Japanese Travel Literature
ASIA 453.desc: Japanese travel literature (myths, legends, poetry, tales, diaries, illustrated guides, satiric sermons, haiku, comic fiction, colonial reporting, and ethnography) from the 8th century to present.
ASIA 453.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 454.name: Japanese Poetry in Translation
ASIA 454.desc: An introduction to Japanese poetry from its origins in song and myth, to its development from a courtly art (waka) to a popular pastime (haiku). Influences on prose, autobiography, and theatre will also be considered.

ASIA 455.name: Adaptations of Japanese Classics
ASIA 455.desc: Introduction to literary, stage, and film adaptations of Japanese classics and legends and the ways in which these "new" works appropriate the past to comment on the present.

ASIA 456.name: History and Culture of Taiwan
ASIA 456.desc: The major social, economic, political, and cultural changes in Taiwan since the seventeenth century; the post-World War II process of democratization and Taiwan’s place in the contemporary world.

ASIA 457.name: The Modern Korean Novel
ASIA 457.desc: Survey of major single-volume novels, ranging from Yi Kwang-su's
ASIA 457.prer: ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable.
preq: ASIA 357. Permission of instructor is also acceptable

ASIA 460.name: Modern Asian Women in Narrative
ASIA 460.desc: Experience of women in the context of a particular Asian culture, as seen through literature, popular culture, film and folklore. Narrative as a medium for the representation and constitution of gender.

ASIA 464.name: Japanese Women's Self-Writing
ASIA 464.desc: Selected aspects of the more than 1000 years of self-writing (diary, autobiography, personal fiction). Theory and criticism about the use of writing as a medium of self-expression.

ASIA 466.name: The History of Christianity in Asia
ASIA 466.desc: A survey of Christian proselytizing drives in South, Southeast, and East Asia, focusing on the period since 1500 and the reasons for successes (the Phillipines and Korea, for example) and failures (Japan). Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 466 and 566.

ASIA 468.name: Approaches to the Study of Asian Religions
ASIA 468.desc: The Western genealogy and problematics of religion, issues in its application to non-Western cultures and traditions, and the practical study of Asian religions, in Asia and its diasporas.
ASIA 468.prer: One of ASIA 376, ASIA 381, ASIA 382, ASIA 383, ASIA 387. Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: ASIA 387. Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration
a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 470.name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
ASIA 470.desc: Ways in which the "self" has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzsche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

ASIA 475.name: Documenting Punjabi Canada
ASIA 475.desc: Exploration of the history of the Punjabi Canadian community through traditional text-based methods and oral history collection (in English or Punjabi).

ASIA 476.name: Topics in Sikh and South Asian Studies
ASIA 476.desc: Seminar class designed to explore current scholarly debates in South Asian and Sikh Studies. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 476 or ASIA 576.
ASIA 476.prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.
preq: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing

ASIA 477.name: New Religious Movements of East Asia
ASIA 477.desc: Examines the rise of new religious movements in China, Japan, and Korea over the last two centuries, from the Taiping, Tonghak, and Tenri-kyo to the Unification Church, SGI International, and Falun Gong. Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 477 and 577.
ASIA 477.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 478.name: The Religious Image in Asia
ASIA 478.desc: The religious image and related material culture within Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, Hinduism, Christianity, and Sikhism with special attention to methodological concerns.  Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 478 or ASIA 578.
ASIA 478.prer: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing or above.
preq: Restricted to students with 2nd year standing

ASIA 484.name: The History of the Choson Dynasty
ASIA 484.desc: Political, social, and cultural history of Korea's Choson Dynasty, focusing on how it lasted from 1392 to 1910 and why it collapsed so quickly at the beginning of the twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 484 and 587.

ASIA 485.name: Inventing Asian Religions in the West/East Encounter
ASIA 485.desc: An examination of how western imperial expansion transformed the descriptions and practices of Asian traditions through systems of classification, missionaries, discovery of languages, modernity, and fragmentation.

ASIA 488.name: Religion, Society and State in Modern India
ASIA 488.desc: History of secular and religious discourse in post-independent India. Partition, state policy of secularism, religious mobilization among Hindus and Muslims, communal violence and religious radicalism.

ASIA 490.name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar
ASIA 490.desc: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

ASIA 495.name: Folk Cultures in the Asian Diaspora
ASIA 495.desc: The mediation of folklore (e.g. slang, songs, games, dance, foodways) in the everyday lives of immigrant and transnational Asian communities. Emphasis on Asian-Canadian folklore in Greater Vancouver through digital documentary media production and archival folklore research.
ASIA 495.prer: Restricted to 4th year students.  Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to 4th year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 498.name: Asia in Museums/the Museum in Asia
ASIA 498.desc: Museological representations of Asia and Asian forms of museological representation in colonial and post-colonial contexts. Credit will not be granted for both ASIA 498 and ASIA 598.
ASIA 498.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

ASIA 499.name: Honours Thesis
ASIA 499.desc: Restricted to fourth-year students admitted to the Honours Program in Asian Studies.
ASIA 499.prer: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.
preq: Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended

OBMS 431.name: Endodontics
OBMS 431.desc: Application of the basic principles of endodontics. [0-1.5-0; 1-1.5-0]

OBMS 434.name: Introduction to Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery

OBMS 436.name: Oral Radiology
OBMS 436.desc: Radiographic techniques and radiological interpretation with emphasis on extraoral techniques. [0.5-1.5]

OBMS 439.name: Oral Medicine and Oral Diagnosis
OBMS 439.desc: Oral diagnosis, including orofacial pain and temporomandibular disorders. [1-3-0; 1-3-0]

OBMS 443.name: Oral Medicine, Oral Diagnosis and Therapeutics
OBMS 443.desc: Assessment and treatment of advanced periodontal diseases. [1-2-2]

OBMS 446.name: Advanced Oral Radiology and Oral Radiography

OBMS 448.name: Directed Research in Oral Biology
OBMS 448.desc: An elective laboratory project taken with the permission of the appropriate supervisor and the department head.

OBMS 449.name: Advanced Periodontics
OBMS 449.desc: Assessment and treatment of advanced periodontal diseases. [1-3-0]

ADHE 327.name: Teaching Adults
ADHE 327.desc: Planning, conducting and evaluating instruction for adults.  Consideration is given to different beliefs and ways of thinking about teaching. [3-0-0]

ADHE 328.name: Institutions of Adult Education
ADHE 328.desc: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education.  Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined. [3-0-0]

ADHE 329.name: Developing Short Courses, Workshops and Seminars
ADHE 329.desc: Organization and administration of adult education events such as short courses, seminars, workshops, conferences and institutes. [3-0-0]

ADHE 330.name: The Community Practice of Adult Education
ADHE 330.desc: Community based adult education with particular emphasis on the application of knowledge of the social, economic, cultural and political environment in developing and conducting adult education programs with an for individuals and groups. [2-3-0]

ADHE 412.name: An Overview of Adult Education
ADHE 412.desc: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

ANTH 100.name: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
ANTH 100.desc: Basic concepts and methods of anthropology; culture and race; comparative study of social systems, religion, symbolism, art, and other institutions. Examples are drawn from a variety of cultures.

ANTH 227.name: Introduction to Medical Anthropology
ANTH 227.desc: An examination of health and illness, in their social and cultural contexts.

ANTH 308.name: Ethnography of Sub-Saharan Africa
ANTH 308.desc: An exploration of ethnographic, topical, and theoretical issues.

ANTH 378.name: Anthropology of Media
ANTH 378.desc: Analysis of contemporary mass media and of the anthropological use of media (photography, film, digital audio and video, etc.).

APBI 100.name: Soil and the Global Environment
APBI 100.desc: Soil as the base of the Earth’s ecosystem pyramid. The interconnection between soil, climate change and human activity, the carbon cycle, water resources, food security, food safety, and biofuel production. Strategies for sustaining soil resources.

APBI 200.name: Introduction to Soil Science
APBI 200.desc: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised. [3-2]

APBI 314.name: Animals and Society
APBI 314.desc: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
APBI 314.prer: At least third-year standing in any faculty.
preq: At least third-year standing in any faculty

APBI 315.name: Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
APBI 315.desc: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas. [1-0-3]
APBI 315.prer: At least third-year standing in any faculty.
preq: At least third-year standing in any faculty

APBI 365.name: Summer Practicum in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
APBI 365.desc: Based at the UBC Farm. Application required. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
APBI 365.prer: One of APBI 260, APBI 265 and third-year standing.

APBI 428.name: Integrated Pest Management
APBI 428.desc: Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops. [3-2]

APBI 490.name: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology
APBI 490.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

APBI 498.name: Undergraduate Essay
APBI 498.desc: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program adviser is required.

APBI 499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
APBI 499.desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
APBI 499.prer: Approval of a program adviser; consult before the end of classes in third year.
preq: Approval of a program adviser; consult before the end of classes in third year

APSC 110.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 110.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 160.name: Introduction to Computation in Engineering Design
APSC 160.desc: Analysis and simulation, laboratory data acquisition and processing, measurement interfaces, engineering tools, computer systems organization, programming languages. Credit will only be given for one of: APSC 160, CPSC 301, or EOSC 211.

APSC 176.name: Engineering Communication
APSC 176.desc: Purpose, audience, content, format, and tone are studied, as are team-based report writings and presentations. Community Service Learning projects are integrated into existing assignments. An LPI level 5 is required for registration in this course.

APSC 179.name: Linear Algebra for Engineers
APSC 179.desc: Systems of linear equations, Gaussian elimination, engineering application of linear algebra, matrix operations, special matrices, determinants, vector space, orthogonality, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, linear transformation. [3-0-0]

APSC 180.name: Statics
APSC 180.desc: Force vectors, Cartesian coordinate system, free body diagram, dot and cross products, forces equilibrium of particles, force and moment equilibrium of rigid bodies, analysis of trusses, frames and machines, friction, wedges, pulleys, and belts. Applications of linear algebra in statics.

APSC 201.name: Technical Communication
APSC 201.desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
APSC 201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

APSC 210.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 210.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 310.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 310.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 410.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 410.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 411.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 411.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education.

APSC 412.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 412.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Programs.

APSC 461.name: Global Engineering Leadership
APSC 461.desc: Introduction to concepts, theory, and practice of engineering leadership, including characteristics; individual and cultural differences, service and management contexts; managing change, conflicts, and crises; real-world ethics and core values.

APSC 462.name: Global Engineering Leadership Practicum
APSC 462.desc: International service learning (ISL) placement in which concepts, theory, and practice of engineering leadership are applied by working with a community organization on appropriate technology projects.
APSC 462.prer: APSC 461 and registration with the Go Global ISL program and successful completion of Go Global program requirements.
preq: registration with the Go Global ISL program
successful completion of Go Global program requirements

ARCL 140.name: Bones: The Origins of Humanity
ARCL 140.desc: The origin and evolution of the human lineage and the emergence of human biological and cultural traits with emphasis on the fossil record before the Pleistocene. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCL 140 or ANTH 225.

ARCL 228.name: Forensic Anthropology
ARCL 228.desc: The application of methods from biological anthropology and archaeology to the identification, recovery, and analysis of skeletal remains from crime scenes, mass disasters, and unexplained deaths.

ARCL 306.name: Summer Field Training in Archaeology
ARCL 306.desc: Intensive training in excavation techniques and interpretation, including mapping procedures, recording, preliminary analysis, and reporting. Students will participate in an excavation for the Summer Session and will use this excavation as a basis for lectures, discussions and reports. Additional Field Trip Fees are charged for this course.

ASTR 311.name: Exploring the Universe: Stars and Galaxies
ASTR 311.desc: A survey of recent discoveries in modern astronomy without the use of advanced mathematics. Stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, quasars and the origin and evolution of the Universe. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-1*]

ASTU 160.name: International Perspectives on Writing in the Social Sciences and Humanities
ASTU 160.desc: Analysis of and practice in writing and reading for research in the social sciences and humanities; national and international aspects of scholarship and of writing cultures. Fulfills the first component of the Arts' Writing and Research Requirement.  Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

ASTU 260.name: Knowledge Dissemination: Communicating Research to Public Audiences
ASTU 260.desc: Research, theory, and practice in the communication of expert knowledge to non-specialist audiences; popular media and dissemination. Restricted to students in the Sciences Po - UBC Dual Degree.

ASTU 310.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
ASTU 310.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Orientation workshops. Final work term report required. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.
ASTU 310.prer: 6 credits first-year English or Arts I; 6 credits of science; 6 credits of literature; satisfaction of Faculty language requirement.
preq: Arts I; 6 credits of science; 6 credits of literature; satisfaction of Faculty language requirement

ASTU 311.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
ASTU 311.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report required.

ASTU 360.name: Community-Based Research and Knowledge Creation
ASTU 360.desc: Principles and practice of conducting research in community partnership.

ASTU 410.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
ASTU 410.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

ASTU 411.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
ASTU 411.desc: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

ASTU 412.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
ASTU 412.desc: Optional extra work placement. Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term report.

ATSC 113.name: Applied Meteorology
ATSC 113.desc: Atmospheric-science principles elucidated by case studies applied to snow sports, sailing, surfing, soaring, and flying. [3-0-0]

ATSC 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
ATSC 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Winter Session (Term 2) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

ATSC 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
ATSC 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

ATSC 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
ATSC 498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.
ATSC 498.prer: ATSC 399 and one of ATSC 303, GEOB 304.

ATSC 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
ATSC 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

AUDI 402.name: Neuroanatomy for Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology
AUDI 402.prer: As indicated on the website at www.audiospeech.ubc.ca or by permission of the instructor.
preq: As indicated on the website at www.audiospeech.ubc.ca

BUSI 100.name: Micro Foundations of Real Estate Economics
BUSI 100.desc: Basic principles of microeconomics and application to current economic problems.

BUSI 101.name: Capital Markets and Real Estate
BUSI 101.desc: Basic principles of macroeconomics and application to current economic problems.

BUSI 111.name: British Columbia Real Estate Law and Real Estate Ethics
BUSI 111.desc: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies in British Columbia.

BUSI 112.name: Canadian Real Property Law and Real Estate Ethics
BUSI 112.desc: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies across Canada.

BUSI 121.name: Foundations of Real Estate Mathematics
BUSI 121.desc: Introduction to mathematics of real estate finance and statistical measures and methods and their application to practical real estate concepts.

BUSI 293.name: Introductory Financial Accounting
BUSI 293.desc: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use.

BUSI 294.name: Introductory Management Accounting
BUSI 294.desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports.

BUSI 300.name: Urban and Real Estate Economics
BUSI 300.desc: Comprehensive treatment of urban and real estate economics; introduction to study of cities and real estate market; analytical microeconomic principles.

BUSI 330.name: Foundations of Real Estate Appraisal
BUSI 330.desc: Introduction to concepts and techniques for appraising the value of real estate.

BUSI 331.name: Real Estate Investment Analysis and Advanced Income Appraisal
BUSI 331.desc: Valuation techniques for income real estate, including income method of appraisal, tax consequences of real property ownership, and portfolio analysis methodology.

BUSI 335.name: Information Systems
BUSI 335.desc: Introduction to information technology related to business use: design, implementation, and application of information systems.

BUSI 344.name: Statistical and Computer Applications in Valuation
BUSI 344.desc: Explores creative, practical uses of statistical and computer applications in determining and analyzing real estate value. Through case studies and hands-on computer work, students will learn the fundamentals of exploratory data analysis and appraisal valuation modeling.

BUSI 352.name: Case Studies in Residential Valuation
BUSI 352.desc: Examines common issues that affect the practice of residential real estate valuation. Credit will be granted for only one of BUSI 352 or both BUSI 442 and BUSI 452.

BUSI 353.name: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
BUSI 353.desc: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

BUSI 354.name: Cost Accounting
BUSI 354.desc: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance.

BUSI 355.name: Introduction to Income Tax
BUSI 355.desc: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and business enterprise.

BUSI 370.name: Business Finance
BUSI 370.desc: An introduction to the basic principles of financial valuation and an examination of corporate enterprise decisions including working capital management; capital budgeting; capital structures and dividend policy.

BUSI 393.name: Introduction to Business Law
BUSI 393.desc: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property, principles of agency, partnership, and company law.

BUSI 398.name: Residental Property Guided Case Study
BUSI 398.desc: The residential property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.

BUSI 400.name: Residential Property Analysis
BUSI 400.desc: Underlying theory and techniques used in design, construction, and inspection of residential properties.

BUSI 401.name: Commercial Property Analysis
BUSI 401.desc: Underlying theory and techniques used in the design and construction of commercial properties.

BUSI 433.name: Real Estate Business
BUSI 433.desc: General business skills for real estate practitioners.

BUSI 442.name: Case Studies in Appraisal I
BUSI 442.desc: Examines the day-to day issues that affect the practice of real estate appraisal.

BUSI 443.name: Assessment Administration
BUSI 443.desc: Introduces the practice of real property assessment, including the nature of the techniques used, the required duties of assessors, and how an assessment office is administrated.

BUSI 444.name: Computer Aided Mass Property Assessment
BUSI 444.desc: This course develops and applies the major techniques for valuing real property.
BUSI 444.prer: Recommend all of BUSI 121, BUSI 330, BUSI 443.
preq: Recommend all of BUSI 121 BUSI 330 BUSI 443

BUSI 450.name: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
BUSI 450.desc: A continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

BUSI 453.name: Advanced Financial Accounting
BUSI 453.desc: An examination of advanced financial accounting topics.

BUSI 455.name: Principles of Auditing
BUSI 455.desc: Principles of internal control; audit evidence; sampling and testing; audit reports; standards and responsibilities of the external audit.
BUSI 455.prer: BUSI 353. Recommended prerequisite or corequisite: BUSI 450.

BUSI 493.name: Strategic Management in Business
BUSI 493.desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of busness strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business.  Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change.
BUSI 493.prer: BUSI 293 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 309.
BUSI 493.crer: Two of BUSI 294, BUSI 329, BUSI 370, BUSI 465.
creq: Two of BUSI 294 BUSI 329 BUSI 370 BUSI 465

BUSI 497.name: Guided Case Study in Agricultural Real Estate
BUSI 497.prer: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

BUSI 499.name: Income Property Guided Case Study
BUSI 499.desc: The income property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.
BUSI 499.prer: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

CAPS 391.name: Introduction to Gross Human Anatomy
CAPS 391.desc: Structure and function of body regions at the macroscopic level. [3-0-0]
CAPS 391.prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001, KIN  190, KIN  191.

CAPS 398.name: Cooperative Work Placement
CAPS 398.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).
