CAPS 398.prer: Co-op Workshops, CAPS 301, CAPS 303 (or, PHYL 301, PHYL 303).

CAPS 399.name: Cooperative Work Placement II
CAPS 399.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for  a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

CAPS 498.name: Cooperative Work Placement III
CAPS 498.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

CAPS 499.name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
CAPS 499.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

CENS 201.name: Contrasts and Conflicts: The Cultures of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
CENS 201.desc: An introduction to the cultural history of the peoples of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe as reflected in their literature, art and music.

CHEM 121.name: Structure and Bonding in Chemistry
CHEM 121.desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories and structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-0]

CHEM 123.name: Thermodynamics, Kinetics and Organic Chemistry
CHEM 123.desc: Fundamentals of chemical reactivity: thermodynamics; kinetics; organic chemistry, including stereochemistry; applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-0]

CHEM 233.name: Organic Chemistry for the Biological Sciences
CHEM 233.desc: Reactions and properties of carbonyl compounds, carbohydrates, amino acids, nucleic acids. [3-0-0]

CHEM 235.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 235.desc: Techniques of organic chemistry. To be taken in conjunction with, or in the term following, CHEM 233. [0-3-0]

CHEM 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
CHEM 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHEM 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
CHEM 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHEM 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
CHEM 498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHEM 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
CHEM 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the fall term of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

CHIN 134.name: Intensive Basic Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 134.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 500 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 134 or CHIN 104 or both CHIN 101, CHIN 103, or both CHIN 131, CHIN 133.

CHIN 233.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 233.desc: Continuation of CHIN 231. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 233 or CHIN 107, or CHIN 234.

CHIN 234.name: Intensive Basic Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 234.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 1000 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 234 or CHIN 108 or both CHIN 105, CHIN 107, or both CHIN 231, CHIN 233.
CHIN 234.prer: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

CHIN 464.name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Intensive)
CHIN 464.desc: A combination of CHIN 461 and 463. Classical poetry from pre-Qin to the early Tang Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 464 or both CHIN 461, CHIN 463.
CHIN 464.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 474.name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Intensive)
CHIN 474.desc: A combination of CHIN 471 and 473. Classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Qing Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 474 or both CHIN 471, CHIN 473.
CHIN 474.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 481.name: Modern Chinese Literature I (Heritage)
CHIN 481.desc: Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 481 or CHIN 484.
CHIN 481.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 484.name: Intensive Modern Chinese Literature (Heritage)
CHIN 484.desc: A combination of CHIN 481 and 483. Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to the present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 484 or both CHIN 481, CHIN 483.
CHIN 484.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CIVL 200.name: Engineering and Sustainable Development
CIVL 200.desc: Implications of a finite biosphere and the complexities inherent in environmental decision-making.

CIVL 235.name: Plane Surveying
CIVL 235.desc: Theory and application of plane surveying methods. Introduction to and use of compass, transit, tape, and level. Construction and topographic surveys. Reduction of field data and construction of drawings. Demonstration of modern instruments, remote sensing methods and geographical information systems (GIS). This course commences immediately after spring examinations and continues full time for two weeks, including Saturdays. Information on the exact dates will be available in the Civil Engineering Office following publication of the final Examination Timetable.

CNPS 362.name: Basic Interviewing Skills
CNPS 362.desc: Development of basic interviewing skills for counselling and guidance. [3-3]

CNPS 363.name: Career Counselling
CNPS 363.desc: Critical survey of career counselling theory and practice. [3-0]

CNPS 364.name: Family Education and Consultation
CNPS 364.desc: Examination of current theories and practices in family education and consultation. [3-0]

CNPS 365.name: Introduction to Theories of Counselling
CNPS 365.desc: An overview of selected theories of counselling. [3-0]

CNPS 427.name: Guidance: Planning and Decision-making
CNPS 427.desc: The work of the beginning counsellor and guidance worker in assisting students with educational, vocational, and personal planning and decision-making. [3-0]

CNPS 433.name: The Personal and Social Development of the Adult
CNPS 433.desc: Personal and social adjustment issues for professional counsellors; basic skills necessary for effective group counselling. [3-3]

CNTO 311.name: Basic Cantonese for Mandarin Speakers
CNTO 311.desc: Basic oral and presentation skills in Cantonese. This is an accelerated course that covers content and topics similar to CNTO 301 and CNTO 303, but is structured specifically for heritage speakers of Mandarin.
CNTO 311.prer: One of CHIN 243, CHIN 244. Or placement approval.

CNTO 401.name: Intermediate Cantonese I
CNTO 401.desc: Intermediate lower level (part I) Cantonese for non-heritage learners.
CNTO 401.prer: One of CNTO 303, CNTO 311. Or placement approval.

COGS 402.name: Research in Cognitive Systems
COGS 402.desc: Supervised research project in a Cognitive Systems-related laboratory. [0-9-0]

COMM 203.name: Managing the Employment Relationship
COMM 203.desc: The role of employment relations in enterprise performance. Managing employees under statutory law, collective bargaining, and progressive human resource management. Key issues in forming, developing, and maintaining a work force. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 203 or COMM 392.
COMM 203.prer: COMM 292 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100.

COMM 204.name: Logistics and Operations Management
COMM 204.desc: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 204 or COMM 399.

COMM 205.name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
COMM 205.desc: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 205 or COMM 391.

COMM 280.name: Entrepreneurship
COMM 280.desc: Entrepreneurial essentials from creating viable opportunities through building a founding team, strategic planning, going to market, fleshing out an organization and planning the future of the business.

COMM 290.name: Introduction to Quantitative Decision Making
COMM 290.desc: Introduction to decision models in business, including basic optimization, linear programming, probability, decision analysis, random variables, simulation, and solving decision problems using spreadsheet tools.
COMM 290.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

COMM 293.name: Financial Accounting
COMM 293.desc: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 293 or COEC 293.

COMM 294.name: Managerial Accounting
COMM 294.desc: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control and the development of cost information for financial reports.

COMM 295.name: Managerial Economics
COMM 295.desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, organization of the firm, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, ECON 301, ECON 304, FRE 295, COMM 295.
COMM 295.prer: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102.

COMM 329.name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
COMM 329.desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them. Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership (for non-Commerce students only).

COMM 335.name: Information Systems Technology and Development
COMM 335.desc: Introduction to information technology related to business use. Design, implementation and application of Information Systems.

COMM 380.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
COMM 380.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce. Option-specific prerequisites apply.

COMM 381.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
COMM 381.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

COMM 390.name: Business Writing
COMM 390.desc: An activity-focused course providing the opportunity to study and practice forms of writing needed in business.
COMM 390.prer: One of ENGL 112, ASTU 150, WRDS 150, ENGL 100, ENGL 120, ENGL 121. ENGL 1st, Arts One, a minimum of 18 cr. of Coordinated Arts Program.
preq: a minimum of 18 cr. of Coordinated Arts Program

COMM 393.name: Commercial Law
COMM 393.desc: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property; principles of agency, partnerships and company law.

COMM 394.name: Government and Business
COMM 394.desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 394 or COMM 394.

COMM 395.name: Business Communications
COMM 395.desc: Understanding non-written communications in day-to-day business.

COMM 398.name: Introduction to Business Processes and Operations
COMM 398.desc: The design and management of systems that efficiently and effectively supply products and services to the end-user. The concepts apply to a variety of settings such as manufacturing, logistics, healthcare, and others (For non-Commerce students only).

COMM 457.name: Fundamentals of Financial Accounting
COMM 457.desc: Financial accounting for business organizations; principles and problems of accounting measurements; forms of business organizations; financing of businesses. (For non-Commerce students only).

COMM 465.name: Marketing Management
COMM 465.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. (For non-Commerce students only).
COMM 465.prer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

COMM 473.name: Business Finance
COMM 473.desc: Introduction to managerial finance, including the role and functioning of financial markets, procurement of funds and financing strategies, dividend policy, capital budgeting and financial analysis and planning. (For non-Commerce students only).
COMM 473.prer: Either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 100 or (c) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310;  and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

COMM 480.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
COMM 480.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the summer term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative. Education Program in Commerce.

COMM 481.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
COMM 481.desc: Approved and supervised work experience for a minimum of 35 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Commerce.

COMM 491.name: Strategic Management
COMM 491.desc: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of private sector, single and multi-business unit enterprises are analysed using the case method. Methodologies which draw on economic and organizational theory are integrated to form the foundations for strategic analyses.
COMM 491.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

COMM 493.name: Strategic Management in Business
COMM 493.desc: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of business strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business. Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change (For non-Commerce students only in fourth year).
COMM 493.prer: One of COMM 293, COMM 457 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) all of ECON 310, ECON 311 or (c) ECON 100 or (d) all of ECON 101, ECON 311 or (e) all of ECON 102, ECON 310.

COMM 498.name: International Business Management
COMM 498.desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 498 or COEC 498.
COMM 498.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

CONS 340.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems for Forestry and Conservation
CONS 340.desc: Introduction to principles, practice and context of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) applied to forest management and natural resource conservation issues. Priority enrolment to students in the Faculty of Forestry. [2-2-0]

CONS 453.name: International Conservation and Forest Ecosystem Management Field School
CONS 453.desc: International, experiential learning in conservation and forest ecosystem management. A 300-level ecology course such as CONS 330 is strongly recommended as a prerequisite. Fee will be assessed for living and traveling expenses. Pre-registration is required.
CONS 453.prer: One of FRST 231, BIOL 300 and all of FRST 210, FRST 211. Or 6 credits of ecology based courses (e.g. BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 260, APBI 360). Third-year standing and permission of the instructor are required.

CPEN 291.name: Computer Engineering Design Studio I
CPEN 291.desc: Design projects involving hardware (electronic devices and circuits, microcomputers) and software.

CPEN 481.name: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
CPEN 481.desc: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

CPSC 103.name: Introduction to Systematic Program Design
CPSC 103.desc: Computation as a tool for systematic problem solving in non-computer-science disciplines. Introductory programming skills. Not for students with existing credit for or exemption from CPSC 110 or APSC 160. No programming experience expected. [3-0-1]

CPSC 110.name: Computation, Programs, and Programming
CPSC 110.desc: Fundamental program and computation structures. Introductory programming skills. Computation as a tool for information processing, simulation and modeling, and interacting with the world. [3-3-0]

CPSC 121.name: Models of Computation
CPSC 121.desc: Physical and mathematical structures of computation.  Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution. [3-2-1]

CPSC 210.name: Software Construction
CPSC 210.desc: Design, development, and analysis of robust software components. Topics such as software design, computational models, data structures, debugging, and testing. [3-2-0]

CPSC 213.name: Introduction to Computer Systems
CPSC 213.desc: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-3-0]

CPSC 221.name: Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
CPSC 221.desc: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency. [3-2-0]
CPSC 221.prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, CPEN 221 and one of CPSC 121, MATH 220.

CPSC 298.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
CPSC 298.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during Winter Session of second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CPSC 299.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
CPSC 299.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education.

CPSC 313.name: Computer Hardware and Operating Systems
CPSC 313.desc: Instruction sets, pipelining, code optimization, caching, virtual memory management, dynamically linked libraries, exception processing, execution time of programs. [3-0-1]
CPSC 313.prer: Either (a) all of CPSC 213, CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 210, CPSC 213, CPSC 260, EECE 320.

CPSC 320.name: Intermediate Algorithm Design and Analysis
CPSC 320.desc: Systematic study of basic concepts and techniques in the design and analysis of algorithms, illustrated from various problem areas. Topics include: models of computation; choice of data structures; graph-theoretic, algebraic, and text processing algorithms. [3-0-1]
CPSC 320.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320. In addition to above pre-requisites, at least 3 credits from COMM 291, BIOL 300, MATH or STAT at 200 level or above.
preq: EECE 320. In addition to above pre-requisites

CPSC 322.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
CPSC 322.desc: Problem-solving and planning; state/action models and graph searching. Natural language understanding Computational vision. Applications of artificial intelligence. [3-0-0]
CPSC 322.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

CPSC 340.name: Machine Learning and Data Mining
CPSC 340.desc: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence. [3-0-1]
CPSC 340.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, MATH 302, STAT 302, MATH 318, BIOL 300;  and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

CPSC 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
CPSC 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CPSC 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
CPSC 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CPSC 449.name: Honours Thesis
CPSC 449.desc: Under supervision of a faculty member, students investigate a research topic and prepare a thesis.

CPSC 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
CPSC 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in the computing industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Computer Science.

CRWR 200.name: Introduction to Creative Writing
CRWR 200.desc: Techniques of and practice in multiple genres of writing, including fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, screenplay, stageplay, graphic forms, lyric forms, children’s literature, and writing for new media. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

DENT 410.name: Dentistry I: Foundations of Clinical Dentistry
DENT 410.desc: Fundamentals of human biology, body systems, diseases, and supporting basic oral health sciences. Learning in small groups, classroom, laboratory, and clinical settings utilizing technology.  Professionalism, ethics, inter-professional education and the social contract, communication skills, and critical evaluation of the literature. Begin to apply foundation knowledge and skills to patient assessment and care.

DENT 420.name: Dentistry II: Basic Clinical Dentistry
DENT 420.desc: Continued exposure to body systems and the supporting biomedical sciences with applications in dental clinical sciences, integrated into small group learning, classroom, laboratory, and community settings utilizing technology; continued engagement in professionalism, ethics and communication skills.

ECED 407.name: Supporting Early Learning in the Pre-School Years
ECED 407.desc: Planning and implementing pre-kindergarten learning experiences; resources, materials, curriculum integration, evaluation, scheduling, and classroom design.

ECED 416.name: Kindergarten Curriculum
ECED 416.desc: The development of kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, curriculum trends and practices, and the place of kindergarten in contemporary education.

ECED 417.name: Supporting Learning in the Kindergarten Year
ECED 417.desc: Designing environments, experiences, activities, instruction, and assessment to foster children's learning in the kindergarten year.
ECED 417.prer: One of ECED 405, ECED 416 or teaching experience, or successful completion of extended practicum.

ECED 420.name: History of Early Childhood Education
ECED 420.desc: Political and social factors which influenced movements and trends in early childhood education in North America, pre-kindergarten through primary.

ECED 438.name: Observation and Documentation in Early Childhood Settings

EDCP 329.name: Agriculture in the Curriculum
EDCP 329.desc: Agricultural awareness, understanding the food system, and integration of food and agricultural literacy across the curriculum.

EDCP 403.name: Visual Arts for Classroom Practice: Three-Dimensional Practices and Processes

EDCP 409.name: Art Education Theory and Research
EDCP 409.prer: Art education as a major or minor and completion of a practicum in Art Education.
preq: completion of a practicum in Art Education

EDCP 432.name: Special Study in Social Studies: Geography

EDCP 453.name: Biology for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP 453.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit towards a graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP 455.name: Earth and Space Science for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP 455.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required.  Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP 456.name: Botany for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP 456.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiecy. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP 474.name: Digital Media in ICT Education: Design and Pedagogy

EDCP 491.name: Home Economics II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 493.name: Special Study in Home Economics: Foods Studies

EDCP 494.name: Special Study in Home Economics: Family Studies

EDUC 179.name: Practicum I
EDUC 179.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.  Pass/Fail.

EDUC 279.name: Practicum II
EDUC 279.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

ELEC 291.name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio I
ELEC 291.desc: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, and microcomputers.
ELEC 291.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211.

ELEC 292.name: Biomedical Engineering Design Studio
ELEC 292.desc: Design projects involving electronic devices and circuits, electromagnetics, signals and systems, microcomputers with applications in biomedical engineering. Final group project requiring oral presentation of student-prepared slides.
ELEC 292.crer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221.

ELEC 341.name: Systems and Control
ELEC 341.desc: Continuous time system analysis by Laplace transforms; system modeling by transfer function and state space methods; feedback, stability and sensitivity; control design; frequency domain analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 or EECE 369.
ELEC 341.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202, ELEC 204, EECE 269, ELEC 221.

ELEC 391.name: Electrical Engineering Design Studio II
ELEC 391.desc: Introduction to project management.  Problem definition.  Design principles and practices.  Implementation techniques including circuit design, software design, solid modeling, PCBs, assembling, and packaging.  Testing and evaluation.  Effective presentations.
ELEC 391.prer: One of CPEN 291, ELEC 291, ELEC 292, EECE 281 and two of EECE 352, ELEC 315, EECE 356, ELEC 301, EECE 359, EECE 360, ELEC 341, EECE 364, ELEC 311, EECE 373, ELEC 342.
preq: two of EECE 352 ELEC 315 EECE 356 ELEC 301 EECE 359 EECE 360 ELEC 341 EECE 364 ELEC 311 EECE 373 ELEC 342

ELEC 481.name: Economic Analysis of Engineering Projects
ELEC 481.desc: Time-money relationships; economic analysis of alternatives including the effects of interest rates, inflation, depreciation, taxation and uncertainty; cost estimation and budgeting; financial analysis of engineering operations.

ENGL 110.name: Approaches to Literature
ENGL 110.desc: Study of selected examples of poetry, fiction, and drama. Essays are required.

ENGL 112.name: Strategies for University Writing
ENGL 112.desc: Study and practice of the principles of university-level discourse, with multidisciplinary readings and emphasis on processes of research-based writing.  Essays are required.

ENGL 220.name: Literature in English to the 18th Century
ENGL 220.desc: A survey of prose, poetry and drama to the 18th Century.
ENGL 220.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 222.name: Literature in Canada
ENGL 222.desc: The major types of Canadian writing: fiction, poetry, non-fictional prose, and drama
ENGL 222.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 224.name: World Literature in English
ENGL 224.desc: English literature produced outside Britain and North America.
ENGL 224.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 301.name: Technical Writing
ENGL 301.desc: Study of the principles of written communication in general business and professional activities, and practice in the preparation of abstracts, proposals, reports, and correspondence. This course is closed to first- and second-year students in Arts.  Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
ENGL 301.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 321.name: English Grammar and Usage
ENGL 321.desc: Descriptive approaches to the English Language

ENPH 253.name: Introduction to Instrument Design
ENPH 253.desc: Practice in engineering design and instrument development including mechanical and electrical design, and communications with sensors, actuators. Micro-controller implementation and system integration. Engineering design review process and presentations. Engineering communication in design and product release. [3-6-0]

ENPH 257.name: Heat and Thermodynamics
ENPH 257.desc: Thermometry, thermal properties of matter; heat transfer by conduction; convection and radiation; kinetic theory of gases and gas laws; heat engines; refrigeration; change of state; first and second laws of thermodynamics. [1-3-1]
ENPH 257.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 255, MATH 263;  and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.

ENPH 270.name: Mechanics II
ENPH 270.desc: Dynamics: systems of particles, kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies (plane motion), energy and momentum, rotating coordinates. [2-0-1]

EOSC 114.name: The Catastrophic Earth: Natural Disasters
EOSC 114.desc: Introduction to causes and physical characteristics of disasters such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, storm surge, thunderstorms, tornadoes, landslides, wind waves, meteor impacts, mass extinctions. [3-0-0]

EOSC 116.name: Mesozoic Earth: Time of the Dinosaurs
EOSC 116.desc: Earth's tectonics, climate, and oceans during the time of the dinosaurs.  Reading the fossil record of Earth from its earliest origins up to and including the Mesozoic, 250 - 65 million years ago. [3-0-0]

EOSC 118.name: Earth's Treasures: Gold and Gems
EOSC 118.desc: Origin, properties, valuation, prospecting and geology of gold, platinum, silver, diamonds, rubies, emeralds, and other precious metals and gems. [3-0-0]

EOSC 310.name: The Earth and the Solar System
EOSC 310.desc: The Earth as a planet: its composition, internal dynamics, and surface evolution. Rotation, magnetic field, plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes. The ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere as components of a varying geo-environment. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in science or mathematics is required. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

EOSC 315.name: The Ocean Ecosystem
EOSC 315.desc: An introduction to life in the oceans, its variety and evolution; primary producers and their links to the environment, zooplankton, marine communities, living marine resources and their role in today's world. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. [3-0-0]

EOSC 326.name: Earth and Life Through Time
EOSC 326.desc: The fossil record of adaptation and extinction emphasizing the interaction of biological and geological processes. Not for credit in any Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences specialization. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
EOSC 326.prer: Biology 100-level and third-year standing in Science.

EOSC 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
EOSC 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EOSC 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
EOSC 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EOSC 447.name: Thesis
EOSC 447.desc: For B.A.Sc. Topic to be approved by the Department. [0-3-0]

EOSC 449.name: Thesis
EOSC 449.desc: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Required of all honours students. Open to major students with a satisfactory standing, appropriate background courses and permission of the course instructor and the directing faculty member.

EOSC 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
EOSC 498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university of government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EOSC 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
EOSC 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.

EPSE 303.name: Teaching Highly Able Learners
EPSE 303.desc: Identification and appraisal of developmental and educational needs of highly able learners. [3-0]

EPSE 312.name: Introduction to the Study of Exceptional Children
EPSE 312.desc: An examination of all groups of exceptional children in terms of definition, incidence, characteristics, diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite to most other courses in Special Education. Can be taken concurrently with several other introductory courses in Special Education. [3-0]

EPSE 316.name: Learning Disabilities
EPSE 316.desc: Identification, assessment and needs of children with learning disabilities. [3-0-0]

EPSE 317.name: Development and Exceptionality in the Regular Classroom
EPSE 317.desc: The teacher's role in dealing with major developmental and special educational issues and problems within the regular classroom program, including working with supportive services, parents, and communities. Designated sections will focus on early childhood, middle childhood or adolescence. Pass/Fail.

EPSE 320.name: Classroom Inclusion of Students who are Blind and Visually Impaired
EPSE 320.desc: Inclusion issues of students with visual impairments in general education classrooms; information about visual impairment, classroom adaptations and accommodations, and application of Universal Design. Appropriate for education majors and classroom teachers. [3-0]

EPSE 348.name: Family-Centred Practice for Children with Special Needs

EPSE 401.name: Instructional Design
EPSE 401.desc: Principles of instructional design and their application to the development, analysis, and evaluation of instructional plans for selected settings, instructional formats, and age groupings of learners. [3-0]

EPSE 403.name: Education of Students with Developmental Disabilities in Inclusive Settings

EPSE 406.name: Typical and Atypical Development in Infants and Children

EPSE 408.name: Educational Programming for Highly Able Learners
EPSE 408.desc: Planning elementary and secondary level programs for highly able learners. [3-0]

EPSE 421.name: Assessment of Learning Difficulties
EPSE 421.desc: Theories of learning and instruction; principles and practices of diagnosis and assessment as these relate to students with relevant special needs.

EPSE 433.name: Assessment and Positive Behavioural Support in School and Community Settings

EPSE 436.name: Survey of Behaviour Disorders in Children and Adolescents

EPSE 437.name: Interventions for Children and Adolescents with Behaviour Disorders

EPSE 482.name: Introduction to Statistics for Research in Education
EPSE 482.desc: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work involving quantitative methodology. [3-0]
EPSE 482.prer: Proficiency in modern high school algebra.
preq: Proficiency in modern high school algebra

EPSE 483.name: Reading and Interpreting Research in Education
EPSE 483.desc: Introductory research methods course for students who wish to be critical readers rather than producers of educational research.  Develops skills for locating, understanding, interpreting and critiquing educational empirical research.  May not be used as a prerequisite to EPSE 592 or EPSE 596. [3-0]

FMST 210.name: Family Context of Human Development
FMST 210.desc: The influence of family dynamics and social conditions on human development.

FMST 312.name: Parent-child Relationships
FMST 312.desc: Parent-child interaction over the life span.

FMST 314.name: Relationship Development
FMST 314.desc: The study of the development, course, and decline of personal relationships.
FMST 314.prer: One of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

FMST 316.name: Human Sexuality
FMST 316.desc: An examination of human sexual development and behaviour.
FMST 316.prer: One of SOCI 200, PSYC 100, PSYC 101, PSYC 102, SOCI 240.

FNEL 483.name: Indigenous Languages of BC: Diversity and Vitality
FNEL 483.desc: Genetic affiliation, areal contact, typological diversity, and initiatives to sustain the vitality and diversity of BC First Nations Languages.

FNH 200.name: Exploring Our Food
FNH 200.desc: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future. [3-0-0]
FNH 200.prer: At least second year standing required.
preq: At least second year standing required

FNH 250.name: Nutrition Concepts and Controversies
FNH 250.desc: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues. [3-0-0]
FNH 250.prer: Either (a) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (b) all of KIN  190, KIN  191. At least second-year standing required.
preq: KIN 191. At least second-year standing required

FNH 330.name: Introduction to Wine Science 1
FNH 330.desc: Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation. [2-1-0]

FNH 355.name: International Nutrition
FNH 355.desc: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world. [3-0-0]

FNH 381.name: Professional Dietetic Practice II
FNH 381.desc: Themes include: nutrition communications, professional practice, and dietetic practice environments. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.

FNH 460.name: International Nutrition Field Studies
FNH 460.desc: Theoretical and practical application of international nutrition and food security knowledge and skills.  International field placement for a minimum of 12 weeks with pre-departure sessions.  Restricted to students in International Nutrition Major or by permission of instructor.

FNH 480.name: Professional Dietetic Practice III
FNH 480.desc: Themes include practice-based research, clinical practice readiness, and orientation to internship.
FNH 480.prer: Fourth-year standing in the Dietetics Major.
preq: Fourth-year standing in the Dietetics Major

FNH 483.name: Dietetic Internship III
FNH 483.desc: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

FNH 499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
FNH 499.desc: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis.
FNH 499.prer: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.
preq: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year

FREN 101.name: Beginners' French I
FREN 101.desc: Grammar, composition, reading and oral practice.  Not available to students with the prerequisite for FREN 102.

FREN 102.name: Beginners' French II
FREN 102.desc: Grammar, composition, reading and oral practice.  Not available to students with prerequisite for FREN 111.

FREN 111.name: Intermediate French I
FREN 111.desc: Not available for credit to students with FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.
FREN 111.prer: One of FREN 11, FREN 102 or equivalent.

FREN 112.name: Intermediate French II
FREN 112.desc: Not available for credit to students with FREN 12.

FREN 220.name: Introduction to Early French Literature and to Textual Analysis
FREN 220.desc: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the Middle Ages to the 17th century, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose. To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
FREN 220.prer: FREN 123 or assignment based on placement test.

FRST 231.name: Introduction to Biometrics
FRST 231.desc: Basic theories of probability and statistics. Sampling distribution, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing; goodness of fit and tests for independence; analysis of variance, regression and correlation. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]
FRST 231.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 180, MATH 184, MATH 190.

FRST 248.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 248.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Orientation workshops required. Final work term report required.

FRST 307.name: Biotic Disturbances
FRST 307.desc: Concepts of disturbance ecology with special reference to insects and diseases in the forests of British Columbia; forest health problems in the biogeoclamatic zones of BC; present management strategies and future potentials in a scenario of climate change. [3-3-0]

FRST 346.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 346.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Facutly of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST 347.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 347.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST 348.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 348.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST 446.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 446.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST 447.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 447.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST 448.name: Co-operative Work Placement
FRST 448.desc: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

FRST 498.name: B.Sc. Thesis in Forestry
FRST 498.desc: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the direction of a staff member. The subject must be appropriate to the student's area of concentration.

GEOB 103.name: Our Changing Environment: Water and Landscapes
GEOB 103.desc: Physical processes acting at the Earth's surface; water cycle; landforms; human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2*-0]

GEOG 122.name: Geography, Modernity and Globalization
GEOG 122.desc: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization.

GEOG 310.name: Environment and Sustainability
GEOG 310.desc: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems.
GEOG 310.prer: One of GEOB 102, GEOB 103. Or 6 credits in the Faculty of Science (BIOL, CHEM, EOSC, PHYS).
preq: GEOB 103. Or 6 credits in the Faculty of Science

GEOG 352.name: Urbanization in the Global South
GEOG 352.desc: Urbanization in the developing countries of Latin America, Africa, and Asia; the role of cities in the development process and the features and problems of rapid urbanization.

GEOG 447.name: Directed Studies: Off Campus Research
GEOG 447.desc: Based on project work outside the university. Not available to co-op students. See the departmental undergraduate adviser for details.
GEOG 447.prer: Permission of the department head and at least 15 credits of relevant 300- or 400- level Geography courses.

GEOG 448.name: Directed Studies in Geography
GEOG 448.desc: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.
GEOG 448.prer: Permission of the department head and supervising faculty member is required.

GERM 100.name: Beginners' German I
GERM 100.desc: Introduction to the language.  Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations.  See also GERM 433.

GERM 110.name: Beginners' German II
GERM 110.desc: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations, speak about past events and express ideas and hypotheses in German. See also GERM 433.

GERM 112.name: German for Singers
GERM 112.desc: Study of the German language in combination with the study of German lyric diction and musical culture. The course includes translation, phonetic transcription, and the performance of vocal music.

GERM 433.name: German for Reading Knowledge I
GERM 433.desc: A multimedia introduction to reading skills in German leading to a second year reading knowledge in just one term. Students are expected to work largely independently. Course restricted to beginners or to students with no more than one term of beginner's German (or equivalent).

GRSJ 101.name: Introduction to Social Justice
GRSJ 101.desc: An overview of intersectional feminist debates and theoretical traditions. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 101.

GRSJ 300.name: Intersectional Approaches to Thinking Gender
GRSJ 300.desc: Interdisciplinary exploration of the multiple intersections between gender and (neo)colonialism, racism, poverty, ableism, and heterosexism in a globalized world; historical and cross-cultural aspects, and the social construction of sex and gender, masculinity and femininity.

HIST 103.name: World History Since 1900
HIST 103.desc: International relations; changes in the nation-state system; the emergence and impact of major political ideologies; genocide; decolonization; the globalization of trade; and the dynamics of economic, social, cultural, and environmental change in a global context.

HIST 106.name: Global Environmental History
HIST 106.desc: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization.

HIST 326.name: Canada Since 1945: Affluence and Anxiety in the Atomic Age
HIST 326.desc: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 326 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

HIST 339.name: The United States Since 1945: The Limits of Power
HIST 339.desc: American military and geo-political power during and after Cold War; wars in Korea, Vietnam, and Middle East; domestic issues including McCarthyism, social movements (blacks, women, youth, gays and lesbians, and Native Americans), consumerism, immigration, and rise of New Right.

HIST 357.name: History of Mexico
HIST 357.desc: Examines themes in the last five hundred years of Mexican history, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources and the use of a variety of texts that may include letters, diaries, paintings, photographs, novels, and movies.

HIST 412.name: The American Impact on Canada
HIST 412.desc: An examination of the influence of the United States' rise to continental, hemispheric, and world power upon Canada in the areas of economics, defence, and foreign policy.

HIST 425.name: War and Society
HIST 425.desc: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history.

HIST 441.name: History of the Holocaust
HIST 441.desc: A study of the systematic attempt to destroy European Jewry during the Nazi regime, 1933-1945. Topics of special importance include: the motivations and behaviour of the perpetrators; the reactions of the victims; the roles of bystanders.

HIST 482.name: Chinese Migration
HIST 482.desc: This history of Chinese migrations from the founding of the state to the present day. Migration is used as a focus through which to examine some key themes of Chinese history; ethnicity, boundary creation, economic growth and international relations.

ISCI 361.name: Field Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
ISCI 361.desc: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate a selected region of the world.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to field course.

ISCI 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
ISCI 398.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Normally taken in Winter Session of third year or Summer Session after third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students in the ISP Co-op program.

ISCI 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
ISCI 399.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

ISCI 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
ISCI 498.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months.  Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

ISCI 499.name: Co-Operative Work Placement IV
ISCI 499.desc: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

ITAL 101.name: First-Year Italian I
ITAL 101.desc: Grammar, reading, writing, and oral practice for beginners without previous exposure to the Italian language or dialects.

ITAL 102.name: First-Year Italian II
ITAL 102.desc: Grammar, reading, writing and oral practice for beginners without previous exposure to the Italian language or dialects.
ITAL 102.prer: ITAL 101. Or permission of the instructor.
preq: ITAL 101. Or permission of the instructor

ITAL 104.name: Italian for Singers
ITAL 104.desc: The study of the Italian language with the study of Italian lyric diction and musical culture; practice in translation, phonetic transcription and the performance of vocal music.

JAPN 100.name: Beginning Japanese IA
JAPN 100.desc: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 11 and/or JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 100 or JAPN 160.

JAPN 101.name: Beginning Japanese IB
JAPN 101.desc: Continuation of JAPN 100 (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 101 or JAPN 160.

JAPN 200.name: Beginning Japanese II A
JAPN 200.desc: Continuation of JAPN 101 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 200 or JAPN 102 or JAPN 260.

JAPN 201.name: Beginning Japanese II B
JAPN 201.desc: Continuation of JAPN 200 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 201 or JAPN 103 or JAPN 260.

JAPN 320.name: Intermediate Japanese I A
JAPN 320.desc: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 320 or JAPN 210 or JAPN 360.
JAPN 320.prer: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

JAPN 321.name: Intermediate Japanese I B
JAPN 321.desc: Continuation of JAPN 320. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 321 or JAPN 211 or JAPN 360.

JAPN 322.name: Intermediate Japanese II A
JAPN 322.desc: It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 or JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.
JAPN 322.prer: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

JAPN 323.name: Intermediate Japanese II B
JAPN 323.desc: A continuation of JAPN 322. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 and JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.

KIN 101.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN 101.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN 151.name: Biomechanics I
KIN 151.desc: Application of elementary principles of physics and math to a quantitative analysis of movement.  Analysis will also focus on the development of forces within muscles and their effect on initiating and controlling human movement. [3-0]

KIN 161.name: Leisure and Sport in Society
KIN 161.desc: Introduction to the political, economic and social basis of leisure and sport; concepts, theories and problems. [3-0]

KIN 190.name: Anatomy & Physiology I
KIN 190.desc: Structure and function of the neuromuscular and skeletal systems of the human body. Special emphasis on movement analysis and the physiological effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477. [2-2]

KIN 191.name: Anatomy & Physiology II
KIN 191.desc: Structure and function of the digestive, endocrine, urinary, circulatory and respiratory systems. Special emphasis on effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477. [2-2]

KIN 201.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN 201.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN 275.name: Exercise Physiology I
KIN 275.desc: Acute and chronic effects of exercise on body systems; basic concepts of cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular responses to physical activity. [2-0-2]

KIN 301.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN 301.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN 375.name: Exercise Physiology II
KIN 375.desc: Transport of oxygen during exercise in humans.  Regulation and integration of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems during exercise. [2-0-2]

KIN 401.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN 401.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN 402.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN 402.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

KIN 499.name: Projects in Kinesiology
KIN 499.desc: Provides opportunities to perform research pertaining to a chosen area of kinesiology.
KIN 499.prer: Fourth-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.)
preq: permission of the Associate Director Undergraduate Program.)

KORN 102.name: Basic Korean
KORN 102.desc: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100/101 or KORN 102.

LATN 101.name: First-Year Latin I
LATN 101.desc: Classical Latin for students with no previous knowledge of Latin, Part I.

LAW 372.name: Administrative Law
LAW 372.desc: The system of legal control exercised through non-judicial agencies and the relationship of the courts to the administrative process. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 210, LAW 372, or LAW 509.

LAW 459.name: Business Organizations
LAW 459.desc: A conceptual overview of business organizations in Canada, including partnerships and corporations, and the rights and duties of shareholders and directors. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 230, LAW 459, or LAW 508.

LAW 476.name: Evidence
LAW 476.desc: The admissibility and use of evidence in litigation. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 280, LAW 476, or LAW 507.

LAW 488.name: Clinical Term
LAW 488.desc: Designed to explore the legal system in relation to disadvantaged members of society. Under supervision, students will act for clients in a range of legal matters and can expect to appear before courts and tribunals. Students will also work with community-based organisations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 490 or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.

LAW 491.name: Law Students Legal Advice Program Credit
LAW 491.desc: Restricted to a limited number of upper year students who (a) in their first or second year have participated in the provision of legal services to the public through the Law Students Legal Advice Program, and (b) continue that participation in their second or third year. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491.

LFS 150.name: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
LFS 150.desc: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status and a Language Proficiency Index (LPI) of 4 or equivalent.

LFS 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
LFS 398.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.
LFS 398.prer: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops.
preq: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops

LFS 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
LFS 399.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

LFS 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
LFS 498.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

LFS 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
LFS 499.desc: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.

LIBE 461.name: Administration of the School Library Resource Centre
LIBE 461.desc: The role, philosophy, and management of school library resource centres in elementary and secondary schools. [3-0-0]

LLED 352.name: Introduction to Teaching and Learning French: Elementary

LLED 353.name: Teaching and Learning English as an Additional Language: Elementary

LLED 423.name: Teaching French Adolescent Literature: Secondary
LLED 423.prer: A completed concentration or major in French or permission of Department Head.

LLED 433.name: Drama in Education: Creative Approaches and Strategies
LLED 433.desc: Drama-based activities relevant to a wide range of classroom contexts; involves reading about, practicing, and discussing various creative drama approaches and strategies developed by contemporary scholars and practitioners. Pass/Fail.

LLED 434.name: Drama in Education: Cross-Curricular Learning and Story

LLED 439.name: Shakespeare in the Classroom
LLED 439.prer: LLED 314. Recommended: at least 3 credit hours of Shakespeare study at the 300- or 400-level in the Faculty of Arts.
preq: LLED 314. Recommended: at least 3 credit hours of Shakespeare study at the 300-

LLED 444.name: Transcultural Children's Literature
LLED 444.desc: Ways in which children's literature is informed by diverse, complex influences including culture(s) and language(s), and related problems, issues and controversies.

LLED 445.name: Teaching Poetry
LLED 445.desc: Instructional methodologies and theories in teaching all forms of poetry.

LLED 449.name: Teaching Adolescents Literature
LLED 449.desc: Instructional methodologies and theories in teaching literature to adolescents.

LLED 469.name: Inquiry-Based Pedagogy in School Library Programs
LLED 469.desc: Principles and practices of teachers and teacher-librarians designing and teaching curriculum using inquiry-based pedagogy. LLED 469 is a core course for the Teacher Librarian Diploma.

LLED 481.name: Digital Media in English Language Arts Education

MATH 002.name: Pre-Calculus
MATH 002.desc: Composite, inverse, polynomial, rational, trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions; sequences and series; and analytical geometry. Non-credit Math course offered by Continuing Studies in consultation with the Mathematics Department and taught by Continuing Studies instructors.
MATH 002.prer: MATH 001 or a score of 73% or higher in Principlies of Mathematics 11 or Pre-calculus 11.

MATH 100.name: Differential Calculus with Applications to Physical Sciences and Engineering
MATH 100.desc: Derivatives of elementary functions. Applications and modeling: graphing, optimization. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 100.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a score of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.
preq: higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12
a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test

MATH 101.name: Integral Calculus with Applications to Physical Sciences and Engineering
MATH 101.desc: The definite integral, integration techniques, applications, modeling, infinite series. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 101.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

MATH 104.name: Differential Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
MATH 104.desc: Derivatives and rates of change, exponential and trigonometric functions, Newton's method, Taylor polynomials, maxima and minima, and graphing. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 104.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12  or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.
preq: higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12
a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test

MATH 105.name: Integral Calculus with Applications to Commerce and Social Sciences
MATH 105.desc: Antiderivatives, the definite integral, techniques of integration, infinite series, partial derivatives, maxima and minima with constraints, discrete and continuous random variables. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 105.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

MATH 200.name: Calculus III
MATH 200.desc: Analytic geometry in 2 and 3 dimensions, partial and directional derivatives, chain rule, maxima and minima, second derivative test, Lagrange multipliers, multiple integrals with applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 200.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH 215.name: Elementary Differential Equations I
MATH 215.desc: First-order equations; linear equations; linear systems; Laplace transforms; numerical methods; trajectory analysis of plane nonlinear systems. Applications of these topics will be emphasized. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 215.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH 215.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 220.name: Mathematical Proof
MATH 220.desc: Sets and functions; induction; cardinality;  properties of the real numbers; sequences, series, and limits. Logic, structure, style, and clarity of proofs emphasized throughout. [3-0-0]
MATH 220.prer: Either (a) a score of 64% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 121, MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 221.name: Matrix Algebra
MATH 221.desc: Systems of linear equations, operations on matrices, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of symmetric matrices. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 221.prer: Either (a) a score of 64% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 or (c) advanced credit for MATH 100.

MATH 253.name: Multivariable Calculus
MATH 253.desc: Partial and directional derivatives; maxima and minima; Lagrange multipliers and second derivative test; multiple integrals and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 253.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH 255.name: Ordinary Differential Equations
MATH 255.desc: Review of linear systems; nonlinear equations and applications; phase plane analysis; Laplace transforms; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 255.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH 255.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 257.name: Partial Differential Equations
MATH 257.desc: Introduction to partial differential equations; Fourier series; the heat, wave and potential equations; boundary-value problems; numerical methods. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH 307.name: Applied Linear Algebra
MATH 307.desc: Applications of linear algebra to problems in science and engineering; use of computer algebra systems for solving problems in linear algebra. [3-0-0]
MATH 307.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 312.name: Introduction to Number Theory
MATH 312.desc: Euclidean algorithm, congruences, Fermat's theorem, applications. Some diophantine equations. Distribution of the prime numbers. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
MATH 312.prer: One of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121 and 9 additional credits of mathematics courses.

MATH 316.name: Elementary Differential Equations II
MATH 316.desc: Power series methods (ordinary and regular singular points, Bessel's equation); boundary value problems and separation of variables (Fourier series and other orthogonal series), applications to the vibrating string, heat flow, potentials. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH 317.name: Calculus IV
MATH 317.desc: Parametrizations, inverse and implicit functions, integrals with respect to length and area; grad, div, and curl, theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 317.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253. MATH 221 is recommended.

MECH 224.name: Integration of Engineering Concepts I
MECH 224.desc: Integration of the theory and practice of Mechanical Engineering to illustrate the commonality and conceptual connectivity of seemingly different technical areas. Emphasis on dynamics, solid mechanics, materials, electronics, and mathematics.

MECH 225.name: Integration of Engineering Concepts II
MECH 225.desc: Integration of the theory and practice of Mechanical Engineering to illustrate the commonality and conceptual connectivity of seemingly different technical areas. Emphasis on thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and mathematics.

MECH 227.name: Approaches to Technical Communication for Mechanical Engineers
MECH 227.desc: Written and oral communication. Preparation of design, business correspondence, verbal, online and visual presentation of technical material. Focus on the linguistic structure and style of technical communication. Restricted to students in Mechanical Engineering. Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 226 or MECH 227.
MECH 227.prer: MECH 220 and one of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

MEDD 431.name: Clerkship
MEDD 431.desc: Core experiences across the breadth of medicine through clinical and academic learning opportunities in ambulatory, hospital-based, and rural/remote settings. Interactions with patients under supervision. Pass/Fail.

MGMT 100.name: Introduction to Canadian Business
MGMT 100.desc: Introduction to the Faculty of Management and functional areas of business including accounting, economics, finance, marketing, organizational behaviour, business policy, and entrepreneurship. Steps needed to build a successful local, national, and international competitive business. Ethical and policy decisions faced by business and government.

MGMT 200.name: Personal and Corporate Social Responsibility
MGMT 200.desc: Increase awareness of a wide range of ethical challenges, test the strengths of personal moral beliefs and ethical arguments, and utilize critical thinking skills in making ethical decisions appropriate for corporate social responsibility practices.

MICB 201.name: Introductory Environmental Microbiology
MICB 201.desc: Prokaryotic diversity and the impact and applications of bacterial and archaeal metabolic, genetic, and growth processes in environmental contexts. [3-0-0]
MICB 201.prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, SCIE 001. For students with BIOL 112, CHEM 121 is recommended.

MICB 202.name: Introductory Medical Microbiology and Immunology
MICB 202.desc: Introduction to cellular and humoral immune responses, the properties of viruses and the principles of bacterial pathogenesis. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) [3-0-0]
MICB 202.prer: One of BIOL 112, BIOL 200, MICB 201, PHAR 201, SCIE 001.

MICB 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
MICB 398.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MICB 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
MICB 399.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MICB 449.name: Research Problem
MICB 449.desc: A laboratory investigation in the final year of the Honours program. The results are presented in a written report, to be reviewed by oral examination.
MICB 449.prer: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

MICB 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
MICB 498.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MICB 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
MICB 499.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Term 1) of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program of Biotechnology in Microbiology and Immunology.

MIDW 240.name: Core Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW 240.desc: Clinical education experiences with the preventative and therapeutic midwifery care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an emphasis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  A clinical practicum in locations around the provice.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW 310.name: Senior Research Project
