MIDW 310.desc: An original piece of scholarship that builds on knowledge and skills acquired from coursework and in consultation with faculty mentors.

MIDW 350.name: Inter-Professional Placement
MIDW 350.desc: Opportunities to explore health professions that partner with midwives to care for the childbearing family within the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW 370.name: Global Clinical Placement
MIDW 370.desc: Social and economic determinants of maternal and fetal health worldwide, innovative public health strategies to reducing maternal and infant mortality and morbidity, and the impact of conflict on the health of mothers and babies.  Ethical considerations related to global clinical placements and medical tourism.  A global clinical placement.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW 420.name: Advanced Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW 420.desc: Clinical education for midwifery care of pregnancy, birth, and the puerperium with an empahsis on abnormal situations in pregnancy, labour and birth, and in newborns.  Clinical practicum around the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW 440.name: Clinical Clerkship
MIDW 440.desc: Students assume a primary care role in clinical placements in midwifery practices across the provinces.  Demonstration of independent decision making and application of the full range of their academic knowledge to professional practice.  A practicum under the supervision of a registered midwife.  Pass/Fail.

MRNE 410.name: Marine Invertebrate Zoology
MRNE 410.desc: A survey of the marine phyla, with emphasis on the benthic fauna in the vicinity of the Marine Station. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.

MRNE 412.name: Biology of Fishes
MRNE 412.desc: Classification, physiology, ecology, behaviour and zoogeography of fishes with particular emphasis on those in the marine environment of the British Columbia coast.
MRNE 412.prer: A course in comparative vertebrate anatomy.
preq: A course in comparative vertebrate anatomy

NURS 333.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Childbearing Individuals and Families
NURS 333.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with childbearing individuals and families during the transition to parenthood in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
NURS 333.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS 333.crer: Either (a) one of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) one of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. (depending on sequencing of NURS 333 with other professional practice courses.)
creq: depending on sequencing of NURS 333 with other professional practice courses.

NURS 334.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Infants, Children, Youth, and their Families
NURS 334.desc: Analysis and application of theories concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with infants, children, youth, and their families through childhood and adolescence in a variety of practice setting and contexts.
NURS 334.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS 334.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 334 with other professional practice courses.
creq: NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 334 with other professional practice courses

NURS 335.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Adults Living with Mental Illness and their Families
NURS 335.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with mental illness and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts. [3-0-9]
NURS 335.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS 335.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 335 with other professional practice courses.
creq: NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 335 with other professional practice courses

NURS 336.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Communities and Populations
NURS 336.desc: Analysis and application of theories and strategies for working in partnership with populations, health professionals, and community services providers. Students use primary health care principles and population health promotion approaches during community nursing practice. [3-0-9]
NURS 336.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS 336.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 336 with other professional practice courses.
creq: NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 336 with other professional practice courses

NURS 337.name: Professional Nursing Practice with Adults, Older Adults, and their Families
NURS 337.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies guiding professional nursing practice with older adults and their families in a variety of practice settings and contexts.
NURS 337.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.
NURS 337.crer: Either (a) all of NURS 338, NURS 339, NURS 340 or (b) all of NURS 341, NURS 342, NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 337 with other professional practice courses.
creq: NURS 343. Depends on sequencing of NURS 337 with other professional practice courses

NURS 340.name: Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Health Care Practice
NURS 340.desc: Exploration and application of the interrelationship of leadership, ethics and policy in a variety of healthcare contexts.
NURS 340.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS 342.name: Critical Inquiry and Research in Nursing Practice
NURS 342.desc: Critical analysis of theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based and informed practice, and research utilization in nursing.
NURS 342.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306, NURS 339.

PATH 451.name: Clerkship in Laboratory Medicine and Infection Prevention and Control
PATH 451.desc: May involve attendance at an approved institution and/or a project assigned by the instructor(s). Instructor permission required. Enrolment may be limited.

PCTH 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
PCTH 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PCTH 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
PCTH 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PCTH 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
PCTH 498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PCTH 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
PCTH 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer after fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Pharmacology.

PHAR 403.name: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
PHAR 403.desc: Training for authorization to administer injections.

PHAR 414.name: Directed Studies in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
PHAR 414.desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of problems involved in the development of pharmaceutical dosage forms.

PHAR 444.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacology
PHAR 444.desc: Individual assignments involving library and laboratory investigation of certain aspects of drug action.

PHAR 469.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience II
PHAR 469.desc: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship focused on delivery of comprehensive patient care and disease management in community practice.
PHAR 469.prer: PHAR 369 and promotion to fourth year.

PHAR 479.name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Community
PHAR 479.desc: A 320-hour pharmacy clerkship emphasizing integration of knowledge and skills in developing and assessing therapeutic plans for patients in community practice.

PHIL 101.name: Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL 101.desc: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as the nature and scope of human knowledge, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and body. Credit will not be given for both PHIL 100 and 101.

PHIL 102.name: Introduction to Philosophy II
PHIL 102.desc: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will not be given for both PHIL 100 and 102.

PHIL 120.name: Introduction to Critical Thinking
PHIL 120.desc: Tools for dealing with both everyday and more technical arguments and concepts. Analysis and resolution of confusions, ambiguities, and fallacies. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

PHIL 220.name: Symbolic Logic
PHIL 220.desc: Sentential and predicate logic. Translation from natural language; truth tables and interpretations; systems of natural deduction up to relational predicate logic with identity; alternative proof methods. Some sections may use computer-based materials and tests.

PHIL 230.name: Introduction to Ethics
PHIL 230.desc: Theories of obligation and value; moral reasoning; normative ethics, descriptive ethics and meta-ethics. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL 331.name: Business and Professional Ethics
PHIL 331.desc: Moral problems in contemporary business and professional practice, general moral theory, the law, and policy formation. Corporate social and environmental responsibility, employee rights, preferential hiring and affirmative action programs, conflicts of interest, advertising, "whistle blowing" and self-regulation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 331 or PHIL 434.

PHIL 333.name: Bio-Medical Ethics
PHIL 333.desc: Moral problems arising in the health sciences, especially in medicine but also in biology, psychology, and social work. Topics include abortion, death and euthanasia, genetic engineering, behaviour modification, compulsory treatment, experimentation with human beings and animals, and the relationship between professionals and their patients, subjects or clients. No philosophical background is required. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 333 or PHIL 433.

PHIL 338.name: Philosophy of Law
PHIL 338.desc: Concepts of law, constitution and sovereignty; law and morality; natural law theories and legal positivism; obligation, responsibility, and punishment.
PHIL 338.prer: Restricted to second- or higher-year standing.

PHIL 375.name: Philosophy and Literature
PHIL 375.desc: Philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions.

PHRM 171.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient I
PHRM 171.desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 271.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient II
PHRM 271.desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world outpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 272.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Inpatient
PHRM 272.desc: Prescription processing, drug distribution systems, and select patient care activities in real world inpatient environments. Focus on direct patient care activities. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 361.name: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
PHRM 361.desc: Training for authorization to administer injections

PHYS 100.name: Introductory Physics
PHYS 100.desc: An introduction to fundamental concepts such as force, energy, momentum, and the use of graphs and vectors in physics; geometrical optics; electricity; laboratory exercises to familiarize the student with both the phenomena and the basic laboratory instruments commonly used to measure them. Students with credit for Physics 12 may not obtain credit for this course unless they took AP, IB, or A-level Physics and were offered advanced credit for PHYS 100. [3-3*-1*]
PHYS 100.prer: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.
preq: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. Principles of Mathematics 12
Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students

PHYS 101.name: Energy and Waves
PHYS 101.desc: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, including diffraction.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-3*-1*]
PHYS 101.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 118.name: Electricity, Light and Radiation
PHYS 118.desc: Optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS 118.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS 118.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS 250.name: Introduction to Modern Physics
PHYS 250.desc: Wave-particle duality of matter, special relativity, processes in atomic, nuclear and solid state, and introduction to quantum mechanical devices and techniques. [3-0-1]
PHYS 250.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

PHYS 298.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
PHYS 298.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 299.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
PHYS 299.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
PHYS 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
PHYS 498.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

PHYS 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
PHYS 499.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

POLI 100.name: Introduction to Politics
POLI 100.desc: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

POLI 101.name: The Government of Canada
POLI 101.desc: An examination of the institutions and processes of Canadian government.

POLI 110.name: Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis
POLI 110.desc: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.

POLI 240.name: Currents of Political Thought
POLI 240.desc: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life.

POLI 260.name: Introduction to Global Politics
POLI 260.desc: Applies conceptual tools to topics such as war, conflict management, the global economy, poverty, and civil society.
POLI 260.prer: Recommended for prospective students of POLI 360-373.
preq: Recommended for prospective students of POLI 360-373

POLI 326.name: European Politics: Selected Cases
POLI 326.desc: The politics and government of one or more European countries: political development, institutional structure, party politics, and policy-making. The specific country or countries will vary by section.

POLI 373.name: Ethics in World Politics
POLI 373.desc: When is it right to wage war?  Who should pay for global warming?  Should the wealthy provide foreign aid- how much?  Analysis of traditions of moral thought to reach reasoned judgments about such dilemmas in global politics.

PORT 101.name: First-Year Portuguese I
PORT 101.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 101 or PORT 110.

PSYC 101.name: Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology
PSYC 101.desc: Introduction to Methods and Statistics, Biopsychology, Learning, Perception, Memory, and Cognition. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 100 and PSYC 101.

PSYC 102.name: Introduction to Developmental, Social, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
PSYC 102.desc: Introduction to methods and statistics, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 100 and PSYC 102.

PSYC 217.name: Research Methods
PSYC 217.desc: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design.  Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts who have declared their major in one of Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences (Linguistics Department).
PSYC 217.crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC 218.name: Analysis of Behavioural Data
PSYC 218.desc: Use of inferential statistics in psychology and conceptual interpretation of data; experimental design (laboratory, field research methods); presentation of data analyses in reports. PSYC 218 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.
PSYC 218.prer: PSYC 217. And a major in Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences.
PSYC 218.crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC 311.name: Psychology of Sport
PSYC 311.desc: Psychological theory, research, and skills training related to sport performance, exercise motivation, and adherence. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 311 and HKIN 231 and 364.
PSYC 311.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC 314.name: Health Psychology
PSYC 314.desc: Health-related behaviours such as smoking and drug use; effects of stressful events on health; methods for coping with stress; impact of chronic illness on the family; social support systems.
PSYC 314.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 315.name: Childhood and Adolescence
PSYC 315.desc: Human development from the preschool period through adolescence.
PSYC 315.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 322.name: Adulthood and Aging
PSYC 322.desc: Issues, theories, and psychological research regarding adulthood and the aging process.
PSYC 322.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or  (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 333.name: Memory: Historical, Clinical and Cognitive Perspectives
PSYC 333.desc: Classical and contemporary metaphors for memory and their impact on theory development.
PSYC 333.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263). Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 460 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.

PSYC 398.name: Cooperative Work Placement I
PSYC 398.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in Summer Session after third year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC 399.name: Cooperative Work Placement II
PSYC 399.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 1. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC 498.name: Cooperative Work Placement III
PSYC 498.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 2. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

PSYC 499.name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
PSYC 499.desc: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full time. Normally taken in Summer Session after fourth year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

RUSS 101.name: Basic Russian I
RUSS 101.desc: Introduction to contemporary Russian with emphasis on specialized vocabulary for science, commerce, law, etc. Oral practice, grammar, reading and writing. Note: Students who intend to use RUSS 101, 102 and 200 to satisfy the Faculty of Arts language requirement must register for both RUSS 101 and 102 in the same year.

SANS 400.name: Intermediate Sanskrit
SANS 400.desc: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402.

SCAN 336.name: Scandinavian Crime Fiction (in English)
SCAN 336.desc: Crime fictions and films as a mirror of Scandinavian society.

SOCI 100.name: Introduction to Sociology
SOCI 100.desc: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

SOCI 102.name: Inequality and Social Change
SOCI 102.desc: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

SOCI 200.name: Sociology of Family
SOCI 200.desc: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

SOCI 217.name: Research Methods
SOCI 217.desc: Introduction to research designs and methodologies.
SOCI 217.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 312.name: Gender Relations
SOCI 312.desc: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality.

SOCI 320.name: Diversity in Family Forms
SOCI 320.desc: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms.
SOCI 320.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 328.name: Social Statistics I
SOCI 328.desc: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.

SOCI 371.name: Classical Traditions in Theory
SOCI 371.desc: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370.

SOCI 380.name: Sociological Methods: Survey Research
SOCI 380.desc: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data.
SOCI 380.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217 and SOCI 328.

SPAN 101.name: Beginners' Spanish I
SPAN 101.desc: Fundamentals of the Spanish language; speaking and writing on everyday activities and future plans in the context of common tasks and situations, including interactive communication, grammatical explanations, and cultural awareness.

SPAN 102.name: Beginners' Spanish II
SPAN 102.desc: Speaking and writing on past events, and expressing desires and wishes in the context of common situations, including interactive communication, grammatical explanations, and cultural awareness.

SPAN 201.name: Intermediate Spanish I
SPAN 201.desc: Reviews the fundamentals of the Spanish language, and introduces more complex structures; listening, speaking, writing, and reading on a range of situations related to everyday life and Hispanic culture.

SPAN 202.name: Intermediate Spanish II
SPAN 202.desc: Expands on the fundamentals of the Spanish language, and presents more complex structures in a variety of tenses and modes; interacting through discussions and gaining cultural awareness through literature and film.

SPPH 200.name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
SPPH 200.desc: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200. [3-0-0]

STAT 200.name: Elementary Statistics for Applications
STAT 200.desc: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-1-0]
STAT 200.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT 241.name: Introductory Probability and Statistics
STAT 241.desc: Probability models, random variables and vectors, estimation, testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit, quality control. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar). [3-1-0]
STAT 241.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT 251.name: Elementary Statistics
STAT 251.desc: Probability, discrete and continuous random variables, joint probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar). [3-1-0]
STAT 251.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

STAT 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
STAT 398.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Winter Session of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.
STAT 398.prer: Registration in Statistics Honours or Major Program.

STAT 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
STAT 399.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

STAT 498.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
STAT 498.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Summer Session following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

STAT 499.name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
STAT 499.desc: Work experience in an industrial research setting. Normally taken during Term 1 of Winter Session of fifth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Statistics.

SURG 430.name: Surgery
SURG 430.desc: Post-operative care of patients, evaluation of pre-operative patients, mastery of technical skills for common ward procedures, assessing ambulatory patients and assisting in the operating room.

VANT 149.name: Multidisciplinary Research Project
VANT 149.desc: Research project that culminates in student-led conference and research presentation. [1-0-1]

VANT 151.name: Multidisciplinary Engineering Design Project
VANT 151.desc: Design project that culminates in student-led project fair. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-1]

WOOD 300.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
WOOD 300.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing who have complete the co-op orientation workshops.

WOOD 305.name: Wood Machining Skills
WOOD 305.desc: Safe working procedures for wood processing machinery, explanation of various manufacturing equipment, product documentation, product development and manufacturing processes.

WOOD 312.name: Co-operative Work Placement III
WOOD 312.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 353.name: Mill Site Visits
WOOD 353.desc: One week of on-site study of forest products manufacturing plants immediately following Spring examinations of second or third year. Representative sawmills, plywood mills, remanufacturing plants, particleboard manufacturers, pulp mills, laminated timber plants and wood preservation facilities in the Interior are studied. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.

WOOD 400.name: Co-operative Work Placement
WOOD 400.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks fulltime.  Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 411.name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
WOOD 411.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 493.name: Project in Program Major
WOOD 493.desc: A report (approved by a faculty supervisor and the Program Director) based on either a technical description of a study, an extension of the senior co-op report, a detailed literature review, a research-based project, or a guided independent study developed by the student.

WRDS 150.name: Research and Writing in the Humanities and Social Sciences
WRDS 150.desc: Writing and reading in the social sciences and humanities, focusing on practices which the research disciplines share, and those which differentiate them. Credit will be granted for only one of WRDS 150 or ASTU 150.

WRIT 098.name: Preparation for University Writing and the LPI

ACAM 350.name: Asian Canadian Community-Based Media
ACAM 350.desc: Digital media production in the context of community engagement. Includes critical media literacy, community-based research ethics, project design, training in media forms such audio, video, photography, and web publishing.

ANAT 392.name: Gross Anatomy of the Limbs and Trunk
ANAT 392.desc: Lectures and laboratory sessions on the human gross and functional anatomy of the limbs and trunk. The course includes the study of predissected specimens. For credit only in the Department of Physical Therapy.

ANTH 210.name: Eating Culture
ANTH 210.desc: An anthropological exploration of how the collection, cultivation and consumption of food shapes human society and culture.

ANTH 213.name: Sex, Gender, and Culture
ANTH 213.desc: An anthropological exploration of how understandings of sex and gender are culturally and historically shaped.

ANTH 215.name: Japanese Popular Culture
ANTH 215.desc: Television shows, dramas, movies, advertising, marketing, manga (Japanese style "comics"), anime (Japanese animation), theatrical forms, popular literature, popular music, fashion fads, tourism, toys, and sports.

ANTH 217.name: Culture and Communication
ANTH 217.desc: The study of communication; the relation between communication and its cultural context with emphasis on verbal and non-verbal communication, cross-cultural communication, and cultural differences in the use of oral, literate, and electronic media.

ANTH 220.name: First Nations of British Columbia
ANTH 220.desc: The cultures, languages, and resources of First Nations, with anthropological perspectives on colonization and development.

ANTH 241.name: Introduction to Museums and Museology
ANTH 241.desc: The critical study of anthropology museums as social institutions and material culture research and classification from the late 19th century to the present day.

ANTH 301.name: Ethnography of Eurasia
ANTH 301.desc: Eurasia, including the Russian Federation, Central Asia, and Mongolia, with an emphasis on issues of power, identities, and transnational mobility in the region.

ANTH 302.name: Ethnography of South Asia
ANTH 302.desc: A specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems relating to South Asia.

ANTH 312.name: Introduction to the Anthropology of Gender
ANTH 312.desc: Theoretical approaches to, and the ethnographic study of, gender in cross-cultural contexts.

ANTH 315.name: Japanese Culture and Society
ANTH 315.desc: Japanese culture and society: patterns of organization, value systems, family, education, work, minorities and diversity, harmony and conflict, urban/rural differences, gender, sexuality, youth, tradition, continuity, change, and future prospects.

ANTH 332.name: Oral Tradition
ANTH 332.desc: An ethnographic perspective on the dynamics of oral tradition in various oral and literate cultures; the characteristics and roles of oral genres including folktale, genealogy, oral history, autobiography, and myth in these societies; and the relationship between orality and literacy.

ANTH 360.name: Introduction to Ecological Anthropology
ANTH 360.desc: Analysis of the relations between human societies and the ecological aspects of their environment (including technology, society, and ideology).  Previously ANTH 460.

ANTH 401.name: First Peoples of North America
ANTH 401.desc: Anthropological perspectives of indigenous cultures and societies of North America.

ANTH 407.name: Principles of Field Work
ANTH 407.desc: An examination of field work as the basic setting for ethnographic research. Research design; relationships with study participants, field techniques, and data analysis and presentation.

ANTH 418.name: Anthropological Statistics
ANTH 418.desc: Applications of statistical techniques to quantitative and qualitative data in Anthropology.

ANTH 428.name: Medicine, Technology, Culture, and Society
ANTH 428.desc: A medical anthropological perspective on medical science, technology, translational research, and clinical practice, in laboratory, clinic, family, social, and cultural contexts. Topics include explanatory models of health, acute and chronic illness, disability; social and cultural dimensions genetics; clinical interaction.

ANTH 429.name: Global Health in Cross-Cultural Contexts
ANTH 429.desc: Includes examination of the social and cultural dimensions of specific life-threatening emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, the political economy of health, cultural interpretations of illness and healing, medical pluralism, therapy management, and the cultural construction of efficacy.

ANTH 451.name: Conservation of Organic Materials
ANTH 451.desc: Conservation of organic materials within a museum environment; the nature of materials, mechanisms of deterioration and principles of preventive conservation. Recommended for students intending to work with cultural materials.

ANTH 471.name: Anthropology of Law
ANTH 471.desc: Cross-cultural study of the operation of law within contested systems of meaning, the social organization of law, and forms of consciousness of the participants in legal/justice practices.

APBI 210.name: Vascular Plants
APBI 210.desc: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function, and ecology. [3-3]
APBI 210.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. Or (c) 7 credits of first-year biology.

APBI 222.name: Introduction to Horticulture
APBI 222.desc: The cultivation of key temperate fruits, vegetables, greenhouse, ornamental and nursery crops in BC, integrated with scientific and practical aspects of their sustainable production and marketing.

APBI 244.name: Introduction to Biometeorology
APBI 244.desc: Basic principles and processes of climatology. Energy and water balance concepts. Weather systems and climate change, microclimate of soils, crops, forests, and animals. [3-2-0]

APBI 260.name: Agroecology I
APBI 260.desc: Introduction to the biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems. [1-3-6]

APBI 265.name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
APBI 265.desc: Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Credit will be given for only one of APBI 265 or APBI 260. [1-3-0]

APBI 290.name: Introductory Topics in Applied Biology
APBI 290.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology. Topics will vary from year to year.

APBI 311.name: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
APBI 311.desc: Cardiovascular, respiratory and osmoregulatory physiology of vertebrates. [1-0-3]
APBI 311.prer: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361. And 3rd year standing.

APBI 312.name: Reproductive and Digestive Physiology
APBI 312.desc: Reproductive and digestive physiology, and current technologies applied to these systems in domestic and wild animals.
APBI 312.prer: One of BIOL 204, BIOL 260. 3rd year standing.

APBI 318.name: Applied Plant Breeding
APBI 318.desc: Small-scale classical (i.e., non-biotechnological) plant breeding. Hands-on, application-oriented approach to techniques and procedures for managing seed inventories, designing and implementing a simple plant breeding program, and evaluating the impact of selection on breeding populations and desired outcomes. [3-1-0]

APBI 319.name: Aquaculture and the Environment
APBI 319.desc: Interactions between aquaculture and the environment. Current issues, comparison of systems, species, production methods, environments, and socioeconomics.
APBI 319.prer: One of BIOL 230, APBI 260, APBI 265, CONS 330, ENVR 200, ENVR 300 and third year standing. Or permission of the instructor.
preq: third year standing. Or permission of the instructor

APBI 322.name: Horticultural Techniques
APBI 322.desc: An introduction to horticultural practice in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, pruning, cultivation media, pesticide application and safety are examined in the context of integrated crop management. An additional fee may be required for the pesticide certification examination. [0-3-3]

APBI 324.name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
APBI 324.desc: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection. [2-3-0]

APBI 327.name: Introduction to Entomology
APBI 327.desc: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology and life-histories of insects; insect-plant relations. [2-3-0]

APBI 342.name: Soil Biology
APBI 342.desc: The diversity of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; interactions between soil organisms; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0]

APBI 351.name: Plant Physiology
APBI 351.desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. [3-3-0]
APBI 351.prer: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. CHEM 233 is recommended.

APBI 360.name: Agroecology II
APBI 360.desc: Animals and Plants as Components of Agricultural Ecosystems. A systems approach is used to investigate the functions and interactions of plants and animals in agricultural systems. Field trips for assessment of existing agroecosystems. [3-0-3]

APBI 361.name: Key Indicators of Agroecosystem Sustainability
APBI 361.desc: A detailed exploration of biophysical, economic, and social ecosystem sustainability indicators for primary production subsystems. [1-0-3]

APBI 398.name: Research Methods in Applied Biology
APBI 398.desc: Research methods including research design, scientific critique, writing proposals and reports, and oral presentation.
APBI 398.prer: Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program and permission of the instructor.
preq: Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program

APBI 401.name: Soil Processes
APBI 401.desc: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes. [3-0-0]

APBI 402.name: Sustainable Soil Management
APBI 402.desc: Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. [1-0-3]

APBI 403.name: Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
APBI 403.desc: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403. [1-3-0]

APBI 410.name: Applied Animal Health and Physiology
APBI 410.desc: Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals. [3-0-0]
APBI 410.prer: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

APBI 412.name: Belowground Ecosystems
APBI 412.desc: Concepts, methods, and applications of belowground ecology with emphasis on biotic interactions in soil; roles that aboveground and belowground communities play in regulating the structure and function of terrestrial ecosystems and their responses to global change. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 512 or APBI 412. [3-0-0]
APBI 412.prer: Fourth year standing in a Bachelor of Science Program. Permission is required for registration.
preq: Fourth year standing in a Bachelor of Science Program. Permission is required for registration

APBI 413.name: Stress and Coping in Animals
APBI 413.desc: Understanding, assessing, and managing stress in farm, companion, captive wildlife, and research animals: sources of stress; behavioural, emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses; effects on growth, reproduction, health.
APBI 413.prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and courses in animal physiology and animal behavior recommended.

APBI 414.name: Animals and Global Issues
APBI 414.desc: Research seminar integrating diverse information to address global animal issues including: animal-source foods and human health, environmental impact of livestock production, trade in exotic animals. [3-0-0]

APBI 415.name: Applied Animal Behaviour
APBI 415.desc: Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict. [3-0-0]

APBI 416.name: Animal Welfare and Conservation Biology
APBI 416.desc: Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
APBI 416.prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 220/330 recommended.

APBI 417.name: Production and Postharvest Physiology of Vegetable Crops
APBI 417.desc: Morphology, growth and development, production, compostition, quality, and postharvest physiology of vegetable crops. [3-2-0]

APBI 418.name: Intensive Fish Production
APBI 418.desc: Management of fin fish throughout the life cycle; broodstock, egg, larvae, and juvenile. Control of environmental factors, including pathogens, for maximum productivity at all life stages. [3-2-0]
APBI 418.prer: Third-year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 recommended.

APBI 419.name: Fish Health
APBI 419.desc: Management of fish health in aquaculture; common fish pathogens, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of diseases.
APBI 419.prer: Third year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 and  APBI 418 strongly recommended.

APBI 426.name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
APBI 426.desc: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society. [3-2-0]

APBI 440.name: Plant Genomics
APBI 440.desc: Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology. [3-0-0]

APBI 442.name: Wine Grape and Berry Biology
APBI 442.desc: Grapevine genetics, morphology, and physiology and major biological features of other important berry crops for British Columbia such as blueberry, cranberry, and raspberry. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 442 or PLNT 542.
APBI 442.prer: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, APBI 210, BIOL 210.

APBI 444.name: Agroforestry
APBI 444.desc: An introduction to the application of knowledge and principles of agroecology and forest ecology to global agroforestry systems. The course includes a one-weekend field trip that requires a supplemental fee. [1-0-3]
APBI 444.prer: An undergraduate course in ecology or equivalent.

APBI 460.name: Advanced Agroecology
APBI 460.desc: The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability for the management of agroecosystems; emphasise on ecological interactions between natural ecosystems and agroecosystems, including connections between agroecology and conservation biology. A fee will be assessed each student to cover field trip costs. [1-0-3]

APBI 495.name: Principles of Wildlife Management in Forests and Agricultural Environments
APBI 495.desc: Impacts of wildlife on crop productivity in temperate and tropical environments, the resiliency of wildlife populations to conventional control methodology, adoption of innovative methods to reduce crop damage, and the impact of introduced species on native fauna. [2-0-1]

APSC 100.name: Introduction to Engineering I
APSC 100.desc: An introduction to the engineering profession including: roles and responsibilities of the engineer, the engineering disciplines, sustainability, an introduction to the engineering design process, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, prototyping, engineering graphics, technical communication, and engineering ethics.

APSC 101.name: Introduction to Engineering II
APSC 101.desc: An introduction to the engineering profession including: the engineering design process, sustainability, prototype testing, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, team functioning, engineering graphics, and technical communication.

APSC 172.name: Engineering Analysis I
APSC 172.desc: Functions, limits, differentiation, applications of derivatives, integration, applications of definite integrals.

APSC 173.name: Engineering Analysis II
APSC 173.desc: Integrals and transcendental functions, techniques of integration, applications of integration, polar coordinates, infinite sequences and series, vectors and the geometry of space, and partial derivatives.

APSC 178.name: Electricity, Magnetism, and Waves
APSC 178.desc: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, electric potential, conductors, capacitance, electric currents, resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields and forces, sources of magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction, mechanical waves, electromagnetic waves, light propagation, geometrical optics.

APSC 182.name: Matter and Energy I
APSC 182.desc: Thermometry, states of matter and phase change, ideal and real gases, 1st law of thermodynamics, 2nd law of thermodynamics, liquids, solutions.

APSC 183.name: Matter and Energy II
APSC 183.desc: Atomic structures and bonding, solid crystals, chemical equilibrium, reactions in gas phase and in aqueous solutions, acid-base and redox reactions, kinetics of chemical reactions, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.

APSC 261.name: Technology and Society I
APSC 261.desc: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic, and environmental aspects of society. The specific subject matter varies from year to year. Examples of subjects considered include, resources, energy, nuclear power, technology, the effects of technology on the family, education, agriculture, international policy and others. [3-0-0]

APSC 262.name: Technology and Society II
APSC 262.desc: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic and environmental aspects of society. The subject matter varies from year to year and differs from APSC 261. It may be taken as a continuation of APSC 261 or taken independently. Examples of subjects considered include pollution, work place health hazards, social impact of computers, problem solving, green revolution, technology and the third world, engineering ethics and others.

APSC 278.name: Engineering Materials
APSC 278.desc: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

APSC 279.name: Engineering Materials Laboratory
APSC 279.desc: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

APSC 366.name: The Art of the Possible: An Introduction to Engineering for Non-Engineers
APSC 366.desc: An introduction to engineering for the non-specialist. A case-studies approach includes examples from sustainability-related technology, consumer products, structures, and energy conversion. [3-0-0]

APSC 377.name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
APSC 377.desc: The evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
APSC 377.prer: Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. programs, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program.

APSC 440.name: Management Fundamentals for Technology-Based Product Marketing and Development
APSC 440.desc: Management topics are presented from the perspective of technology-based industrial practice; project management, marketing and marketing planning, product development and commercialization, introduction to quality management, teamwork and effective individual participation.

APSC 450.name: Professional Engineering Practice
APSC 450.desc: Legislation affecting the practice of engineering; ethical principles and responsibilities. Management of engineering enterprises; labour relations, safety and environmental legislation. Restricted to engineering undergraduate students in the final year of their program.

APSC 486.name: New Venture Design
APSC 486.desc: Teams comprising students in APSC 486 and COMM 486 create a business plan and a prototype or engineering solution of a novel product, process, or process component.

ARBC 101.name: Introduction to the Grammar and Vocabulary of Classic Arabic

ARBC 102.name: Introduction to the Grammar and Vocabulary of Classic Arabic II

ARBC 201.name: Classical Arabic (Intermediate) I
ARBC 201.desc: Increased reading ability as well as learning the further essentials of grammar.

ARBC 202.name: Classical Arabic (Intermediate) II
ARBC 202.desc: Increased reading ability as well as learning the further essentials of grammar. Continuation of ARBC 201.

ARCH 403.name: Themes in Architecture and Design
ARCH 403.desc: Introduction to a broad range of themes in architecture and design. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

ARCH 404.name: Architectural History I
ARCH 404.desc: Architecture from 1400 to 1900 and the design theory and practice that have shaped it.  Restricted to B.En.D. students.  Credit will be given for only one of  ARCH 405 or ARCH 505.

ARCH 405.name: Architectural History II
ARCH 405.desc: Critical analysis of developments in modern and contemporary architectural thought and practice.   Restricted to B.En.D. students. Credit will be given for only one of ARCH 405 or ARCH 505.

ARCH 411.name: Materials and Methods of Construction
ARCH 411.desc: An investigation of building materials and systems considering design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. The major building systems of light wood frame, steel, and concrete and the technical and expressive opportunities inherent in each.  Restricted to B.En.D. students.

ARCH 437.name: Geometric Modeling
ARCH 437.desc: Advanced modeling, rendering and image processing applications; the construction of geometric models, their viewing transformations, light and material attributes; mapping and rendering are introduced. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

ARCL 103.name: Introduction to Archaeology
ARCL 103.desc: Survey of world archaeology, from the emergence of humankind to the beginning of state societies.

ARCL 203.name: Archaeological Methods
ARCL 203.desc: Introduces the methods and principles applied in anthropological archaeology and cultural-historical research.

ARCL 204.name: Great Archaeological Discoveries
ARCL 204.desc: An examination of some momentous discoveries in archaeology that have shaped our knowledge of the ancient world and the history of humanity.

ARCL 231.name: Ancient North America
ARCL 231.desc: Introductory survey of North American archaeology comparing the ancient cultures from all major regions of Canada and the US.

ARCL 305.name: Archaeological Interpretation
ARCL 305.desc: Current theoretical developments explored through the practice of archaeology. Examples drawn from a range of times and places focusing on emerging technologies, food production, colonial encounters and culture contact, materiality and symbolic systems, social inequality and complexity, and human-environmental interactions.

ARCL 309.name: The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
ARCL 309.desc: An evaluation of the issues of sustainability and collapse of ecological and social systems through the archaeological study of the past.

ARCL 318.name: Archaeology of Hunter-Gatherer-Forager-Societies
ARCL 318.desc: Early hunter-gatherer-forager societies, spanning the period from the emergence of the first tool-using hominins to the origins of agriculture.

ARCL 326.name: Primatology
ARCL 326.desc: A comprehensive survey of primates, with emphasis on evolution, ecology, social organization,  social behaviour, and field studies.

ARCL 405.name: Archaeological and Anthropological Mapping
ARCL 405.desc: Current methods in mapping spatial information in archaeology and related subfields of anthropology.

ARCL 419.name: The Archaeology of Death
ARCL 419.desc: A survey of methods, theory, and case-studies in mortuary archaeology.

ARCL 424.name: Practicing Archaeology and the Management of Cultural Resources
ARCL 424.desc: Survey of the use of archaeology in the public context and interest, particularly the identification, evaluation, conservation, and management of archaeological resources.  Laws and policies, principles, methods, and ethical concerns guiding current practices, public involvement, relationships with indigenous communities, and contemporary issues in cultural resources management.

ARCL 425.name: Nutritional Archaeology
ARCL 425.desc: The archaeological evidence for the change of human diets over time and the methods used to reconstruct past diets.

ARTH 101.name: Ways of Seeing: Introduction to Visual Studies
ARTH 101.desc: Drawing on examples from across history and around the world, this course deals with the role of the visual in society, culture, and everyday experience.

ARTH 102.name: Crisis and Contradiction in Art and the Built Environment
ARTH 102.desc: Concepts and issues critical to the understanding of art and its histories in a global context.

ARTH 225.name: Art in Europe to the Sixteenth Century
ARTH 225.desc: A selective survey of painting, sculpture, and architecture.

ARTH 226.name: Art in an Era of Global Expansion
ARTH 226.desc: A selective survey of painting, sculpture, and architecture from the 16th century to the emergence of the modern era.

ARTH 227.name: Art and the Visual Environment in the Modern and Post-modern Periods
ARTH 227.desc: A selective survey of visual art, architecture and other visual media since 1900.

ARTH 253.name: Asian Architecture: Sacred and Urban Spaces
ARTH 253.desc: Select built forms in Asia, such as temples, tombs, palaces, cities and gardens, and their relations to cultural, social and political systems.

ARTH 300.name: Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History
ARTH 300.desc: Theories, problems, and literature in the study of art history. Required of all Major and Honours students in art history.

ARTH 311.name: Art in the Early Medieval West
ARTH 311.desc: From pagan adornment to Christian devotion to service of Christian or Islamic rule (AD 500 - 1000). Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 311 or ARTH 331.

ARTH 321.name: Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1350-1550)
ARTH 321.desc: Visual art and culture within the social, political, and religious contexts of the Papacy and the city-states.

ARTH 338.name: Visual Culture in the Age of Enlightenment and Revolution (1715-1830)
ARTH 338.desc: Art, architecture, and social space in Europe and America: redefining gender, identity and nation in the era of industrialization and political change.

ARTH 339.name: 19th-Century Art and Social Space
ARTH 339.desc: Ideologies of gender, class, race, ethnicity, and economics in 19th-century European and American visual culture.

ARTH 340.name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Triumph and Demise of Modernism
ARTH 340.desc: A critical survey of western art and cultural production from the turn of the century to the development of Pop Art.

ARTH 341.name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern
ARTH 341.desc: A critical examination of international visual art and culture from the 1950s to the present;  the role of art in consumerist society and the emergence of postmodernism.

ARTH 344.name: Art and Photography in Canada, 1920 to the Present
ARTH 344.desc: Art movements and art institutions from the landscape paintings of the Group of Seven to the photo-conceptualist practices of the Vancouver school.

ARTH 345.name: History of Photography: Archive, Spectacle, Reality
ARTH 345.desc: History and theory of photography, from the competitive context of invention in the 1830s to contemporary uses in social media.

ARTH 352.name: Historic India:  Images, Temples and the Construction of Indian Art History
ARTH 352.desc: North and South Indian art and architecture with an emphasis on Buddhism and Hinduism.

ARTH 353.name: Nepal and Tibet:  Art, Ritual and Performance
ARTH 353.desc: Art of the Himalayan region situated within social and religious practices, festivals, and performances.

ARTH 358.name: Chinese Art for the Afterlife
ARTH 358.desc: Close analyses of Chinese tomb objects and tombs as spatial constructs in their historical, ritual, and social context.

ARTH 363.name: Art in Japan: The Problem with Painting
ARTH 363.desc: Key debates in the history of painting and its institutionalization.

ARTH 368.name: Art in Japan: Print Media
ARTH 368.desc: Historical and theoretical questions concerning the development of print media in Japan, from Edo period woodcuts to the advent of digital technologies.

ARTH 377.name: Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The South
ARTH 377.desc: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Southern  Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

ARTH 380.name: Art as Technology
ARTH 380.desc: Relationship between artistic practice and media, examined through a history of paradigm shifts in technology.

ARTH 432.name: Seminar in the Art of the Middle Ages

ARTH 455.name: Seminar in the Art of South Asia

ARTH 479.name: Performance Actions and Approaches
ARTH 479.desc: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

ARTH 480.name: Visual and Digital Media Theory
ARTH 480.desc: A thematic examination of key arguments in visual and digital media theory, focusing on developments in lens-based and digital media in relationship to twentieth-century and contemporary artistic practice.

ASIC 200.name: Global Issues in the Arts and Sciences
ASIC 200.desc: Selected global issues explored through the methodologies and perspectives of both the physical and life sciences and the humanities and social sciences. [3-0-0]
ASIC 200.prer: Second year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Faculty of Science.
preq: Second year standing in the Faculty of Arts

ASIC 220.name: Introduction to Sustainability
ASIC 220.desc: Sustainability examined from scientific, economic, and societal perspectives. [3-0-0]

ASTR 101.name: Introduction to the Solar System
ASTR 101.desc: General principles of the celestial sphere, laws of motion and light, optics, and telescopes; current knowledge of the Sun and Solar System. [3-2*-0]
ASTR 101.prer: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. plus Principles of Mathematics 12.

ASTR 102.name: Introduction to Stars and Galaxies
ASTR 102.desc: Modern stellar and extragalactic astronomy. Stars and stellar evolution from protostars to black holes; galaxies and quasars; cosmology. ASTR 200/205 rather than ASTR 102 are recommended for students who intend to pursue studies in Astronomy. [3-2*-0]
ASTR 102.prer: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. plus Principles of Mathematics 12.

ASTR 200.name: Frontiers of Astrophysics
ASTR 200.desc: Stellar masses and evolution. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Extrasolar planet formation and detection. Dark matter in the Milky Way and other galaxies. Cosmological observations and principles. [3-0-0]
ASTR 200.prer: Either (a) one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

ASTR 205.name: Stars and Stellar Populations
ASTR 205.desc: Measurement of positions, motions, and distances in astronomy.  Temperature, masses, and spectra of stars.  Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.  Quantitative stellar structure and evolution.  Chemical composition of stars in different Galactic populations. Globular and open star clusters. [3-0-0]
ASTR 205.prer: ASTR 200 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

ASTR 300.name: Galaxies
ASTR 300.desc: Structure and kinematics of our galaxy. Spiral arms and dynamics of stars in spiral and elliptical galaxies. Galactic formation, evolution, dynamics, and groups. Active galaxies and quasars.
ASTR 300.prer: ASTR 205 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

ASTR 310.name: Exploring the Universe: The Solar System
ASTR 310.desc: A survey of recent discoveries about the planets and other objects in the solar system, without the use of advanced mathematics. The Sun, the existence of planetary systems around other stars, and the search for life. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-1*]

ASTR 333.name: Exoplanets and Astrobiology
ASTR 333.desc: Observations and basic characteristics of extrasolar planets, including their formation, evolution, and potential for supporting life. Not to be used to satisfy any Physics and Astronomy major or honours specialization requirement, but may be used as an upper-level science elective. [3-0-0]
ASTR 333.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, BIOL 300.

ASTR 349.name: Directed Research Project in Astronomy
ASTR 349.desc: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report.  Requires approval of the course instructor and program advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. [1*-6-0]

ASTR 403.name: Cosmology
ASTR 403.desc: Introduction to the study of the Universe as a whole. Foundations of the Hot Big Bang model, the early Universe, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure, galaxy formation and quasars. [3-0-0]
ASTR 403.prer: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. ASTR 300 is recommended.

ASTR 404.name: Astronomical and Astrophysical Measurements
ASTR 404.desc: Astronomical instrumentation and techniques for ground and space-based observations. Theory of measurement, imaging, interferometry and spectroscopy of electromagnetic radiation at optical, radio, infrared, and X-ray wavelengths. Astronomical data analysis. [3-0-0]
ASTR 404.prer: All of PHYS 210, PHYS 408 and one of PHYS 312, MATH 316.

ASTR 405.name: Astronomical Laboratory
ASTR 405.desc: Experiments in the use of astronomical instrumentation and data analysis. Use of the 40-cm reflector, spectrograph and electronic detectors. Photometric and spectroscopic analysis of digital data. [0-0-3]

ASTR 406.name: High-Energy Astrophysics
ASTR 406.desc: Radiative processes. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Accreting systems. Gamma-ray bursts. [3-0-0]
ASTR 406.prer: All of PHYS 203, PHYS 301, MATH 215 and ASTR 300.

ASTR 407.name: Planetary Science
ASTR 407.desc: Structure of planetary systems, planetary interiors, planet formation, planetary atmospheres, meteoritics, impact cratering. [3-0-0]
ASTR 407.prer: One of PHYS 210, EOSC 211 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 316, PHYS 312 and one of ASTR 200, EOSC 212.
ASTR 407.crer: One of PHYS 206, PHYS 216, PHYS 306, EOSC 352.

ASTR 449.name: Honours Thesis in Astronomy
ASTR 449.desc: A research project in astronomy, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis. [1*-6-0]

ASTU 100.name: 1st Year CAP Seminar
ASTU 100.desc: CAP seminar focused on writing and reading, including both literature and introduction to academic scholarship. Topics vary each year. Credits count toward both the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement and the Literature Requirement. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

ASTU 101.name: Writing for Research in the Social Sciences and the Humanities
ASTU 101.desc: Analysis of and practice in academic writing and reading in the social sciences and the humanities. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

ASTU 201.name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Cultural Studies
ASTU 201.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the cultures of Canada and Japan, and the interrelations between them. Specific topics vary from year to year but will include themes such as constructing the past; nationalism; self-perceptions; cross-cultural perceptions; multiculturalism in Canada and Japan; images in architecture, film and literature; mythologies.

ASTU 202.name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Political, Economic and Geographical Perspectives
ASTU 202.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to political, economic and geographical interactions between Japan and Canada, the links between these countries and other Pacific Rim nations, and the historical origins of these connections. Specific topics will vary from year to year, but will include themes such as economic integration in the Pacific region; the role of resource economies such as Canada's; security relations in the Pacific; the role of Japanese investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

ATSC 201.name: Meteorology of Storms
ATSC 201.desc: Characteristics and physical processes of thunderstorms, tornadoes, lightning, hail, hurricanes, blizzards, cyclones and other storms. [3-0-0]

ATSC 404.name: Dynamic Meteorology
ATSC 404.desc: Dynamic principles governing atmospheric motions on a rotating planet. Simplified mathematical models of atmospheric flow based on scale analysis. Application to synoptic-scale and general circulation of the troposphere. [3-0-0]
ATSC 404.prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316 and one of EOSC 250, MATH 217, MATH 317.

ATSC 405.name: Cloud Physics and Chemistry
ATSC 405.desc: Cloud thermodynamics, chemistry and microphysics. Computer modelling of droplet growth, convection, and mixing. Application of differential equations to atmospheric problems. [3-0-0]
ATSC 405.prer: MATH 215. Familiarity with a programming language is required.
preq: MATH 215. Familiarity with a programming language is required

ATSC 409.name: Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
ATSC 409.desc: Web-based introduction to the practical numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations including considerations of stability and accuracy. Credit will be granted for only one of ATSC 409 or ATSC 506/EOSC 511. [0-0-3]
ATSC 409.prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265. Familiarity with a programming language is required.
preq: MATH 265. Familiarity with a programming language is required

ATSC 449.name: Honours Project
ATSC 449.desc: Honours students must submit a graduating report based on a project undertaken with the approval of the Associate Chair of the Atmospheric Science Program.

BUSI 221.name: Real Estate Finance in a Canadian Context
BUSI 221.desc: History, function and mechanics of Canadian mortgage markets.

BUSI 291.name: Application of Statistics in Business
BUSI 291.desc: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

BUSI 329.name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
BUSI 329.desc: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them.  Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, evironments, group processes, motivation and leadership.

BUSI 441.name: Real Estate Management I
BUSI 441.desc: Examines the day-to-day issues which affect the practice of property management.

BUSI 445.name: Real Estate Development I
BUSI 445.desc: Real estate development process from the project idea to the cursory feasibility stage.  Steps in development planning, including analysis, design and evaluation.  Evaluating development potential, land acquisition, and site planning.

BUSI 446.name: Real Estate Development II
BUSI 446.desc: Analysis of real estate development process with an examination of economic feasibility studies, approval processes, project financing, construction, project management, and marketing phases.

BUSI 460.name: Critical Analysis and Forecasting in Real Estate
BUSI 460.desc: Delves into two quantitative decision-making methodologies – decision analysis and forecasting – and explores them using a problem-solving framework.
BUSI 460.prer: BUSI 121. BUSI 331 and BUSI 444 are also recommended.

BUSI 465.name: Marketing Management
BUSI 465.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.

CAPS 200.name: Biomedical Research: Essential Skills and Concepts
CAPS 200.desc: Analysis of the underlying questions and assumptions, experimental approach, results and significance of work described in selected biomedical research presentations. [3-0-0]
CAPS 200.prer: BIOL 200. Limited to students in second year.
preq: BIOL 200. Limited to students in second year

CAPS 301.name: Human Physiology
CAPS 301.desc: Organ systems function with particular reference to mammalian and human physiology.  See credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-0-0]
CAPS 301.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

CAPS 303.name: Laboratory in Human Physiology (Honours)
CAPS 303.desc: Techniques and principles of human physiology. This course must be taken in conjunction with CAPS 301. Restricted to Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences and Pharmacology Honours students. [0-3]

CAPS 390.name: Introduction to Microscopic Human Anatomy
CAPS 390.desc: Organ system development, structure and function at the microscopic level. [3-0-0]
CAPS 390.prer: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. BIOL 200 is recommended.

CAPS 421.name: Advanced Cellular and Molecular Physiology
CAPS 421.desc: Recent advancements in cellular and molecular physiology that have revolutionized our understanding of cell function in health and disease.
CAPS 421.prer: Either (a) all of ANAT 390, PHYL 301 or (b) all of CAPS 301, CAPS 390 and third-year standing.

CAPS 422.name: Mammalian Cardiovascular and Respiratory Physiology
CAPS 422.desc: The control and integration of cardio-pulmonary function in mammals. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences. [3-0-0]
CAPS 422.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301 or its equivalent. Permission of the course director is also required.
preq: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program
a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301
its equivalent. Permission of the course director is also required

CAPS 423.name: Mammalian Renal and Gastrointestinal Physiology
CAPS 423.desc: Control of mammalian renal and gastrointestinal systems. Role in homeostasis. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences. [3-0-0]
CAPS 423.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.
preq: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program
a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301
PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required

CAPS 424.name: Mammalian Endocrinology
CAPS 424.desc: Hormonal control of homeostatic, metabolic and reproductive function. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences. [3-0-0]
CAPS 424.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.
preq: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program
a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301
PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required

CAPS 426.name: Physiological Basis of Central Nervous System Functions
CAPS 426.desc: An integrated study of the structural and functional organization of the central nervous system with special emphasis on neurophysiological mechanisms. [3-0-0]
CAPS 426.prer: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.
preq: A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program
a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301
PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required

CAPS 430.name: Advanced Laboratory in Physiology
CAPS 430.desc: Methods, techniques, and use of instruments required for physiological investigation. CAPS 303 or PHYL 303 and the consent of the department are required and enrolment will be limited. [0-6]

CAPS 449.name: Graduating Essay
CAPS 449.desc: Written report and presentation on an independent investigaton approved by the department head.

CENS 202.name: Great Works of Literature from Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
CENS 202.desc: Major works of Central, Eastern and Northern European literature from the eighteenth century to the present in their European context.

CENS 307.name: Witches: Myth and Reality
CENS 307.desc: Examination of the cultural, social, and historical construction of the witch in central and northern Europe with comparisons to recent history, current events, and popular culture.

CENS 404.name: Gender and Nation: Women's State in Modern Central, Eastern and Northern European Literatures and Cultures
CENS 404.desc: Cultural and social discourses of gender in literary works written in Central, Eastern and Northern Europe roughly between 1850 - 1930.

CHBE 201.name: Integrated Technical Communication
CHBE 201.desc: Written and oral communication in chemical and biological engineering: business correspondence, laboratory reports, technical description, and poster presentations. Restricted to students in second year of the Chemical and Biological Engineering programs.
CHBE 201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

CHBE 230.name: Computational Methods
CHBE 230.desc: Mathematical formulation of chemical and biological engineering problems; standard techniques of numerical analysis and their application to chemical, environmental and biotechnological systems; program development; use of commercial numerical analysis software.

CHBE 241.name: Material and Energy Balances
CHBE 241.desc: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering; units; stoichiometry; phase equilibria; material balances; energy balances.

CHBE 243.name: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering Process and Technology
CHBE 243.desc: Processes used in chemical and biological industries, which emphasize underlying physical, chemical, and biological principles.

CHBE 244.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics I
