CHBE 244.desc: Energy and the first law; second law of thermodynamics; entropy; availability (energy) analysis; thermodynamic properties of fluids, application to power generation, refrigeration, and liquefaction, as well as biological, environmental, and electrochemical systems.

CHBE 251.name: Transport Phenomena I
CHBE 251.desc: Fluid Mechanics. Momentum-transfer in fluids in laminar and turbulent flow; microscopic and macroscopic material; momentum and energy balances; rheology; dimensional analysis; flow in conduits; pumps; fluid metering.

CHBE 262.name: Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry Laboratory
CHBE 262.desc: Experiments chosen to illustrate and use material presented in 200-level CHBE and CHEM courses.
CHBE 262.crer: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHEM 250, CHEM 251, CHEM 260.

CHBE 344.name: Unit Operations I
CHBE 344.desc: Characterization of particles, droplets, and bubbles; comminution, screening and classification; filtration, sedimentation, centrifugal separations and fluidization; thermal operations including evaporation and crystalization.

CHBE 345.name: Unit Operations II
CHBE 345.desc: Stage-wise mass transfer operations; extraction and absorption; single and stage-wise binary and multi-component distillation; principles and equipment design for continuous contact mass transfer operations including absorption, binary distillation and others such as extraction, drying, humidification, membrane separations.

CHBE 346.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics
CHBE 346.desc: Volumetric and thermodynamic properties of fluids; equations of state; heat effects; ideal and non-ideal mixtures; fugacities and activity coefficients; vapor-liquid and liquid-liquid phase equilibrium; solubility of gases and solids in liquids; chemical reaction equilibrium; equilibrium partitioning of pollutants.

CHBE 351.name: Transport Phenomena II
CHBE 351.desc: Heat and mass transfer; conduction and molecular diffusion; convective transfer; thermal radiation; analogies among heat, mass and momentum transfer; heat exchanger design.

CHBE 356.name: Process Dynamics and Control
CHBE 356.desc: Introduction to modeling of chemical processes; transient response analysis; design of feedback control systems; stability analysis; frequency response analysis; process control applications; instrumentation; advanced control techniques; distributed control systems.

CHBE 362.name: Process and Environmental Engineering Laboratory
CHBE 362.desc: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 200 and 300-level CHBE courses.  Field trips may be required.

CHBE 364.name: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
CHBE 364.desc: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in environmental engineering as used by  engineers.

CHBE 365.name: Biological Engineering  Laboratory
CHBE 365.desc: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in biotechnology as used by engineers. Field trips may be required.

CHBE 366.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CHBE 366.desc: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 300-level CHBE process option courses. Field trips may be required.

CHBE 373.name: Water Pollution Control
CHBE 373.desc: Legal, environmental and physicochemical aspects of industrial water pollution and its abatement will be surveyed; techniques for design of wastewater treatment processes currently used in industry; case studies from chemical and process industries will be considered in detail.
CHBE 373.prer: One of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280, MTRL 263.

CHBE 376.name: Computer Flowsheeting and Fluid Properties Estimation
CHBE 376.desc: Theory and practice of computer flowsheeting in chemical plant design; hands-on use of modern process simulators, prediction of thermodynamic properties of fluids; behaviour of single and multiphase systems.

CHBE 381.name: Bioprocess Engineering I
CHBE 381.desc: Design of industrial bioreactor systems: organism selection; kinetics of microbial processes and enzyme reactions; design and modeling of single and multi-stage bioreactors.
CHBE 381.prer: BIOL 112 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, CHBE 241, CHBE 251. Third or fourth year standing.

CHBE 402.name: Biomass Fractionation Technology
CHBE 402.desc: Process and unit operations in the conversion of wood chips to pulp and green bio-products. Biorefinery concepts and emerging technologies for the production of biomaterials, biochemicals and bioenergy.

CHBE 419.name: Industrial Biotechnology Laboratory
CHBE 419.desc: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Restricted to students in the Joint Degree in Biotechnology. [1-4-0]

CHBE 453.name: Biological Process and Product Design
CHBE 453.desc: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical and biological engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major biological processes.
CHBE 453.prer: All of BIOL 112, CHBE 346, CHBE 356, CHBE 376, CHBE 381.

CHBE 454.name: Chemical Process and Product Design
CHBE 454.desc: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major chemical processes.
CHBE 454.prer: All of CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 376.

CHBE 455.name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
CHBE 455.desc: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models.

CHBE 456.name: Heterogenous Catalysis and Advanced Reactor Design
CHBE 456.desc: Definition of heterogeneous catalysis; properties of catalysts; kinetics of catalytic reactions; ideal heterogeneous reactors; non-isothermal reactor design; mass and heat transfer effects in heterogeneous reactors; examples of industrial reactors.

CHBE 457.name: Process Synthesis
CHBE 457.desc: Strategy for the conceptual design of industrial chemical and biological processes; rules of thumb for chemical engineers, simulation to assist process synthesis, reactor-separator network synthesis, introduction to product design and molecular structure design, efficiency and sustainability in the chemical industry.
CHBE 457.prer: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 346, CHBE 376, CHBE 344.

CHBE 459.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Economics
CHBE 459.desc: Estimation of capital and operating costs; interest calculations; taxes; economic comparison of alternatives; economic optimization.

CHBE 464.name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory
CHBE 464.desc: Experiments in unit operations relating to process, environmental and biological engineering. Experiments are designed to provide experience in instrumentation and control. Field trips may be required.
CHBE 464.prer: All of CHBE 345, CHBE 355, CHBE 356, CHBE 362 and one of CHBE 365, CHBE 366.

CHBE 474.name: Process Control Engineering
CHBE 474.desc: Frequency response analysis; advanced control techniques; multivariable control systems; mathematical tools for computer control systems; design of computer control systems; engineering design of industrial control applications; plant wide control concepts; distributed control systems concepts.

CHBE 476.name: Modelling and Optimization in Chemical Engineering
CHBE 476.desc: Mathematical modelling of chemical plants and processes; computer simulation; introduction to numerical optimization techniques.

CHBE 477.name: Fuel Cell and Electrochemical Engineering
CHBE 477.desc: Stoichiometry, thermodynamics and kinetics of electrode reactions; conductivity and mass transport in electrolytes; material, energy and voltage balances; design of  electrosynthesis, electrorecovery of metals, and energy generation of batteries and fuel cells.

CHBE 481.name: Bioprocess Engineering II
CHBE 481.desc: Bioprocess flowsheeting; production-scale fermenter design; product recovery and purification; bioseparations; chromatography; viral inactivation and removal; process validation.

CHBE 482.name: Petroleum Refining Process Modeling and Simulation
CHBE 482.desc: Petroleum feed stocks testing methods, pseudocomponents, and property methods. Design and simulation of separation and reaction systems. Steady state and dynamic simulation.

CHBE 483.name: Energy Engineering
CHBE 483.desc: Supply and use of conventional and alternative fuels and energy.  Design and operation of unit operations for processing of fossil fuels, biomass, and other energy sources.  Environmental considerations of energy use.

CHBE 484.name: Green Engineering Principles and Applications for Process Industries
CHBE 484.desc: Pollution prevention, cleaner production, green chemistry and engineering, industrial ecology, eco-industrial parks, and sustainable development; environmental impact assessment including life-cycle assessment, total cost analysis and environmental systems analysis; reduce/recycling/reuse of wastes and by-products.

CHBE 485.name: Air Pollution Prevention and Control
CHBE 485.desc: Impacts of air pollutants on health, visibility, smog formation, ozone depletion and global warming; air quality and emission standards; atmospheric dispersion of air pollutants; prevention and control technologies for particulates, SOx, NOx, VOCs, and CO2.

CHBE 486.name: Waste Management for Resource Recovery
CHBE 486.desc: Physico-chemical, thermal, and biological methods for purification of solid waste and wastewater, and conversion to bioproducts/industrial products, energy and clean water.

CHBE 487.name: Interfacial Phenomena
CHBE 487.desc: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 357 and CHBE 487. [3-0-0]

CHBE 491.name: Thesis Proposal
CHBE 491.desc: Literature searching, planning, equipment design, experimental design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation.

CHBE 492.name: Thesis
CHBE 492.desc: Research project under the direction of a staff member.

CHBE 493.name: Thesis Proposal-Environmental Topic
CHBE 493.desc: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of environmental topics offered by the department.

CHBE 495.name: Thesis Proposal-Biotechnology Topic
CHBE 495.desc: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of biotechnology topics offered by the department.

CHEM 111.name: Structure, Bonding, and Equilibrium in Chemistry
CHEM 111.desc: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society. [3-3-1]
CHEM 111.prer: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12.
preq: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12

CHEM 154.name: Chemistry for Engineering
CHEM 154.desc: Chemical bonding, properties of matter. Chemical thermodynamics with applications to phase equilibria, aqueous equilibria and electrochemistry. Processes at surfaces. [3-3*-0]

CHEM 203.name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
CHEM 203.desc: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.  Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 233, 235. [3-3-0]

CHEM 205.name: Physical Chemistry
CHEM 205.desc: Chemical kinetics and thermodynamics and spectroscopy useful in biological, medical, agricultural, earth, and related sciences. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 201 and 205. [3-0-0]
CHEM 205.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154.

CHEM 208.name: Coordination Chemistry
CHEM 208.desc: Fundamental concepts and principles governing bonding and reactivity of coordination complexes: ligand field theory; symmetry and point groups; frontier molecular orbital theory.

CHEM 211.name: Introduction to Chemical Analysis
CHEM 211.desc: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography.

CHEM 213.name: Organic Chemistry
CHEM 213.desc: Spectroscopy of organic compounds.  Mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-carbon bond formation; functional group interconversion.  Preference will be given to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. [3-0-0]
CHEM 213.prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 233.

CHEM 218.name: Fundamentals of Reactivity in Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 218.desc: Chemical reactivity of inorganic systems: oxidation/reduction chemistry; multiply-bonded systems; main group chemistry.

CHEM 245.name: Intermediate Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 245.desc: Techniques in synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.
CHEM 245.prer: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 235.

CHEM 250.name: Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 250.desc: Chemistry of selected groups of inorganic compounds, considered in relation to industrial processes. [2-0-0]
CHEM 250.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

CHEM 251.name: Physical Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM 251.desc: States of matter, properties of gases, phase diagrams. Elementary chemical thermodynamics and kinetics. Reaction equilibria. [3-0-1]
CHEM 251.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

CHEM 260.name: Organic Chemistry for Engineers
CHEM 260.desc: A description of the properties and reactions of organic compounds. [3-0-0]
CHEM 260.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

CHEM 300.name: Communicating Chemistry
CHEM 300.desc: Effective argumentation and communication skills in chemistry. Only open to students in a Chemistry specialization.

CHEM 301.name: Aqueous Environmental Chemistry
CHEM 301.desc: Properties of natural waters, including gas and solid equilibria, pH, redox, complexation analysis, corrosion treatment, ion exchange, colloids and microbial transformations. [3-0-0]
CHEM 301.prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 251 and Third year standing.

CHEM 302.name: Atmospheric Environmental Chemistry
CHEM 302.desc: Introduction to structure, composition and chemical processes occurring in Earth's atmosphere, including interactions with solar radiation, stratospheric ozone layer, photochemical smog and acid rain. [3-0-0]
CHEM 302.prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 251 and Third year standing.

CHEM 304.name: Fundamentals of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
CHEM 304.desc: Principles of chemical thermodynamics; introduction to statistical mechanics; phase equilibria; electrochemistry. [3-0-1]
CHEM 304.prer: CHEM 123 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

CHEM 305.name: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM 305.desc: Diffusion and transport phenomena; interaction of radiation and matter. Methods for determining molecular weight, size, and shape of molecules in solution. [3-0-0]
CHEM 305.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 205 or (c) CHEM 304 or (d) PHYS 203.

CHEM 311.name: Instrumental Analytical Chemistry
CHEM 311.desc: Theory, design, and application of instrumental methods of chemical analysis including spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, electroanalysis, and chemical separations.. [3-0-1]

CHEM 312.name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
CHEM 312.desc: Principles of quantum mechanics; atomic wavefunctions; angular momentum; spin; atomic term symbols. [3-0-1]
CHEM 312.prer: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

CHEM 313.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
CHEM 313.desc: Chemistry of organic substances having particular relevance to the life sciences. [3-0-0]

CHEM 315.name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory I
CHEM 315.desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]
CHEM 315.prer: One of CHEM 201, CHEM 202, CHEM 203, CHEM 208, CHEM 211, CHEM 235.

CHEM 318.name: Principles of Catalysis
CHEM 318.desc: Fundamental aspects of chemical catalysis: kinetic models; catalytic processes in biochemistry and industry; emerging topics in catalysis.

CHEM 319.name: Practical Skills for Chemical Research
CHEM 319.desc: The nature of scientific research; practical skills for chemical research; communicating science.  Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

CHEM 325.name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory I
CHEM 325.desc: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry specializations. [0-8-0]
CHEM 325.prer: All of CHEM 211, CHEM 213, CHEM 245 and either (a) all of CHEM 201, CHEM 202 or (b) CHEM 208.

CHEM 327.name: Introduction to Materials Chemistry
CHEM 327.desc: Basic principles of materials chemistry: classification; nomenclature; synthetic methods; characterization.
CHEM 327.prer: One of CHEM 208, CHEM 250 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

CHEM 329.name: Research Ethics and Data Analysis Skills
CHEM 329.desc: Research ethics; data analysis skills for chemical research. Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

CHEM 330.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CHEM 330.desc: Application of carbonyl group chemistry, cyclization reactions, conformational analysis and rearrangement reactions in organic synthesis. [3-0-0]

CHEM 335.name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory II
CHEM 335.desc: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. [0-4-0]

CHEM 341.name: Global Challenges: A Chemical Perspective
CHEM 341.desc: Importance of chemistry in society. Detailed case studies drawn from modern chemistry: human health, energy, commodity chemicals, materials, green chemistry, agriculture. [3-0-0]

CHEM 345.name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory II
CHEM 345.desc: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.   Open only to students in Chemistry Major or Honours specializations. [0-8-0]

CHEM 401.name: Principles of Spectroscopy
CHEM 401.desc: Rotational, vibrational, electronic and magnetic resonance spectroscopy and associated techniques; group theory. [3-0-0]

CHEM 402.name: Diffraction Methods
CHEM 402.desc: Crystal structures; point and space groups; X-ray diffraction, neutron diffraction, electron diffraction of gases and surfaces. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 402 and 514. [3-0-0]

CHEM 403.name: Surface Chemistry and Surface Analysis
CHEM 403.desc: Surfaces and phenomena occurring at surfaces and interfaces: adsorption, thermodynamic treatments, technological applications. Methods for characterization and modification of surfaces. Dynamic electrochemistry and its application to understanding fuel cells. [3-0-0]
CHEM 403.prer: CHEM 304 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

CHEM 405.name: Biophysical Chemistry
CHEM 405.desc: Interactions of macromolecules in solution: ligand, antibody and ion binding to macromolecules; thermodynamics of polymer solutions; excluded volume effects; phase separation; partition in two phase polymer solutions. [3-0-0]

CHEM 406.name: Polymer Chemistry
CHEM 406.desc: Structure and availability of monomers; Propagation mechanisms; synthesis of polymers with predetermined properties; measurement and interpretation of physical properties of polymers. [3-0-0]
CHEM 406.prer: One of CHEM 213, CHEM 260 and one of CHEM 304, CHEM 251.

CHEM 407.name: Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
CHEM 407.desc: Introductory concepts of statistical mechanics and statistical thermodynamics. Applications to chemistry with emphasis on understanding chemical reactivity. Credit will not be given for CHEM 503/CHEM 407 and PHYS 455. [3-0-0]

CHEM 410.name: Properties of Materials
CHEM 410.desc: Electromagnetic, optical, thermal and mechanical properties, and chemical reactivity of solids; electrons in periodic systems: bands, zones; excitations: excitons, phonons, plasmons, polaritons; crystalline order and disorder; ionic conductivity. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 410 or CHEM 502. [3-0-0]
CHEM 410.prer: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

CHEM 411.name: Synthesis and Chemistry of Natural Products
CHEM 411.desc: Methods and tactics for the synthesis of biologically active natural products and analogs, particularly alkaloids, polyketides, steroids and terpenes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 411 or CHEM 566. [3-0-0]

CHEM 412.name: Electronic Structure of Atoms and Molecules
CHEM 412.desc: Introduction to variational methods; many-electron systems; semi-empirical methods; perturbation theory; computational methods. [3-0-0]
CHEM 412.prer: One of CHEM 312, PHYS 304 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

CHEM 413.name: Bioorganic Chemistry
CHEM 413.desc: Enzyme catalysis; mechanistic enzymology; chemistry of cofactors; biosynthetic transformations; natural product biosynthesis; topics in chemical biology. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 413, CHEM 569, or BIOC 403. [3-0-0]

CHEM 417.name: Nuclear Chemistry and Radiochemistry
CHEM 417.desc: Basic treatment of the nucleus, with analogy to concepts in chemistry. Nuclear stabilities and associated radioactive decay processes. Nuclear structure. Applications of radioisotopes in chemistry. The interaction of radiation with matter. [3-0-0]
CHEM 417.prer: CHEM 123 and Third year standing. CHEM 312 is recommended.
preq: Third year standing. CHEM 312 is recommended

CHEM 418.name: Organometallic Chemistry
CHEM 418.desc: The chemistry of compounds containing organic groups directly bonded to metals and metalloids. Emphasis will be placed on the structure and bonding of the compounds and their use in synthetic chemistry. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 418 and CHEM 524. [3-0-0]

CHEM 419.name: Establishing a Career in Chemical Research
CHEM 419.desc: Current research and career perspectives in chemistry.  Restricted to Honours students with fourth year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory fourth year standing.

CHEM 427.name: Applications of Materials Chemistry
CHEM 427.desc: Contemporary materials chemistry, including design and synthesis of materials for energy, electronics, and health applications. [3-0-0]

CHEM 434.name: Principles of Chemical Separation
CHEM 434.desc: Unified theory of separation science; liquid and gas chromatography; capillary electrophoresis; electrochemical and spectroscopic detection; separation methods coupled with mass spectrometry and tandem mass spectrometry; biochemical applications. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 434 or CHEM 534. [3-0-0]

CHEM 449.name: Seminar and Thesis
CHEM 449.desc: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Weekly seminar. Required of all Honours students. Open to Majors students with a satisfactory standing and permission of the department head.

CHEM 460.name: Organic Synthesis: A Mechanistic Approach
CHEM 460.desc: Presentation, mechanistic discussion and analysis of modern synthetic methods using principles of physical organic chemistry. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 460 or CHEM 560. [3-0-0]

CHEM 473.name: Structure Determination and Reaction Analysis
CHEM 473.desc: Application of mass spectrometry and modern spectroscopic techniques, including multidimensional NMR spectroscopy, to reaction analysis and detailed characterization of complex organic and organometallic molecular structures. [3-0-0]
CHEM 473.prer: CHEM 245 and one of CHEM 313, CHEM 318, CHEM 330.

CHIN 131.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 131.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 250 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 131 or CHIN 101 or CHIN 134.

CHIN 133.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 133.desc: Continuation of CHIN 131. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 133 or CHIN 103 or CHIN 134.

CHIN 141.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
CHIN 141.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 141 or CHIN 111 or CHIN 144.

CHIN 143.name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN 143.desc: Continuation of CHIN 141. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 143 or CHIN 113 or CHIN 144.

CHIN 231.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 231.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing Mandarin Chinese, active vocabulary of about 750 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 231 or CHIN 105 or CHIN 234.
CHIN 231.prer: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

CHIN 241.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Heritage)
CHIN 241.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 241 or CHIN 115 or CHIN 244.
CHIN 241.prer: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

CHIN 243.name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN 243.desc: Continuation of CHIN 241. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 243 or CHIN 117 or CHIN 244.

CHIN 331.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 331.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 331 or CHIN 201 or CHIN 334.
CHIN 331.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

CHIN 333.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 333.desc: Continuation of CHIN 331. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 333 or CHIN 203 or CHIN 334.

CHIN 335.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 335.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 335 or CHIN 205 or CHIN 338.
CHIN 335.prer: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

CHIN 337.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 337.desc: Continuation of CHIN 335. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 337 or CHIN 207 or CHIN 338.

CHIN 341.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
CHIN 341.desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 341 or CHIN 211 or CHIN 344.
CHIN 341.prer: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

CHIN 343.name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN 343.desc: Continuation of CHIN 341. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 343 or CHIN 213 or CHIN 344.

CHIN 345.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Heritage)
CHIN 345.desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 345 or CHIN 215 or CHIN 348.
CHIN 345.prer: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

CHIN 347.name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
CHIN 347.desc: Continuation of CHIN 345. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 347 or CHIN 217 or CHIN 348.

CHIN 401.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 401.desc: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 405. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 401 or CHIN 301 or CHIN 404.
CHIN 401.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN 403.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 403.desc: Continuation of CHIN 401. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 407. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 403 or CHIN 303 or CHIN 404.

CHIN 405.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 405.desc: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 401. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 405 or CHIN 305 or CHIN 408.
CHIN 405.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN 407.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 407.desc: Continuation of CHIN 405. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 403. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 407 or CHIN 307 or CHIN 408.

CHIN 435.name: Business Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN 435.desc: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to advertising, the stock market and E-commerce. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 435 or CHIN 321.
CHIN 435.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN 437.name: Business Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN 437.desc: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to legal and financial documents such as contracts, investments, and insurance. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 437 or CHIN 323.
CHIN 437.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN 441.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Heritage)
CHIN 441.desc: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and CHIN 445. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 441 or CHIN 311 or CHIN 444.
CHIN 441.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN 443.name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Heritage)
CHIN 443.desc: Continuation of CHIN 441. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437 and/or CHIN 447. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 443 or CHIN 313 or CHIN 444.

CHIN 445.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Heritage)
CHIN 445.desc: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and/or CHIN 441. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 445 or CHIN 315 or CHIN 448.
CHIN 445.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN 461.name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (to Han)
CHIN 461.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the pre-Qin to the end of the Han Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 461 or CHIN 464.
CHIN 461.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 463.name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Han to Tang)
CHIN 463.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the Six Dynasties to early Tang, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 463 or CHIN 464.
CHIN 463.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 471.name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Tang)
CHIN 471.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Tang Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 471 or 474.
CHIN 471.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 473.name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (after Tang)
CHIN 473.desc: Readings in classical poetry from the Song to the Qing dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 473 or 474.
CHIN 473.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 483.name: Modern Chinese Literature II (Heritage)
CHIN 483.desc: Historical continuation of CHIN 481. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 483 or CHIN 484.
CHIN 483.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 491.name: Classical Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN 491.desc: The development of early Chinese from the classical period through the Six Dynasties (5th century BCE to 6th century CE). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 491 or CHIN 431 or CHIN 494.
CHIN 491.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CHIN 493.name: Classical Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN 493.desc: Focus in on the Tang and Song dynasties (617 - 1279). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 493 or CHIN 433 or CHIN 494.
CHIN 493.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

CIVL 201.name: Civil Engineering I
CIVL 201.desc: The design process; graphical, visualization and computational tools; civil engineering disciplines; decision-making; teamwork; conceptual design project reflecting community, economic, environmental, sustainability and technical considerations.
CIVL 201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

CIVL 202.name: Civil Engineering II
CIVL 202.desc: The social and biophysical context of infrastructure and the impact of technologies on people, the economy, and the environment. Specific topics vary from year to year.

CIVL 210.name: Soil Mechanics I
CIVL 210.desc: Soil classification, principle of effective stress, analysis of seepage, filter criteria, introduction to shear strength and slope stability analysis.
CIVL 210.crer: EOSC 210 and one of CIVL 215, MECH 280, EOSC 329.

CIVL 215.name: Fluid Mechanics I
CIVL 215.desc: Fluid properties, hydrostatics, kinematics, and fluid dynamics: energy and momentum methods with applications. Dimensional analysis, modelling, introduction to flow in pipes and forces on immersed objects.

CIVL 228.name: Introduction to Structural Engineering
CIVL 228.desc: Static determinacy, stability, superposition, analysis and design of trusses, deflection of trusses by principles of virtual work, statically indeterminate trusses, beams and frames, cables and arches, design objectives, loads and load combinations, structural safety, load paths, design of simple steel, timber, and reinforced concrete members.

CIVL 230.name: Solid Mechanics I
CIVL 230.desc: Stress and strain, Hooke's law, axially loaded members, torsion, shear forces and bending moments in beams, bending of beams, shear stresses in beams, shear centre, composite members, introduction to elasto-plastic and statically indeterminate problems.

CIVL 231.name: Solid Mechanics II
CIVL 231.desc: Deflection of beams, combined axial load and bending moment, inelastic bending, plastic analysis of structures, beam-columns, buckling (stability), principal axes and principal moments of inertia, biaxial stress and strain, Mohr’s circle.

CIVL 300.name: Construction Engineering and Management
CIVL 300.desc: Project delivery systems: traditional; construction management; turnkey; project management. Network planning methods. Activity planning, including construction methods selection. Estimating, bidding and bonding. Project control tools and procedures. Human resources, including equity considerations; occupational health and safety and quality control.

CIVL 301.name: Optimization and Decision Analysis in Civil Engineering
CIVL 301.desc: Review of numerical methods; introduction to systems engineering; application of optimization, probability, and decision-making to civil engineering systems and projects.

CIVL 304.name: Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering
CIVL 304.desc: Environmental engineering issues and projects; application of scientific and engineering principles to addressing these; soil, water and air pollution, and remediation.

CIVL 305.name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
CIVL 305.desc: Environmental ethics and legislation; risk assessment; urban water sources and sinks; water pollutants and impacts; mass balance and reactor design concepts; water and wastewater treatment; the environmental impact assessment process.

CIVL 311.name: Soil Mechanics II
CIVL 311.desc: One-dimensional compression and stress-strain response of soils with application to estimation of the settlements and capacities of foundations and of retaining walls.

CIVL 315.name: Fluid Mechanics II
CIVL 315.desc: Two dimensional flow around immersed objects; velocity and pressure fields; lift and drag on cylinders and aerofoils; fluid loads on structures and structural response; pumps and turbines; analysis and design of pipeline systems; unsteady flow in pipes; frictionless waterhammer analysis.

CIVL 316.name: Hydrology and Open Channel Flow
CIVL 316.desc: Introduction to open channel hydraulics, engineering hydrology, and water resource systems; estimation of design discharge; flood statistics; nonuniform steady open channel flow; energy and momentum principles, backwater analysis; culvert and bridge hydraulics.

CIVL 320.name: Civil Engineering Materials
CIVL 320.desc: The structure and properties of common Civil Engineering materials: aggregates, Portland cement, concrete, asphalt, timber and metals. The emphasis is on the relationship between the structure of materials and their mechanical properties.

CIVL 331.name: Steel and Timber Design
CIVL 331.desc: Introduction to limit states design of steel and timber structures: material properties, design of tension and compression members, beams, columns, and connections.

CIVL 332.name: Structural Analysis
CIVL 332.desc: Introduction to indeterminate structural analysis; approximate analysis of structures; calculation of displacements using virtual work; flexibility (force) method; stiffness method for frames; moment distribution method; introduction to structural dynamics.

CIVL 340.name: Transportation Engineering I
CIVL 340.desc: The analysis and design of the elements of transportation facilities in development of transport technology; vehicle motion; vehicle/pavement interaction; elements of road design; principles of queuing and roadway capacity; rail transit performance and capacity analysis; economics as applied to transport.

CIVL 402.name: Professionalism and Law in Civil Engineering
CIVL 402.desc: The Engineers and Geoscientists Act; professional ethics, conflicts of interest, confidentiality and accountability; health and safety; sustainable development and environmental stewardship; equity considerations; design and construction contracts, specifications and tendering; labour and employment law; dispute resolution; evidence and expert witnesses; torts and legal liability.

CIVL 403.name: Engineering Economic Analysis
CIVL 403.desc: Time value of money; cash flow analysis; comparing options; depreciation, taxes, and inflation; financial accounting; company structures; public sector projects; decision-making.

CIVL 406.name: Water Treatment and Waste Management
CIVL 406.desc: Processes used in water and wastewater treatment. Conditions which necessitate treatment of water or wastewater, water and wastewater treatment processes and plant design. Municipal services required and associated with solid waste management.

CIVL 407.name: Environmental Laboratory Analysis
CIVL 407.desc: Testing procedures used in water quality studies and in the operation of water and wastewater treatment plants.

CIVL 408.name: Geo-Environmental Engineering
CIVL 408.desc: Environmental contamination, regulatory requirements, site investigation, migration of contaminants, containment systems, site remediation technologies, design considerations related to soil-contaminant interactions, hydrogeology, geochemistry and types of contaminants. Design and performance case histories.

CIVL 409.name: Municipal Engineering
CIVL 409.desc: Design of municipal infrastructure, including streets, water supply networks, and sewers, garbage collection and solid waste management. Focus is on solutions for providing an adequate water supply, collecting and disposing of stormwater and sewage, and managing excess stormwater flow.

CIVL 410.name: Foundation Engineering I
CIVL 410.desc: An introduction to the process of foundation engineering. Empirical and analytical approaches used in current professional practice. Topics include site investigation, preloading, liquefaction assessment, ground improvement, design of shallow and deep foundations, and retaining structures. The importance of geology and technical communication are emphasized.

CIVL 411.name: Foundation Engineering II
CIVL 411.desc: Aspects of Geotechnical Engineering. Design considerations illustrated by case histories pertinent to BC. Topics include: site investigation, terrain analyses, in situ testing, groundwater problems, deep foundations, tie back walls and bracing, tailings impoundments, Northern construction, ground ice, dikes and dams engineering. Many case histories presented in part by prominent consulting engineers in BC.

CIVL 413.name: Design of Earth Dams and Containment Structures
CIVL 413.desc: Purpose and types of dams; design criteria; construction sequence; compaction; seepage; filter design; factors influencing the design of earth dams; stability and deformation under static and earthquake loading; slope protection; field instrumentation.

CIVL 415.name: Water Resource Engineering
CIVL 415.desc: An introduction to the planning and design of water resource systems, stream systems, and municipal and hydropower engineering.

CIVL 416.name: Environmental Hydraulics
CIVL 416.desc: Application of hydraulic engineering principles to problems of environmental concern. Pollutant transport and dispersion. Mixing in rivers and lakes. Theory of jets and plumes. Design of outfall diffusers.

CIVL 417.name: Coastal Engineering
CIVL 417.desc: General discussion of waves; linear wave theory; finite amplitude waves; standing waves; seiches; harbour design; wave shoaling, refraction and diffraction; beaches and coasts; wave statistics; wave generation; wave forces on piles, walls and breakwaters; tides; instrumentation and modelling techniques.

CIVL 418.name: Engineering Hydrology
CIVL 418.desc: Hydrologic processes - weather, precipitation, infiltration, evaporation, snowmelt and runoff generation. Emphasis on quantitative techniques including: hydrograph analysis, reservoir and channel routing, statistical methods and design floods, hydrologic modelling.

CIVL 420.name: Concrete Technology
CIVL 420.desc: Physical and chemical properties and microstructure of hydrated Portland cement; construction practices; modern use of industrial by-products such as fly ash, blast furnace slag, silica fume and metakaolin; use of chemical admixtures; environmental issues; properties of hardened concrete; issues in standardized and accelerated testing, non-destructive testing.

CIVL 422.name: Project Based Learning in Civil Engineering Materials
CIVL 422.desc: Some topical problems will be identified and students in groups will carry out experiments to study the materials involved. Site visits and external consultations are an integral requirement. [1-4-0]

CIVL 425.name: Case Studies of Construction Methods
CIVL 425.desc: Identification and evaluation of solutions to construction site operation problems: the relationship between design and construction; factors affecting productivity and safety; measurement of on-site performance. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 425 or CIVL 493. [3-0-0]

CIVL 426.name: Virtual Design and Construction
CIVL 426.desc: Creation and use of building information models (BIM) for managing the construction process.  3D parametric modeling, 4D modeling, design coordination, model-based cost estimating, BIM performance measurement, and integrated project delivery methods.

CIVL 430.name: Design of Concrete Structures
CIVL 430.desc: Non-linear response of reinforced concrete members subjected to axial load, bending and shear; design of simple one-way members including beams, columns, slabs and footings.

CIVL 432.name: Advanced Structural Steel Design
CIVL 432.desc: Design of steel structures to resist vertical and lateral loads. Floor and roof systems including conceptual layout, floor deck, beams, joists, trusses, and columns. Stability issues and limit states design. Connections and construction aspects. Seismic design.

CIVL 433.name: Advanced Concrete Design
CIVL 433.desc: Design of continuous reinforced concrete building frames and structures.

CIVL 435.name: Advanced Structural Analysis
CIVL 435.desc: Shear flow, shear deformation, St. Venant torsion, warping torsion, P-delta and geometric stiffness, buckling of columns and frames, cylindrical shells, beams on elastic foundation, shear wall analysis, elasto-plastic analysis. Introduction to the finite element method.

CIVL 436.name: Matrix Structural Analysis and Dynamics
CIVL 436.desc: Further techniques in matrix structural analysis; non-rigid supports, temperature-shrinkage effects, computer implementation; matrix representation of structural dynamics; mode shapes, natural frequencies, continuous systems; lumped mass models, modal analysis, response spectra.

CIVL 437.name: Introduction to Ship Structures
CIVL 437.desc: Structural theory and practice of ship structural design; longitudinal and transverse strength of hull girder; plates and shells; matrix analysis; introduction to classification society rules; ship section design synthesis; finite element analysis.

CIVL 439.name: Design of Timber Structures
CIVL 439.desc: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

CIVL 440.name: Transportation Engineering II
CIVL 440.desc: Traffic operations and network analysis: traffic studies and data design; traffic stream flow and roadway analysis; weaving and interchange ramp analysis; intersection traffic control measures and control design; progressive signal system design; flows prediction; road network simulation and assignment algorithms; motor vehicle accident analysis; field exercises.

CIVL 441.name: Transportation Planning and Analysis
CIVL 441.desc: Transportation systems planning and analysis: data needs; surveys and analysis; sampling techniques; trip generation; trip distribution; modal choice; trip assignment; traffic impact studies; system evaluation. Credit will be granted for only one of CIVL 441, CIVL 583 or PLAN 535.

CIVL 445.name: Engineering Design and Analysis I
CIVL 445.desc: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Focus on conceptual designs.

CIVL 446.name: Engineering Design and Analysis II
CIVL 446.desc: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Extends the conceptual design of CIVL 445 into detailed design projects.

CIVL 478.name: Building Science
CIVL 478.desc: Building science concepts associated with the design of modern buildings, focusing particularly on the building envelope's role in environmental separation, controlling the movement of heat, air, and water in liquid and vapour states.

CLCH 389.name: Introduction to Classical Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CLCH 389.desc: The basics of classical Chinese grammar, with short illustrations from texts of the Warring States and early Han Period. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 389 or ASIA 389.
CLCH 389.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234, JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260, KORN 200. Or placement approval.

CLST 105.name: Greek and Roman Mythology
CLST 105.desc: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation.

CLST 110.name: Golden Age of Athens
CLST 110.desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of fifth-century Athens.

CLST 111.name: Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome
CLST 111.desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Late Republican and Early Imperial Rome.

CLST 204.name: Gods, Graves, and Goods: The Archaeology of Ancient Greece and Rome
CLST 204.desc: A survey of the material cultures of the pre-classical and classical civilizations of Greece and Rome, illustrating the principles and techniques used to illuminate the archaeological history of these civilizations.

CLST 211.name: Greek Philosophy I
CLST 211.desc: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for CLST/PHIL 212 and PHIL 310.

CLST 212.name: Greek Philosophy II
CLST 212.desc: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310 and PHIL 311.

CLST 231.name: Ancient Greece
CLST 231.desc: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE).

CLST 232.name: Ancient Rome
CLST 232.desc: A survey of the ancient Roman world from the foundation of the city to the death of Constantine.

CLST 260.name: Gladiators, Games, and Spectacle in the Greek and Roman World
CLST 260.desc: History, development, and social function of various forms of spectacle in ancient Greece and Rome, from the Olympic games to the Roman arena.

CLST 301.name: The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science
CLST 301.desc: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences.

CLST 306.name: Applied Science and Technology in Classical Antiquity
CLST 306.desc: The origins and achievements of applied technology in the Greek and Roman world from the Bronze Age to late Antiquity, with special attention to archaeological evidence.

CLST 307.name: Greek Law
CLST 307.desc: The study of Greek legal theory, practice, and institutions from their origin in self-help, through the early lawgivers and their codes, to the developed system of Athens in the fifth and fourth centuries. A variety of test cases from the works of the Greek orators will be explored.

CLST 312.name: Women in the Roman World of Republican and Imperial Times
CLST 312.desc: Women  in the Roman world in the culture of the Republic and the Empire. Literary, artistic, and mythological sources are compared and contrasted to historical, legal, and archaeological records.

CLST 317.name: Classical Tragedy
CLST 317.desc: The plays of the Greek and Roman tragic dramatists, in translation.

CLST 331.name: Greek Art and Architecture
CLST 331.desc: An introduction to the visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE.

CLST 332.name: Roman Art and Architecture
CLST 332.desc: An introduction to the visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

CLST 333.name: Greek Religion
CLST 333.desc: A survey of both traditional and exoteric religious practices from the Archaic to the Hellenistic period.  Some knowledge of ancient Greece is recommended.

CLST 353.name: The Early Roman Empire
CLST 353.desc: Roman imperial history during the Julio-Claudian and Flavian periods (30 BC-96 AD).

CLST 355.name: The Athenians and their Empire
CLST 355.desc: The sources (literary, epigraphical and other) for Athens' emergence as one of the two leading city-states in late archaic and classical Greece and the stages by which her empire grew.

CLST 356.name: Alexander the Great and his Empire
CLST 356.desc: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East.

CNPS 426.name: The Role of the Teacher in Guidance
CNPS 426.desc: This course is designed to assist the teacher in understanding and using guidance techniques for day-to-day use in the classroom. The emphasis will be on techniques for working with people towards better self-understanding and better perspectives of alternatives. [2-1]

CNRS 370.name: Theories of Myth
CNRS 370.desc: Origins, nature, and transmission of myth in the Western tradition, with particular attention devoted to the interpretation of myth from ancient times up to the present. Some background in myth is recommended.

CNRS 410.name: The Archaeology of Ancient Cyprus
CNRS 410.desc: An overview of the archaeology of ancient Cyprus from the island's initial colonization in the 10th millennium BCE through the period of its rule as part of the Roman Empire (4th century CE).

CNTO 301.name: Basic Cantonese I
CNTO 301.desc: Elementary level (part I) course in Cantonese for non-heritage learners with no prior exposure to or background in Cantonese. Focus on training for basic listening and conversational skills in Cantonese.
CNTO 301.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 233, CHIN 108, CHIN 234. Or placement approval.

CNTO 303.name: Basic Cantonese II
CNTO 303.desc: Elementary level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 301. Focus on training for basic listening, conversational, and reading skills.

CNTO 451.name: Advanced Cantonese through Popular Culture
CNTO 451.desc: Popular culture in Hong Kong from media such as television, cinema, popular music, literature, social media, etc., through advanced authentic Cantonese listening and reading materials.  Open to non-heritage and heritage speakers of Mandarin and/or Cantonese.
CNTO 451.prer: CNTO 401. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework is strongly recommended.
preq: CNTO 401. Prior to registration a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework is strongly recommended

COEC 293.name: Financial Accounting
COEC 293.desc: Construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 293.

COEC 365.name: Market Research
COEC 365.desc: The process of marketing research including problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.

COEC 370.name: Corporate Finance
COEC 370.desc: Corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice; and financial policies, tools, and valuation.

COEC 371.name: Investment Theory
COEC 371.desc: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 371 or COMM 371.

COEC 377.name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
COEC 377.desc: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 377 or COMM 377.

COEC 491.name: Strategic Management
COEC 491.desc: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of single- and multi-business unit private sector enterprises, analyzed using the case method. Integrates methodologies from economic and organizational theory to form the foundations for strategic analyses.

COEC 497.name: New Enterprise Development
COEC 497.desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.

COEC 498.name: International Business Management
COEC 498.desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 498 or COMM 498.

COGS 200.name: Introduction to Cognitive Systems
COGS 200.desc: Interdisciplinary examination of human mental processes and how these are mediated by the brain. Will draw on cognitive psychology, linguistics, cognitive neuroscience, philosophy, artificial intelligence. [3-0-0]
COGS 200.prer: second-year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Science.
preq: second-year standing in the Faculty of Arts

COGS 300.name: Understanding and Designing Cognitive Systems
COGS 300.desc: Theory and methods for integrating diverse disciplinary content in cognitive systems. [2-3-0]

COGS 303.name: Research Methods in Cognitive Systems
COGS 303.desc: Examination and comparison of the research methodologies of different disciplines relevant to cognitive systems. [3-0-0]

COGS 401.name: Seminar in Cognitive Systems
COGS 401.desc: Interdisciplinary seminar integrating theory, methods, and current research topics. [1-0-4]

COHR 301.name: Business and Management Values
COHR 301.desc: Balancing organizational, personal, and community interests in a global economy. In addition to standard management textbooks and readings, the class will draw from the work of poets, fiction writers, essayists, and social critics.
COHR 301.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 303.name: Strategic Staffing
COHR 303.desc: Processes of workforce recruitment, selection, retention, and renewal. Includes human resources planning, development of an effective staffing strategy and employer brand, job analysis and descriptions, cost-benefit analysis of various recruiting methods, analysis and evaluation of selection methods.
COHR 303.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 304.name: Training, Development, and Performance Management
COHR 304.desc: Employee training, development and performance management in a variety of employment settings. Application of various training methods to performance enhancement, performance appraisal, feedback, and empirical evaluation of training investments.
COHR 304.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 305.name: Strategic Compensation
COHR 305.desc: Employee compensation, including pay systems, benefits systems, and rewards and recognition programs. Examination of the motivational underpinnings of compensation administration and the application of compensation principles to the achievement of employer strategic objectives.
COHR 305.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 401.name: Organizational Change
COHR 401.desc: The tactics and strategies for implementing constructive modifications in organizations.
COHR 401.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 402.name: Leadership
COHR 402.desc: Explores the characteristics of effective leadership and examines how to be a better leader.
COHR 402.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 404.name: Power and Politics
COHR 404.desc: Examines the sources and consequences of power in the context of different corporate and national cultures.
COHR 404.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 408.name: Organizational Design
COHR 408.desc: Techniques and approaches for evaluating and adjusting the structures of organization.
COHR 408.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 411.name: Managing and Building Teams
COHR 411.desc: Techniques and approaches for building effective teams, handling decision-making in teams, creating reward structures, and developing appropriate leadership models.
COHR 411.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 433.name: Employment Law
COHR 433.desc: Introduction to legislation and application of legal principles that govern the employment relationship.
COHR 433.prer: All of COMM 292, COMM 393 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COMM 100.name: Introduction to Business
COMM 100.desc: An overview of all functional areas of business. Students will be introduced to the computer and internet tools commonly used in business. For non-Commerce students only.

COMM 101.name: Business Fundamentals
COMM 101.desc: The different disciplines of business and their combination in management planning and decision-making.

COMM 120.name: Business Immersion
COMM 120.desc: A broad introduction to the field of business and how the different disciplines within business interact and combine in business decision-making. For Master of Management - Dual Degree Option students only.

COMM 202.name: Career Fundamentals
COMM 202.desc: Fundamentals of career management including effective resume and cover letter writing, performing well in interviews and learning about the recruiting cycles, networking and resources available at the Hari B. Varshney Business Career Centre.

COMM 220.name: Business Communications and Ethics
COMM 220.desc: An experiential course covering a broad range of business writing and communications. Ethical challenges and issues will be presented throughout the course and form an integral part of the content, particularly in the major assignments and in-class activities.

COMM 291.name: Application of Statistics in Business
COMM 291.desc: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

COMM 292.name: Management and Organizational Behaviour
COMM 292.desc: Behaviour in organizations as it affects people as individuals, their relationships with others, their performance in groups and their effectiveness at work.

COMM 296.name: Introduction to Marketing
COMM 296.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.
COMM 296.crer: COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM 298.name: Introduction to Finance
COMM 298.desc: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 298 or COEC 298.
COMM 298.prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 293 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM 306.name: Urban Land Economics
COMM 306.desc: Examines economic factors affecting the urban land market, with an emphasis on determinants of urban land values, the housing market, urban transportation, and land use policies.

COMM 307.name: Real Estate Investment
COMM 307.desc: Evaluation of investment in real estate assets; proforma analysis, property and asset management, equity securitization, appraisal, and international real estate investment.
COMM 307.prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298.

COMM 311.name: Research Theory for Commerce Scholars
COMM 311.desc: Social science research: theory, research design, methods, and criticism. For students in the Commerce Scholars Program only.

COMM 320.name: Financial Accounting
COMM 320.desc: Preparation of financial statements and use of financial information contained in financial statements to make better decisions.

COMM 321.name: Organizational Behaviour
COMM 321.desc: Effects of individual and group behaviour on organizational processes and outcomes. Application of relevant frameworks from the social sciences to particular organizational situations.

COMM 336.name: Introduction to e-Business
COMM 336.desc: Fundamental concepts for moving into e-Business including: technology infrastructure; security; electronic payment systems; business-to-consumer and business-to business e-commerce; business models; strategy, behavioral and interface issues; legal and privacy concerns cases.

COMM 337.name: Business Programming and Analytics
COMM 337.desc: Introduction to object-oriented computer programming; computational thinking; program design; scripting; documentation techniques; file handling; database access; and web crawling techniques. Students will apply data structures and programming constructs to the development of business analytics and other related applications.

COMM 353.name: Financial Accounting: Intermediate I
COMM 353.desc: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.
COMM 353.crer: Either (a) all of COMM 297, COMM 397 or (b) COMM 298.

COMM 354.name: Cost Accounting
COMM 354.desc: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance. The utilization of statistical analysis and linear models is included.
COMM 354.prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 291, COMM 293, COMM 294.

COMM 355.name: Income Taxation
COMM 355.desc: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and of business enterprise.

COMM 362.name: Consumer Behaviour
COMM 362.desc: The use of consumer research and theory in marketing and policy decisions. Psychological, sociological and economic theory and research relevant to consumer behaviour are considered.

COMM 363.name: Marketing Analysis
COMM 363.desc: Analytical methods applicable to marketing management decision making; attention to strategic considerations linking analysis of consumer data, corporate data, environmental factors, and competitive response. The course makes extensive use of micro computers.

COMM 365.name: Market Research
COMM 365.desc: The process of marketing research including topics such as problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.
COMM 365.prer: All of COMM 290, COMM 291 and either (a) COMM 296 or (b) COMM 396;  and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM 370.name: Corporate Finance
COMM 370.desc: Examination of corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice, and financial policies, tools, and valuation.

COMM 371.name: Investment Theory
COMM 371.desc: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 371 or COEC 371.

COMM 374.name: Applied Financial Markets
COMM 374.desc: Introduction to methodologies and evidence concerning the structure and operation of security markets and the valuation of financial securities including stocks, bonds, options and futures contracts; portfolio management, corporate finance and investment decisions.

COMM 377.name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
COMM 377.desc: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 377 or COEC 377.

COMM 382.name: Economics of Entrepreneurship and Innovation
COMM 382.desc: Fundamental economic issues faced by entrepreneurs who want to commercialize innovations within start-ups and established firms.

COMM 387.name: Entrepreneurial Finance
COMM 387.desc: Financial issues encountered by those active on the investing side of entrepreneurship, such as working for banks, venture capital firms, or corporate venture organizations, or anyone interacting with entrepreneurs and private equity investors.

COMM 388.name: Design Methods for Business Innovation
COMM 388.desc: Studio-based experience in thinking strategies and design processes applied to business innovation in the private, public, and social sectors. Emphasis on problem solving, co-creation, and innovation for external clients in a collaborative environment.

COMM 389.name: Creativity in Business
COMM 389.desc: The role and importance of creativity in developing successful business solutions.

COMM 405.name: Real Estate Finance
COMM 405.desc: The role of mortgage markets, mathematical analysis of return and valuation issue and methods of dealing with lender and borrower risk exposure.

COMM 407.name: Real Estate Economics
COMM 407.desc: The economics of real estate markets. Topics include real estate cycles and bubbles, search models and vacancy, the relationship between real estate and the economy, housing demand, and models of housing supply.

COMM 408.name: Real Estate Development
COMM 408.desc: The development process from theories of development, market analysis, site selection, project design, land use regulation and financial analysis.
COMM 408.prer: One of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301.

COMM 412.name: Negotiation
COMM 412.desc: Negotiation simulations to provide experience and confidence in the negotiation process and to develop effective skills for achieving objectives.

COMM 414.name: Data Visualization and Business Analytics
COMM 414.desc: Descriptive analytics including data analysis and visualization. Predictive analytics including forecasting and various statistical techniques. Predictive analytics including optimization, Monte Carlo simulation, decision trees, and discrete event simulation.

COMM 415.name: Quantitative Policy Analysis
COMM 415.desc: Quantitative evaluation of public policies using statistical evaluation methods, cost benefit, and effectiveness analyses. Public policies affecting service provision and infrastructure investment in air, rail, marine, public transit, and pipelines evaluated on pricing, operating costs, productivity, safety, security, and the environment.

COMM 420.name: Marketing
COMM 420.desc: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services. Analytical frameworks and techniques that are used to guide marketing strategy decisions.

COMM 421.name: Corporate Finance
COMM 421.desc: Introduces the basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions.

COMM 431.name: Law of Business Associations
COMM 431.desc: The application of various statutes to business entities including corporations, partnerships, societies, co-operatives, credit unions, trust companies and banks; the consequences of bankruptcy on legal entities.

COMM 434.name: Land Law
COMM 434.desc: Legal principles and concepts relating to real estate and land development.

COMM 436.name: Information Systems Analysis and Design
COMM 436.desc: The process of information systems development; modern techniques and tools for systems analysis and design.

COMM 437.name: Database Technology
COMM 437.desc: Theory and technology of database management from an applications perspective; database design; database administration. Credit will not be granted for both COMM 437 and CPSC 304.

COMM 438.name: Management of Information Systems
COMM 438.desc: Managerial issues in the administration of computerized information systems.

COMM 439.name: Business Telecommunications
COMM 439.desc: Basic data communications concepts and technology; local area, wide area, and enterprise networks; the Internet; wireless networking; network development life cycle; network security and management.

COMM 443.name: Service Operations
COMM 443.desc: This primarily case-based course will cover service operations in general (50%), health care operations (25%), and revenue management (25%). Applications of queuing models will be included in both services in general and healthcare.

COMM 444.name: Air Transportation
COMM 444.desc: An integrative treatment of air transport management including: demand analysis, sales and marketing, globalization trends, aircraft selection and fleet planning; airport economics and management.

COMM 445.name: Maritime and International Transportation
COMM 445.desc: The characteristics of shipping services and the role of shipping services in the design and management of international logistics systems.

COMM 447.name: Applied Project Management
COMM 447.desc: Evaluation of transport projects in the private and public sector; cost benefit analysis and related framework; project management, financing transport infrastructure.

COMM 449.name: Supply-Chain Management
COMM 449.desc: Integrated management of production and logistics systems; management of inter-organizational  relationships in the supply chain, including vendor selection, bidding and negotiation processes, partnering and performance measurement.

COMM 450.name: Financial Accounting - Intermediate II
COMM 450.desc: Intermediate II. Continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

COMM 452.name: Taxes and Decision Making
COMM 452.desc: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

COMM 453.name: Financial Accounting-Advanced
COMM 453.desc: An examination of advanced financial accounting.

COMM 454.name: Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
COMM 454.desc: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

COMM 455.name: Principles of Auditing
COMM 455.desc: Principles of internal control, audit evidence, sampling and testing; audit reports; standards; responsibilities of the external auditor.

COMM 458.name: Fundamentals of Managerial Accounting
COMM 458.desc: Use of accounting data in decision making by businesses; financial statement analysis; cash flows; cost behaviour patterns; methods of accounting for costs. (For non-Commerce students only).

COMM 459.name: Financial Statement Analysis
COMM 459.desc: An examination of financial statement information from the perspective of decision makers external to the firm, e.g., investors and financial institutions.
COMM 459.prer: COMM 293 and one of COMM 297, COMM 298 and one of COMM 370, COMM 397.

COMM 460.name: Social and Nonprofit Marketing
COMM 460.desc: Examines the role, use, and application of marketing in government agencies and nonprofit institutions.

COMM 461.name: Business Development
COMM 461.desc: Principles and practice of personal selling and leadership of teams: strategy, tactics, and implementation.

COMM 462.name: Integrated Marketing Communication
COMM 462.desc: Marketing communication campaign strategy, conceptual framework, and practical application for integrated marketing communications, including advertising.

COMM 464.name: Digital Marketing
COMM 464.desc: Investigation of Internet-based marketing, emphasizing customer-focused perspectives, competitive situations and analysis of the effectiveness of business websites using marketing principles and practices.

COMM 466.name: New Venture Design
COMM 466.desc: Teams comprising students in COMM 466 and APSC 486 propose a new product, produce a viable prototype, and develop a business plan for the marketplace.  Credit may only be obtained for one of COMM 466 and APSC 486.

COMM 467.name: Brand Management
COMM 467.desc: Issues and challenges commonly faced by brand managers, including: assessing brand meaning, evaluating brand health, assessing a brand?s leverage potential, evaluating brand extensions, managing brands through a crisis, and assessing brand value.

COMM 468.name: Marketing Applications
COMM 468.desc: Applied marketing planning with emphasis on a major industrial analysis and the subsequent development of a detailed marketing plan for an operating organization.

COMM 469.name: International Marketing
COMM 469.desc: An analysis of the scope and significance of contemporary international business operations with particular reference to the marketing management problems encountered by firms with multinational branches and subsidiaries.

COMM 471.name: Mergers and Acquisitions
COMM 471.desc: Mergers and acquisitions as a focal point in making important corporate decisions deduced from careful study of relevant business cases.

COMM 474.name: Fixed Income Markets and Management
COMM 474.desc: Fixed income instruments and derivatives. Risk profiles and their use in establishing fixed income investment portfolios. Performance attribution techniques.

COMM 475.name: Investment Policy
COMM 475.desc: The management of security portfolios for individual and institutional investors; relation of investment policy to money markets and business fluctuations.

COMM 477.name: Risk Management and Financial Engineering
COMM 477.desc: Principles of financial engineering and risk management. Use of derivatives in risk management. Valuation and hedging models for contingent claims.

COMM 482.name: New Product Development
COMM 482.desc: How new products are developed and the factors that influence success and failure throughout the various stages of development.

COMM 483.name: Leadership and General Management
COMM 483.desc: Integration and application of business knowledge to make business decisions across disciplines; development of personal leadership ability and style. Case-based with guest speakers.

COMM 484.name: Sustainability Marketing
COMM 484.desc: Role of marketing in creating social value. Integration of marketing fundamentals with core social, environmental, and economic principles of sustainability. Analysis of current sustainability trends. Development of strategic and practical marketing recommendations for for-profit enterprises. Potential and pitfalls of sustainability marketing.

COMM 485.name: Social Entrepreneurship
COMM 485.desc: An applied course that examines the innovative, growing, and rapidly evolving field of social entrepreneurship, which tackles social and environmental challenges through business perspectives and methods.

COMM 487.name: Environmental Management
COMM 487.desc: Explores corporate environmental strategy by introducing economic principles underlying environmental policy, law, and technologies for pollution prevention and abatement, environmental management systems, ISO-14001, energy systems, eco-marketing, and life-cycle analysis.  Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 487 or COMM 597.

COMM 497.name: New Enterprise Development
