COMM 497.desc: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.
COMM 497.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

CONS 101.name: Introduction to Conservation
CONS 101.desc: Seminars on current natural resources conservation and forest sciences topics. [1-0-0]

CONS 127.name: Observing the Earth from Space
CONS 127.desc: Exploration of innovative Earth observation and other geospatial technologies and how they allow us to better understand the changing Earth. [3-0-0]

CONS 200.name: Foundations of Conservation
CONS 200.desc: Conceptual foundations of conservation; means of conserving nature and natural resources. [3-0-0]

CONS 210.name: Visualizing Climate Change
CONS 210.desc: Introduction to climate change through the lens of local landscapes and future scenarios, using visual media to communicate the underlying science & psychology, and engage communities in local climate change solutions.

CONS 302.name: Issues in Genomics and the Environment
CONS 302.desc: Current and topical issues, including genetic determinism, environmental DNA, genomics and climate change, revival of extinct species, and applications of genomics in natural environments.

CONS 330.name: Conservation Science and Sustainability
CONS 330.desc: Fundamental concepts in conservation science. Different philosophies, perspectives, and disciplines used in setting priorities for managing biodiversity at all scales. [3-2-0]

CONS 370.name: Aboriginal Forestry
CONS 370.desc: Issues the may be encountered in professional natural resources work with or for Aboriginal communities and organization, including contemporary issues of Aboriginal rights and title, traditional uses, and self-government. [3-0-0]

CONS 425.name: Sustainable Energy: Policy and Governance
CONS 425.desc: Energy as a global policy problem; current energy challenges; energy systems and energy analysis; the politics and policy of energy alternatives. [3-0-0]
CONS 425.prer: Third- or fouth-year standing; 100-level MATH course.

CONS 451.name: Integrated Field School
CONS 451.desc: Field methods, research and analysis, community oriented projects, and the interactions between biological and social aspects of conservation research. Students may not take any other courses in conjunction with CONS 451. Restricted to B.Sc.N. students in the fourth year of the Science and Management Major.

CONS 452.name: Global Perspectives Capstone
CONS 452.desc: Examination of global resources and sustainability via scenario evaluation, modelling, and prescription.
CONS 452.prer: One of CONS 340, GEOB 270 and fourth year standing in the Global Perspectives Major.
preq: fourth year standing in the Global Perspectives Major

CONS 481.name: Conservation Planning and Wildland Recreation
CONS 481.desc: Theory and tools needed for the selection and design of protected areas, the designation of land use types, and the management and conservation of wildland recreation resources. [2-2-0]

CONS 486.name: Fish Conservation and Management
CONS 486.desc: Principles of fish biology, population and community ecology necessary to understand conservation and management; overview of current issues, tactics and institutions involved with fisheries conservation and management. [2-3-0]

CONS 491.name: Recreation and Tourism Planning
CONS 491.desc: Principles and methods for planning urban and rural recreation and related tourism resources including analyzing recreation resources, applying policies and standards, developing park/recreation area management plans, and understanding benefits to human and community wellbeing and biodiversity. [3-0-0]

CONS 495.name: Principles of Managing Problem Wildlife in Forests and Agricultural Environments
CONS 495.desc: Impacts of wildlife on crop productivity in temperate and tropical environments, the resiliency of wildlife populations to conventional control methodology, adoption of innovative methods to reduce crop damage, and the impact of introduced species on native fauna. [2-0-1]
CONS 495.prer: One of BIOL 230, BIOL 306, APBI 444, APBI 460, FRST 201, FRST 202, FRST 395, FRST 444, FRST 495 and one of FRST 231, BIOL 300.

CONS 498.name: Thesis or Special Project
CONS 498.desc: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the supervision of a staff member.

CPEN 211.name: Introduction to Microcomputers
CPEN 211.desc: Boolean algebra; combinational and sequential circuits; organization and operation of microcomputers, memory addressing modes, representation of information, instruction sets, machine and assembly language programming, systems programs, I/O structures, I/O interfacing and I/O programming, introduction to digital system design using microcomputers.

CPEN 221.name: Principles of Software Construction
CPEN 221.desc: Design, implementation, reasoning about software systems: abstraction and specification of software, testing, verification, abstract data types, object-oriented design, type hierarchies, concurrent software design.

CPEN 281.name: Technical Communication
CPEN 281.desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
CPEN 281.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

CPEN 311.name: Digital Systems Design
CPEN 311.desc: Advanced combinational and sequential electronic system design. Hardware specification, modeling, and simulation using hardware description languages (HDLs) and CAD tools. Design with programmable logic including FPGA's. Applications include complex state machines, microcontrollers, arithmetic circuits, and interface units. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 353, CPEN 311 and EECE 379.
CPEN 311.prer: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN 312.name: Digital Systems and Microcomputers
CPEN 312.desc: Data representation in digital computers; boolean algebra; the design and optimization and implementation of combinatorial and sequential circuits; modern digital circuit technologies; memory and programmable logic devices; organization and operation of microcomputers; data/address bus organization; input-output interfacing. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 355, CPEN 312, EECE 259, CPEN 211, and EECE 256.
CPEN 312.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 252, ELEC 204, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

CPEN 321.name: Software Engineering
CPEN 321.desc: Engineering practices for the development of non-trivial software-intensive systems including requirements specification, software architecture, implementation, verification, and maintenance. Iterative development. Recognized standards, guidelines, and models. Credit will only be granted for only one of CPSC 310, EECE 310, or CPEN 321.
CPEN 321.prer: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, CPSC 210, EECE 309.

CPEN 331.name: Operating Systems
CPEN 331.desc: Operating systems, their design and their implementation. Process concurrency, synchronization, communication and scheduling. Device drivers, memory management, virtual memory, file systems, networking and security.
CPEN 331.prer: CPSC 261 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309.

CPEN 333.name: System Software Engineering
CPEN 333.desc: Operating systems principles, real-time systems, principles of concurrent and multi-threaded programming, information structures, introduction to object oriented analysis, design, and modeling using UML, testing of software systems.
CPEN 333.prer: One of CPSC 259, CPSC 260 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN 391.name: Computer Engineering Design Studio II
CPEN 391.desc: Design and implementation of a hardware platform and software design and implementation at the operating system and application layers.  Project management skills. Effective presentations.
CPEN 391.prer: One of CPEN 291, ELEC 291, ELEC 292, EECE 281 and one of EECE 353, CPEN 311.

CPEN 411.name: Computer Architecture
CPEN 411.desc: Modern processors, GPUs, and memory hierarchies; quantitative principles and instruction set design; pipelining, superscalar issue, out-of-order execution, branch prediction and speculation; memory hierarchies, caches, virtual addressing, prefetching, coherence, and consistency; multicores, VLIW, on-chip networks, and other advanced architectures. Credit will be given for only one of CPSC 313 or EECE 476 or CPEN 411.
CPEN 411.prer: Either (a) one of EECE 353, CPEN 311 or (b) one of EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN 421.name: Software Project Management
CPEN 421.desc: Advanced project planning, cost estimation and scheduling. Project management tools. Factors influencing productivity and success. Productivity metrics. Analysis of options and risk. Tools. Case studies.

CPEN 431.name: Design of Distributed Software Applications
CPEN 431.desc: Communications, processes, naming, synchronization, consistency and replication, fault tolerance, object-based middleware, and security technologies for distributed applications. [3-2-0]
CPEN 431.prer: One of EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, CPSC 210.

CPEN 432.name: Real-time System Design
CPEN 432.desc: Multi-tasking; interrupt-driven systems; task scheduling; schedulability analysis; inter-process communication and synchronization; resource management; performance measurement; hardware/software integration; hardware/software tradeoffs; system reliability.
CPEN 432.prer: One of EECE 314, CPEN 333, EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313.

CPEN 441.name: Human Computer Interfaces in Engineering Design
CPEN 441.desc: Practical issues for interfaces for modern software. Task analysis, user modeling, usability engineering, representations, metaphors, prototyping tools. Applications: interactive multimedia systems, engineering, scientific visualization, engineering design.
CPEN 441.prer: One of CPSC 260, CPSC 221 and one of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, CPSC 210, EECE 314, CPEN 333.

CPEN 442.name: Introduction to Computer Security
CPEN 442.desc: Security risks, threats, and vulnerabilities from technical perspectives; confidentiality, integrity, and hybrid policies; cryptography, access control, assurance, accountability, and engineering of secure systems.
CPEN 442.prer: One of EECE 314, CPEN 333, EECE 315, CPEN 331, CPSC 313.

CPEN 491.name: Computer Engineering Capstone Design Project
CPEN 491.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world computer engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

CPEN 492.name: Software Engineering Capstone Design Project
CPEN 492.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world software engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

CPSC 100.name: Computational Thinking
CPSC 100.desc: Meaning and impact of computational thinking. Solving problems using computational thinking, testing, debugging. How computers work. No prior computing experience required. Not for students with existing credit for or exemption from CPSC 110 or APSC 160. [3-1-0]

CPSC 259.name: Data Structures and Algorithms for Electrical Engineers
CPSC 259.desc: Advanced procedural programming.  Fundamental algorithms for sorting and searching.  Data structures including lists, trees, and hash tables.  Introduction to scripting languages and file input/output. [3-2-0]

CPSC 261.name: Basics of Computer Systems
CPSC 261.desc: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures.  Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks. [3-2-1]
CPSC 261.prer: One of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of CPSC 260, EECE 210, CPEN 221.

CPSC 301.name: Computing in the Life Sciences
CPSC 301.desc: Basic concepts, tools, and techniques for working with scientific data at larger scales, higher speeds, and lower costs that would otherwise be impossible. Applications and examples drawn from the life sciences. No prior computing background is required. Not for credit for students who have credit for any of the following: APSC 160, Computer Science AP, IB Computer Science, EOSC 211, or 3 credits of CPSC beyond CPSC 101. [3-2-0]

CPSC 302.name: Numerical Computation for Algebraic Problems
CPSC 302.desc: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving no discretization, and their analysis. Solution of linear systems, including analysis of round-off errors; norms and condition number; introduction to iterative techniques in linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems; solution to nonlinear equations. [3-0-0]
CPSC 302.prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPSC 260, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

CPSC 303.name: Numerical Approximation and Discretization
CPSC 303.desc: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving discretization, and their analysis. Interpolation and approximation, including splines and least squares data fitting; numerical differentiation and integration; introduction to numerical initial value ordinary differential equations. [3-0-0]
CPSC 303.prer: One of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPSC 260, EOSC 211, PHYS 210 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

CPSC 304.name: Introduction to Relational Databases
CPSC 304.desc: Overview of database systems, ER models, logical database design and normalization, formal relational query languages, SQL and other commercial languages,data warehouses, special topics. [3-0-1]
CPSC 304.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320 and one of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309.

CPSC 310.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
CPSC 310.desc: Specification, design, implementation and maintenance of large, multi-module software systems. Principles, techniques, methodologies and tools for computer aided software engineering (CASE); human-computer interfaces, reactive systems, hardware-software interfaces and distributed applications. [3-2-0]

CPSC 311.name: Definition of Programming Languages
CPSC 311.desc: Comparative study of advanced programming language features. Statement types, data types, variable binding, parameter passing mechanisms. Methods for syntactic and semantic description of programming languages. [3-0-1]

CPSC 312.name: Functional and Logic Programming
CPSC 312.desc: Principles of symbolic computing, using languages based upon first-order logic and the lambda calculus. Algorithms for implementing such languages. Applications to artificial intelligence and knowledge representation. [3-0-0]
CPSC 312.prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

CPSC 314.name: Computer Graphics
CPSC 314.desc: Human vision and colour; geometric transformations; algorithms for 2-D and 3-D graphics; hardware and system architectures; shading and lighting; animation. [3-1-0]
CPSC 314.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320.

CPSC 317.name: Internet Computing
CPSC 317.desc: Computer networking, basic communication protocols, network infrastructure and routing.  Common application-level protocols and principles associated with developing distributed applications. [3-0-1]

CPSC 319.name: Software Engineering Project
CPSC 319.desc: The design, implementation, and test of a large software system, using a team approach. [3-0-2]

CPSC 344.name: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Methods
CPSC 344.desc: Basic tools and techniques, teaching a systematic approach to interface design, task analysis, analytic and empirical evaluation methods. [2-2-2]
CPSC 344.prer: One of CPSC 210, EECE 210, EECE 309, CPEN 221.

CPSC 349.name: Honours Research Seminar
CPSC 349.desc: Students will attend a series of research seminars presented by faculty members, produce a thesis proposal, and choose their honours thesis supervisor. Available to Honours students. Majors students with satisfactory standing may also be permitted to enrol. [1-0-0]

CPSC 404.name: Advanced Relational Databases
CPSC 404.desc: Physical database design, indexing, relational query processing and optimization, transaction processing, concurrency control, crash recovery, data warehouses, data cubes, views, special topics. [3-0-0]
CPSC 404.prer: CPSC 304 and one of CPSC 213, CPSC 261.

CPSC 406.name: Computational Optimization
CPSC 406.desc: Formulation and analysis of algorithms for continuous and discrete optimization problems; linear, nonlinear, network, dynamic, and integer optimization; large-scale problems; software packages and their implementation; duality theory and sensitivity. [3-0]

CPSC 410.name: Advanced Software Engineering
CPSC 410.desc: Specification, design, construction and validation of multi-version software systems. [3-0-0]
CPSC 410.prer: Either (a) CPSC 310 or (b) one of EECE 310, CPEN 321 and one of EECE 315, CPEN 331.

CPSC 411.name: Introduction to Compiler Construction
CPSC 411.desc: A practical introduction to lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type-checking, code generation and optimization. This will be used to design and implement a compiler for a small language. [3-0-0]

CPSC 415.name: Advanced Operating Systems
CPSC 415.desc: Process synchronization and communication schemes, including message-passing and concepts of monitor and serializer. Virtual memory systems management and the problem of information sharing in such systems. The working set principle. Traps and interrupt handling. Elementary queuing theory and its application such as process scheduling, system balancing and load control. File systems and operating system design methodologies. [3-0-0]

CPSC 416.name: Distributed Systems
CPSC 416.desc: Concepts and design of distributed systems. Communication architecture and models for interprocess communication. Process migration, naming, distributed file systems, fault tolerance, and concurrency control. [3-0-0]
CPSC 416.prer: One of CPSC 313, EECE 315, CPEN 331 and one of CPSC 317, EECE 358, ELEC 331.

CPSC 418.name: Parallel Computation
CPSC 418.desc: Algorithms, architectures, and programming paradigms for parallel computation.  Shared memory, message passing, and data parallel architectures and programming models.  Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks.  Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs.  Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs. [3-0-0]
CPSC 418.prer: One of CPSC 261, CPSC 313, EECE 476, CPEN 411 and one of CPSC 320, EECE 320.

CPSC 420.name: Advanced Algorithms Design and Analysis
CPSC 420.desc: The study of advanced topics in the design and analysis of algorithms and associated data structures. Topics include algorithms for graph-theoretic; algebraic and geometric problems; algorithms on nonsequential models; complexity issues; approximation algorithms. [3-0-0]

CPSC 421.name: Introduction to Theory of Computing
CPSC 421.desc: Characterizations of computability (using machines, languages and functions). Universality, equivalence and Church's thesis. Unsolvable problems. Restricted models of computation. Finite automata, grammars and formal languages. [3-0-0]
CPSC 421.prer: Either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320. CPSC 320 is recommended.

CPSC 422.name: Intelligent Systems
CPSC 422.desc: Principles and techniques underlying the design, implementation and evaluation of intelligent computational systems. Applications of artificial intelligence to natural language understanding, image understanding and computer-based expert and advisor systems. Advanced symbolic programming methodology. [3-0-0]

CPSC 424.name: Geometric Modeling
CPSC 424.desc: Digital representation of curves and surfaces, including splines, subdivision surfaces and meshes. Principles, algorithms and mathematical foundations for  geometry representation in computer graphics, computer vision, fabrication, CAD/CAM, and medical imaging. Algorithms for acquisition, creation, representation, and processing of 3D shapes. [3-0-1]
CPSC 424.prer: CPSC 320 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

CPSC 444.name: Advanced Methods for Human Computer Interaction
CPSC 444.desc: Design and evaluation methodologies and theories; formal models of the user including visual, motor, and information processing; advanced evaluation methods including laboratory experiments and field studies; HCI research frontiers. [2-2-2]
CPSC 444.prer: All of CPSC 310, CPSC 344 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241.

CPSC 445.name: Algorithms in Bioinformatics
CPSC 445.desc: Sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree reconstruction, prediction of RNA and protein structure, gene finding and sequence annotation, gene expression, and biomolecular computing. [3-0-0]
CPSC 445.prer: CPSC 320 and six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111.
preq: six credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111

CPSC 490.name: Student Directed Seminars
CPSC 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". [3-0-0]

CRWR 201.name: Introduction to Writing Poetry
CRWR 201.desc: An exploration of and practice in the writing of poetry, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of poetry. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 203.name: Introduction to Writing for Children and Young Adults
CRWR 203.desc: Techniques of and practice in creating, developing and writing for children and young adults. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 205.name: Introduction to Writing Creative Nonfiction
CRWR 205.desc: An exploration of and practice in the writing of creative nonfiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of creative nonfiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 206.name: Introduction to Writing for the Screen
CRWR 206.desc: Techniques of and practice in creating, developing, and writing a screenplay. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 208.name: Introduction to Writing for Graphic Forms
CRWR 208.desc: Techniques of and practice in creating, developing, and writing the graphic novel, manga, and other forms of illustrated writing. The ability to draw is not required. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 209.name: Introduction to Writing Fiction
CRWR 209.desc: An exploration of the writing of fiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of fiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 213.name: Introduction to Writing for the New Media
CRWR 213.desc: An exploration of and practice in writing for new media, including podcasting, blogging, and writing for websites, games, and online environments. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 220.name: Introduction to Creative Writing with an Indigenous Focus
CRWR 220.desc: Covers three genres from fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, radio drama, radio feature, or stageplay.

CRWR 230.name: Introduction to Writing for Comedic Forms
CRWR 230.desc: An examination of and practice in creative writing in comedic forms, including stand-up, sketch, film, new media, and text. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 301.name: Intermediate Writing Poetry
CRWR 301.desc: The writing of poetry in various forms using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 302.name: Writing for Podcast
CRWR 302.desc: Exploration of and practice in writing for podcast.

CRWR 303.name: Intermediate Writing for Children and Young Adults
CRWR 303.desc: The writing of work for children and young adults in various forms using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 305.name: Intermediate Writing of Creative Nonfiction
CRWR 305.desc: An exploration of and practice in the writing of creative non-fiction, covering four of the more basic forms of this genre: memoir, profile, commentary, and exposition. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 306.name: Intermediate Writing for the Screen
CRWR 306.desc: An exploration of and practice in writing for the screen, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of screenwriting. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 307.name: Intermediate Writing for the Stage and Radio
CRWR 307.desc: An exploration of practice in the writing of the one-act stage play and short radio drama, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of these dramatic genres. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 308.name: Intermediate Writing for Graphic Forms
CRWR 308.desc: The writing of graphica (comics, manga and graphic novels), using a combination of workshopping and online modules. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 309.name: Intermediate Writing Fiction
CRWR 309.desc: An exploration of the writing of fiction, focusing on how a writer employs the technical elements of the craft of fiction. Manuscript submission not required for admission.

CRWR 310.name: Video Game Writing and Narrative
CRWR 310.desc: Narrative design and writing for video games.

CRWR 311.name: Intermediate Writing for Lyric Forms
CRWR 311.desc: Techniques of and practice in writing for lyric forms, including song lyrics, lyrical narratives, and libretti. Manuscript submission is not required for admission.

CRWR 430.name: Preparation for a Career in Writing

CSIS 200.name: Critical Engagements in Sexuality Studies
CSIS 200.desc: Introductory survey to sexuality studies that emphasizes how sexuality intersects with race, gender, class, ability, and geography.

CSIS 301.name: Introduction to Trans* Studies
CSIS 301.desc: How race, citizenship, gender, sexuality, culture and dis/ability are materially and socially constructed together to give meaning to the category trans*. (Trans*: transgender, transsexual, gender variant and other articulations.)

CSPW 100.name: Coordinated Science Program Workshop
CSPW 100.desc: Students participate in activities related to their CSP courses, including hands-on work, discussion and analysis of scientific topics. Graded Pass/Fail.

DENT 430.name: Dentistry III: Intermediate Clinical Dentistry
DENT 430.desc: A multi-disciplinary course integrating didactic, simulation, clinical, and community service learning. Students function as team members in clinical group practices with individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships.

DENT 440.name: Dentistry IV
DENT 440.desc: A continuing integrated, multi-disciplinary course with ongoing participation in clinical group practices and individual progression through the Clinical Clerkships and community service learning.

DHYG 106.name: Basics of Oral Microbiology
DHYG 106.desc: Basic principles in the study of microorganisms and their relation to human health for dental hygiene students.

DHYG 108.name: Oral Health Sciences I
DHYG 108.desc: An introduction to normal, healthy facial, oral, and dental structures; oral health records, and charting terminology and symbols.

DHYG 110.name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice I
DHYG 110.desc: An introduction to the Dental Hygiene profession, practice roles and the process of care model.

DHYG 208.name: Oral Health Sciences II
DHYG 208.desc: An introduction to desease-related concepts during the study of dental materials, general pathology, plaque biofilm, nutrition, radiology, periodontology, and oral pathology.

DHYG 210.name: Dental Hygiene Theory and Practice II
DHYG 210.desc: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice in clinical and community-based settings.

DHYG 310.name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice III
DHYG 310.desc: The study of dental hygiene theory and practice with emphasis on diverse clients with oral health care needs.

DHYG 325.name: Applied Pharmacology
DHYG 325.desc: Applied pharmacology concepts and principles for the dental health professional.

DHYG 401.name: Oral Epidemiology
DHYG 401.desc: Basic epidemiological and statistical concepts and tests relevant to evidence-based oral health practices.

DHYG 405.name: Oral Microbiology and Immunology
DHYG 405.desc: Microbiology and immunological concepts relevant for dental hygiene practice.

DHYG 406.name: Guided Study in Dental Hygiene
DHYG 406.desc: Conduct an in-depth investigation of a health promotion issue.
DHYG 406.prer: All of DHYG 400, DHYG 401, DHYG 461. And Faculty approval.

DHYG 410.name: Dental Hygiene Theory & Practice IV
DHYG 410.desc: Critical analysis of dental hygiene theory and practice related to diverse clients with complex oral health care needs.

DHYG 412.name: Oral Health Care Trends & Topics
DHYG 412.desc: Critical analysis of health care trends and oral health care delivery with emphasis on underserved diverse populations.

DHYG 433.name: Assessment and Treatment Planning for Advanced Periodontal Diseases
DHYG 433.desc: Available in online distance education format only.

DHYG 435.name: Oral Medicine and Pathology
DHYG 435.desc: Pathobiology of oral diseases. Available in online distance education format only.

ECED 400.name: Introduction to Early Childhood Education and Care

ECED 401.name: Supporting Young Children's Health and Well-Being in Early Childhood Settings

ECED 406.name: Early Learning Curriculum in the Pre-School Years
ECED 406.desc: The development of pre-kindergarten programs with reference to recent research, theories of early learning, and curriculum trends and practices.

ECED 421.name: Supporting Young Children Through Home, School, and Community Relationships

ECED 439.name: Assessment of Infants and Young Children with Special Needs

ECED 440.name: Supporting Social and Communication Development in Infants and Young Children with Special Needs

ECED 441.name: Early Intervention for Infants and Young Children with Sensory Loss and Motor Impairments

ECED 442.name: Supporting Indigenous Infants and Young Children within the Context of Their Communities

EDCP 210.name: Introduction to Music Education
EDCP 210.desc: Role of music education in schools and society, including historical, philosophical, psychological, and sociological perspectives. Includes guided class observations and practice music teaching in elementary and secondary schools. Criminal Record Check required.

EDCP 303.name: Ceramic Design and Pedagogical Approaches: Art Education
EDCP 303.prer: 6 credits of introductory art studio or art history courses.

EDCP 304.name: Textile Design and Pedagogical Approaches: Art Education
EDCP 304.prer: 6 credits of introductory art studio or art history courses.

EDCP 305.name: Digital Media in Arts Education: Introduction

EDCP 306.name: Digital Media in Arts Education: Advanced

EDCP 320.name: Physical Education - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 323.name: Outdoor Environmental Education: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 323.desc: Costs for field trips and an overnight experience are borne by students. Pass/Fail.

EDCP 331.name: Social Studies - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 333.name: Contemporary Issues in Social Studies: Secondary

EDCP 340.name: Mathematics - Elementary and Middle Years: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 354.name: Biological Sciences - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 354.prer: A completed concentration in biological sciences or permission of the Head.
preq: A completed concentration in biological sciences

EDCP 356.name: Earth and Space Science - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 356.prer: A completed concentration in earth and space science or permission of the Head.

EDCP 357.name: Physics - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 357.prer: A completed concentration in physics or permission of the Head.

EDCP 377.name: Design and Technology II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 378.name: Business Education II - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 411.name: Music - Elementary: Advanced Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 411.prer: EDCP 308 or an introductory course in music education.
preq: an introductory course in music education

EDCP 412.name: Conducting and Rehearsal Techniques for Teachers

EDCP 454.name: Chemistry for Teaching: Topics and Pedagogical Approaches - Secondary
EDCP 454.desc: Teacher Education Office approval is required. Open only to secondary students admitted with an academic deficiency. Not for credit toward graduate degree or for undergraduate credit in an academic subject. Pass/Fail.

EDCP 492.name: Special Study in Home Economics: Textile Studies

EDCP 498.name: Curriculum Inquiry in Home Economics Education
EDCP 498.desc: Culminating inquiry in curriculum and pedagogy for the Home Economics Education Diploma.

EDST 493.name: Introduction to the Study of Higher Education
EDST 493.desc: An overview of the field of study of higher education in Canada and other countries emphasizing current issues such as accessibility, enrolment, diversity of offerings, and internationalization. [3-0-0]

ELEC 201.name: Circuit Analysis I
ELEC 201.desc: The fundamentals of analysis of lumped linear time-invariant circuits; network theorems; operational amplifiers; first order circuits; DC analysis of diodes, BJT, and FET circuits.
ELEC 201.prer: MATH 101 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158.

ELEC 202.name: Circuit Analysis II
ELEC 202.desc: Phasor analysis and AC three phase systems power; transfer functions; Bode plots; filters and resonance; Laplace transforms; transformers; two-port networks. First and second order circuits.
ELEC 202.prer: All of PHYS 153, MATH 101 and one of EECE 251, EECE 263, ELEC 201, ELEC 203.

ELEC 203.name: Basic Circuit Analysis
ELEC 203.desc: Ideal passive elements and sources; Kirchhoff's Laws; DC circuits; natural and complete response of first order circuits; operational amplifiers; impedance; phasors; complex power. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

ELEC 204.name: Linear Circuits
ELEC 204.desc: Basic concepts and analysis techniques in the context of electric and electronic circuits including Bode plots and the Laplace transform. Treatment of RLC circuits, phasors, op-amps. Introduction to nonlinear circuit elements, diodes, BJT, FET circuits.
ELEC 204.prer: MATH 152 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 158, PHYS 153.

ELEC 205.name: Electronics Laboratory
ELEC 205.desc: Experiments involving electronic devices and circuits.

ELEC 211.name: Engineering Electromagnetics
ELEC 211.desc: Electrostatics, electric currents, dielectrics, capacitance, electrostatic potential, magnetostatics.
ELEC 211.prer: One of MATH 263, MATH 253 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153, PHYS 158.

ELEC 221.name: Signals and Systems
ELEC 221.desc: Complex numbers, LTI systems, convolution sum, discrete-time Fourier series and transforms, z-transform, sampling, introduction to filtering and modulation, feedback systems, stability.

ELEC 271.name: Selected Topics in Biomedical Engineering
ELEC 271.desc: Effective communication in a multidisciplinary environment, introduction to emerging areas of biomedical engineering and biotechnology, ethics, and responsibility. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering program in Electrical Engineering.

ELEC 281.name: Technical Communication
ELEC 281.desc: Written and oral communication in engineering. Technical description, report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of Electrical and Computer Engineering programs. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 281, CPEN 281, or APSC 201.
ELEC 281.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

ELEC 301.name: Electronic Circuits
ELEC 301.desc: Analysis and design of electronic circuits; biasing of and small-signal models for transistors; frequency response of amplifiers; feedback and stability aspects of amplifier design; OP-AMPs; active filters; oscillators; IC specification and selection. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 356, ELEC 301, and EECE 374.
ELEC 301.prer: Either (a) one of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 263, ELEC 203 and one of EECE 253, ELEC 202;  or (b) one of EECE 252, ELEC 204.

ELEC 302.name: Electronic Circuits for Electromechanical Design
ELEC 302.desc: Semiconductor fundamentals; modelling of electronic devices including diodes and transistors; design of power supplies, waveform generators and logic circuits; signals in time and frequency domains; operational amplifiers; active filters; oscillators; device specification and selection.
ELEC 302.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

ELEC 311.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Waves
ELEC 311.desc: Waves and propagation; Maxwell's equations; applications including transmission lines; impedance matching and Smith charts; reflection and refraction; waveguides and antennas.
ELEC 311.prer: One of EECE 261, ELEC 211 and either (a) all of MATH 101, MATH 263, MATH 265, MATH 267 or (b) all of MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 264, MATH 265, MATH 267 or (c) all of MATH 101, MATH 253, MATH 256, MATH 264.

ELEC 315.name: Electronic Materials and Devices
ELEC 315.desc: Fundamental aspects of electronic materials such as: semiconductors, metals, dielectrics, piezoelectrics, magnetic materials, and their applications in devices such as diodes, transistors, and transducers.

ELEC 321.name: Stochastic Signals and Systems
ELEC 321.desc: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems; discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making. Credit will be granted for only one of ELEC 321 or STAT 357.
ELEC 321.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Electrical and Computer Engineering Student Services.
preq: STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently

ELEC 331.name: Computer Communications
ELEC 331.desc: Analysis, design and implementation of computer networks and their protocols. Application layer protocols, transmission control protocol (TCP), Internet protocol (IP), routing algorithms, reliable data transfer, multiple access, Ethernet.
ELEC 331.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, CPSC 261, EECE 359, EECE 315, CPEN 331.

ELEC 342.name: Electro-Mechanical Energy Conversion and Transmission
ELEC 342.desc: Three phase power; transformers and harmonics; magnetic materials and circuits, electromechanical energy conversion; DC machines; rotating magnetic field, AC induction and synchronous machines; variable frequency operation, brushless DC machines; stepper and single-phase motors. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 373, ELEC 342, and EECE 374.
ELEC 342.prer: PHYS 170 and one of EECE 253, EECE 263, ELEC 202, ELEC 203.

ELEC 343.name: Electromechanics
ELEC 343.desc: Electromechanical energy conversion; linear actuators; torque/speed of rotating devices; reluctance, stepper, permanent-magnet, induction, brushless-DC motors and DC motors; actuator/motor drive circuits/controllers. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 365, ELEC 344, EECE 370, EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374, EECE 376, or ELEC 343.
ELEC 343.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202, EECE 363, ELEC 302.

ELEC 344.name: Applied Electronics and Electromechanics
ELEC 344.desc: Characteristics of semiconductor devices; analog circuits; force and torque production; motor principles and torque-speed characteristics; principles of power electronics. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.
ELEC 344.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201, EECE 263, ELEC 203, MECH 221.

ELEC 352.name: Electric Energy Systems
ELEC 352.desc: Balanced and unbalanced three phase energy systems. Modeling of generators, transmission lines, transformers and loads. High voltage transmission, low voltage industrial and domestic distribution.
ELEC 352.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202 and one of EECE 373, ELEC 342.

ELEC 371.name: Biomedical Engineering Instrumentation
ELEC 371.desc: Theory and experiments involving instruments for general, orthopedic, cardiac and minimally invasive surgery as well as sensors for respiratory, cardiac, bioelectric, biochemical and nervous system measurement. Restricted to students admitted to the Biomedical Engineering option in Electrical Engineering.
ELEC 371.prer: Either (a) all of MATH 265, MATH 267 or (b) MATH 256;  and one of MATH 253, MATH 263;  and either (a) EECE 253 or (b) all of ELEC 202, EECE 259 or (c) all of CPEN 211, EECE 261 or (d) all of ELEC 211, EECE 282 or (e) ELEC 292.

ELEC 401.name: Analog CMOS Integrated Circuit Design
ELEC 401.desc: Design and analysis of analog integrated circuits, with emphasis on CMOS design techniques. Gain stages, opamp design, frequency compensation, oscillators, A/D, D/A converters, PLL, DLL.
ELEC 401.prer: One of EECE 356, ELEC 301, EECE 363, ELEC 302, EECE 374.

ELEC 402.name: Introduction to VLSI Systems
ELEC 402.desc: Static CMOS combinational logic circuits. Standard cells design and layout. Memory element (flip-flop and latch) design. Dynamic logic families. Synchronous logic and timing analysis. Power, scaling, and industry trends. Verification. VHDL/Verilog design, layout and synthesis project using CAD tools.

ELEC 403.name: Advanced Digital VLSI Systems
ELEC 403.desc: Logical effort. Noise in digital systems. Low power techniques. Power distribution. SRAM and DRAM design. Non-volatile memory technologies. High speed adder, multiplier and divider design. Clock Trees. Synchronization and FIFO. Scaling, and industry trends. High-speed circuit design and layout project.

ELEC 404.name: RF Integrated Circuits
ELEC 404.desc: Introduction to radio-frequency (RF) communication systems; matching networks, transceiver architectures, low noise amplifiers, mixers, oscillators, etc.

ELEC 411.name: Antennas and Propagation
ELEC 411.desc: Basic antenna concepts; antennas for low, medium and high frequencies; terrestrial and satellite propagation links; environmental effects on electromagnetic radiation.
ELEC 411.prer: One of EECE 364, ELEC 311, PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

ELEC 412.name: Optical Waveguides and Photonics
ELEC 412.desc: Planar dielectric waveguides; single mode optical fibers; integrated optics waveguides and devices; semiconductor lasers; optical detectors; optical communications links.

ELEC 413.name: Semiconductor Lasers
ELEC 413.desc: An introduction to lasers and applications. Theory, modeling, fabrication and performance of semiconductor lasers. Optical communications links.

ELEC 415.name: Semiconductor Devices: Physics, Design and Analysis
ELEC 415.desc: Physics of operation, and design and analysis of semiconductor devices of topical interest, e.g., solar cells, LEDs, high-speed MOSFETs, high-frequency HBTs, low-noise HEMTs.

ELEC 421.name: Digital Signal and Image Processing
ELEC 421.desc: DSP fundamentals; image processing; signal representation; digital filtering; statistical estimation; DSP applications.
ELEC 421.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359, EECE 369.

ELEC 422.name: Biosignals and Systems
ELEC 422.desc: Data acquisition, time and frequency domain analysis, analog and discrete filter design, sampling theory, time-dependent processing, linear prediction, random signals, biomedical system modeling, and stability analysis; introduction to nonlinear systems.
ELEC 422.prer: One of EECE 331, ELEC 371 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359 and one of CPSC 260, CPSC 259 and one of STAT 251, MATH 318, MATH 302, STAT 302.

ELEC 431.name: Communication Systems I
ELEC 431.desc: Review of probability theory, signals and noise; digital communication over Gaussian noise channels, optimal receiver design, modulation techniques and error performance calculations; measure of information, source coding, symbol and stream codes; channel coding, capacity, simple linear block codes; practical applications.
ELEC 431.prer: One of EECE 269, EECE 359, ELEC 221 and one of EECE 357, ELEC 321, MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 251, STAT 302, STAT 357.

ELEC 432.name: Communication Systems II
ELEC 432.desc: Communication over bandlimited additive white Gaussian noise channels; power spectra of digitally modulated signals; intersymbol interference; cyclic, convolutional, low-density parity check and turbo codes; trellis coded modulation; spread spectrum techniques; security; wireless communication systems and standards; practical applications.

ELEC 433.name: Error Control Coding for Communications and Computers
ELEC 433.desc: Design techniques, including Hamming, BCH, Reed-Solomon, LDPC and convolutional codes, ARQ techniques, and LFSR implementation of encoding-decoding algorithms.

ELEC 434.name: Introduction to Optical Networks
ELEC 434.desc: Wavelength division multiplexing, framing techniques, traffic grooming, virtual topology design, routing and wavelength assignment, protection and restoration, optical packet switching.
ELEC 434.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359, EECE 369.

ELEC 441.name: Control Systems
ELEC 441.desc: Relationships between system parameters and system responses for linear control systems. Design specifications for dynamic and steady-state performance and realization by use of feedback control. Robust design of PID controllers and multivariable controllers.

ELEC 442.name: Introduction to Robotics
ELEC 442.desc: Common manipulator configurations, actuator and sensor technology. Efficient representations and computational methods for real-time microprocessor-based implementation of robot control algorithms. Robot control methods, network equivalents, impedance control. Introduction to teleoperation implementation aspects.

ELEC 451.name: Power Electronics
ELEC 451.desc: Power diodes, thyristors, transistors and FETs; analysis of idealized circuits with generalized loads; AC-DC, DC-DC, DC-AC, AC-AC converters, modulation techniques, gating circuits; practical design and applications.
ELEC 451.prer: One of EECE 356, EECE 365, ELEC 301, ELEC 344, EECE 373, ELEC 342.

ELEC 453.name: Power System Analysis
ELEC 453.desc: Transmission and distribution; phasors, complex power; balanced/unbalanced three-phase operation; symmetrical components, sequence networks; voltage regulation; short circuit capacity; circuit breakers; transmission lines, series/shunt impedance; short, medium, and long line models.

ELEC 454.name: Power System Analysis II
ELEC 454.desc: Power system monitoring/control; large networks; automatic generation control; optimum power flow calculations; traveling wave transmission lines; EMTP and MATLAB programs for transients, short-circuit, and transient stability analysis.

ELEC 455.name: Power Systems Protection
ELEC 455.desc: Analysis of disturbances, security of power systems, cascading and blackouts; role and impact of protection; transducers and measuring elements; protection of transmission and distribution systems; protection of generators, substation equipment, special protection systems and relays.
ELEC 455.prer: One of EECE 458, ELEC 453 and one of EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 374.

ELEC 456.name: Decision Support Methods in Power Systems Operation
ELEC 456.desc: Principles; acceptable regions of operation; energy management systems; load flow methods; static and dynamic security; contingency analysis; transient and voltage stability; on-line stability assessment.

ELEC 457.name: Optimization of Power System Operation
ELEC 457.desc: Application of linear and nonlinear optimization methods in power systems; constrained optimization; optimal power flow; economic dispatch; electricity market; local prices for active and reactive power; security-constrained OPF; state estimation, reliability analysis.

ELEC 461.name: Nanotechnology in Electronics
ELEC 461.desc: Topics of special importance to understanding and designing electronic devices in which quantum effects and the discrete nature of matter become important.
ELEC 461.prer: One of CHEM 312, EECE 352, ELEC 315, PHYS 250, PHYS 304.

ELEC 462.name: Sensors and Actuators in Microsystems
ELEC 462.desc: The mechanisms, design, fabrication, and testing of microsensors, actuators, and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS).

ELEC 463.name: Micro/Nanofabrication and Instrumentation Laboratory
ELEC 463.desc: Microfabrication methods and nanofabrication techniques. Imaging and characterization of micro and nanostructures. Restricted to students admitted to the Nanotechnology and Microsystems Option in Electrical Engineering.

ELEC 465.name: Microsystems Design
ELEC 465.desc: Structured modeling and design practices; multiphysics at microscales; physical limitations in MEMS; interface with electronics; behavioural modeling languages for mixed analog-digital system design. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 489, ELEC 465, or EECE 581.

ELEC 471.name: Medical Imaging
ELEC 471.desc: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, X-ray projection imaging and molecular imaging in medical imaging for diagnostics, therapeutics, and interventions.
ELEC 471.prer: One of EECE 331, ELEC 371 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341 and one of EECE 364, ELEC 311 and one of EECE 269, ELEC 221, EECE 359.

ELEC 473.name: Biological Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems
ELEC 473.desc: Principles of sensors, actuators, microfluidics, biotechnology and nanotechnology, with applications in probing, detection, assaying and drug delivery.

ELEC 474.name: Biophotonics
ELEC 474.desc: Lens theory, light sources and detectors, image resolution and contrast, tissue absorption and scattering, fluorescence, microscopy, spectroscopy, optical imaging systems, and their applications to life sciences and medicine.

ELEC 491.name: Electrical Engineering Capstone Design Project
ELEC 491.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world electrical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ELEC 492.name: Electrical Energy Systems Capstone Design Project
ELEC 492.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world electrical energy systems problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ELEC 493.name: Nanotechnology and Microsystems Capstone Design Project
ELEC 493.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world nanotechnology and microsystems engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ELEC 494.name: Biomedical Engineering Capstone Design Project
ELEC 494.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world biomedical engineering problem, provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

ENDS 101.name: Introductory Workshop
ENDS 101.desc: Week long orientation to the School community, the City and the study of design one week prior to the start of Winter Session Term 1. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 101 or DES 101.

ENDS 110.name: Measured Architectural Drafting
ENDS 110.desc: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing.

ENDS 220.name: Architecture in Context: Vancouver
ENDS 220.desc: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region.

ENDS 221.name: Sustainability by Design
ENDS 221.desc: Introduction to interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs.

ENDS 231.name: Thinking by Design
ENDS 231.desc: Introduction to design thinking through the analysis of architecture, landscape architecture, urban design, and hands-on design projects.

ENDS 301.name: Environmental Design Studio I
ENDS 301.desc: Introduction to the study of relationships of human beings' environments; methods of analysis and composition; physical properties of land, natural and man-made; simple spatial and functional programs deployed in the creation of outdoor spaces.

ENDS 302.name: Environmental Design Studio II
ENDS 302.desc: Expands the terms of the purposeful transformation of "place" to include modifications to the environment at the scale of the individual; concepts of dwelling and habitation; the human body as an instrument of measure, dimension and design of the private realm.

ENDS 320.name: Design, Media and Representation
ENDS 320.desc: Theories, histories and techniques of design representation; geometry, design and expression are principle areas of focus.

ENDS 401.name: Environmental Design Studio III
ENDS 401.desc: The exploration of a complex physical and spatial program for building in the public realm, resulting in an integrative design project.

ENDS 402.name: Environmental Design Studio IV
ENDS 402.desc: Expands the scale and design enquiry to emphasize the relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure, and ecological systems.

ENDS 420.name: Technology and Technique
ENDS 420.desc: Introduction to fundamental design principles and investigations of buildings, landscape, machines and furniture, including structure, enclosure, envelope and detailing.

ENDS 440.name: Environment and Urban Form
ENDS 440.desc: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and livability of cities.

ENGL 100.name: Reading and Writing about Literature
ENGL 100.desc: A writing-intensive introduction to the disciplines of literary studies through the exploration of texts in their critical and theoretical contexts. Fulfils the first-year component of the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement. Open only to students in the Faculty of Arts. Recommended for students intending to become English majors. Essays are required.

ENGL 111.name: Approaches to Non-fictional Prose
ENGL 111.desc: Study of a selection of prose texts ranging in length from the essay to the book, with emphasis on writing of the twentieth century. Essays are required.

ENGL 120.name: Literature and Criticism
ENGL 120.desc: Enriched study of selected works of literature from a number of critical perspectives. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of "A" in English 12 or "B+" in English Literature 12. Essays are required.

ENGL 140.name: Challenging Language Myths
ENGL 140.desc: Critical consideration of a broad range of commonly held beliefs about language and its relation to the brain and cognition, learning, society, change and evolution. Note: This is an elective course that does not fulfill writing requirements in any faculty or the literature requirement in the Faculty of Arts.

ENGL 210.name: An Introduction to English Honours
ENGL 210.desc: For Honours students accepted by the English Honours Committee on the recommendation of the instructor. Students permitted to take this course must take ENGL 211 concurrently.
ENGL 210.prer: Restricted to students in the Honours program.
preq: Restricted to students in the Honours program

ENGL 211.name: Seminar for English Honours
ENGL 211.desc: An introduction to practical criticism; required of and open only to students of ENGL 210. A limited number of texts from a range of genres and periods will be chosen for close critical analysis.

ENGL 221.name: Literature in Britain: the 18th Century to the Present
ENGL 221.desc: A survey of poetry, drama, fiction and non-fiction prose from the 18th century to the present.
ENGL 221.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 223.name: Literature in the United States
ENGL 223.desc: The major types of American writing: fiction, poetry, drama and non-fictional prose.
ENGL 223.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 225.name: Poetry
ENGL 225.desc: Principles, methods, and resources for reading poetry.
ENGL 225.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 226.name: Drama
ENGL 226.desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading drama.
ENGL 226.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 227.name: Prose Fiction
ENGL 227.desc: Principles, methods and resources for reading the novel and the short story.
ENGL 227.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 231.name: Introduction to Indigenous Literatures
ENGL 231.desc: A study of cultural expression in contemporary indigenous contexts.
ENGL 231.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 232.name: Approaches to Media Studies
ENGL 232.desc: Approaches to the study of media: philosophical; technological; cultural; theoretical.
ENGL 232.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 309.name: Rhetoric of Science, Technology, and Medicine
ENGL 309.desc: Exploration of the persuasive dimension of discourse practices in science, technology, and medicine.

ENGL 310.name: History and Theory of Rhetoric: Classical Rhetoric
ENGL 310.desc: Introduction to classical rhetoric with attention to the analysis of present-day texts.

ENGL 311.name: History and Theory of Rhetoric: The Later Theory
ENGL 311.desc: Rhetorical theory from Augustine to the 21st century, emphasizing questions of persuasion in everyday life.

ENGL 318.name: History of the English Language: Early History
ENGL 318.desc: Principles of language change and language typology. The development of the English language from its Indo-European origins to the end of the Anglo-Saxon period.

ENGL 319.name: History of the English Language: Later History
ENGL 319.desc: Principles of language change. The development and spread of the English language from the Norman Conquest to the Modern English period.
ENGL 319.prer: Third-year standing. Knowledge of the International Phonetic Alphabet. ENGL 318 or ENGL 330 or the equivalent is recommended.
preq: Third-year standing. Knowledge of the International Phonetic Alphabet. ENGL 318

ENGL 328.name: Metaphor, Language and Thought
ENGL 328.desc: Exploration of the concepts underlying figurative language (in vocabulary as well as in grammar), using data from both colloquial and literary language.

ENGL 331.name: The Structure of Modern English: Sentences and Their Uses
ENGL 331.desc: An introduction to syntax, pragmatics, and sentence semantics.

ENGL 332.name: Approaches to Media History
ENGL 332.desc: History of media and technological change; literary, rhetorical, or linguistic methods of inquiry.
ENGL 332.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 340.name: Introduction to Old English
ENGL 340.desc: Old English grammar, with readings in the prose of the period.

ENGL 343.name: Old English Literature
ENGL 343.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 358.name: Studies in an Eighteenth-Century Genre
ENGL 358.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 358.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 362.name: Studies in a Nineteenth-Century Genre
ENGL 362.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 362.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 480.name: Asian Canadian and/or Asian Transnational Studies
ENGL 480.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 480.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 489.name: Language Majors Seminar
ENGL 489.desc: Required of all Language Majors.  See department website (http://www.english.ubc.ca/ugrad/majors/compl_lang.htm) for options.

ENGL 490.name: Literature Majors Seminar
ENGL 490.desc: Required of all Literature Majors. See Department Website (www.english.ubc.ca) for options.

ENPH 259.name: Experimental Techniques
ENPH 259.desc: Basic experimental techniques in acquisition, analysis, and presentation and communication of data and technical results. [2-3-0]
ENPH 259.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121 and either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.

ENPH 352.name: Laboratory Techniques in Physics
ENPH 352.desc: Some of the experiments will be based on the lecture material for PHYS 301. Other techniques and subjects will also be covered. [0-3-0]

ENPH 459.name: Engineering Physics Project I
ENPH 459.desc: Project planning, management and reporting. This course involves writing a project proposal, carrying out an open-ended Engineering project, and reporting the results both orally and in writing.

ENPH 479.name: Engineering Physics Project II
ENPH 479.desc: Projects designed to give students research development and design experience. Projects are provided by research faculty in Science and Engineering and from local industry.

ENPH 480.name: Engineering Physics Project III
ENPH 480.desc: An optional course for those students wishing to continue their project work beyond the development in ENPH 479.

ENPH 481.name: Entrepreneurial Projects I
ENPH 481.desc: A project course for students pursuing entrepreneurial training within Engineering Physics, and wishing to further develop projects resulting from ENPH 459.

ENVR 200.name: Introduction to Environmental Science
ENVR 200.desc: Seminars and field trips introducing the major global, regional, and local environmental issues facing human societies. [3-0-0]
ENVR 200.prer: Open to all students with second-year, or higher, standing.
preq: Open to all students with second-year

ENVR 300.name: Introduction to Research in Environmental Science
ENVR 300.desc: Environmental research.  Students investigate research methodologies and reporting in a range of scientific disciplines and fields. [3-0-0]
ENVR 300.prer: Open to all students with third-year, or higher, standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Open to all students with third-year
standing in the Faculty of Science

ENVR 400.name: Community Project in Environmental Science
ENVR 400.desc: Instructor-guided collaboration between student teams and community partners on community-based environmental science projects. Teams articulate project questions and goals, devise methods, conduct research and communicate results. Credit will be given for only one of ENVR 400 or ENVR 449. [3-0-0;3-0-0]

ENVR 420.name: Ecohydrology of Watersheds and Water Systems
ENVR 420.desc: Analysis of water resources from a water-in-ecosystem perspective. Application to natural, managed, and urban systems, considering ecological interactions with hydrological processes. Exploration of biogeochemical processes related to water quality, and human impacts on water resources. [3-0-0]

ENVR 430.name: Ecological Dimensions of Sustainability
ENVR 430.desc: Current issues. Application to agricultural, energy, and resource systems in terrestrial and aquatic contexts. Analysis of complex problems; incorporation of science into novel interdisciplinary solutions. [3-0-0]
ENVR 430.prer: One of ENVR 300, BIOL 230. Or fourth year standing in the BSCN program or other demonstrated ecology background.
preq: BIOL 230. Or fourth year standing in the BSCN program

ENVR 440.name: Analytical Methods in Sustainability Science
ENVR 440.desc: Sustainability analysis through a series of case studies. Example approaches include cost-benefit analysis, trade-offs analysis, and life-cycle analysis. Active learning in a computer lab using real-world data. [2-2-0]
ENVR 440.prer: One of ENVR 200, ASIC 220, SCIE 220, GEOG 211. Third-year standing.

ENVR 449.name: Environmental Science HonoursThesis
ENVR 449.prer: ENVR 300 and fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program.
preq: fourth-year standing in the B.Sc. Environmental Sciences honours program

EOSC 110.name: The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet
EOSC 110.desc: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes.  Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of  the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

EOSC 111.name: Laboratory Exploration of Planet Earth
EOSC 111.desc: An examination of the processes that shape and change the planet earth.  This laboratory course accompanies any of EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116.  Course content is customizable at the individual student level. [0-3-0]
EOSC 111.crer: One of EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116.

EOSC 112.name: The Fluid Earth: Atmosphere and Ocean
EOSC 112.desc: Introduction to processes in ocean and atmosphere. Heat, current, winds, clouds, marine life, resources. Effects of coupling, climate change, pollution. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list, within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-0-0]

EOSC 210.name: Earth Science for Engineers
EOSC 210.desc: Focus on the interaction between society and the geologic environment.  Locating, assessing and developing natural resources; understanding and preparing for natural hazards, design of structures and waste disposal sites.  For applied science and forestry students only. [3-2-0]

EOSC 211.name: Computer Methods in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
EOSC 211.desc: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere. [2-0-2]
EOSC 211.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

EOSC 212.name: Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences
EOSC 212.desc: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.  Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature. [3-0-0]
EOSC 212.prer: Second-year standing in science or engineering.

EOSC 213.name: Computational Methods in Geological Engineering
EOSC 213.desc: Combining basic physical principles with their mathematical description and generating computational models that describe them. Introduction to basic building blocks in modeling, simulation and parameter estimation. [3-1-0]
EOSC 213.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211.

EOSC 220.name: Introductory Mineralogy
EOSC 220.desc: Introduction to crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals. Recognition and identification of common minerals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-3-0]

EOSC 221.name: Introductory Petrology
EOSC 221.desc: Optical mineralogy and the classification and genesis of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks. [2-3-0]

EOSC 222.name: Geological Time and Stratigraphy
EOSC 222.desc: Measuring geological time and understanding Earth history using stratigraphic principles, paleontology and radioactive decay. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-2-0]
EOSC 222.prer: Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1**, EOSC 210, GEOB 103 is recommended.
preq: Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1** EOSC 210 GEOB 103 is recommended

EOSC 223.name: Field Techniques
EOSC 223.desc: Introduction to the techniques of geological mapping and the interpretation of field data. Includes three one-day field trips on weekends plus a seven-day field school after Spring examinations. A fee is to be paid by January 31. [2-2-0]

EOSC 240.name: Site Investigation
EOSC 240.desc: Theory and practice of site investigation for geological engineers, including background studies, field work, remote sensing, development of ground models, importance of geological variability and uncertainty. Impacts on design, project risk and decision making. [2-2-0]

EOSC 250.name: Fields and Fluxes
EOSC 250.desc: Application of classical theory of scalar and vector fields to geophysical sciences. Conductive, convective and radiative energy flux, gravitation, electrostatics, and magnetostatics. Gauss' and Stokes' theorems. [3-0-0]
EOSC 250.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157.
EOSC 250.crer: MATH 200. One of PHYS 102, 108, 118, 158 is recommended.
creq: MATH 200. One of PHYS 102 108 118 158 is recommended

EOSC 270.name: Marine Ecosystems
EOSC 270.desc: Introduction to diversity of marine habitats and ecosystems; hydrothermal vent, intertidal, coral reef, estuarine, deep sea, and polar ecosystems; impacts of ecosystem change; evolution of ocean plankton; invasive species; climate change; pollution. [3-0-0]
EOSC 270.prer: One of SCIE 001, CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154.

EOSC 311.name: The Earth and its Resources
EOSC 311.desc: An introduction to the Earth with emphasis on its industrial and aesthetic resources. Rocks, minerals, gold, diamonds, sediments, fossils, oil and gas, canyons, and volcanoes and the processes that create them. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required. [3-0-0]

EOSC 314.name: The Ocean Environment
EOSC 314.desc: An introduction to the oceans and the processes that have shaped them, their composition and movement, waves, tides, beaches, interactions with the atmosphere and human exploitation of the non-living resources. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required. [3-0-0]

EOSC 320.name: Sedimentology
EOSC 320.desc: Origin, diagenesis and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks. [2-2-0]
EOSC 320.prer: EOSC 221 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

EOSC 321.name: Igneous Petrology
EOSC 321.desc: The origin and formation of igneous rocks. [2-3-0]

EOSC 322.name: Metamorphic Petrology
EOSC 322.desc: Deciphering lithospheric processes as recorded by the mineralogy, chemistry and textures of metamorphosed rocks. [2-3-0]

EOSC 323.name: Structural Geology I
EOSC 323.desc: Analysis and interpretation of natural deformation. [2-3-0]
EOSC 323.prer: All of EOSC 221, EOSC 223 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.

EOSC 328.name: Field Geology
EOSC 328.desc: Recording and processing geological data in the field. Held within the three weeks following April examinations after third year. A special fee is to be paid by January 31.
EOSC 328.prer: All of EOSC 323, EOSC 330 and one of EOSC 321, EOSC 322.

EOSC 329.name: Groundwater Hydrology
EOSC 329.desc: Introduction to theory of groundwater flow; flow nets; regional groundwater resource evaluation; well hydraulics; role of groundwater in geologic processes. [2-3*-3*]
EOSC 329.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

EOSC 330.name: Principles of Geomorphology
EOSC 330.desc: Landform development; morphological and historical analysis of landforms; applications in engineering and resource development. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2-0]

EOSC 331.name: Introduction to Mineral Deposits
EOSC 331.desc: Introduction to economic geology and models related to mineral exploration. Study includes typical deposit types and their plate tectonic setting. [2-3-0]

EOSC 332.name: Tectonic Evolution of North America
EOSC 332.desc: An overview of the geology and tectonic evolution of North America; comparisons and contrasts between Precambrian rocks of the North American craton and Phanerozoic belts of the Cordilleran, Appalachian, Ouachita and Innuitian orogens;  interrelations between sedimentation, deformation, metamorphism and magmatism in a plate tectonic context. [3-0-0]
EOSC 332.prer: EOSC 323 or permission of the instructor.

EOSC 333.name: Elemental and Isotopic Geochemistry
EOSC 333.desc: Analytical methods in geochemistry, major and trace element geochemistry, radiogenic isotopes, geochemistry of seawater, the mantle, basalts, subduction zones, sedimentary rocks, continental crust. [2-3-0]

EOSC 340.name: Global Climate Change
EOSC 340.desc: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global environmental and climate change. [3-0-0]
EOSC 340.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC 350.name: Environmental, Geotechnical, and Exploration Geophysics I
EOSC 350.desc: Principles of geophysical survey design, data acquisition, processing and interpretation with emphasis on near-surface problems. Magnetic, seismic reflection/refraction, electromagnetic and ground penetrating radar surveys. Case history analysis of environmental and geotechnical problems. [3-2-0]
EOSC 350.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and third-year standing or higher in Science or Applied Science.

EOSC 352.name: Geophysical Continuum Dynamics
EOSC 352.desc: Introduction to tensor calculus and continuum mechanics. Stress, strain and strain-rate tensors. Mass, momentum and energy balance. Applications to problems of geophysical heat transport, elasticity and fluid dynamics illustrated using MATLAB. [3-0]

EOSC 353.name: Seismology
EOSC 353.desc: Hooke's law for isotropic continua, elastic wave equation, reflection and refraction methods for imaging the Earth's internal structure, plane waves in an infinite medium and interaction with boundaries, body wave seismology, inversion of travel-time curves, generalized ray theory, crustal seismology, surface waves and earthquake source studies. [3-3*]

EOSC 354.name: Analysis of Time Series and Inverse Theory for Earth Scientists
EOSC 354.desc: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, correlation and convolution, spectral estimates, optimum least-squares filters, deconvolution and prediction, frequency-wave number filtering. A practical course on computer techniques applied to the analysis of a wide range of geophysical phenomena. [3-2-0]
EOSC 354.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157.

EOSC 372.name: Introductory Oceanography: Circulation and Plankton
EOSC 372.desc: Physical and chemical processes and their controls on the distribution of plankton in the ocean. [3-0-0]
EOSC 372.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC 373.name: Introductory Oceanography: Climate and Ecosystems
EOSC 373.desc: Physical, chemical, and biological processes in the ocean and their interaction with climate and marine food-webs. [3-0-0]

EOSC 420.name: Volcanology
EOSC 420.desc: Field and lab-based studies in volcanology concentrating on physical and chemical aspects of volcanic processes. [2-3-0]

EOSC 422.name: Structural Geology II
EOSC 422.desc: Studies of natural deformation using advanced techniques. [2-3-0]

EOSC 424.name: Advanced Mineral Deposits
