EOSC 424.desc: Advanced concepts in the processes that lead to the formation of mineral deposits. Introduction to the study of ore minerals using reflected light microscopy. [2-3-0]

EOSC 425.name: Paleontology
EOSC 425.desc: Paleobiogeography in the context of plate tectonics. Mass extinction events. Fossilization and biases in the fossil record. Species concepts in paleontology. Biostratigraphy. Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates. [2-3-0]

EOSC 428.name: Field Techniques in Groundwater Hydrology
EOSC 428.desc: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Held over five days after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field-school site. Enrolment limitations.
EOSC 428.prer: EOSC 329 or permission of the instructor.

EOSC 429.name: Groundwater Contamination
EOSC 429.desc: Contaminant transport processes in groundwater flow systems; aqueous and multiphase transport; mathematical models describing migration and chemical evolution of contaminant plumes; case studies. [2-2-0]

EOSC 430.name: Aqueous Geochemistry
EOSC 430.desc: Quantitative approaches to practical aqueous geochemistry problems. Equilibrium thermodynamics, kinetics, complexation, oxidation reduction, cation exchange, sorption and partitioning of organics. Case Studies. [2-2-0]
EOSC 430.prer: Either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) CHEM 154.

EOSC 433.name: Geological Engineering Practice I - Rock Engineering
EOSC 433.desc: Application of rock mechanics, hydrogeology, and engineering design tools in realistically complex geological environments. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty, and use of field data, geotechnical monitoring, and numerical analyses for tunnelling, mining and rock slope engineering projects. Case histories. [2-2-0]

EOSC 434.name: Geological Engineering Practice II - Soil Engineering
EOSC 434.desc: Application of geomorphology, hydrogeology, and soil mechanics to geotechnical design. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty in geotechnical hazard and risk assessments; multi-disciplinary approaches to geotechnical engineering problems in realistically complex geological environments. Case histories. [2-2-0]

EOSC 442.name: Climate Measurement and Analysis
EOSC 442.desc: Local climate time series collection and analysis. Retrieval and analysis of on-line climate data and model output. [0-3-0]
EOSC 442.prer: EOSC 340 and one of CPSC 110, CPSC 301, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, BIOL 300.

EOSC 445.name: Engineering Design Project
EOSC 445.desc: Geological engineering design project from scope definition to final design.  Based on a problem from industry. [2*-3-0, 2*-3-0]

EOSC 450.name: Potential Fields in Earth and Planetary Sciences
EOSC 450.desc: Theory, application and quantitative interpretation of potential field methods in Earth and planetary sciences. Topics drawn from problems in geophysical exploration, geodesy, geodynamics of the planets, geomagnetism, planetary magnetic fields, heat flow and fluid flow. [3-0-0]
EOSC 450.prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316, MATH 257 and one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, SCIE 001.

EOSC 453.name: Physics of the Earth and Other Planets
EOSC 453.desc: Identification and quantitative analysis of diverse physical problems in the earth, ocean, atmospheric, and planetary sciences. [3-0-0]

EOSC 454.name: Applied Geophysics
EOSC 454.desc: Using geophysics to characterize the Earth's subsurface for resource exploration, engineering, or environmental applications. Data acquisition, processing, and interpretation of geophysical surveys. Inversion examples drawn from potential (electrical, magnetic, gravity) or wave field (seismic, ground penetrating radar) surveys. [3-2-0]
EOSC 454.prer: All of EOSC 352, EOSC 353, EOSC 450 and one of PHYS 301, PHYS 354.

EOSC 470.name: Biological Oceanography
EOSC 470.desc: A quantitative examination of processes regulating the abundance, distribution and production of phytoplankton, zooplankton, microbes and fish. Controls of primary and secondary production, ecosystem dynamics and foodwebs. [3-0-0]

EOSC 471.name: Waves, Currents and Ocean Mixing
EOSC 471.desc: Use of observations, theory and model results to solve physical oceanographic problems including applications to transport and mixing of pollutants or nutrients. [3-0-0]
EOSC 471.prer: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, EOSC 372, GEOB 200 and one of SCIE 001, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC 472.name: Chemical Oceanography and Marine Geochemistry
EOSC 472.desc: Controls on chemical composition and elemental distributions in seawater and marine sediments (including nutrient elements, dissolved gases, the carbonate system, marine organic matter, and trace metals); solution chemistry of seawater; isotopic tracers of rates and dates in marine systems; geochemical balance in the oceans. [3-0-2*]

EOSC 473.name: Methods in Oceanography
EOSC 473.desc: Methods of data acquisition, study and analysis required in solving oceanographic problems. Includes a field school held during the mid-term break. A fee is to be paid by January 31. Open to third- and fourth-year students in Oceanography, or with permission of the Department Head. [0-3-0]

EOSC 474.name: Marine Pollution
EOSC 474.desc: An interdisciplinary study of pollution, with examples drawn from coastal and oceanic environments, including areas of local interest. Intended for third and fourth year students with a background in the sciences. [3-0-0]

EOSC 475.name: Marine Microbiology
EOSC 475.desc: Advanced biology, ecology and diversity of marine microbes. Emphasis on the roles of bacteria and viruses in marine foodwebs and geochemical cycles. [3-0-0]
EOSC 475.prer: A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses.
preq: A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses

EOSC 478.name: Introduction to Fisheries Science
EOSC 478.desc: An introduction to the ecology and management of freshwater and marine fisheries. Topics include: population dynamics, species interactions, communities, environmental influences, stock assessment, economics and sociology of fisheries. Laboratories will consist of numerical analyses and simulations. [2-0-3]

EPSE 311.name: Cultivating Supportive School and Classroom Environments

EPSE 411.name: Augmentative and Alternative Communication for Individuals with Severe Speech and/or Physical Impairments

EPSE 431.name: Programming for Children with Specific Learning Disabilities
EPSE 431.desc: Methods and programs for learning disabilities are reviewed. Practical experience in the development and execution of a remedial program is required. [3-0]

EPSE 481.name: Introduction to Research in Education
EPSE 481.desc: The nature of scientific study and essentials of survey, experimental and other empirical research designs. Designed for students proceeding to graduate work.
EPSE 481.prer: EPSE 482. May also be taken as a corequisite.
preq: EPSE 482. May also be taken as a corequisite

FIPR 101.name: Introduction to the History of Film Production
FIPR 101.desc: The history of film and film production by decade with a strong emphasis on filmmakers and advances in production technology.

FIPR 131.name: Introduction to Screen Acting
FIPR 131.desc: Fundamental techniques used to create emotionally engaged and narratively effective performances for film and digital media.

FIPR 133.name: Introduction to Film and Media Production
FIPR 133.desc: A hands-on introduction to Film and Multi/New Media production, focusing on fundamental techniques for creating effective presentations.

FIPR 230.name: Introduction to Motion Picture Directing
FIPR 230.desc: The role and methods of the motion picture director.

FIPR 233.name: Film and Media Production I
FIPR 233.desc: Camera operation, lighting, sounds, and editing for film and media production.

FIPR 234.name: Production Planning and Professional Practices
FIPR 234.desc: Planning of film productions from concept to completion.

FIPR 333.name: Film and Media Production II
FIPR 333.desc: Intermediate film and media production. Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program. Students who have not already completed FIPR 337, FIPR 338 must complete them at the same time as FIPR 333.

FIPR 337.name: Cinematography and Lighting I
FIPR 337.desc: Introductory cinematography and lighting techniques and aesthetics for 16mm film and digital media.

FIPR 338.name: Motion Picture Sound
FIPR 338.desc: An introduction to the technique and aesthetics of creating production and post-production sound for film and media.

FIPR 339.name: Post-Production Techniques I
FIPR 339.desc: Open only to students in the Film Production BFA Program.

FIPR 434.name: Producing for Film and Television
FIPR 434.desc: The creative and business aspects of producing for film and television.

FIPR 437.name: Cinematography II
FIPR 437.desc: Advanced camera operation, lighting, and shot design. Open only to students in the FILM BFA Program.

FIPR 439.name: Post-Production Techniques II
FIPR 439.desc: Advanced instruction in motion picture and sound editing practice. Open only to students in FILM BFA Production Program.

FIST 100.name: Introduction to Film Studies
FIST 100.desc: Basic aesthetic, economic, sociological, and technological aspects of film.

FIST 200.name: Introduction to Canadian Cinema
FIST 200.desc: History and aesthetics of Canadian cinema.

FIST 210.name: Early Cinema
FIST 210.desc: Aesthetics, economics, history, and technological characteristics of international early film.

FIST 220.name: Hollywood Cinema 1930-1960
FIST 220.desc: Analysis of the aesthetics, economics, history and technological characteristics of the Classical Hollywood period.

FIST 230.name: Introduction to Asian Cinema
FIST 230.desc: Overview of the cinemas of China, India, Japan, and Korea.

FIST 240.name: Media Industries
FIST 240.desc: Overview of today's film and media industries, and of the concepts governing their practices.

FIST 331.name: Studies in Film Theory
FIST 331.desc: A seminar introducing the many theoretical approaches to film: formalist, historical, Marxist, psychoanalytic, semiotic, and structuralist.

FIST 334.name: Seminar in Documentary
FIST 334.desc: An analysis of the representational strategies and ethics of the form.

FIST 336.name: Seminar in European Cinema
FIST 336.desc: Topics may include a study of a European national cinema.

FIST 338.name: Asian and Australasian Cinema
FIST 338.desc: Topics may include an analysis of a national cinema, such as that of China, India, or Australia.

FIST 340.name: Media Audiences
FIST 340.desc: Overview of approaches for studying audiences and receptions of film and contemporary media.

FIST 436.name: Seminar in American Cinema Since 1960
FIST 436.desc: Topics may include an analysis of a specific period.

FIST 449.name: Honours Essay
FIST 449.desc: A course allowing honours students to work with a faculty member on a major research paper.

FMST 238.name: Family Resource Management
FMST 238.desc: Conceptual models of resource management as related to families.

FNEL 101.name: Introduction to a Salish Language I
FNEL 101.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed.

FNEL 102.name: Introduction to a Salish Language II
FNEL 102.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

FNEL 141.name: Introduction to a Wakashan Language I
FNEL 141.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 142.name: Introduction to a Wakashan Language II
FNEL 142.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 180.name: Introduction to Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
FNEL 180.desc: Foundational concepts in the critical study of cultural, historical, social, and political factors that impact language loss, retention, and revival. Introducing strategies and practical methodologies for collaborative, interdisciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization projects for First Nations and Indigenous languages.

FNEL 201.name: Intermediate Salish Language I
FNEL 201.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context.

FNEL 202.name: Intermediate Salish Language II
FNEL 202.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use.

FNEL 281.name: Sounds of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
FNEL 281.desc: Development of skills in the perception and transcription of speech sounds in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. Capacity-building techniques for digital recording, editing, analysis, and archiving; guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

FNEL 282.name: Structures of Endangered Languages: Conservation and Revitalization
FNEL 282.desc: Development of skills in the documentation, transcription and analysis of grammatical structures in endangered languages, focusing on the diversity within BC Aboriginal languages. Applied techniques in documentation, workflow and multi-media digital annotation, guided by community-based ethical protocols and conservation/revitalization goals.

FNEL 380.name: Technologies for Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
FNEL 380.desc: Digital tools for endangered language documentation, conservation, and revitalization. Overview of best practices, introduction to community engagement and capacity-building, protocols and ethics, project design, cultural context, orthographies, use of audio, video and still photography, data management, archiving and web publishing.

FNEL 381.name: Biocultural Diversity: Language, Community, and Environment
FNEL 381.desc: Critical exploration of the links between linguistic, biological and cultural diversity; including connections with linguistic relativity, linguistic identity, language and place; and strategies for collective, interdisciplinary action to promote and support the protection of languages, cultures, and the environment.

FNEL 482.name: Applied Research in Endangered Language Reclamation
FNEL 482.desc: Application of research skills and methodologies in the design and implementation of a research project relevant to endangered language conservation and/or revitalization. Project co-constructed in collaboration with a First Nations community, guided by community-based ethical protocols. FNEL 481 recommended.
FNEL 482.crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282, FNEL 389. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 482.
creq: FNEL 389. Corequisites can be taken either alongside

FNH 300.name: Principles of Food Engineering
FNH 300.desc: Units and dimensions, mass balance, energy balance, steady state and transient heat flow, fluid handling and measurement. [3-0-1]

FNH 301.name: Food Chemistry I
FNH 301.desc: Constituents of food and related chemical physical properties including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals, and vitamins. [3-0-1]
FNH 301.prer: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

FNH 302.name: Food Analysis
FNH 302.desc: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data. [3-0-1]
FNH 302.prer: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

FNH 303.name: Food Product Development
FNH 303.desc: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.
FNH 303.prer: One of LFS  252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200.

FNH 309.name: Food Process Science
FNH 309.desc: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions. [3-0-1]

FNH 313.name: Microorganisms in Food Systems
FNH 313.desc: Microorganisms of importance in safety, spoilage and preservation of foods; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in fermented food systems; food processing plant cleaning and sanitation. [3-0-0]

FNH 325.name: Food Science Laboratory I
FNH 325.desc: Integrated laboratory introducing techniques used in food processing and analysis. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. [0-3-1]
FNH 325.prer: All of FNH  300, FNH  301, FNH  302. These courses can be taken as corequisites.
preq: FNH 302. These courses can be taken as corequisites

FNH 326.name: Food Science Laboratory II
FNH 326.desc: Integrated laboratory encompassing the processing and analysis of foods.  Enrolment restricted to Food Science students. [0-3-1]

FNH 335.name: Introduction to Wine Science II
FNH 335.desc: Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis. [3-1-0]
FNH 335.prer: FNH  330 and third-year standing or higher.

FNH 340.name: Food Theory
FNH 340.desc: Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food.
FNH 340.prer: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

FNH 341.name: Food Theory Applications
FNH 341.desc: Experimental and practical application of scientific principles and theories to problems of food preparation. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe I certificate.

FNH 342.name: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
FNH 342.desc: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces. [3-0-0]
FNH 342.prer: At least third year standing required.
preq: At least third year standing required

FNH 350.name: Fundamentals of Nutrition
FNH 350.desc: Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism. [3-0-0]
FNH 350.prer: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

FNH 351.name: Vitamins, Minerals, and Health
FNH 351.desc: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health. [3-0-0]
FNH 351.prer: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

FNH 370.name: Nutrition Assessment
FNH 370.desc: The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations. [3-0-0]

FNH 371.name: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
FNH 371.desc: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span. 3-0-0

FNH 380.name: Professional Dietetic Practice I
FNH 380.desc: Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.

FNH 398.name: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
FNH 398.desc: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program. [3-0-0]
FNH 398.prer: FNH  250 and either (a) LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

FNH 402.name: Functional Foods and Nutraceuticals
FNH 402.desc: Functional food and nutraceutical concepts related to ingredient safety and quality; examples of nutrient-disease relationships, requirements for standards of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional food and nutraceutical industries. [3-0-0]

FNH 403.name: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
FNH 403.desc: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance. [3-0-1]
FNH 403.prer: LFS  252 or equivalent background in statistics.

FNH 405.name: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
FNH 405.desc: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake).
FNH 405.prer: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, BIOL 201, BIOL 203, BIOC 203. Third-year standing.

FNH 413.name: Food Safety
FNH 413.desc: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.

FNH 415.name: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
FNH 415.desc: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
FNH 415.prer: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.
preq: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land

FNH 425.name: Food Science Laboratory III
FNH 425.desc: Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry. [0-3-1]

FNH 436.name: Integrated Functional Genomics
FNH 436.desc: Global transcript, protein and metabolite profiling technologies, their integration, application, and furtherance of our understanding of how higher organisms function in general.

FNH 440.name: Food Service Systems Management
FNH 440.desc: Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate.

FNH 451.name: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
FNH 451.desc: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism. [3]

FNH 455.name: Applied International Nutrition
FNH 455.desc: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

FNH 470.name: Foundations of Nutrition Care I
FNH 470.desc: Etiology and pathophysiology of and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions, and skill development related to the Nutrition Care Process. Restricted to students in year 4 of the Dietetics Major.

FNH 472.name: Maternal and Fetal Nutrition
FNH 472.desc: Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply. [3-0-0]

FNH 473.name: Applied Public Health Nutrition
FNH 473.desc: Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health. [3-0-0]

FNH 474.name: Sport Nutrition
FNH 474.desc: Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

FNH 475.name: Foundations of Nutrition Care II
FNH 475.desc: Etiology and pathophysiology of and nutrition therapy for additional diseases and conditions, and further skill development related to the Nutrition Care Process. Restricted to students in year 4 of the Dietetics Major.

FNH 477.name: Nutrition and Disease Prevention
FNH 477.desc: Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease. [3-0-0]

FNH 481.name: Dietetic Internship I
FNH 481.desc: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.
FNH 481.prer: Fifth-year standing in the Dietetics Major.
preq: Fifth-year standing in the Dietetics Major

FNH 482.name: Dietetic Internship II
FNH 482.desc: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

FNIS 100.name: Indigenous Foundations
FNIS 100.desc: The historical, cultural, political, economic and legal issues that inform the experiences of Indigenous peoples in Canada, examined from both Indigenous and non-Indigenous perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 100, FNSP 100, or FNSP 200.

FNIS 210.name: Indigenous Politics and Self-Determination
FNIS 210.desc: The cultural, historical, political, economic, and gender dynamics that structure the relationship between Indigenous peoples and the state in Canada; Indigenous self-determination struggles in relation to constitutional recognition, self-government, land claims, and economic development. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, or FNSP 210.

FNIS 220.name: Representation and Indigenous Cultural Politics
FNIS 220.desc: Representation, identity, and cultural politics through Indigenous literature, film, and the visual arts; the relationship between these sites of cultural production and the self-determination struggles of Indigenous peoples. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 200, FNIS 220, or FNSP 220.

FNIS 310.name: Critical Indigenous Theory Seminar
FNIS 310.desc: Adapting and integrating current conceptual paradigms in the humanities, social sciences, performing arts, and Indigenous studies into approaches in First Nations/Indigenous Studies, including identity construction, political and cultural self-determination, representation, essentialism/authenticity, ethics, and decolonization. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 310 or FNSP 310.
FNIS 310.prer: Either (a) FNSP 200 or (b) all of FNIS 210, FNIS 220 or (c) all of FNSP 210, FNSP 220.

FNIS 320.name: Critical Indigenous Methodologies and Ethics
FNIS 320.desc: Responsible and community-based research from a critical Indigenous perspective; methods for identifying and assessing research materials, critical analysis, oral history/qualitative research interviewing and analysis, and research ethics in the design and implementation of community-based student research projects. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 320 or FNSP 320.

FNIS 400.name: Practicum/Advanced Research Seminar
FNIS 400.desc: Applied research/community oriented project designed and implemented in collaboration with student, faculty and Aboriginal community organization. Emphasis on examining ethical issues and developing culturally respectful and academically rigorous forms of research. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 400 or FNSP 400.
FNIS 400.prer: Either (a) all of FNIS 310, FNIS 320 or (b) all of FNSP 310, FNSP 320. Students must pass FNIS 320 or FNSP 320 with a B- or higher or request program approval.

FNIS 451.name: Indigenous Feminisms
FNIS 451.desc: The historical, cultural, political, and activist roots of contemporary Indigenous feminisms. Indigenous feminist methodologies, theory, and praxis in relation to contemporary Indigenous politics and social justice movements. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401D, FNIS 451, or FNSP 451.
FNIS 451.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or third-year standing.

FNIS 453.name: Indigenous Legal Traditions
FNIS 453.desc: Socio-historical, political and cultural context of Indigenous legal traditions and strategies for ethical engagement within state and Indigenous polities. Methods include oral history analysis, legal theory, literary/narrative studies, and philosophy from an Indigenous studies perspective.
FNIS 453.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or 3rd year standing.

FNIS 454.name: Indigenous New Media
FNIS 454.desc: New media and digital storytelling works designed and implemented by Indigenous artists, authors, and programmers.
FNIS 454.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220, or third year standing.

FNIS 455.name: Indigenous Geographies: Our Home on Native Land
FNIS 455.desc: Indigenous people's place-based relations, colonial processes of de-territorialization, and spatial negotiations of settler colonialism.
FNIS 455.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220, or third year standing.

FOPR 264.name: Geomatics, Forest Access and Transportation
FOPR 264.desc: Geomatics, the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability. [2-4-0]

FOPR 362.name: Forest Harvesting Systems
FOPR 362.desc: The mechanics and productivity of a broad range of forest harvesting systems. [3-0-1]

FOPR 388.name: Analytical Methods in Forest Hydrology
FOPR 388.desc: Analytical methods in forest hydrology and their applications in the planning of forest operations with a focus on the hydrologic and hydraulic design procedures for stream crossings. [3-2]

FOPR 459.name: Economics, Contracts, and Finances in Forest Operations
FOPR 459.desc: A capstone project-based course with applications of engineering economics, contract preparation, and financial planning in the context of Forest Operations. [2-2]

FOPR 464.name: Forestry Machines
FOPR 464.desc: A detailed examination of the performance of heavy trucks used in forestry plus highlights of particular aspects of the performance of hydraulic tracked machines and cable logging machines. [2-2-0]

FRE 295.name: Managerial Economics
FRE 295.desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 201, ECON 206, FRE 295, COMM 295. [3-0-0]
FRE 295.prer: Either (a) ECON 100 or (b) all of ECON 101, ECON 102;  and MATH 105.

FRE 302.name: Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
FRE 302.desc: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally. [3-0-1]

FRE 306.name: Introduction to Global Food Markets
FRE 306.desc: An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies. [3-0-1]

FRE 340.name: International Agricultural Development
FRE 340.desc: Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment. [3-0]

FRE 374.name: Land and Resource Economics
FRE 374.desc: Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity. [3-0]

FRE 385.name: Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
FRE 385.desc: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management. [2-1-0]
FRE 385.prer: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of LFS  252, BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200.

FRE 420.name: The Economics of International Trade and the Environment
FRE 420.desc: Market failure and gains from trade in the presence of natural resource externalities; the multilateral trading system and the environment; case studies in trade-related environmental impacts. [3-0]
FRE 420.prer: One of ECON 301, FRE  295, COMM 295 or 6 credits of upper-level FRE or ECON.

FRE 460.name: Economics of Food Consumption
FRE 460.desc: Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics. [3-0]

FRE 490.name: Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics

FREN 122.name: Contemporary French Language and Literature I
FREN 122.desc: A review of French grammar and an introduction to contemporary literature written in French, with emphasis on essay writing and textual analysis.
FREN 122.prer: One of FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.

FREN 123.name: Contemporary French Language and Literature II
FREN 123.desc: Continuation of FREN 122 with emphasis on literature, essay writing and textual analysis.
FREN 123.prer: FREN 122 or assignment based on placement test.

FREN 124.name: Keeping Up Your French
FREN 124.desc: Task-based entry-level course for non-specialists. Credits from this course may not count towards a Major or Minor in French, nor as prerequisite to subsequent core courses in French.
FREN 124.prer: One of FREN 12, FREN 112 or equivalent.

FREN 215.name: Oral French Practice
FREN 215.desc: Opportunities for students already well-grounded in grammar to improve their oral skills. Credit will not be given for both FREN 215 and FREN 224 or FREN 225.

FREN 221.name: Introduction to Modern Literature written in French and to Textual Analysis
FREN 221.desc: Students will familiarize themselves with techniques of literary analysis, as applied to representative works from the 18th century to the present, including theatre, fiction, poetry and non-fiction prose.  To be taken by all students intending to proceed to the Minor, Major or Honours program.
FREN 221.prer: FREN 123 or assignment based on placement test.

FREN 222.name: French Language and Style I
FREN 222.desc: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context.
FREN 222.prer: FREN 123. Or assignment based on placement test.
preq: FREN 123. Or assignment based on placement test

FREN 223.name: French Language and Style II
FREN 223.desc: Grammar, vocabulary, composition, language in context.
FREN 223.prer: FREN 222. Or assignment based on placement test.
preq: FREN 222. Or assignment based on placement test

FREN 224.name: An Interdisciplinary Approach to French I
FREN 224.desc: French language for ex-immersion students. Credit will not be granted for both FREN 215 and FREN 224. Not available for credit to anyone who has received credit for FREN 222.

FREN 225.name: An Interdisciplinary Approach to French II
FREN 225.desc: French language for ex-immersion students. Credit will not be granted for both FREN 215 and FREN 225. Not available for credit to anyone who has received credit for FREN 223.

FREN 329.name: Selected Works of European French Literature
FREN 329.desc: Representative works viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

FREN 330.name: Selected Works of Quebecois Literature
FREN 330.desc: Representative works viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

FREN 334.name: French Civilization II
FREN 334.desc: A historically based approach to French civilization and culture from the Third Republic to the present, completed by a thematic study of contemporary French culture.
FREN 334.prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223 or permission of the instructor.

FREN 351.name: Corrective French Phonetics
FREN 351.desc: Theory and practice of French pronunciation, corrective phonetics; foundation for the phonetic transcription of international French.

FREN 353.name: French Grammar
FREN 353.desc: Systematic study of the fundamental principles of French grammar.

FREN 355.name: Advanced Composition
FREN 355.desc: Development of essay writing skills in French.

FREN 370.name: Introduction to French Linguistics
FREN 370.desc: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French linguistics, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced language study in French.

FREN 371.name: Introduction to French Literary Theory and Methodology
FREN 371.desc: A survey of basic terminology, methods, problems, and theoretical trends in French literary criticism, specifically designed to provide students with a foundation for advanced study of literature in French.

FRST 100.name: Sustainable Forests
FRST 100.desc: An overview of forests and forestry.  Survey of the disciplines, areas of study, and values that frame sustainable management of forests in BC and the world.  Assignments focus on critical thinking and written communication skills. [3-0-0]

FRST 200.name: Forest Plant Biology I
FRST 200.desc: The structure, diversity and development of trees and other plants, with emphasis on the angiosperms. [3-2-0]

FRST 201.name: Forest Ecology
FRST 201.desc: The structure and function of forest ecosystems, including: energetics; productivity; nutrient, carbon and water cycling; soils; the physical environment; population and community ecology; disturbance ecology; ecological succession; biological diversity and ecological resilience. [3-2-0]

FRST 202.name: Forest Ecology
FRST 202.desc: The Ecosystem concept; energy biomass and nutrient cycling; the physical environment; population and community ecology; succession, Biogeoclimatic classification and some coastal ecosystems. Available only through Distance Education. [3-2]

FRST 210.name: Forest Plant Biology II
FRST 210.desc: The functional biology of trees and other forest plants in their environment, with an emphasis on gymnosperms. [3-2-0]

FRST 211.name: Forest Classification and Silvics
FRST 211.desc: Forest classification and the application of silvics in forest management, including world forest classification systems, the Biogeoclimactic Ecosystem Classification system, and ecosystem diagnosis in the field. [3-2-0]

FRST 232.name: Computer Applications in Forestry
FRST 232.desc: Techniques involved in solving forestry problems with microcomputers using word processing, spreadsheet, procedural language, and database management tools. [3-2]

FRST 239.name: Tree and Stand Level Measurements
FRST 239.desc: An introduction to measurement of individual trees and stands; use of aerial photographs, maps, and various measurement instruments. [3-2-0]

FRST 270.name: Community Forests and Community Forestry
FRST 270.desc: Community forests and community forestry throughout the world, with special attention to participation by aboriginal peoples; emphasis is on forms of governance, public participation, and adaptive learning. [3-0-0]

FRST 302.name: Forest Genetics
FRST 302.desc: Population genetics and conservation of genetic resources; principles of genetics and their application to forestry. [2-2]

FRST 303.name: Principles of Forest Science
FRST 303.desc: Introduction to growth of trees and forests with emphasis on evolutionary, ecological and environmental aspects. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry. [3-0-0]

FRST 304.name: The Science Underlying Forestry Issues
FRST 304.desc: Examination of current forestry issues with specific reference to their scientific basis. Not available for credit to undergraduate students in the Faculty of Forestry. [3-0-0]

FRST 305.name: Silviculture
FRST 305.desc: Silviculture concepts and principles; stand dynamics; artificial and natural regeneration; cultural techniques for forest stand establishment and stand tending; silvicultural systems; decision making and development of prescriptions; connections to forest planning. [3-4*]

FRST 308.name: Forest Entomology
FRST 308.desc: An introduction to insects that cause damage to forests and forest products; how insects live; life cycles and attack symptoms of representatives of major groups of insects; principles for control and management. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST 309.name: Forest Pathology
FRST 309.desc: Biology and management of forest tree diseases. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST 310.name: Soil Biology
FRST 310.desc: The diversity and interactions of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; responses to environmental change. [2-3-0]

FRST 311.name: Plant Physiology I
FRST 311.desc: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. CHEM 203, CHEM 213, or CHEM 233 and CHEM 235  is recommended. [3-3-0]

FRST 318.name: Forest and Conservation Economics
FRST 318.desc: Practical problem solving of economic issues related to forestry and conservation, touching on investment analysis, capital budgeting, non-timber economics, ecosystem services, and forest certification. Completion of FRST 232 or intermediate knowledge of MS Excel essential. [2-3-0]

FRST 319.name: Principles of Forestry Economics
FRST 319.desc: Introduction to the economics of production, distribution and consumption of goods and services produced by, and dependent on, the forest resource. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST 320.name: Abiotic Disturbances: Fire and Climate
FRST 320.desc: Ecological effects of fire and climatic (wind, temperature, and snow) disturbances; fire danger rating, principles of fire management and prescribed fire use; windthrow risk modeling and management. [3-2-0]

FRST 339.name: Forest Level Measurement and Productivity
FRST 339.desc: Obtaining and forecasting information for stands and forests. [3-2-0]

FRST 351.name: Interior Field School
FRST 351.desc: Field study at an interior BC location concentrating on land use, management and silviculture. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.

FRST 385.name: Watershed Hydrology
FRST 385.desc: Measurement and analysis of hydrological processes in response to forest management activities. [3-2-0]

FRST 386.name: Aquatic Ecosystems and Fish in Forested Watersheds
FRST 386.desc: Effects of forest management activities on fish and aquatic ecosystems. [3-2-0]
FRST 386.prer: Third- or fourth-year standing in Forestry, Science or Applied Science.

FRST 395.name: Forest Wildlife Ecology and Management
FRST 395.desc: Biology of important bird and mammal species resident in forested regions, with particular emphasis on the influences of silvicultural and logging practices. [3-2-0]

FRST 399.name: Introduction to Research Methods
FRST 399.desc: Lectures and seminars in research philosophies and the scientific method, with special emphasis on field research. [2-1]

FRST 408.name: Problems of Forest Entomology
FRST 408.desc: Decision-making in the protection of forests from insects. Insect problems viewed from other disciplines of forestry. Bases of biological and economic evaluation, and choice of control methods. [2-2]

FRST 411.name: Complex Adaptive Systems, Global Change Science, and Ecology Sustainability
FRST 411.desc: Concepts of complex adaptive systems (CAS); exploration of how CAS can be used to manage natural and social environments for multiple goals under changing climatic and socio-economic conditions. [3-0-0]

FRST 413.name: Ecological Plant Biochemistry
FRST 413.desc: The structure, biosynthesis, distribution and biological function of secondary plant metabolites. [3-0-0]
FRST 413.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201 and one of BIOL 209, BIOL 210;  or (b) all of FRST 200, FRST 210.

FRST 415.name: Sustainable Forest Policy
FRST 415.desc: The development, implementation, and analysis of forest policy. [3-0-0]

FRST 421.name: Quantitative Forest Management
FRST 421.desc: Introduction to the quantitative tools necessary in forest management. Available only through Distance Education.

FRST 424.name: Sustainable Forest Management
FRST 424.desc: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of forest management.
FRST 424.prer: Fourth year standing in the B.S.F. program.
preq: Fourth year standing in the B.S.F. program

FRST 430.name: Advanced Biometrics
FRST 430.desc: Analysis of variance, multiple regression and analysis of covariance. Design and analysis of experiments. [3-2]

FRST 439.name: International Forestry
FRST 439.desc: The socio-economic, biological and technological aspects of forestry within the international frame, in both the developed and developing world. Regional studies and the role of national and international agencies. [2-2-0]

FRST 443.name: Remote Sensing for Ecosystem Management
FRST 443.desc: Basic biological concepts related to interpretation of remote sensing data for land management, including the use of films and filters, and interpretation of air photographs, and other imagery. [2-2-0]

FRST 444.name: Agroforestry
FRST 444.desc: Integration of farms and forests, including tropical agroforestry systems, non-timber forest products, forest farming, woodlot management, silvopastoralism, riparian buffers, windbreaks, soil fertility improvement and nutrient cycling. [3-2-0]

FRST 452.name: Coastal Field School
FRST 452.desc: Site diagnosis and preparation of management options in coastal forests. Extrasessional course; fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
FRST 452.prer: Third or fourth year-standing in the B.S.F. program.
preq: fourth year-standing in the B.S.F. program

FRST 490.name: Visual Resource Management and Planning for Aesthetics
FRST 490.desc: Methodologies for visual analysis, perceptions, planning & management of urban, natural and working landscapes, and implications for sustainable land-use management & community engagement.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551. [2-2]

FRST 492.name: Environmental Perception
FRST 492.desc: How individuals perceive their environment.  Emphasis will be given visual perception in the context of natural resource issues and the effects of those perceptions on individuals including issues of human wellbeing. [3-0-0]

FRST 495.name: Biological Diversity and Forest Management
FRST 495.desc: Principles, problems, and practices of managing  forests and nature reserves for biological diversity; integration of forestry and wildlife with particular emphasis on diversity of all life forms. [2-2-0]

FRST 497.name: Graduating Essay or Technical Report
FRST 497.desc: A technical description of a study or a detailed literature review of at least 4,000 words, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

FRST 499.name: B.S.F. Thesis
FRST 499.desc: An independent study or research project on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

GEOB 102.name: Our Changing Environment: Climate and Ecosystems
GEOB 102.desc: Energy and water in the Earth-Atmosphere system, global climates and climate change, ecosystem properties and processes, human impacts. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-2*-0]

GEOB 200.name: Atmospheric Environments
GEOB 200.desc: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates at scales from valleys to the globe. Daily weather, air pollution, global change. Credit will be given for one only of GEOB 200, 204, GEOG 200, 204, AGRO 244. [3-2*-0]
GEOB 200.prer: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102 or first-year science.

GEOB 204.name: Introduction to Biometeorology
GEOB 204.desc: Basic principles and processes of climatology. Energy and water balance concepts. Weather systems and climate change, microclimate of soils, crops, forests, and animals. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 200, 204, APBI 244. [3-2-0]

GEOB 206.name: Geomorphic Processes and Hazards
GEOB 206.desc: Earth surface processes shaping the landscape; identification of hazards and hazardous areas associated with these processes; introduction to techniques for measurement and analysis at various spatial and time scales; field trips are required. [3-2*-0]
GEOB 206.prer: One of GEOB 103, EOSC 110, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

GEOB 207.name: Introduction to Biogeography
GEOB 207.desc: Geographical ecology emphasizing plant distributions, abiotic-biotic interactions, effects of disturbance, succession, and human impacts across scales. Labs and field trips examine a local site. [3-2*-0]
GEOB 207.prer: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102 and one of GEOG 103, GEOB 103.

GEOB 270.name: Geographic Information Science
GEOB 270.desc: Computer-based graphical methods of data input and analysis. Emphasis on data visualization techniques such as cartographic modelling and exploratory data analysis. Preclusion: Not available to those who completed GEOG 370 before September 2005. [2-2-0]

GEOB 300.name: Microscale Weather and Climate
GEOB 300.desc: Meteorology and climatology at the micro-, local, and meso-scales. Interactions between land surfaces and atmosphere. Basics of atmospheric turbulence and transfer processes. Microclimates on scales of a leaf to those of a large valley. [3-0-0]

GEOB 305.name: Introduction to Hydrology
GEOB 305.desc: Principles of hydrology at site, watershed, and larger regional scales. Introduction to techniques of measurement and analysis. Emphasizes surface water hydrology of western North America. [3-2*-0]
GEOB 305.prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOB 204, APBI 244, ATSC 201.

GEOB 307.name: Biogeography and Global Change
GEOB 307.desc: Biogeographic concepts in understanding responses in ecosystems to environmental change at global, regional, and local scales. Conservation issues such as the loss of biodiversity and endangered species. [3-2*-0]

GEOB 309.name: Geographical Sciences Field Course
GEOB 309.desc: Field sampling, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, and data analysis; mandatory multi-day field camp in April or May. Special fees and liability insurance are required.
GEOB 309.prer: One of BIOL 230, GEOB 207 and one of GEOB 200, GEOB 204.

GEOB 370.name: Advanced Geographic Information Science
GEOB 370.desc: Theoretical and practical aspects of Geographic Information Systems, including cartographic modeling, digital terrain models, management issues, and spatial interpolation. [2-2-0]
GEOB 370.prer: GEOB 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOB specializations, with some introductory knowledge of GIS.
preq: GEOB 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC
with some introductory knowledge of GIS

GEOB 372.name: Cartography
GEOB 372.desc: Cartographic methods: development of cartography; projections; data ordering, compilation and symbolization; cartographic design, map reproduction. [2-2-0]
GEOB 372.prer: 6 credits from GEOB 102, GEOB 103, GEOB 200, GEOB 204, GEOB 207.
preq: 6 credits from GEOB 102 GEOB 103 GEOB 200 GEOB 204 GEOB 207

GEOB 373.name: Introductory Remote Sensing
GEOB 373.desc: Aerial photography; measurement from aerial photographs; photo-interpretation in geographic analysis; remote sensing of the earth's surface and atmosphere. [3-2*-0]
GEOB 373.prer: GEOB 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC or GEOB specializations.
preq: GEOB 270. Or third-year standing in ENSC

GEOB 400.name: Global Change Science
GEOB 400.desc: Processes controlling the planetary cycles of elements like carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus, the human perturbation of these biogeochemical cycles, and the consequences for the atmosphere, terrestrial ecosystems, and aquatic ecosystems. [3-0-1]
GEOB 400.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, CHEM 111 or (b) all of BIOL 121, CHEM 121 or (c) SCIE 001. Fourth year standing is also required.
preq: SCIE 001. Fourth year standing is also required

GEOB 402.name: Air Pollution Meteorology
GEOB 402.desc: The nature of atmospheric pollutants. The ability of the atmosphere to disperse, transform, and remove pollutants. Air pollution dispersion models. Air quality monitoring, criteria, and standards. [3-0-0]

GEOB 406.name: Watershed Geomorphology
GEOB 406.desc: Hillslope and stream channel processes and their rates of operation. Analysis and modeling geomorphic processes and associated hazards at the watershed scale. Applications in geoscience and engineering. [2-2-0]

GEOB 407.name: Vegetation Dynamics: Disturbance, Climate and Human Impacts
GEOB 407.desc: Investigation of vegetation dynamics integrating theory and research to address contemporary issues of global environmental change. Students will conduct fieldwork and learn to analyze data and interpret results. [2-3-0]

GEOB 472.name: Research in Cartography
GEOB 472.desc: Use of cartography in primary research applications. Discussion of contemporary topics in cognitive, social, and technical cartography and data visualization. [3-2*-0]

GEOB 479.name: Research in Geographic Information Science
GEOB 479.desc: Students use GIS in primary research applications in conservation biology, crime analysis, and health geography; theoretical and practical aspects considered in a hands-on environment. [2-2-0]

GEOG 121.name: Geography, Environment and Globalization
GEOG 121.desc: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability.

GEOG 211.name: The State of the Earth
GEOG 211.desc: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future.
GEOG 211.prer: One of GEOB 102, GEOB 103. GEOG 121, GEOG 122 recommended.  Second-year standing.

GEOG 220.name: Geopolitics
GEOG 220.desc: Political geographic perspectives on todays interdependent world through three themes: borders, regions, and flows.

GEOG 250.name: Cities
GEOG 250.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

GEOG 281.name: Geography of the Pacific Rim
GEOG 281.desc: An introduction to changing geographies (social, economic, and political) of the Pacific Rim, with special emphasis on the relationships between Canada and Japan.

GEOG 290.name: Introduction to the Geography of Canada
GEOG 290.desc: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

GEOG 311.name: Urban Environments
GEOG 311.desc: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies.

GEOG 312.name: Climate Change: Science and Society
GEOG 312.desc: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems.
GEOG 312.prer: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102, GEOG 200, GEOB 200, GEOG 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. 3rd year standing.

GEOG 316.name: Geography of Natural Hazards
GEOG 316.desc: The role of geophysical events, human ecology, environmental perception, world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction and contrasts between developed and developing nations.
GEOG 316.prer: Either (a) GEOG 101 or (b) all of GEOG 102, GEOG 103 or (c) all of GEOB 102, GEOB 103.

GEOG 318.name: Sustainability in a Changing Environment
GEOG 318.desc: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy.

GEOG 319.name: Environmental Impact Assessment
GEOG 319.desc: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally.

GEOG 321.name: Historical Geography of Urbanization: Cities, Space, and Power
GEOG 321.desc: From the origins of urbanism to the modern era.

GEOG 327.name: Creating Canada
GEOG 327.desc: Canada from the beginning of European contact to the mid-19th century, stressing the changing geographical patterns of settlement, economy, and culture.

GEOG 328.name: Constructing Canada
GEOG 328.desc: The construction of Canadian political space after Confederation, aboriginal-newcomer relations, regional development and conflict, industrialization, urbanization, and war.

GEOG 329.name: Political Geography
GEOG 329.desc: The heritage of political geography; the spatial structure of political organization including regional and global structures.
GEOG 329.prer: One of GEOG 121, GEOG 122. Or Major and Honours students in History, International Relations or Political Science.

GEOG 345.name: Theory and Practice in Human Geography
GEOG 345.desc: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society.

GEOG 350.name: Urban Worlds
GEOG 350.desc: City systems and theories of urban location; internal spatial structure of the city; commercial and industrial location; social areas; neighbourhood and land use change; urban trends and public policy.

GEOG 353.name: Geographies of Migration and Settlement
GEOG 353.desc: International regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographics, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.

GEOG 357.name: Introduction to Social Geography
GEOG 357.desc: The development of social and behavioural geography, focusing on how places, landscapes, and enviromments both reflect and shape social life.

GEOG 361.name: Introduction to Economic Geography
GEOG 361.desc: History and methods of economic geography. Location of resource industries, manufacturing, and service activities with emphasis on British Columbia in its North American and world setting. Recommended for students with no previous exposure to Economic Geography, before taking other courses in the 36x and 46x series.

GEOG 364.name: Globalization, Cities, and Regions
GEOG 364.desc: Forms of economic development; changing location of economic activities and functions; implications for government and politics; local strategies for growth and equity.
GEOG 364.prer: One of GEOG 121, GEOG 122. GEOG 361 is recommended.

GEOG 371.name: Research Strategies in Human Geography
GEOG 371.desc: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography.

GEOG 374.name: Statistics in Geography
GEOG 374.desc: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

GEOG 380.name: Geography of Asia
GEOG 380.desc: A comparative regional analysis stressing the historical development and changing cultural, economic, and political patterns of the area. Special reference to India, Indonesia, China, and Japan.

GEOG 391.name: Modern Europe: Places and Borders
GEOG 391.desc: An introductory survey, focusing on the present-day human geography of the area between the Atlantic and the Ural Mountains.

GEOG 395.name: Culture, Nature, and Coloniality in Latin America
GEOG 395.desc: Socio-ecologies in 1491; Spanish colonialism and biological imperialism; contemporary coloniality and neoliberalism; and social movements.

GEOG 410.name: Environment and Society
GEOG 410.desc: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy.

GEOG 412.name: Water Management: Theory, Policy, and Practice
GEOG 412.desc: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally.  Focus on social science perspectives.  Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills.

GEOG 423.name: Development of Environmental Thought
GEOG 423.desc: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society.

GEOG 424.name: Feminist Geographies
GEOG 424.desc: An introductory survey of contemporary feminist approaches to human geography.

GEOG 450.name: Urban Research
GEOG 450.desc: Individual or group primary research. Instructor and content vary and it may be offered over 2 terms. Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor from April 1preceding the course. Not necessarily offered each year.
GEOG 450.prer: Registered as Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits completed.
preq: Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits completed

GEOG 453.name: Political Geographic Analysis
GEOG 453.desc: Political organization of space; territorial and spatial patterns of power and identity; contemporary geopolitical struggles.

GEOG 456.name: Film and the City
GEOG 456.desc: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

GEOG 457.name: Social and Behavioural Geography
GEOG 457.desc: Theories of social change in the global city; labour markets; poverty and inequality; social polarization; housing markets; gentrification and housing affordability; immigration and segregation; diversity and multiculturalism; transnationalism; the entrepreneurial state; the convivial city.

GEOG 481.name: Geography of Japan
GEOG 481.desc: A critical analysis of significant human adaptations to changing ecological conditions in the Japanese archipelago. Normally alternates with GEOG 468.

GEOG 495.name: Geographies of Social Movements in the Americas
GEOG 495.desc: The politics of North-South solidarity in theory and practice through community service learning models.

GEOG 497.name: The Arctic
GEOG 497.desc: Physical and biological characteristics of the circumpolar Arctic, emphasizing terrestrial environments and the impacts on and by humans, including: glacial history; climatology; biogeography/ecology of arctic tundra; human-environment interactions, settlement and exploration; and current environmental, social and economic problems.

GEOG 498.name: Geographies of the Middle East
GEOG 498.desc: Critical analysis of economic, social, and political development and processes defining the modern Middle East region.

GERM 200.name: Intermediate German I
GERM 200.desc: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies.

GERM 210.name: Intermediate German II
GERM 210.desc: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies; introduction to German for professional purposes.

GERM 300.name: Intermediate German III
GERM 300.desc: Fluency in many relevant situations; competence in the most important areas of cultural life; familiarity with study resources and study skills. Review and expansion of grammar; fostering of speaking and writing skills.

GERM 301.name: German Literature 1900 - 1945 (in English)
GERM 301.desc: Reading and discussion of selected works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in twentieth-century Germany with special emphasis on plays and novels dealing with the First World War and Nazism.

GERM 302.name: German Literature after 1945 (in English)
GERM 302.desc: Reading and discussion of selected literary works from West, East, and the United Germany, as well as from Austria and Switzerland.

GERM 303.name: German Literature Before 1900 (in English)
GERM 303.desc: Reading and discussion of translated works from the German-speaking countries from the Middle Ages to 1900.

GERM 304.name: German Cinema (in English)
GERM 304.desc: Screening, discussion, and critical analysis of German cinema from the silent era to the 21st century.

GERM 310.name: Intermediate German IV
GERM 310.desc: Fostering of the ability to discuss controversial issues, express ideas clearly in writing and write essays on selected topics in German. Ongoing grammar review and expansion.

GERM 313.name: Conversational German II
GERM 313.desc: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Fluency in many situations, communicative competence in important areas of cultural life, ability to participate in discussions of current as well as controversial issues to express ideas clearly in spoken word.

GERM 314.name: Business German
GERM 314.desc: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business.

GERM 325.name: German Translation
GERM 325.desc: Theory, methodology, and practice of translation from German into English.

GERM 360.name: Heaven and Earth: Studies in German Culture and Literature before 1700
GERM 360.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of the German literature of the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Baroque against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM 380.name: Tradition and Change: Studies in the 19th Century
GERM 380.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of ninteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM 400.name: Advanced German I
GERM 400.desc: Near-native competence and thorough understanding of critical contemporary topics in a limited number of areas fostering study skills. All skills will be fostered but the course focuses on accurate writing and conversation in particular.

GERM 402.name: Words and Music in German Literature (in English)
GERM 402.desc: Study of individual works and genres in which words and music together form a whole. Possible topics include the Lutheran Hymn, the Volkslied, the Romantic Lied and Brecht songs, operas by Mozart, Wagner and Strauss, and music and the musician as a subject in literature. No musical training is necessary to take this course.

GERM 410.name: Advanced German II
GERM 410.desc: Development of capabilities to deal with a variety of authentic texts from and about Germany, Austria and Switzerland; fostering of communicative skills, cross-cultural analysis and critical thinking; effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written German.

GERM 411.name: Major Controversies in German Culture (in English)
GERM 411.desc: Selected debates and controversies in the German-speaking countries.

GERM 412.name: German Media Studies (in English)
GERM 412.desc: Major themes and methods in German media studies.

GERM 414.name: Business German
GERM 414.desc: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business. Formerly GERM 314.

GERM 426.name: German Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
GERM 426.desc: The German Nazi Holocaust in German literature and film.
GERM 426.prer: Third Year Standing or permission of instructor.

GERM 434.name: German for Reading Knowledge II (Languages for special purposes)
GERM 434.desc: Multimedia teaching of reading skills in German for special purposes. Students are expected to work largely independently. Focuses on specific topics of the student's choice in the humanities, the natural sciences, economics/business and music and enhances skills in technical reading.
GERM 434.prer: GERM 433 or no more than one year of beginner's German.
preq: no more than one year of beginner's German

GREK 101.name: First-Year Ancient Greek I
GREK 101.desc: An introduction to Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part I.

GREK 102.name: First-Year Ancient Greek II
GREK 102.desc: An introduction to Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part II.

GREK 201.name: Second-Year Ancient Greek I
GREK 201.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part I.

GREK 202.name: Second-Year Ancient Greek II
GREK 202.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part II; introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Greek literature.

GREK 351.name: Intermediate Ancient Greek: Prose
GREK 351.desc: Readings in the major authors in Greek Prose.

GREK 352.name: Intermediate Ancient Greek: Verse
GREK 352.desc: Readings in the major authors in Greek Verse.

GRS 290.name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
GRS 290.desc: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken prior to studying abroad. [0-0-2; 0-0-2]
GRS 290.prer: Open only to students in the B.Sc. (GRS) program.
preq: Open only to students in the B.Sc.

GRS 390.name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
GRS 390.desc: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken while studying abroad. [0-0-2]

GRS 490.name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
GRS 490.desc: Students interact face-to-face and on-line as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken after studying abroad. [0-0-2]

GRSJ 102.name: Global Issues in Social Justice
GRSJ 102.desc: Intersectional feminist theory and practice, focusing on contemporary issues in a transnational context. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 102.

GRSJ 200.name: Gender and Environmental Justice
GRSJ 200.desc: An interdisciplinary and cross-cultural overview of contemporary environmental issues, as they relate to gender equality and social justice challenges and initiatives that respond to ecological crises.

GRSJ 230.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Representation in Modern Asia
GRSJ 230.desc: The complex relationships between mechanisms of power, gender, and representation in Asia in different spaces examined through an interdisciplinary lens.

GRSJ 235.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Structures in Modern Asia
GRSJ 235.desc: Situates “Asia” in a global context and explores the complex relationships between gender, social structures, and social change.

GRSJ 301.name: Gender, Race and Indigeneity in Canada
GRSJ 301.desc: Gender and indigeneity in the documented histories and narrated lives of Indigenous people in Canada.
GRSJ 301.prer: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 303.name: Gender, Race, Social Justice and the Law
GRSJ 303.desc: A survey of feminist legal thought and recent developments in feminism and law, with a focus on Canada.
GRSJ 303.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 305.name: Social Justice Issues in Community and International Organizing
GRSJ 305.desc: Critical examination and practical applications of concepts, theories, methods, and strategies of gender-aware organizing at the community and international levels.
GRSJ 305.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 306.name: Globalization and Social Justice: Gender, Race, and Sexuality in International Politics
GRSJ 306.desc: Critical examination of the gender dimension of globalization and the theories, discourse, and practices in international politics using gender analysis.
GRSJ 306.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 307.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
GRSJ 307.desc: Critical examination of mainstream and alternative media images of gender, race, and sexuality in the context of networked social media, film, music, and television.
GRSJ 307.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 310.name: Gender, Race, Social Justice and Health
GRSJ 310.desc: Interdisciplinary introduction to gender and health issues using selected theoretical frameworks.
GRSJ 310.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 311.name: African/Black Women in the Americas
GRSJ 311.desc: An interdisciplinary survey of gender studies and histories of African/Black women in the Americas from the beginning of the slave trade to the present.
GRSJ 311.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 320.name: Feminist Anti-Racist Pedagogies
GRSJ 320.desc: Feminist pedagogies and feminist debates about pedagogy in formal, nonformal, and informal educational settings.
GRSJ 320.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 325.name: Anti-colonial and Feminist Qualitative Methodologies
GRSJ 325.desc: Data collection techniques, the politics of interpretation, and the formulation of a research proposal using a feminist, anti-racist framework.
GRSJ 325.prer: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 326.name: The Politics of Gender, Families, and Nation-Building
GRSJ 326.desc: Investigation of historical and contemporary scholarship on the diversity of families, focusing on differences of gender, sexuality, race/ethnicity, and social class within and across national borders.
GRSJ 326.prer: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 327.name: Theories of Representation and Difference
GRSJ 327.desc: Feminist scholarship emphasizing languages and processes of representation and the construction of difference in cultural discourses and institutions.
GRSJ 327.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 328.name: Theories of Subjectivity
GRSJ 328.desc: How feminist scholarship has shaped and reinterpreted accounts of the subject, drawing on such traditions as structuralism, poststructuralism, psychoanalysis, postcolonialism, postmodernism, and Queer Theory.
GRSJ 328.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 401.name: Body, Gender and Society
GRSJ 401.desc: An interdisciplinary examination of the body, exploring how social relations and space are implicated in the constitution and experience of gendered bodies and identities, with an emphasis on feminist analyses of body-societal relations.
GRSJ 401.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 410.name: Religious Feminism
GRSJ 410.desc: Examines religious feminism from three Abrahamic traditions. An in-depth study of challenges various doctrinal discourses and practices pose for feminist projects.

GRSJ 422.name: Advanced Research Seminar
GRSJ 422.desc: Critical theories, methodologies, ethics and practices appropriate for advanced feminist research.
GRSJ 422.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 480.name: Decolonizing Praxis: A Practicum in Social Justice
GRSJ 480.desc: Connects feminist and critical race theory and practice through placement in a community organization. As is the case with all UBC practice-related courses, this course requires a Criminal Record Check. Open to GRSJ Majors or Minors. This course is graded Pass/Fail.
GRSJ 480.prer: Either (a) two of GRSJ 325, GRSJ 326, GRSJ 327, GRSJ 328 or (b) two of WMST 325, WMST 326, WMST 327, WMST 328. Consult the department.
preq: two of GRSJ 325 GRSJ 326 GRSJ 327 GRSJ 328
two of WMST 325 WMST 326 WMST 327 WMST 328. Consult the department

HEBR 201.name: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew I
HEBR 201.desc: The second year of Biblical Hebrew with emphasis on rapid reading of poetry and prose along with grammar.

HEBR 202.name: Intermediate Biblical Hebrew II
HEBR 202.desc: The second year of Biblical Hebrew with emphasis on rapid reading of poetry and prose along with grammar.

HGSE 350.name: Case Studies in Haida Gwaii
HGSE 350.desc: Integration of concepts of history, politics, First Nations, rural development, and forest ecology in natural resources management in Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.

HGSE 351.name: History and Politics of Resource Management
HGSE 351.desc: Historical examination of resource management in Canada and conflicts arising therefrom, with emphasis on forests.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE 351.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 352, HGSE 353, HGSE 354.

HGSE 352.name: First Nations Governance and Natural Resource Management
HGSE 352.desc: The political, economic, and legal environment of Aboriginal-Canadian relations and its influence on resource use and management; review of historic relationships, emerging case law, and new reconciliation frameworks. A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE 352.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 353, HGSE 354.

HGSE 353.name: Rainforest Ecology and Management
HGSE 353.desc: Ecology of the temperate rainforests of Haida Gwaii.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE 353.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 352, HGSE 354.

HGSE 354.name: Diversifying Resource-Dependent Communities
HGSE 354.desc: Examination of the forces that restructure local economies, both historically and contemporarily; link between rural economic development and the legacy of resource development in Aboriginal communities across British Columbia.  A core element of the Haida Gwaii Semester.
HGSE 354.crer: All of HGSE 350, HGSE 351, HGSE 352, HGSE 353.

HGSE 355.name: Applied Ecology of Coastal Terrestrial Ecosystems
HGSE 355.desc: Processes that shape coastal terrestrial ecosystems through time and applications to current ecological reality.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE 355.crer: All of HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

HGSE 356.name: Biophysical Dynamics of the Marine-Terrestrial Interface
