HGSE 356.desc: Nutrient cycling between the marine environment and coastal forest ecosystems; how the physical characteristics of this interface affect inputs; which species play a pivotal role in driving interactions.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE 356.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 357, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

HGSE 357.name: Ecology and Management of Island Wildlife
HGSE 357.desc: Unique biological attributes of island wildlife, such as subspecies, isolated populations, and distinct evolutionary pathways, with a focus on endemic species on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 395 or HGSE 357.
HGSE 357.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 358, HGSE 359.

HGSE 358.name: Systems Thinking for Resource Management
HGSE 358.desc: Introduction to systems thinking and resilience to understand dynamics of social change and innovation; use of case studies to demonstrate applications of different types of ecological knowledge, including traditional knowledge and experiential knowledge. Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE 358.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 359.

HGSE 359.name: Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
HGSE 359.desc: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.
HGSE 359.crer: All of HGSE 355, HGSE 356, HGSE 357, HGSE 358.

HINU 102.name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu
HINU 102.desc: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.

HIST 101.name: World History to Oceanic Contact
HIST 101.desc: Origins and diffusion of the world's great religions; cultural contact along overland trade routes; emergence of civilizations such as the Inca, Chinese, and Christian European; ordering of societies and their political development.

HIST 102.name: World History from 1500 to the Twentieth Century
HIST 102.desc: The civilizations of Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas, with emphasis on the political, economic, ecological and cultural links among them, and the impact of oceanic contact, imperialism, warfare, migration, and globalization.

HIST 104.name: Topics in World History
HIST 104.desc: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

HIST 105.name: Contemporary Global Issues in Historical Perspective
HIST 105.desc: Places issues and problems of current relevance such as disease, terrorism, drugs, or ethnic conflict in historical perspective. Each section will explore a single theme. Check with department for course offerings.

HIST 235.name: History of Canada: Moments that Matter
HIST 235.desc: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history.  Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century.

HIST 236.name: Public History in Canada: Memory, Representation, and Interpretation
HIST 236.desc: An introduction to public history in Canada.  An exploration of the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, and questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience.

HIST 256.name: History of Africa
HIST 256.desc: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism.

HIST 260.name: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
HIST 260.desc: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

HIST 271.name: Japan and Global History, 1550 - 1900
HIST 271.desc: Thematic study of comparisons and relations between Japan and the world outside (primarily Europe and China). Commercial expansion, systems of world order, social institutions, religious and ideological expression, and state organization.

HIST 280.name: Islamic World History
HIST 280.desc: The history of the Islamic world in its global dimensions from its origins to the present day through the themes of religion, law, politics, culture, and modernity.

HIST 302.name: History of the Indigenous Peoples of North America
HIST 302.desc: Indigenous peoples from pre-contact to the present in Canada and the U.S.  Topics include colonial frontiers, disease, fur trade, government policies, environment, gender, religion, oral narratives, activism, urbanization, and identity.

HIST 311.name: The British Empire after 1850
HIST 311.desc: Transformation of the British imperial system from the mid-nineteenth century to de-colonization and neo-colonialism after the second World War.

HIST 312.name: Southern Africa
HIST 312.desc: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary, emphasizing South Africa.

HIST 313.name: Africa from Imperialism to Independence
HIST 313.desc: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence.

HIST 318.name: Early Twentieth-Century Britain
HIST 318.desc: British society and politics in the era of the two world wars: the liberal reforms before the Great War, war experiences, the Great Depression, and the impact of new political movements.

HIST 319.name: Britain, 1945 to the Present
HIST 319.desc: Survey of recent British history, with emphasis on de-colonization, emergence of the welfare state, new social movements and patterns of immigration, and Britain's changing relationship with Europe.

HIST 323.name: Empires, Wars, and Revolutions in Europe and the Americas,1763-1838
HIST 323.desc: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to the American, French, and Haitian Revolutions, the Latin American Wars of Independence and Canadian rebellions.

HIST 324.name: Inventing Canada, 1840-1896
HIST 324.desc: An examination of political, cultural and national developments within the British North American colonies in the second half of the nineteenth century. Credit will not be granted for both HIST 324 or 326, if 326 was taken before 2007W.

HIST 325.name: Canada 1896-1945: Boom, Bust and War
HIST 325.desc: Includes Aboriginal policy, immigration and national identity; Canada, Britain and the US; World Wars; economic modernization; the Great Depression; regionalism; political and social movements; and the creation of 'Canadian' culture.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 325 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

HIST 331.name: The United States, 1865-1900: Labour, Race, Gender, and Empire
HIST 331.desc: The complicated political, economic and social history of the United States in the three decades following the Civil War.

HIST 334.name: Senegambia to South Carolina, Ghana to Georgia: African-American History, 1450 - 1850
HIST 334.desc: The history of African Americans from the beginnings of the African slave trade in the 15th Century through the mid-1800s and the coming of the U.S. Civil War.

HIST 335.name: From Slavery to Citizenship and Beyond: African-American History, 1850 to the Present
HIST 335.desc: The history of African-Americans from the Civil War and emancipation through the present. Topics include the "Jim Crow" system; the Harlem Renaissance; the Civil Rights Movement; and the current economic and political status of Americans of African ancestry.

HIST 350.name: The Soviet Union
HIST 350.desc: Political, social, and cultural history of the Soviet Union and post-Soviet successor states from 1900 to the present.

HIST 355.name: Nineteenth Century Germany
HIST 355.desc: The political, social, and cultural history of modern Germany during the "long nineteenth century" (1780s to the early twentieth century).

HIST 356.name: Twentieth-Century Germany
HIST 356.desc: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century.

HIST 363.name: Europe in the Early Middle Ages
HIST 363.desc: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 400 through about 1000 CE.

HIST 364.name: Europe in the Late Middle Ages
HIST 364.desc: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 1000 CE through the fourteenth century.

HIST 365.name: Europe During the Renaissance
HIST 365.desc: The interplay between new and traditional ideas, styles, and institutions from the fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth century, with emphasis upon the relationship of social, economic, and political factors to intellectual and cultural change.

HIST 366.name: Europe During the Reformation
HIST 366.desc: An examination of European history that place both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era.

HIST 367.name: Europe in the Age of the Enlightenment
HIST 367.desc: Europe during the age of the Enlightenment, from the end of the religious wars to the French Revolution, with emphasis on political, social, cultural, and intellectual changes in their global context.

HIST 368.name: Europe in the 19th Century
HIST 368.desc: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century.

HIST 369.name: Europe, 1900-1950
HIST 369.desc: Europe in the first half of the twentieth century. Themes include the imperialist system, two world wars and their aftermaths, political and social movements of the interwar years, the Depression, and the crisis of liberal democracy. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 369 or 462.

HIST 370.name: Europe Since 1950
HIST 370.desc: Europe since the middle of the twentieth century. Themes include the Cold War, the development of separate social and political systems in Western and Eastern Europe, the emergence of the welfare state, and the problems of European integration.

HIST 373.name: History of Hong Kong
HIST 373.desc: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

HIST 376.name: Modern Japanese History Since 1800
HIST 376.desc: The building of a modern state, its crisis in the 1930s, and its postwar recovery; topics include business institutions, politics, imperialism, intellectual syncretism, social change, and Japan's growing influence in the world.

HIST 378.name: History of Early China
HIST 378.desc: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang Empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

HIST 382.name: Post-Colonial Southeast Asia
HIST 382.desc: The history of the Japanese occupation, wars of independence, international relations of the independent nation-states, and internal armed conflicts. Special attention will be paid to the wars in Vietnam, Indonesia, and East Timor.

HIST 385.name: India from Raj to Republic
HIST 385.desc: Exploration of the rise of the East India Company as territorial power, the formation of a colonial society in India, competing responses to British rule, the struggle for independence, and the legacies of partition.

HIST 387.name: Voices from Medieval India
HIST 387.desc: History of medieval India explored through different stories from and about India's pre-modern past. Studies trends in society, religion, politics, and material life to reveal the dynamism of this period and to challenge simplified narratives of Hindu-Muslim confrontation.

HIST 388.name: India in the Early Modern World: Mughals, Merchants, and Marauders
HIST 388.desc: History of India during the period of Mughal rule (roughly 1500-1750). Studies the role of India and the Mughals within the global dynamics of the early modern world.

HIST 391.name: Human Rights in World History
HIST 391.desc: Changing ideas about humanity and rights. Considers the relationship between human rights and the nation-state, imperialism, and capitalism. Assesses the efforts to end large-scale human rights violations and the role of the United Nations.

HIST 393.name: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
HIST 393.desc: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

HIST 394.name: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
HIST 394.desc: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

HIST 405.name: Diplomacy and Conflict in the Middle East, 1914 to the Present
HIST 405.desc: International relations in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Ottoman Empire, with special attention to the conflicts between Jews of Palestine/Israel and their Arab neighbours.

HIST 408.name: U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II
HIST 408.desc: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

HIST 409.name: U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945
HIST 409.desc: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

HIST 413.name: Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada
HIST 413.desc: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum.

HIST 418.name: The 1960s in Global Perspective
HIST 418.desc: The history of the 1960s from a transnational perspective: culture, social change, student activism, and global conflict.

HIST 432.name: International Relations of the Great Powers in the Twentieth Century
HIST 432.desc: The international relations of the great powers from the end of the First World War to the end of the Cold War.

HIST 444.name: Slave Societies in the Americas
HIST 444.desc: A comparative analysis of the institution of chattel slavery, its growth, its effects on slaves and masters, its relation to the larger society, and the causes of its decline, in the various cultures of the Americas.

HIST 455.name: Gender and Sexuality in Latin America
HIST 455.desc: The construction of gender ideologies and gendered and sexual identities, including masculine, feminine, and transgendered, in modern Latin America. [3-0-0]

HIST 469.name: Aboriginal Title in British Columbia: History and Legacy
HIST 469.desc: Colonial land policy, Indigenous resistance and organizing, treaties, and court decisions. Some previous knowledge of Indigenous history is strongly recommended.

HIST 483.name: Asian Migrations to the Americas
HIST 483.desc: Examines both the historical and contemporary contexts for migration from Asia to Canada and the Americas.

HIST 484.name: East Asian Military systems and warfare China
HIST 484.desc: Confucian societies are often thought of as ones in which the brush is mightier than the sword. In fact the military has been a crucial factor in East Asia, and warfare has been the engine which has driven many of the most significant changes in East Asian history. This course will look at the evolution of East Asian military systems, and at the impact of recurrent warfare on East Asia societies.

IGEN 201.name: Integrated Technical Communication
IGEN 201.desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material.  Restricted to students in second year of the Integrated Engineering Program.
IGEN 201.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

IGEN 230.name: Introduction to Engineering Design
IGEN 230.desc: Introduction to engineering design methods, problem solving, working individually and in teams, and methods of communication of results. Engineering design projects will be assigned. Restricted to students in the second year of the Integrated Engineering program.

IGEN 330.name: Intermediate Engineering Design
IGEN 330.desc: Intermediate level engineering design projects involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program.
IGEN 330.prer: Third-year standing in the Integrated Engineering program.
preq: Third-year standing in the Integrated Engineering program

IGEN 340.name: Technology Entrepreneurship
IGEN 340.desc: Theory and skills needed for engineers to capitalize on the opportunities that exist in commercializing technology, including the relationships between ideas and opportunities, customers and competition, and products and solutions.

IGEN 430.name: Advanced Engineering Design Projects
IGEN 430.desc: Projects involving all material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering Program. Students will be expected to propose a project and complete the design and construction of a prototype. Restricted to students in the fourth year of the Integrated Engineering program.

IGEN 450.name: Pipeline Engineering
IGEN 450.desc: Pipeline materials and material selection; fracture mechanics; manufacturing and processing; welding and corrosion; soil-pipe interactions; surveying and site investigations; slope stability; natural hazards; pipeline loads and response.
IGEN 450.prer: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

IGEN 451.name: Pipeline Systems and Infrastructure
IGEN 451.desc: Energy infrastructure; pipe flows; equipment and facilities including compressors, pumping stations, coolers, and controls; terminals; pipeline integrity; corrosion control.
IGEN 451.prer: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

IGEN 452.name: Pipeline Design
IGEN 452.desc: Pipeline and pipeline system design reflecting technical, regulatory, environmental, societal, professional, and economic aspects; pipeline design project.

INDE 440.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE 440.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE 441.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE 441.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE 442.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE 442.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE 443.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE 443.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE 450.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE 450.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INDE 451.name: Clinical Skills IV
INDE 451.desc: Final examination for third year encompassing all clinical subjects.

INDE 453.name: Preparation for Medical Practice
INDE 453.desc: Diagnostics; therapeutics; information management; evidence-based practice; professionalism and ethics; cultural competence; advanced communication skills; patient safety; health and wellness; and the health care team.

INDE 455.name: Senior Clerkship
INDE 455.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular rotation.

INFO 250.name: Networks, Crowds, and Communities
INFO 250.desc: Introduces network concepts and methods for exploring social and organizational connectivity for work, socializing, and knowledge production. Examines impact of social media on connections that span space and place; peer production on authority structures; ubiquitous mobile connectivity on daily life.

INFO 419.name: Information Visualization
INFO 419.desc: Basic theory and practice required to visually represent information. Introduces design principles and practical skills to create effective information visualizations. Examines effect of different visual representations on understanding and meaning.

INFO 456.name: Information Policy and Society
INFO 456.desc: Develops capabilities required to assess the need for information policies in professional contexts, evaluate relevant socio-technical dimensions and envision likely implications for specific communities and practice settings.

ISCI 300.name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
ISCI 300.desc: Critical analysis of recent scientific literature that combines disciplines that students are integrating in their Integrated Sciences Curriculum.

ISCI 311.name: The Size of Things
ISCI 311.desc: Scaling as a general approach to laws governing the geometry, kinematics and dynamics of systems. Dimensional analysis, isometry and allometry applied to topics from Biology, Physics, Earth Science and Economics. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI 311.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 320.name: Research Development Project
ISCI 320.desc: Retreat to develop skills in writing scientific research proposals.  Emphasis on formulating and testing hypotheses to explain observations.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to retreat.
ISCI 320.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 350.name: Darwinian Medicine
ISCI 350.desc: Using the Darwinian theory of natural selection to explore explanations of infectious diseases, allergies, cancer, mental illness, and other human diseases. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI 350.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 360.name: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
ISCI 360.desc: Application of systems science encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems approaches to study regional sustainability. [3-0-0]
ISCI 360.prer: Third-year or higher standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: higher standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 422.name: Models in Science
ISCI 422.desc: Meaning, nature, use, strengths and limitations of models as investigative tools in all scientific disciplines. Detailed investigation of selected model systems from different scientific disciplines. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI 422.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 433.name: Ethical Issues in Science
ISCI 433.desc: Theoretical and practical consideration of ethics in the practice, reporting, public impact and accountability of science. [3-0-0]

ISCI 490.name: Student Directed Seminars
ISCI 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars. [3-0-0]
ISCI 490.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ITAL 201.name: Second-Year Italian I
ITAL 201.desc: Reading, writing and oral practice, with constant and systematic reference to the grammatical structure of the language.
ITAL 201.prer: ITAL 102. Or permission of the instructor.
preq: ITAL 102. Or permission of the instructor

ITAL 202.name: Second-Year Italian II
ITAL 202.desc: Reading, writing and oral practice, with constant and systematic reference to the grammatical structure of the language.
ITAL 202.prer: ITAL 201. Or permission of the department.
preq: ITAL 201. Or permission of the department

ITAL 206.name: Conversational Italian for Intermediate Learners
ITAL 206.desc: The development of spoken proficiency. Contemporary Italy will be presented and discussed through a variety of multimedia resources in this highly interactive environment.

ITAL 301.name: Third-Year Italian I
ITAL 301.desc: Reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice and on composition.
ITAL 301.prer: One of ITAL 202, ITAL 203. Or permission of the department.
preq: ITAL 203. Or permission of the department

ITAL 302.name: Third-Year Italian II
ITAL 302.desc: Reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice and on composition.
ITAL 302.prer: ITAL 301. Or permission of the department.
preq: ITAL 301. Or permission of the department

ITAL 303.name: Italian Literature and Culture of the Medieval and Early Modern Period
ITAL 303.desc: A thematic approach to Italian literary works from the origins to the end of the sixteenth century considered in a broad cultural context. Alternates with ITAL 304.
ITAL 303.crer: ITST 231. Or permission of the Departmental Undergraduate Advisor in Italian.
creq: ITST 231. Or permission of the Departmental Undergraduate Advisor in Italian

ITAL 304.name: Italian Literature and Culture of the Modern and Contemporary Age
ITAL 304.desc: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Alternates with ITAL 303.
ITAL 304.crer: ITST 232. Or permission of Departmental Undergraduate Advisor in Italian.
creq: ITST 232. Or permission of Departmental Undergraduate Advisor in Italian

ITAL 325.name: Italian Translation
ITAL 325.desc: A task-based introduction to the theory and practice of translation as applied to Italian and English texts: word choice, semantic correspondence, cultural adaptation, communicative purpose, target readerships. Languages of instruction are English and Italian.

ITAL 401.name: Advanced Studies in Italian Language and Style I
ITAL 401.desc: Advanced reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on oral practice. Alternates with ITAL 402.

ITAL 403.name: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy
ITAL 403.desc: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works:

ITAL 409.name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture
ITAL 409.desc: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITST 419.

ITST 110.name: Introduction to Italian Literature and Culture

ITST 231.name: Introduction to Italian Culture I: From the Middle Ages to the Early Modern Period

ITST 232.name: Introduction to Italian Culture II: From the Modern to the Post-Colonial Age

ITST 345.name: Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
ITST 345.desc: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures.

ITST 413.name: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy in Translation
ITST 413.desc: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works:

ITST 419.name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
ITST 419.desc: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 409.

ITST 432.name: Italian Cinema and Its Cultural Background
ITST 432.desc: Films with English subtitles. Precludes credit for ITAL 430. Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

JAPN 160.name: Intensive Beginning Japanese I
JAPN 160.desc: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions. Offered in Term 1. Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 160 or JAPN 150 or both JAPN 100, JAPN 101.

JAPN 260.name: Intensive Beginning Japanese II
JAPN 260.desc: Continuation of JAPN 160. Offered in Term 2. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 260 or JAPN 151 or both JAPN 102, JAPN 103 or both JAPN 200, JAPN 201.

JAPN 360.name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese I
JAPN 360.desc: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and  cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 or JAPN 212 or both JAPN 210, JAPN 211 or both JAPN 320, JAPN 321.
JAPN 360.prer: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

JAPN 361.name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese II
JAPN 361.desc: Continuation of JAPN 360. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 361 or JAPN 251 or both JAPN 212, JAPN 213 or both JAPN 322, JAPN 323.
JAPN 361.prer: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

JAPN 400.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing I
JAPN 400.desc: Selected texts covering various aspects of Japanese cultural history and contemporary Japanese culture/society; emphasis on grammatical analysis and development of advanced competencies for reading and writing. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 400 or JAPN 300.
JAPN 400.prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

JAPN 401.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing II
JAPN 401.desc: Continuation of JAPN 301. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 401 or JAPN 301.

JAPN 402.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition I
JAPN 402.desc: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on appropriate language use in formal situations. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 402 or JAPN 302.
JAPN 402.prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

JAPN 450.name: Advanced Oral Communication I
JAPN 450.desc: Oral communication skills appropriate for studying and working in a Japanese-speaking environment either formal or informal. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 450 or JAPN 410.
JAPN 450.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

JAPN 452.name: Readings in Modern Japanese Essays
JAPN 452.desc: Advanced reading and analysis of scholarly texts in modern Japanese drawn from history, sociology, economics, etc. Advanced conversation, composition, and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to taking JAPN 452. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 452 or JAPN 406.

JAPN 453.name: Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
JAPN 453.desc: An advanced course in the reading and analysis of literary texts in modern Japanese. Advanced conversation, translation into English and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for advanced research in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 453 or JAPN 408.

JAPN 456.name: Newspaper Japanese I
JAPN 456.desc: Developing fluency in reading contemporary Japanese newspapers; concentration on current and emerging vocabulary, evolving grammatical features, and style of presentation. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 456 or JAPN 416.
JAPN 456.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

KIN 103.name: Active Health
KIN 103.desc: Role of physical activity in the maintenance of a healthy life. Application of basic physical fitness and exercise methods, exercise techniques and fitness appraisal. [2-2]

KIN 230.name: Human Motor Behaviour I
KIN 230.desc: Processes underlying human movement and learning motor skills and factors influencing acquisition, performance, and movement control. [3-0-0]

KIN 231.name: Sport and Exercise Psychology
KIN 231.desc: Psychological theories and research related to sport and exercise behaviour. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477 [3-0-0]

KIN 261.name: Health Policy and Society
KIN 261.desc: Health policy and the social context in relation to active health. [3-0]

KIN 284.name: Lifespan Motor Development
KIN 284.desc: A lifespan approach to motor development that examines underlying factors affecting physical growth, physical activity behaviour, and human motor performance, while highlighting contemporary issues and trends in society. [3-0]

KIN 303.name: High Performance Conditioning in Physical Activity and Sport
KIN 303.desc: Conditioning methods, exercise techniques and appraisal methods for fitness in high performance physical activity and sport. [2-2]

KIN 330.name: Human Motor Behaviour II
KIN 330.desc: Acquisition, performance, and control of skilled movements. Processes and underlying mechanisms involved in learning and performing motor skills. Credit will be granted for only one of KIN 330 or KIN 468. [2-2]

KIN 351.name: Biomechanics II Mechanical Properties of Tissues
KIN 351.desc: Mechanics of muscular contraction and how the mechanical properties of the muscle, ligaments, tendons, and bone work synergistically. [2-0-2]

KIN 360.name: Sport, Peace, and Conflict
KIN 360.desc: Relationships that sport and leisure have with peace, conflict, and social inequality in Canada and internationally. [3-0]

KIN 361.name: Introduction to Athletic Training
KIN 361.desc: Recognition, prevention, and first aid treatment of common sports injuries. Laboratory sessions emphasize principles and techniques of basic protective taping and strapping. [2-2]

KIN 362.name: Inclusive Physical Activity for Individuals with Special Needs
KIN 362.desc: For persons with disabilities; a developmental, lifelong approach to programming. Includes field work. [2-0-2]

KIN 365.name: Foundations of Coaching
KIN 365.desc: Methods of athletic conditioning, planning the program, psychology of training and coaching, athletic evaluation. [3-0]

KIN 366.name: Movement Experiences for Young Children
KIN 366.desc: The design and implementation of movement experiences for children in early childhood years. [3-0]

KIN 367.name: Leisure Services for Persons with a Disability
KIN 367.desc: Policy issues relating to leisure opportunities for persons with disabilities. [3-0]

KIN 369.name: Instructional Analysis and Design in Sport and Physical Activity Programs
KIN 369.desc: Instructional design and technologies applied to sport and physical activity programs. [2-2]

KIN 371.name: Introduction to Statistics in Kinesiology
KIN 371.desc: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics, and distribution-free statistical techniques. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477. [3-0-0]

KIN 373.name: Research Methods in Kinesiology
KIN 373.desc: Critical evaluation of research studies and methods with emphasis on the physical activity context. [3-0]

KIN 381.name: Leisure, Sport and Popular Culture
KIN 381.desc: Selected aspects of leisure and sport examined in relation to modern social structures and cultures. Credit will be granted for only one of KIN 281 or KIN 381. [3-0-0]

KIN 382.name: Meaning and Values in Sport
KIN 382.desc: An analysis of the experience of sports activities. [3-0]

KIN 383.name: The Modern Olympics: Power, Politics, and Performance
KIN 383.desc: Examination of the Modern Olympic Games as an event with important political, economic, environmental, and cultural ramifications. [3-0]

KIN 389.name: Neuromuscular Integration of Human Movement
KIN 389.desc: The neurophysiological and functional neuroanatomical processes involved in the sensory and motor control of movement, posture and balance in the human. Peripheral and central sensorimotor structures, and neurological diseases that effect human movement and balance control will be discussed. [2-2]

KIN 390.name: Human Functional Musculoskeletal Anatomy
KIN 390.desc: The musculoskeletal structures and neural innervations involved in the control of human movement. Attention will be given to the practical application of human anatomy as it pertains to clinical, athletic, or everyday situations.
KIN 390.prer: Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK and BKIN programs.
preq: Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK

KIN 400.name: Planning Physical Education, Sport and Exercise Programs
KIN 400.desc: Processes, techniques and considerations in the planning, implementation and evaluation of physical education, sport and exercise programs in both public and private agencies. [3-0]

KIN 415.name: Conceptual Approaches to Games Education
KIN 415.desc: Examination of developmentally appropriate conceptual and tactical approaches to team game instruction. [2-2]

KIN 425.name: Aging, Health, and the Body
KIN 425.desc: The sociology of aging and the body. Focus on how older adults perceive and experience health and illness.

KIN 456.name: Field Experiences in Physical Education Settings
KIN 456.desc: Analytical observations and supervised professional practice in physical activity settings.
KIN 456.prer: KIN  369. Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK and BKIN programs.
preq: KIN 369. Third-year standing. Restricted to students in the BHK

KIN 461.name: Prevention of Sports Injuries I
KIN 461.desc: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries to the musculoskeletal system and sense organs. [3-0]
KIN 461.prer: One of KIN  361, HKIN 361 and third-year standing.

KIN 462.name: Skeletal Muscle Physiology: From Generation to Regeneration
KIN 462.desc: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of muscle adaptability to physical activity: muscle development, signaling cascades of hypertrophy and atrophy, and satellite cell contribution to muscle regeneration/repair; etiology of intramuscular fatigue. [3-0-1]
KIN 462.prer: One of KIN  375, HKIN 375 and third-year standing.

KIN 464.name: Health Promotion and Physical Activity
KIN 464.desc: Current perspectives on health promotion and health education; design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity. [3-0]

KIN 465.name: Interculturalism, Health and Physical Activity
KIN 465.desc: Examination of multiculturalism and interculturalism in the delivery of community-based physical activities for diverse populations; connections between physical activity and health in different cultural contexts.  Community service learning and participation in culturally unfamiliar physical activities are core elements.

KIN 471.name: Prevention of Sports Injuries II
KIN 471.desc: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries or disorders of internal organs and central nervous system. Environmental and nutritional factors in conditioning and pre-event preparation. [3-0]

KIN 473.name: Neuroanatomy of Human Movement
KIN 473.desc: Neuroanatomy of human motion in healthy and clinical populations. [3-0]

KIN 475.name: Pulmonary Physiology of Exercise
KIN 475.desc: Operation of the lungs, chest wall, and ventilatory control mechanisms during dynamic whole-body exercise. [3-0]

KIN 481.name: Sport Marketing and Communication
KIN 481.desc: A seminar on the application of social science theories and methods to sport marketing and communication. [3-0]

KORN 200.name: Intermediate Korean
KORN 200.desc: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201/202 or KORN 200.

KORN 301.name: Readings in Korean Topics I
KORN 301.desc: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

KORN 302.name: Readings in Korean Topics II
KORN 302.desc: Continuation of KORN 301. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

LARC 316.name: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
LARC 316.desc: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition.  Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to  Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students. [2-2]

LARC 415.name: A Behavioural Approach to Planting Design
LARC 415.desc: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales. [2-2]

LARC 431.name: Landscape Technologies I: Site Engineering
LARC 431.desc: Terrain design, drainage, and stormwater management. Open only to B. End. students. Credit will be given for only one of LARC 431, LARC 531.

LARC 440.name: SITE ANALYSIS AND PLANNING II
LARC 440.desc: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Open only to B.En.D. students. Credit will be given for only one of LARC 440, LARC 540.

LARC 444.name: Green Network Planning
LARC 444.desc: Theory and methods of long-range green space planning for urban areas.

LASO 204.name: Introduction to Law and Society
LASO 204.desc: Ideas, concepts, and frameworks for thinking about the nature of law and legal processes in both Canadian and global contexts.

LATN 102.name: First-Year Latin II
LATN 102.desc: Classical Latin for students with no previous knowledge of Latin, Part II.

LATN 201.name: Second-Year Latin I
LATN 201.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part I.

LATN 202.name: Second-Year Latin II
LATN 202.desc: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part II, and an introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Latin literature.

LATN 350.name: Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Prose)

LATN 351.name: Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Verse)

LAW 300.name: Jurisprudence and Critical Perspectives
LAW 300.desc: Introduction to the basic principles of legal theory and critical perspectives on law. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 290 or LAW 300.

LAW 303.name: Legal Traditions and Ideas of Law
LAW 303.desc: Historical and comparative study of the evolution of legal systems from custom and proto law emphasizing influences and sharing ideas among traditions of the Ancient Near East, Athens, Roman Empire, Western Europe and China. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 305.name: Law, Society and State
LAW 305.desc: Theories of the relationship between the legal system, social relations and the state. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 307.name: Women, Law and Social Change
LAW 307.desc: A survey of feminist approaches to law, with reference to selected substantive areas of the law.

LAW 316.name: International Law
LAW 316.desc: The history, sources and evidence of international law and its relation to municipal law; international personality; state jurisdiction; and treaties. Students who have taken POLI 465 cannot take this course.

LAW 325.name: Conflict of Laws
LAW 325.desc: A study of the private legal problems arising in cases in which the relevant facts cut across provincial or national boundaries. Recommended to be taken in third year.

LAW 334.name: Introduction to Asian Legal Systems
LAW 334.desc: Introduction to the comparative study of legal systems of East and South-East Asia, including those of China and Japan.

LAW 336.name: Chinese Law: Implications for Canada-China Relations
LAW 336.desc: Overview of the laws and legal system in the People's Republic of China with some introduction to Taiwan law. Legal interpretation of implications for Canada-China relations.

LAW 340.name: Comparative Law
LAW 340.desc: Basic theory of comparative law and the differences between the civil law tradition and the common law tradition.

LAW 352.name: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Law
LAW 352.desc: Survey of the history and present status of the legal relationships between Canada's Aboriginal peoples and the state. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 200 or LAW 352.

LAW 356.name: First Nations and Economic Development
LAW 356.desc: Legal issues affecting land use and economic activity involving First Nations' resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 359.name: Family Law
LAW 359.desc: The law relating to family relationships, including the law of marriage, divorce, maintenance, custody, matrimonial property, and related matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 240 or LAW 359. [3-0]

LAW 367.name: Reproduction and Law
LAW 367.desc: Legal issues relating to human reproduction. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 374.name: Municipal Law
LAW 374.desc: The municipality as a legal entity; its creation, operation and powers; by-laws and their validity; contractual liability; judicial review; business regulation; expropriation and land use control.

LAW 377.name: Immigration Law
LAW 377.desc: Admission of immigrants into Canada; refugee protection; practice and procedure before immigration tribunals and the courts.

LAW 381.name: Disabilities and Law
LAW 381.desc: Legal issues relating to people with disabilities. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 382.name: Health Law
LAW 382.desc: Legal and policy issues relating to the health care system, including legal aspects of individual and public health decision-making.

LAW 387.name: Environmental Law
LAW 387.desc: A foundation course dealing with the regulatory and policy framework for the protection of the environment in Canada, such as pollution control and biodiversity conservation.

LAW 390.name: Environmental Law Workshop
LAW 390.desc: Legal research and writing for environmental agency or NGO under supervision of faculty member and lawyer. Not offered every year, consult Faculty.

LAW 392.name: Natural Resources Law
LAW 392.desc: A foundation course dealing with legal problems common to the management of natural resources such as fisheries, mines and minerals, petroleum, forests, and water resources.

LAW 395.name: Forest Law
LAW 395.desc: Acquisition of timber interests; development, financing and organization of timber companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

LAW 400.name: Advanced Criminal Procedure
LAW 400.desc: Selected topics relating to procedural law and practice in criminal matters. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 260 or LAW 400.

LAW 407.name: Taxation
LAW 407.desc: A survey of the law and practice of income and capital gains taxes. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 220, LAW 407, or LAW 506. [3-0]

LAW 408.name: Taxation of Corporations and Shareholders
LAW 408.desc: The taxation of corporations, the taxation of shareholders, and the tax implications of the reorganization of corporations. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 408 or LAW 562.

LAW 409.name: Taxation of Partnerships and Trusts
LAW 409.desc: Survey of statutory and judicial rules governing the taxation of income earned through partnerships and trusts. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 409 or LAW 563.

LAW 410.name: International Taxation
LAW 410.desc: The tax aspects of international transactions. Not offered each year; consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 410 or LAW 565.

LAW 412.name: Taxation of Trusts and Estates
LAW 412.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.  Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 412 or LAW 564.

LAW 416.name: Labour Law
LAW 416.desc: Union-management relations; the collective bargaining process; the collective agreement, arbitration and conciliation procedure. The relationship between the union and its membership. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 415 or LAW 416. [2-0] or [3-0]

LAW 422.name: Intellectual Property
LAW 422.desc: Copyright, patents, trade marks, industrial design, the protection of computer software, and torts such as passing-off and breach of confidence.

LAW 424.name: Communications Law
LAW 424.desc: Selected legal issues relating to the communications industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 430.name: Advanced Legal Research
LAW 430.desc: Research using electronic databases, information systems, and non-legal databases relevant to the resolution of legal issues.

LAW 434.name: Medical Negligence Law
LAW 434.desc: Legal issues relating to tort claims in negligence and related causes of action against health care providers, with a primary focus on physicians and hospital authorities.

LAW 437.name: Commercial Transactions
LAW 437.desc: The law of sale of goods, bills of exchange, promissory notes, and cheques. [3-0]

LAW 438.name: Secured Transactions
LAW 438.desc: The law governing the creation, perfection and enforcement of security interests in personal property.

LAW 439.name: Construction Law
LAW 439.desc: Legal issues relating to the construction process. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 440.name: Insurance Law
LAW 440.desc: The general legal principles of life, automobile, fire and other types of insurance; the regulation of the insurance industry.

LAW 442.name: Condominium Law
LAW 442.desc: Legal issues over the lifecycle of condominium/strata property from creation and development, through operating life, to termination.

LAW 443.name: Creditors' Remedies
LAW 443.desc: Remedies of an unsecured creditor; fraudulent conveyances and preferences; builders' liens; bankruptcy.

LAW 444.name: Insolvency Law
LAW 444.desc: The law relating to insolvency, receivership and bankruptcy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 448.name: Sports Law
LAW 448.desc: Legal issues relating to the sports industry and those who participate in it. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 449.name: Media and Entertainment Law
LAW 449.desc: Selected legal issues relating to the media and entertainment industries and their regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 451.name: Trusts
LAW 451.desc: History and nature of trusts; express, resulting, implied and constructive trusts; charitable and purpose trusts; administration of trusts; breach of trust. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 250 or LAW 451.

LAW 452.name: Succession
LAW 452.desc: The law of wills and intestate succession, variation of wills, principles of probate and administration of estates.

LAW 453.name: Equitable Remedies
LAW 453.desc: The history and development of equitable remedies such as specific performance, injunctions, declarations, relief against forfeiture, and tracing.

LAW 455.name: Real Estate Transactions
LAW 455.desc: The law relating to the sale and purchase of land, real estate agency, and mortgages.

LAW 457.name: Real Estate Development
LAW 457.desc: A study of the legal aspects of the development of real estate projects such as shopping centres, sports centres and condominiums. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 461.name: Corporate Transactions
LAW 461.desc: Legal aspects of selected transactions relating to public corporations and corporate governance. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 462.name: Close Corporations
LAW 462.desc: The corporation, taxation, accounting, insurance and estate planning aspects of the close corporation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 463.name: Securities Regulation
LAW 463.desc: The law relating to the distribution of securities. Continuous and timely disclosure requirements and civil liability.

LAW 464.name: Competition Policy
LAW 464.desc: The law and policy relating to the regulation of competition in Canada and other jurisdictions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 414 or LAW 464.

LAW 465.name: Introduction to Corporate Finance
LAW 465.desc: Interdisciplinary elements of corporate finance and law, in both theory and practice.

LAW 466.name: Business Law Capstone
LAW 466.desc: Integration of theoretical and practical elements of business law. For students opting for the Business Law Concentration.
LAW 466.prer: All of LAW  407, LAW  459, LAW  463. And 6 credits of other courses from the Concentration.
preq: 6 credits of other courses from the Concentration

LAW 468.name: Ethics and Professionalism
LAW 468.desc: The ethical dimensions of legal practice in Canada, including legislation, regulations, rules of professional conduct and cases, and the roles of lawyers, the legal profession and the legal system including their role in securing access to justice.

LAW 469.name: Civil Procedure
LAW 469.desc: Problems in the conduct of civil litigation including: ethical considerations; substantive problems such as notice, pleading, and discovery; and selected procedural problems. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 270 or LAW 469. [2-0] or [3-0]

LAW 470.name: Innocence Project
LAW 470.desc: Clinical program giving hands-on experience in reviewing claims of innocence post-conviction. Not offered every year; consult Faculty.
LAW 470.crer: One of LAW  280, LAW  476 and LAW  471.

LAW 472.name: Advanced Trial Advocacy
LAW 472.desc: Skills-training in all aspects of civil and criminal trial advocacy.
LAW 472.prer: One of LAW  270, LAW  469. LAW 280 or LAW 476 is also recommended.

LAW 473.name: Appellate Advocacy
LAW 473.desc: Issues relating to advocacy before appellate courts; techniques of appellate advocacy. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 474.name: Trial Advocacy
LAW 474.desc: Techniques of advocacy in civil and criminal cases including interviewing, pre-trial preparation, tactical analysis, development of facts, direct and cross examination and various ethical considerations.

LAW 477.name: Negotiation and Dispute Resolution
LAW 477.desc: Negotiation and bargaining; formulation of general principles governing the negotiation process; negotiation in legal practice; alternative means of dispute resolution.

LAW 478.name: Foundations of Dispute Resolution
LAW 478.desc: Theoretical premises underlying the dispute-resolving process; arbitration, other non-judicial means of resolving legal disputes, and their relationship to litigation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 490.name: Clinical Criminal Law
LAW 490.desc: Dealing with criminal files under the supervision of experienced lawyers. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 488, LAW 490, or LAW 491. Pass/Fail.
LAW 490.prer: One of LAW  260, LAW  400 and one of LAW  280, LAW  476.

LFS 100.name: Introduction to Land, Food and Community
LFS 100.desc: Orientation to the programs, learning environment and core values of the Faculty of Land and Food Systems; career programs; survey of professional opportunities and requirements. [1-0-0]

LFS 250.name: Land, Food and Community I
LFS 250.desc: Introduction to managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum. [4-0-4]

LFS 252.name: Land, Food, and Community: Quantitative Data Analysis
LFS 252.desc: Introduction to tools needed for data analysis of the economic, ecological, health, and scientific components of land and food systems. [3-0-1]
LFS 252.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

LFS 340.name: First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
LFS 340.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

LFS 350.name: Land, Food, and Community II
LFS 350.desc: Introduction to tools and skills required to assess the economic, ecological, social, and technological components of managed landscapes, agrifood systems and communities comprising the land, food, nutrition and health continuum. [3-0-0]

LFS 400.name: Audio Storytelling
LFS 400.desc: Adopts a journalistic framework to communicate powerful stories and present academic content in new ways through the use of audio technology. [1-2-0]

LFS 450.name: Land, Food, and Community III: Food System Sustainability
LFS 450.desc: Problem-based analysis of complex case studies aimed at increasing the sustainability of the UBC Vancouver campus food system. The main activities are integrated into the ongoing UBC Food System Project. Cases are specifically designed to require development of integrated disciplinary and inter-disciplinary analysis. [1-0-3]

LLED 200.name: Introduction to Writing in Academic and Professional Registers
LLED 200.desc: Examination of sociolinguistic knowledge and skills that are central to the production of academic and professional texts.

LLED 201.name: Critical Reading and Writing in Academic and Professional Registers

LLED 212.name: Introduction to Language Communities and Variation in Language Practices
LLED 212.desc: Sociolinguistic analysis of language variation according to age, ethnicity, class, race, and gender, and how these variations function in both reflecting and constructing specific identities and memberships in society.

LLED 213.name: Introduction to Intercultural Communication and Socialization in Multicultural Contexts
LLED 213.desc: The processes by which individuals become competent members of society through the use of language.

LLED 220.name: Introduction to Translating in a Globalized Society
LLED 220.desc: Basic tenets of translation as a methodology for increasing students' sociocultural understanding, intercultural communication, pragmatics, and written English.

LLED 222.name: Introduction to Public and Private Language Practices in a Globalized Society
LLED 222.desc: Exploration of the interrelationships between language structure, usage and social context and the interpretive differences that may result from their interaction.

LLED 223.name: Introduction to the Nature of World Englishes
LLED 223.desc: Exploration of the emergence of new English varieties, as well as a critical examination of main reasons linked to the rise of English worldwide and its proposed role as a neutral global language.

LLED 360.name: Classroom Discourses and Teaching English Language Learners: Secondary

LLED 366.name: Teaching Literature
LLED 366.desc: Curriculum and pedagogy related to the theories, concepts, and strategies relevant in secondary school classrooms.

LLED 371.name: Foundations of Teaching French: Secondary
LLED 371.prer: A completed concentration in French of permission of the Department Head.
preq: A completed concentration in French of permission of the Department Head

LLED 372.name: Teaching French Language and Literacy: Secondary
LLED 372.desc: Language of instruction is French. Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students. Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail grading.

LLED 381.name: Foundations of Teaching Modern Languages: Secondary

LLED 386.name: Secondary Theatre: Introduction to Curriculum & Pedagogy

LLED 399.name: Practicum in Teaching English as a Second Language

LLED 443.name: Teaching Folklore in the Elementary Classroom

LLED 446.name: Teaching with Illustrated Materials, K-12: From Picture Books to Information Texts

LLED 450.name: Teaching and Learning Language and Literacy: Kindergarten and Primary Grades
LLED 450.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course

LLED 452.name: Disciplinary Literacies: Intermediate Through Secondary
LLED 452.desc: How teachers can support students to develop disciplinary literacies that will enable them to understand, analyze, interpret and critique ideas, genres, and language in discipline-specific texts in and beyond the intermediate and secondary school contexts.

LLED 459.name: Trends and Issues in Literacy Instruction
LLED 459.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

LLED 479.name: The Education of Immigrant Students
LLED 479.desc: An examination of the cultural backgrounds of major ethnic groups. Instructional techniques for meeting the needs of immigrant students in the regular classroom with respect to culture and language.

MATH 001.name: Algebra
MATH 001.desc: Numbers and their properties; exponents, radicals, absolute value, inqualities, functions and their graphs; factoring; solving polynomial, rational, and exponetial equations; and the sine and cosine law. Non-credit Math course offered by Continuing Studies in consultation with the Mathematics Department and taught by Continuing Studies instructors.

MATH 102.name: Differential Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
MATH 102.desc: Functions, derivatives, optimization, growth and decay, discrete probability. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 102.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.
preq: higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12
a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test

MATH 103.name: Integral Calculus with Applications to Life Sciences
MATH 103.desc: Antiderivatives and definite integrals, infinite series, applications to probability and dynamical systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 103.prer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

MATH 110.name: Differential Calculus
MATH 110.desc: Topics as for MATH 100, but including relevant topics from algebra, geometry, functions, trigonometry, logarithms, and exponentials. [3-0-1.5]
MATH 110.prer: Pre-requisite: BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 (or equivalent), plus permission of  the Mathematics Department;  permission will normally be based on a low grade in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 (or equivalent) and a low score in the optional UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test if taken. See http://www.math.ubc.ca/Ugrad/m110.shtml for details.
preq: plus permission of the Mathematics Department; permission will normally be based on a low grade in BC Principles of Mathematics 12
a low score in the optional UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test if taken. See http://www.math.ubc.ca/Ugrad/m110.shtml for details

MATH 120.name: Honours Differential Calculus
MATH 120.desc: Limits, derivatives, Mean Value Theorem and applications, elementary functions, optimization, Taylor series, approximation. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [4-0-0]
MATH 120.prer: High-school calculus and one of (a) a score of 95% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12; or (b) permission from the Mathematics Department Head.
preq: higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12
permission from the Mathematics Department Head

MATH 121.name: Honours Integral Calculus
MATH 121.desc: Definite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, techniques and applications of integration, infinite series. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [4-0-0]
MATH 121.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 120 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 180, MATH 184 or (c) a score of 5 in AP Calculus AB.
preq: a score of 5 in AP Calculus AB

MATH 152.name: Linear Systems
MATH 152.desc: 2D and 3D geometry, vectors and matrices, eigenvalues and vibration, physical applications. Laboratories demonstrate computer solutions of large systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-1*-0]

MATH 180.name: Differential Calculus with Physical Applications
MATH 180.desc: Topics as for Math 100; intended for students with no previous knowledge of Calculus. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. Not for credit for students with AP Calculus AB, AP Calculus BC, or a passing score on the UBC-SFU-UVIC-UNBC Calculus Challenge Examination. [3-0-1.5]
MATH 180.prer: One of BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.
preq: a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test

MATH 184.name: Differential Calculus for Social Science and Commerce
MATH 184.desc: Topics as for Math 104; intended for students with no previous knowledge of Calculus. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.  Not for credit for students with AP Calculus AB, AP Calculus BC, or a passing score on the UBC-SFU-UVIC-UNBC Calculus Challenge Examination. [3-0-1.5]
MATH 184.prer: One of BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and one of (a) a grade of 80% or higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12, or (b) a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test.
preq: higher in BC Principles of Mathematics 12
a satisfactory score in the UBC Mathematics Basic Skills Test

MATH 190.name: Calculus Survey
MATH 190.desc: Functions, derivatives, integrals, curve sketching growth functions, volume calculations.  Only for credit in the Faculty of Forestry.  Students with credit for MATH 100, 102, 104, 120, 180, or 184 cannot in the same term or later terms obtain credit for MATH 190. [3-0-2]
MATH 190.prer: Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 and registration in the B.S.F. or B.Sc.N. programs.

MATH 210.name: Introduction to Mathematical Computing
MATH 210.desc: Introduction to numerical computation, computer algebra, mathematical graphics. Primarily for second year students taking a degree in mathematics. One hour laboratory each week. [3-1-0]
MATH 210.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
MATH 210.crer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

MATH 217.name: Multivariable and Vector Calculus
MATH 217.desc: Partial differentiation, extreme values, multiple integration, vector fields, line and surface integrals, the divergence theorem, Green's and Stokes' theorems.  Intended for students in Honours Physics and Engineering Physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [4-0-0]
MATH 217.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH 223.name: Linear Algebra
MATH 223.desc: Matrices, eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonality, linear systems, applications. Intended for Honours students. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 223.prer: Either (a) MATH 121 or (b) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001.

MATH 226.name: Advanced Calculus I
MATH 226.desc: Functions of several variables: limits, continuity, differentiability; implicit functions; Taylor's theorem; extrema; Lagrange multipliers; multiple integration, Fubini's theorem; improper integrals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 226.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 121 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, SCIE 001.

MATH 227.name: Advanced Calculus II
MATH 227.desc: Parametrization of curves and surfaces; line and surface integrals; theorems of Green, Gauss, Stokes; applications to physics and/or introduction to differential forms. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 227.prer: A score of 68% or higher in MATH 226.

MATH 256.name: Differential equations
MATH 256.desc: Linear ordinary differential equations, Laplace transforms, Fourier series and separation of variables for linear partial differential equations. Tutorial session focuses on examples from chemical and biological engineering. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfmtree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
MATH 256.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH 256.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 264.name: Vector Calculus for Electrical Engineering
MATH 264.desc: Divergence, gradient, curl, theorems of Gauss and Stokes. Applications to Electrostatics and Magnetostatics. MATH 264 content is strongly coupled to ELEC 211 with topics and student evaluations weighted accordingly.
MATH 264.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 300.name: Introduction to Complex Variables
MATH 300.desc: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, elementary functions, Cauchy's theorem and contour integration, Laurent series, poles and residues. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 300.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.
MATH 300.crer: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 263, MATH 317.

MATH 301.name: Applied Analysis
MATH 301.desc: Integrals involving multi-valued functions, conformal mapping and applications, analytic continuation, Laplace and Fourier transforms. [3-0-0]
MATH 301.prer: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH 302.name: Introduction to Probability
MATH 302.desc: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems.   Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 302.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 303.name: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
MATH 303.desc: Discrete-time Markov chains, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, renewal theory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH 305.name: Applied Complex Analysis
MATH 305.desc: Functions of a complex variable, Cauchy-Riemann equations, contour integration, Laurent series, residues, integrals of multi-valued functions, Fourier transforms.  See Credit Exclusion List [link to http://www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414]. [3-0-0]
MATH 305.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH 308.name: Euclidean Geometry
MATH 308.desc: Classical plane geometry, solid geometry, spherical trigonometry, polyhedra, linear and affine transformations. Linear algebra proofs are used. It is suggested that MATH 307 be taken concurrently. [3-0-0]
MATH 308.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH 310.name: Abstract Linear Algebra
MATH 310.desc: Linear spaces, duality, linear mappings, matrices, determinant and trace, spectral theory, Euclidean structure. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfmtree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 310.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH 313.name: Topics in Number Theory
MATH 313.desc: Topics chosen by the instructor. These might include: division algorithms, group theory, continued fractions, primality testing, factoring.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH 318.name: Probability with Physical Applications
MATH 318.desc: Random variables, discrete and continuous distributions. Random walk, Markov chains, Monte Carlo methods. Characteristic functions, limit laws. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 318.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.
MATH 318.crer: One of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 267, MATH 316.

MATH 320.name: Real Variables I
MATH 320.desc: The real number system; real Euclidean n-space; open, closed, compact, and connected sets; Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem; sequences and series. Continuity and uniform continuity. Differentiability and mean-value theorems. [3-0-0]
MATH 320.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 226 or (b) one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

MATH 321.name: Real Variables II
MATH 321.desc: The Riemann or Riemann-Stieltjes integrals. Sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence. Approximation of continuous functions by polynomials. Fourier series. Functions from R

MATH 322.name: Introduction to Group Theory
MATH 322.desc: Groups, cosets, homomorphisms, group actions, p-groups, Sylow theorems, composition series, finitely generated Abelian groups. [3-0-0]
MATH 322.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 223, MATH 310 or (b) one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and a score of 80% or higher in MATH 220.

MATH 323.name: Introduction to Rings and Modules
MATH 323.desc: Rings, ideals, unique factorization, Euclidean rings, fields, polynomial rings, modules; structure theory of modules over a principal ideal domain. [3-0-0]

MATH 335.name: Introduction to Mathematics
MATH 335.desc: Intensive course with required tutorial. Combinatorics, probability, geometry and elementary number theory. Not for credit in the Faculty of Science. Students who obtain credit at UBC for any other mathematics course cannot in the same or later years obtain credit for MATH 335. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-2]

MATH 340.name: Introduction to Linear Programming
MATH 340.desc: Linear programming problems, dual problems, the simplex algorithm, solution of primal and dual problems, sensitivity analysis. Additional topics chosen from: Karmarkar's algorithm, non-linear programming, game theory, applications. [3-0-0]

MATH 342.name: Algebra and Coding Theory
MATH 342.desc: Error-correcting codes via abstract and linear algebra.  Emphasis on proofs and computation.  Finite fields, Hamming distance and error-correction, upper and lower bounds on the size of a code, linear codes, groups and cosets, encoding and decoding schemes. [3-0-0]
MATH 342.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH 345.name: Applied Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
MATH 345.desc: Phase plane methods, bifurcation and stability theory, limit-cycle behavior and chaos for nonlinear differential equations with applications to the sciences.  Assignments involve the use of computers. [3-1-0]
MATH 345.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH 358.name: Engineering Analysis
MATH 358.desc: Fourier series; auto- and cross-correlation; power spectra;  discrete Fourier transform; boundary-value problems; numerical methods; partial differential equations; heat, wave, Laplace, Poisson, and wave equations.  Applications to mechanical engineering and practical computing applications emphasized.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 358 or MATH 358. [3-2*-0]

MATH 360.name: Mathematical Modeling in Science
MATH 360.desc: Principles of model selection and basic modeling techniques in biology, earth science, chemistry and physics. Optimization, dynamical systems and stochastic processes. Preference will be given to Combined Major in Science students, or to students in Year 3 or higher.
MATH 360.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

MATH 398.name: Co-operative Work Placement I
MATH 398.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

MATH 399.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
MATH 399.desc: Approved and supervised technical work experience involving mathematics in industry for a minimum of 3.5 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Mathematics Co-operative Education Program.

MATH 400.name: Applied Partial Differential Equations
MATH 400.desc: Separation of variables, first order equations, Sturm-Liouville theory, integral transform methods. [3-0-0]
MATH 400.prer: One of MATH 300, MATH 305 and one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316.

MATH 401.name: Green's Functions and Variational Methods
MATH 401.desc: Green's functions for partial differential equations. Calculus of variations. Eigenfunction expansions. Rayleigh-Ritz and finite element methods.  See Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
MATH 401.prer: Either (a) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 256, MATH 257, MATH 316 or (b) MATH 400.

MATH 403.name: Stabilization and Optimal Control of Dynamical Systems
MATH 403.desc: Dynamical systems; stability by Liapunov's direct method; controllability and eigenvalue assignment for autonomous linear systems; linear-quadratic regulator, time optimal control, Pontryagin maximum principle, dynamic programming; applications in engineering, economics and resource management. [3-0-0]
MATH 403.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320. MATH 402 is recommended.

MATH 405.name: Numerical Methods for Differential Equations
