PATH 402.desc: A theoretical and practical examination of those modern concepts of haematology which relate to the practice of medical laboratory science.

PATH 404.name: Diagnostic Histochemistry
PATH 404.desc: A lecture and laboratory course that encompasses the theory and the practice of currently available histochemical techniques. This course is to supplement the histopathological technique course taken as a requirement for CSLT (RT).

PATH 405.name: Seminars in Current Topics
PATH 405.desc: Oral and written presentation and critical appraisal of scientific papers.

PATH 406.name: Clinical Chemistry
PATH 406.desc: This course will review and discuss the methodology of clinical chemistry in order to put these analytical methods into the broad perspective of the pathophysiology of human disease and biochemistry.

PATH 407.name: Medical Laboratory Toxicology: Analytical, Clinical
PATH 407.desc: A theoretical and practical examination of analytical and pathophysiological aspects of clinical and forensic toxicology.

PATH 408.name: Laboratory Administration
PATH 408.desc: Personnel management, staff management relationships, stock control, record keeping, etc. Medicolegal aspects of medical laboratory science. Theory and practice of quality control. Use of computers in the medical laboratory.

PATH 427.name: Basic Principles of Infection Prevention and Control
PATH 427.desc: This course provides the basic principles to prevent the spread of microorganisms pathogenic to humans. It may be taken towards a Certificate in Infection Control.

PATH 437.name: Viral Infections in Humans
PATH 437.desc: Interactions between viruses and humans; pathogenesis; prompt virological diagnosis; rationale for antiviral chemotherapy and prophylaxis. [3-0-0]

PATH 467.name: Basic Microbiology for Infection Control
PATH 467.desc: The identification, clinical significance, and transmission of pathogenic organisms are presented. This course is available by correspondence or webCT. It may be taken towards fulfillment of the Certificate in Infection Control.

PATH 477.name: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
PATH 477.desc: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control.

PCTH 201.name: Drugs and Society
PCTH 201.desc: Introductory principles of drug action. Historical and present day medical and non-medical use of drugs. [3-0]
PCTH 201.prer: One of Biology 12, BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155, or SCIE 001.  Second-year standing is required.

PCTH 300.name: Introduction to Pharmacology
PCTH 300.desc: The concepts, language and techniques of scientific pharmacology. Intended primarily for Honours and Major students in Pharmacology. [3-3-0]
PCTH 300.prer: Either (a) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 233, CHEM 235 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, CHEM 203, CHEM 204;  and CHEM 211 and one of CHEM 205, CHEM 201. Permission of the undergraduate adviser is required.
preq: CHEM 201. Permission of the undergraduate adviser is required

PCTH 302.name: Introductory Pharmacology Laboratory
PCTH 302.desc: A series of experimental demonstrations and individual laboratory experiments illustrating the basic principles of pharmacology. [1-3*]

PCTH 305.name: Basic Human Pharmacology
PCTH 305.desc: Lectures and assigned reading on the effects, mechanisms of action, absorption, distribution, fate and excretion of major classes of therapeutic agents. Indications for the use of particular drugs will be discussed in terms of risk versus benefit for the individual and for society. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

PCTH 325.name: Rational Basis of Drug Therapy
PCTH 325.desc: The principles and applications underlying the action and disposition of therapeutic agents (including alternative medicines) in the body.  Use of drugs as tools in experimental research. [3-0]
PCTH 325.prer: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOC 300.

PCTH 400.name: Systematic Pharmacology
PCTH 400.desc: Lectures and discussions in scientific pharmacology. All aspects of the study of drugs will be covered, but the course will concentrate on the scientific aspects of the pharmacology of neurohumoral transmission, mathematics of pharmacology, cardiovascular and clinical pharmacology, and to a lesser extent on the pharmacology of various organs and tissues. [3-0-1*]

PCTH 402.name: Systematic Pharmacology Laboratory
PCTH 402.desc: A series of demonstrated, group, and individual laboratory experiments designed to illustrate the concepts and hypotheses of pharmacology. The course is restricted to Honours students in Pharmacology, but may be taken by others with permission of the department head. [0-9; 0-9]

PCTH 404.name: Drug Assay and Pharmacometrics
PCTH 404.desc: The techniques, including methods of statistical analysis, used to detect and measure the actions of endogenous or exogenous chemicals, using chemical assays and bioassays as appropriate. Enrolment limited to students in Pharmacology and others with permission of the department head. [1-0; 2-0]

PHAR 400.name: Pharmacy Management
PHAR 400.desc: Application of management principles to pharmacy operations.

PHAR 406.name: Drug Safety
PHAR 406.desc: Pharmacist knowledge and skills in relation to current issues in drug safety.

PHAR 408.name: Clinical Pharmacokinetics
PHAR 408.desc: Lectures and discussions of topics on the application of pharmacokinetic principles and the use of therapeutic drug level monitoring in clinical pharmacy practice.
PHAR 408.prer: Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum.
preq: Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum

PHAR 409.name: Renal Pharmacotherapeutics
PHAR 409.desc: Case-based approach to the pathophysiology, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy in nephrology with emphasis on the integration and application of fundamental principles to clinical situations in class and during their experiential component.
PHAR 409.prer: Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum.
preq: Successful completion of all required courses in the first three years of the pharmacy curriculum

PHAR 440.name: Pain Research and Therapy
PHAR 440.desc: A multidisciplinary course dealing with basic mechanisms and the clinical management of acute and chronic pain.

PHAR 448.name: Environmental and Cellular Toxicology
PHAR 448.desc: Basic principles of toxicology; toxicity of drugs and environmental chemicals, including pesticides.

PHAR 456.name: Applied Pharmacoeconomics
PHAR 456.desc: Principles and methods of economic assessments to determine the value of health technologies, with a focus on pharmaceuticals and services provided by pharmacists.

PHAR 457.name: Pharmaceutical Care in Aboriginal Health
PHAR 457.desc: Aboriginal health in Canada and the role a culturally-competent pharmacist can have in collaborating with other health professionals and Aboriginal communities in providing care and healing.

PHAR 489.name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Institutional
PHAR 489.desc: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship emphasizing integration of knowledge and skills in developing and assessing therapeutic plans for patients in institutional practice.

PHAR 499.name: Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences IV
PHAR 499.desc: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts.

PHIL 100.name: Introduction to Philosophy
PHIL 100.desc: Basic problems and methods of Philosophy. Topics such as the existence of God, the nature and scope of human knowledge, the relationship between mind and body, personal identity, free will, issues and problems in moral philosophy. Credit will not be granted for both PHIL 100 and either or both PHIL 101 or PHIL 102.

PHIL 125.name: Introduction to Scientific Reasoning
PHIL 125.desc: Historical and logical analysis of various types of scientific hypotheses and the data that support or undermine them. This course is restricted to students with fewer than 90 credits.

PHIL 211.name: Greek Philosophy I
PHIL 211.desc: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato.  Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

PHIL 212.name: Greek Philosophy II
PHIL 212.desc: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310.

PHIL 235.name: Contemporary Moral Issues
PHIL 235.desc: Moral issues such as life and death decisions, paternalism, markets, animal welfare, technology, and global justice.

PHIL 240.name: Introduction to Epistemology
PHIL 240.desc: Topics in epistemology such as skepticism, truth, justification, a priori and a posteriori knowledge. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL 250.name: Minds and Machines
PHIL 250.desc: Philosophical and theoretical issues that pertain to how mental phenomena fit into the material world. Examine questions such as whether a sophisticated enough computer should be deemed a conscious intelligent being. Focus on philosophical literature on consciousness, intelligence, animal minds, and the mind-body relation. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 250 or PHIL 150.

PHIL 260.name: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
PHIL 260.desc: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

PHIL 310.name: The Philosophy of Plato
PHIL 310.desc: A study of Plato's dialogues and his influence on subsequent philosophy.

PHIL 311.name: The Philosophy of Aristotle
PHIL 311.desc: A study of Aristotle's writings and his influence on subsequent philosophy.

PHIL 314.name: Philosophy in the 17th Century
PHIL 314.desc: Survey of 17th-century philosophy from Bacon to Leibniz, including the writings of Hobbes, Descartes, and Spinoza. The influence of science and religion on philosophical thought.

PHIL 315.name: Philosophy in the 18th Century
PHIL 315.desc: Survey of 18th-century philosophy from Locke to Kant, including the writings of Berkeley, Rousseau, and Hume. The influence of science and religion on philosophy.

PHIL 316.name: Philosophy After 1800
PHIL 316.desc: Survey of 19th and 20th century philosophy. May include Hegel, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Mill, Meinong, Brentano, the British Idealists, Russell, and Moore. Social and political currents in 19th century philosophical thought.

PHIL 320.name: Logic: Metatheory and Computability
PHIL 320.desc: Continuation of PHIL 220. A system of deduction for predicate logic is selected for further study. Completeness of this system and other metatheoretic results are proved. Other topics include computability, recursive function theory, incompleteness and decidability.

PHIL 321.name: Induction, Decision and Game Theory
PHIL 321.desc: Formal methods relevant to probabilistic and inductive reasoning. Decision theory, game theory, axiomatic probability theory and its interpretations, belief dynamics, simulation and modelling.
PHIL 321.prer: One of PHIL 125, PHIL 220 or instructor permission.

PHIL 326.name: Philosophy of Language I
PHIL 326.desc: Philosophical discussion of language, meaning, and communication. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 326 or PHIL 425.
PHIL 326.prer: 9 credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

PHIL 330.name: Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL 330.desc: Theories of political and legal obligation and authority, legal reasoning, society and the state. Readings in classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL 332.name: Environmental Ethics
PHIL 332.desc: Moral problems arising in the context of human relationships to nature and to non-human living things, considered in terms of both general moral theory and policy formation. Topics include moral standing, animal rights, obligations to future generations, pollution, hazardous materials, the depletion of natural resources and the treatment of non-human living things. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 332 or PHIL 435.

PHIL 334.name: Sex, Gender and Philosophy
PHIL 334.desc: Relationship between sex, gender, and philosophy. Topics may include ethics, epistemology, science, social relations, law, and personhood.

PHIL 335.name: Power and Oppression
PHIL 335.desc: Philosophical approaches to historical problems of inequality and social harm, with readings drawn from historical and contemporary sources. Topics to be studied may include slavery, colonialism, labour, and the position of women in society.

PHIL 339.name: Philosophy of Art
PHIL 339.desc: Topics include art and perception, art and reality, imagination, expression, censorship, and the role of art in human life.

PHIL 340.name: Introduction to Metaphysics
PHIL 340.desc: Topics in metaphysics such as the nature of physical reality, personal identity, the mind/body problem, free will, causation and action theory. Readings from classic and contemporary texts.

PHIL 347.name: Philosophy of Religion
PHIL 347.desc: A critical and analytical examination of arguments for and arguments against the existence of God, and other related topics. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 347 or PHIL 349.

PHIL 360.name: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
PHIL 360.desc: An examination of historical, conceptual and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

PHIL 362.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Aristotle to Adam Smith
PHIL 362.desc: The development of economic thought from Aristotle to Adam Smith, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution, and economic growth.

PHIL 363.name: History and Philosophy of Economics from Ricardo to Keynes
PHIL 363.desc: The development of economic thought from David Ricardo up to the present, including such figures as Malthus, Mill, Jevons, and Keynes, focusing primarily on the conceptual foundations of economics, particularly the problems of value, distribution and growth.

PHIL 364.name: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
PHIL 364.desc: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

PHIL 369.name: Philosophy of Science
PHIL 369.desc: Issues common to all sciences. Philosophical questions including the character of scientific laws, theories and revolutions, the nature of scientific confirmation, causality, explanation and prediction, and the use of logic and probability. Difficulties in the interpretation of atomic physics and questions about relationships between biology and psychology. No philosophical background is assumed. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 369 or PHIL 460.

PHIL 385.name: Existentialism
PHIL 385.desc: Meaning, identity and alienation as explored in the works for example of Kierkegaard, Dostoyevsky, Tolstoy, Sartre, and Camus.

PHIL 388.name: Buddhist, Brahmanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
PHIL 388.desc: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

PHIL 418.name: Topics in Twentieth-Century Philosophy
PHIL 418.desc: Intensive study of a major philosopher such as Wittgenstein, Russell, or Heidegger, or school, such as pragmatism or logical empiricism.

PHIL 432.name: Topics in Ethical Theory
PHIL 432.desc: Classic or contemporary works in ethical theory.
PHIL 432.prer: 9 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above; PHIL 230 is recommended.

PHIL 441.name: Philosophy of Perception
PHIL 441.desc: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge.
PHIL 441.prer: PHIL 240 or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.
preq: COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level

PHIL 448.name: Topics in Continental Philosophy
PHIL 448.desc: A study of European philosophers from amongst Husserl, Heidegger, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Lacan, Levinas, and others. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 448 or PHIL 449.

PHIL 451.name: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL 451.desc: The nature of the mental and physical; the relation between minds and bodies; the character of psychological explanation.
PHIL 451.prer: PHIL 240 or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.
preq: COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level

PHIL 461.name: Philosophy of Social Science
PHIL 461.desc: Topics in the philosophy of science of special concern to the social and behavioural sciences; hypotheses and explanation; principles, theories, models; the formation of scientific concepts; the function of mathematics in social science.
PHIL 461.prer: 9 credits at the 200-level or above from philosophy, anthropology, geography, economics, history, political science, psychology or sociology.

PHIL 491.name: Seminar for Majors in Philosophy
PHIL 491.desc: Selected problems in philosophy, with attention to methods of research. Check with the department for specific topics. Primarily for fourth-year Philosophy Major students, but also open to Philosophy Honours.

PHRM 100.name: Foundations of Pharmacy
PHRM 100.desc: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities.

PHRM 111.name: Medication Management I
PHRM 111.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on: an introduction to infectious diseases; musculoskeletal disorders; dermatology; eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders; and hematology.

PHRM 131.name: Study Design and Interpretation I
PHRM 131.desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials.

PHRM 141.name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice I
PHRM 141.desc: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice.

PHRM 161.name: Technology in Healthcare
PHRM 161.desc: Knowledge and skills related to the role and applications of technology in health care.

PHRM 211.name: Medication Management II
PHRM 211.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on respirology and cardiovascular disorders.

PHRM 212.name: Medication Management III
PHRM 212.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on nephrology, endocrinology, and neurology.

PHRM 221.name: Nutrition for Pharmacists
PHRM 221.desc: Foundations of nutrition, nutrition for healthy individuals through the lifespan, and selected clinical applications of nutrition in pharmacy practice.

PHRM 231.name: Study Design and Interpretation II
PHRM 231.desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, non-inferiority designs, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines.

PHRM 241.name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice II
PHRM 241.desc: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice, focusing on the roles and training opportunities for pharmacists in specialty areas of outpatient and inpatient practice.

PHRM 251.name: Institutional Practice Skills
PHRM 251.desc: Preparation for experiential learning in the hospital setting. Focuses on enhancing familiarity with the care environment and developing skills suited for students to apply to patient care during institutional experiential rotations.

PHRM 311.name: Medication Management IV
PHRM 311.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on psychiatry; gastroenterology disorders; and oncology and palliative care.

PHRM 312.name: Medication Management V
PHRM 312.desc: Modules and integration activities focusing on special infectious diseases; obstetrics, gynecology, sexual health, and genito-urinary disorders; and toxicology.

PHRM 341.name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice III
PHRM 341.desc: Current and potential roles for pharmacists, and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice. Focus on the role of pharmacists as patient educators, researchers and collaborators in interprofessional teams.

PHRM 351.name: Practice Management and Leadership
PHRM 351.desc: Application of management and leadership principles and skills to pharmacy operations.

PHYS 107.name: Enriched Physics 1
PHYS 107.desc: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-3*-1*]
PHYS 107.prer: Either (a) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in MATH 12;  or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 100 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in PREC 12;  or (d) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 12 and a score of 85% or higher in CALC 12. MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12, PHYS 12 = Physics 12.
PHYS 107.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
preq: higher in CALC 12. MATH 12 = Principles of Mathematics 12; PREC 12 = Pre-calculus 12; CALC 12 = Calculus 12

PHYS 108.name: Enriched Physics II
PHYS 108.desc: Electricity and magnetism, electrical circuits, induction, electromagnetic waves, Maxwell's equations and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-0-1]
PHYS 108.prer: Either (a) PHYS 107 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 101 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 117.
PHYS 108.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS 109.name: Enriched Experimental Physics
PHYS 109.desc: A laboratory course accompanying PHYS 108 with emphasis on data collection and analysis and experimental techniques. [0-3-0]

PHYS 117.name: Dynamics and Waves
PHYS 117.desc: Kinematics including curvilinear motion. Forces and Newton's laws of motion. Work-energy theorem, conservation of energy. Conservation of momentum, collisions. Torque, rotational dynamics, angular momentum. Oscillations and waves. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS 117.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 119.name: Experimental Physics Lab
PHYS 119.desc: Introductory laboratory course, with emphasis on data collection, data analysis techniques, and scientific reasoning. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [0-3-0]
PHYS 119.prer: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 117.
PHYS 119.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 157.name: Introductory Physics for Engineers I
PHYS 157.desc: Heat, thermodynamics, oscillations, waves, and sound. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS 157.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 158.name: Introductory Physics for Engineers II
PHYS 158.desc: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, optics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS 158.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS 159.name: Introductory Physics Laboratory for Engineers
PHYS 159.desc: A laboratory course with emphasis on experimental design, measurement and analysis techniques. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [0-3-0]

PHYS 170.name: Mechanics I
PHYS 170.desc: Statics of particles, equilibrium or rigid bodies, rigid body statics and internal forces, trusses; kinematics: rectilinear motion; dynamics:  Newton's second law, friction, impulse, momentum, work and energy.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1]
PHYS 170.prer: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.
PHYS 170.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS 200.name: Relativity and Quanta
PHYS 200.desc: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei. [4-0-0]
PHYS 200.prer: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS 203.name: Thermal Physics I
PHYS 203.desc: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical physics; entropy, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, free energy, phase transitions, Boltzmann statistics, quantum statistics. [4-0-0]
PHYS 203.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.
PHYS 203.crer: One of MATH 217, MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS 210.name: Introduction to Computational Physics
PHYS 210.desc: Introduction to UNIX/Linux; software tools for processing, fitting and displaying data; numerical methods and application in the physical sciences. [2-3-0]
PHYS 210.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

PHYS 216.name: Intermediate Mechanics
PHYS 216.desc: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. [3-0-1]
PHYS 216.prer: One of PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 170, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
PHYS 216.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS 219.name: Intermediate Experimental Physics I
PHYS 219.desc: Analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics, analog-to-digital converters and an introduction to use of computers in data analysis and simulations. [1-3-0]
PHYS 219.prer: Either (a) one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118 and one of PHYS 109, PHYS 119;  or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001.
PHYS 219.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253.

PHYS 229.name: Intermediate Experimental Physics II
PHYS 229.desc: Thermodynamics experiments, modern physics experiments and use of computers in data analysis. [0-3-1*]

PHYS 301.name: Electricity and Magnetism
PHYS 301.desc: Maxwell's equations and their applications, electrical fields and potentials of static charge distributions, current, fields of moving charges, magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction. [3-0-1]
PHYS 301.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

PHYS 304.name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
PHYS 304.desc: Principles and applications of quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, expectation values, Hermitian operators, commuting observables,  one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, three dimensional systems, time dependent perturbations. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

PHYS 305.name: Introduction to Biophysics
PHYS 305.desc: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes. [3-0-0]
PHYS 305.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and either (a) PHYS 203 or (b) one of ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.

PHYS 306.name: Advanced Mechanics
PHYS 306.desc: Variational calculus, Lagrangian dynamics, rigid body motion including free and forced precession, Hamiltonian mechanics, Poisson brackets, canonical coordinates, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action angle variables. Introduction to dynamical chaos: determinism, Lyapunov exponents. [3-0-1]
PHYS 306.prer: One of PHYS 216, ENPH 270 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

PHYS 309.name: Electrical Laboratory
PHYS 309.desc: Selected experiments in electromagnetism and electronics; computer data acquisition; advanced data analysis and simulation. [1-4-0]

PHYS 312.name: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
PHYS 312.desc: The application of ordinary and partial differential equations to physical problems; boundary and initial value problems associated with heat, wave and Laplace equations. Fourier analysis; expansions in Bessel and Legendre functions. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 312 and MATH 316. [3-0-0]

PHYS 315.name: Physics of Materials
PHYS 315.desc: Crystal structure, elasticity and phonons, elementary electronic transport, defects, alloys, liquid crystals and polymers. [3-0-0]
PHYS 315.prer: One of PHYS 203, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of PHYS 200, PHYS 250, CHEM 312.

PHYS 319.name: Electronics Laboratory
PHYS 319.desc: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices. [1-4-0]

PHYS 333.name: Energy and Climate
PHYS 333.desc: The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change.  Not to be used to satisfy an upper-level specialization requirement in any Physics & Astronomy major or honours specialization, but may be used as an upper-level science elective. [3-0-0]
PHYS 333.prer: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS 340.name: From Atoms to the Universe
PHYS 340.desc: Ancient Greek ideas of substance and forms and modern concepts of forces and fields. The twentieth-century quantum revolution. The modern universe, from quarks and atoms to the big bang. Quantum paradoxes. Not for credit in the faculties of Science and Applied Science. No mathematics required. [3-0-0]

PHYS 341.name: Physics of Music
PHYS 341.desc: An introduction to the physical principles important to the production, transmission and perception of musical sounds. The treatment will be non-mathematical; with emphasis on demonstrations. Topics may include the description of sound waves, resonances, scales, physics of hearing, examination of specific musical instruments, etc. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [3-0-0]

PHYS 348.name: Frontiers in Physics and Astronomy
PHYS 348.desc: Current research topics in physics and astronomy are investigated and explored. Technical communication and research skills are studied and developed via oral presentations and written scientific reports on these current research topics. [3-0-0]
PHYS 348.prer: Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.
preq: Third-year standing in a physics honours program

PHYS 349.name: Directed Research Project in Physics
PHYS 349.desc: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report. This course requires  approval of the course instructor  and  program  advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. [1*-6-0]

PHYS 350.name: Applications of Classical Mechanics
PHYS 350.desc: Review of principles. Particle mechanics: Euler's equations, tops and gyroscopes, motion of the Earth, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian methods. Variational principles in optics and mechanics, Liouville's theorem and statistical mechanics. The relationship between classical and quantum mechanics. [3-0-0]

PHYS 400.name: Introduction to Elementary Particles
PHYS 400.desc: Standard model, classification of elementary particles and forces of nature, symmetries, conservation laws, quark model, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and the theory of weak interactions. [3-0-0]

PHYS 401.name: Electromagnetic Theory
PHYS 401.desc: Applications of Maxwell's theory. Wave propagation in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas, wave guides, radiation, antennae, and special relativity. [3-0-0]

PHYS 402.name: Applications of Quantum Mechanics
PHYS 402.desc: Spin and angular momentum addition, perturbation methods, and applications in the fields of Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, and Solid State Physics. [3-0-0]

PHYS 403.name: Statistical Mechanics
PHYS 403.desc: Principles and applications of  statistical mechanics. Ideal gases, degenerate Fermi gases, Bose-Einstein condensation, black body radiation, fluctuations and phase transitions. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
PHYS 403.prer: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450, CHEM 312. One of MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251 is recommended.

PHYS 404.name: Introduction to Medical Physics
PHYS 404.desc: Radiotherapy, X-ray imaging, nuclear medicine, magnetic resonance imaging and biomedical optics. [3-0-0]
PHYS 404.prer: Third yearstanding in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 267) is recommended.
preq: Applied Science is required. MATH 200 is recommended

PHYS 405.name: Radiation Biophysics
PHYS 405.desc: Physical and chemical interactions of ionizing radiations and their biological effects at the cellular, tissue and whole-animal levels. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 405, 536. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]
PHYS 405.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.

PHYS 407.name: Introduction to General Relativity
PHYS 407.desc: Physical consequences of Einstein's equations, including the principle of equivalence, curved space-time, geodesics, the Schwarzschild solution, deflection of light, black holes, and gravitational radiation. [3-0-0]
PHYS 407.prer: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255. PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.

PHYS 408.name: Optics
PHYS 408.desc: Principles and applications of optical physics. Interference, diffraction, coherence, polarization, Fresnel relations, optical coatings, waves in dielectric media, Gaussian beams, waveguides, optical cavities, lasers, fibre optics, and Fourier optics. [3-3-0]
PHYS 408.prer: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

PHYS 410.name: Computational Physics
PHYS 410.desc: Scientific programming applied to problems in physics. Fundamentals of numerical analysis for continuum problems. Solution of linear and non-linear algebraic systems, ordinary differential equations and stochastic problems. [3-0-1]
PHYS 410.prer: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 111, APSC 160.

PHYS 438.name: Zoological Physics
PHYS 438.desc: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping. [3-0-0]
PHYS 438.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. BIOL 325 is recommended.

PHYS 449.name: Honours Thesis
PHYS 449.desc: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis. [1*-6-0]

PHYS 473.name: Applied Nuclear Physics
PHYS 473.desc: Radioactive decay and radiations, nuclear properties, interactions of neutrons, physical principles of power reactors, nuclear fusion, radiation monitoring, and safety. [3-0-1*]

PHYS 474.name: Applied Solid State Physics
PHYS 474.desc: Symmetry of crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, band theory, conduction in metals and semiconductors, phonons and superconductivity. [3-0-0]

PHYS 490.name: Student Directed Seminar
PHYS 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars".  Cannot be used as a specialization requirement in any PHYS and/or ASTR specialization.

PLAN 211.name: City-Making: A Global Perspective
PLAN 211.desc: Contemporary city development trends, policies, and practices across the globe as explored against the backdrop of culture and technology. Includes hands-on learning.
PLAN 211.prer: Second-year standing or above in any program.

PLAN 221.name: City Visuals
PLAN 221.desc: An exploratory journey through the vast world of visualizing the city and ways of representing the built environment, including how to both interpret and use visualizations to read the city.
PLAN 221.prer: Second-year standing or above in any program.

PLAN 331.name: The Just City in a Divided World
PLAN 331.desc: Considers the city as a terrain for the manifestation and mediation of social justice. Explores how the allocation of land, goods, and services in cities (re)produces social stratification, and how institutions and civil society negotiate just and unjust outcomes.
PLAN 331.prer: Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.
preq: above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor

PLAN 425.name: Urban Planning Issues and Concepts
PLAN 425.desc: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning.

POLI 220.name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
POLI 220.desc: A comparative analysis of foreign governments. Specific countries to be covered will vary according to section; consult the brochure issued by the Department.

POLI 303.name: Federalism in Canada
POLI 303.desc: Theory and practice of federalism; cultural duality, social stresses, and problems of flexibility. The constitution and role of the courts.

POLI 304.name: British Columbia Government and Politics
POLI 304.desc: An examination of the party system, and other institutions and processes of the British Columbia political system.

POLI 309.name: Canadian Perspectives on Human Rights
POLI 309.desc: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 310.name: Parliament and Party: The Strategy of Politics
POLI 310.desc: Parliamentary and party politics, showing how politicians in Canada and other countries strike bargains with allies, outmanoeuvre opponents in debates, and manipulate institutional rules.

POLI 327.name: European Integration
POLI 327.desc: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union.

POLI 332.name: Politics and Government of Latin America
POLI 332.desc: A comparative examination of democracy and authoritarianism in Latin America: populism, corporatism, bureaucratic authoritarianism, transitions from authoritarianism, and contemporary debates on the quality and diversity of democratic institutions.

POLI 345.name: Gender and Politics: Political Thought and Practice
POLI 345.desc: The role of gender in Western political theory and the implications for the practice of politics.

POLI 366.name: International Political Economy
POLI 366.desc: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Pre-requisite: ECON 100 or 309 are recommended.

POLI 377.name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
POLI 377.desc: Evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
POLI 377.prer: Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program

POLI 380.name: Quantitative Methods in Political Science
POLI 380.desc: An introduction to quantitative methods as utilized in the study of Political Science. Not available for credit in the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

POLI 390.name: Honours Seminar
POLI 390.desc: An examination of the dimensions of Political Science and the major debates within the discipline.

POLI 461.name: Peace and Conflict Studies
POLI 461.desc: A seminar on a selected topic concerning the causes of war and strategies for the promotion of peace. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 461.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.
preq: Two of POLI 260 POLI 360 POLI 361 POLI 362 POLI 363 POLI 364 POLI 365 POLI 366 POLI 367 POLI 368 POLI 369 POLI 370

POLI 462.name: International Relations Theory
POLI 462.desc: This seminar examines some of the major theoretical approaches to the study of international relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 462.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.
preq: Two of POLI 260 POLI 360 POLI 361 POLI 362 POLI 363 POLI 364 POLI 365 POLI 366 POLI 367 POLI 368 POLI 369 POLI 370

POLI 463.name: International Interdependence
POLI 463.desc: This seminar analyses issues relating to the politics of international economic relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the brochure issued by the Department.
POLI 463.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370. 6 credits of ECON are recommended.
preq: Two of POLI 260 POLI 360 POLI 361 POLI 362 POLI 363 POLI 364 POLI 365 POLI 366 POLI 367 POLI 368 POLI 369 POLI 370. 6 credits of ECON are recommended

POLI 492.name: Honours Thesis
POLI 492.desc: In consultation with faculty, students develop a research project, report on their project during seminars, give feedback on their fellow students' projects, and write a thesis.

POLS 300.name: Intermediate Polish
POLS 300.desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition.

POLS 426.name: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English)
POLS 426.desc: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film.

PORT 102.name: First-Year Portuguese II
PORT 102.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 102 or PORT 110.

PORT 110.name: Elementary Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
PORT 110.desc: A single-term alternative to PORT 101 and 102 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 110, PORT 101, or PORT 102.

PORT 201.name: Second-Year Portuguese I
PORT 201.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 201 or PORT 210

PORT 202.name: Second-Year Portuguese II
PORT 202.desc: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit may be granted for only one of PORT 202 or PORT 210.

PORT 210.name: Intermediate Portuguese for Romance Language Speakers
PORT 210.desc: A single-term alternative to PORT 201 and 202 for students with heritage Portuguese or another Romance language. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 210, PORT 201, or PORT 202.
PORT 210.prer: PORT 110. Heritage speakers who feel ready to enter PORT 210 directly should consult the undergraduate adviser in Portuguese.
preq: PORT 110. Heritage speakers who feel ready to enter PORT 210 directly should consult the undergraduate adviser in Portuguese

PORT 222.name: Introduction to the Analysis of Portuguese and Brazilian Cultures
PORT 222.desc: Critical analysis of different cultural genres, including music, film and visual art through the study of selected Portuguese and Brazilian texts. This course is taught in English.

PORT 301.name: Advanced Portuguese
PORT 301.desc: Advanced work in composition for students who have reached the Language-Requirement level of Portuguese.

PORT 392.name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature

PORT 405.name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture
PORT 405.desc: Selected topics on Portuguese and Brazilian Culture. Please refer to section details for up to date course offering information. This course is taught in English.

PSYC 207.name: Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology
PSYC 207.desc: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in neuroscience, cognition, perception, memory, and learning.

PSYC 208.name: Contemporary Topics in Social, Developmental, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
PSYC 208.desc: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in social, developmental, personality, and clinical psychology.

PSYC 216.name: Questioning Psychological Science in the Media
PSYC 216.desc: Use basic principles of quantitative psychological research methods to critique psychological claims presented in the media and to translate psychological science to everyday life.

PSYC 260.name: Experimental Psychology and Laboratory
PSYC 260.desc: Detailed introduction to experimental and theoretical aspects of motivation, sensation, perception and learning.
PSYC 260.prer: Completion of first-year Science program and permission of the department head is also required.
PSYC 260.crer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.
preq: permission of the department head is also required

PSYC 301.name: Brain Dysfunction and Recovery
PSYC 301.desc: Cognitive and behavioral impairments resulting from brain dysfunction. Focus on the efficacy of various intervention approaches.
PSYC 301.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not PSYC 205 or PSYC 263).

PSYC 302.name: Infancy
PSYC 302.desc: Human cognition, perception, motor, social, emotional needs, brain development and their interactions from birth until the emergence of language.
PSYC 302.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 304.name: Brain and Behaviour
PSYC 304.desc: The neurobiological bases of behaviour; brain processes involved in perception, motivation, emotion, psychopathology, learning and memory. Open to all Arts and Science majors except those in the B.Sc. Psychology program. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 304 and PSYC 360.
PSYC 304.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) two of PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (d) PSYC 260.
preq: two of PSYC 207 PSYC 208 PSYC 217 PSYC 218

PSYC 307.name: Cultural Psychology
PSYC 307.desc: Cultural influences on human thought and behaviour; interactions of culture and self; multicultural experiences; intercultural relations; methodological issues.
PSYC 307.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 319.name: Applied Developmental Psychology
PSYC 319.desc: Applications of theories and research in developmental psychology to contemporary social issues; topics may include daycare, child abuse, divorce and remarriage, substance abuse, sexuality.
PSYC 319.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 321.name: Environmental Psychology
PSYC 321.desc: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.
PSYC 321.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 331.name: Forensic Psychology
PSYC 331.desc: The application of psychological theory and research to legal issues and the criminal justice system. Credit will not be granted for both PSYC 331 and PSYC 430.
PSYC 331.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level psychology (but not PSYC 205 or 263).

PSYC 335.name: Gambling and Decision Making
PSYC 335.desc: The psychology of gambling behaviour, with emphasis on relevant work from judgment and decision-making, the cognitive neuroscience of choice, and clinical perspectives on disordered gambling.
PSYC 335.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

PSYC 336.name: The Psychology of Language I
PSYC 336.desc: Psychological abilities underlying human language; language processing, lexical representation, and principles of online conversation; animal versus human communication.
PSYC 336.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.
preq: PSYC 102. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329

PSYC 349.name: Honours Seminar
PSYC 349.desc: Orientation to psychological research, with special emphasis on ongoing research within the department; effective presentation of research findings, oral and written; critical evaluation of research. Requires a research project.
PSYC 349.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102;  and all of PSYC 217,  218.

PSYC 358.name: Evolutionary Psychology
PSYC 358.desc: Theory and research on the evolution of the human mind, with emphasis on implications for cognition and behaviour in contemporary environments.
PSYC 358.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level PSYC (but not PSYC 205 and 263).

PSYC 359.name: Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences
PSYC 359.desc: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications.
PSYC 359.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366.

PSYC 360.name: Biopsychology
PSYC 360.desc: The relationship between the nervous system and behaviour; the physiological basis of perception, motivation, learning, and memory. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PSYC 361.name: Motivation
PSYC 361.desc: Experimental analysis of hunger, thirst, exploratory and curiosity behaviour, maternal and reproductive behaviour, fixed action patterns, and complex processes involved in social motivation with emphasis on the biological basis of motivation.
PSYC 361.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (b) one of PSYC 100, PSYC 260, PSYC 304, PSYC 360.

PSYC 363.name: Principles of Animal Learning
PSYC 363.desc: Introduction to basic theories of non-associative learning, classical and operant conditioning. Experimental findings from behavioural and biological analyses with animals and humans.

PSYC 365.name: Cognitive Neuroscience
PSYC 365.desc: Brain mechanisms underlying cognitive processes such as perception, attention, consciousness, and memory.

PSYC 366.name: Methods in Research
PSYC 366.desc: Detailed coverage of basic research methods; the design of experiments and statistical analysis; methods will be applied in laboratory and project work. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List:  www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

PSYC 367.name: Sensory Systems
PSYC 367.desc: Anatomy and physiology of the sensory pathways and their relation to perception.
PSYC 367.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 368.name: Perceptual Processing
PSYC 368.desc: Perceptual phenomena and their underlying brain mechanisms.

PSYC 401.name: Clinical Psychology
PSYC 401.desc: Theoretical and research foundations of the processes of assessment and behaviour modification in clinical psychology. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 400 and PSYC 401.

PSYC 404.name: Psychology of Religion
PSYC 404.desc: Cognitive, emotional, and motivational underpinnings of religious behaviour; supernatural beliefs, magical thinking, ritual, sacrifice; religion's role in morality, prosociality, health, violence, and intergroup relations.
PSYC 404.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 307, PSYC 308.

PSYC 409.name: Cognitive Neuropsychology
PSYC 409.desc: The structure of the mind as revealed by brain injury, neurological illness, and surgical intervention.  Topics include attention, memory, language, sense of self, topographic awareness, moral reasoning, emotion, theory of mind, and social awareness.
PSYC 409.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 309, PSYC 365.

PSYC 449.name: Honours Seminar and Essay
PSYC 449.desc: Students carry out a research project and report on its development during seminars. Students also discuss research by Departmental staff, with emphasis on choice of problems, research design and data analysis.

PSYC 460.name: Behavioural Neuroendocrinology
PSYC 460.desc: Detailed examination of the interaction between hormones and neural control of reproductive and non-reproductive behaviours; emphasis on gonadal and adrenal hormone effects on learning and memory in the brain.

PSYC 461.name: Neuroplasticity and Behaviour
PSYC 461.desc: Experimental findings and theory documenting the plasticity of the brain and its relationship to behaviour: emphasis on gene regulation, neurogenesis and cell morphology changes in relation to learning and experience.

PSYC 462.name: Drugs and Behavioural Neuroscience
PSYC 462.desc: Introduction to neurochemical systems and functional neuroanatomy; animal models of human cognitive processes and mental disorders; neurochemical foundations and treatments for mental disorders. BIOL 205 and/or PCTH 325 recommended.

PUNJ 102.name: Introductory Punjabi
PUNJ 102.desc: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.

PUNJ 200.name: Intermediate Punjabi
PUNJ 200.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ 300.name: Advanced Punjabi
PUNJ 300.desc: Advanced grammar and conversation. Major genres of Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 301/302 or PUNJ 300.

PUNJ 402.name: Medieval and Early Modern Punjabi Literature
PUNJ 402.desc: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

RELG 101.name: Introduction to the Western (Abrahamic) Religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
RELG 101.desc: An overview of the three main western monotheistic (Abrahamic) religions, together with the concepts used in studying religion, The focus will be on the origins and representative texts along with some historical development and current experience of each religion.

RELG 201.name: Near Eastern and Biblical Mythology
RELG 201.desc: An introduction to the world of Near Eastern mythology, from the Gilgamesh Epic to the Book of Genesis and beyond.

RELG 203.name: Scriptures of the Near East
RELG 203.desc: An introduction to the scriptures of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

RELG 207.name: Classical Islam
RELG 207.desc: The history and culture, values, and achievements of Islamic societies from 700-1500; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

RELG 208.name: Modern Islam
RELG 208.desc: The history and culture, values, and socio-political movements of the Islamic world from 1500 to the modern day; the interconnections between power, politics, gender, and the arts in modern Islamic societies. This course is highly recommended as a basis for all 300- and 400-level Islamic Studies courses.

RELG 209.name: Eden to Exile: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
RELG 209.desc: An overview of the Hebrew Bible ("Old Testament"), with emphasis on its ancient Near Eastern context; its competing religious perspectives; and its limits as a historical source.

RELG 306.name: Archaeology and the Bible
RELG 306.desc: The impact of archaeological research on understanding the history and religion of ancient Israel.

RELG 307.name: Sex, Lies, and Violence in the Hebrew Bible
RELG 307.desc: An exploration of the Bible's "dark side," with emphasis on texts that center on sex, deceit, and murder.

RELG 317.name: The Origins of Christianity: Social, Religious, and Political Milieux
RELG 317.desc: The origins of Christianity as reflected in early Christian literature of the first and early second centuries (including the New Testament).

RELG 330.name: The Origins of Judaism
RELG 330.desc: Surveys the history of Jews and Judaism in the Second Temple era, from the destruction of the First Jerusalem Temple (586 B.C.E.) to the beginnings of the rabbinic movement (200 C.E.).

RELG 414.name: The Gospels and the Historical Jesus
RELG 414.desc: The canonical and apocryphal gospels and the life and teachings of the historical Jesus.

RELG 415.name: The Life and Thought of Paul of Tarsus
RELG 415.desc: The life and literature of Paul in the Roman imperial world: letter writing, patronage and power; Roman imperial iconography; Paul and community formation.

RELG 448.name: Seminar in the History of the Religion of Islam
RELG 448.desc: A topic relevant to the study of Islam as a religion: e.g., the text and doctrines of the Qur'an; the Hadith (or Traditions) of the Prophet; Islamic Law; mysticism in Islam; the Shi'ah and the Isma'ilis. Not offered every year. Consult the departmental brochure for the topic to be offered.

RMST 221.name: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern
RMST 221.desc: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.

RMST 222.name: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
RMST 222.desc: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.

RUSS 200.name: Second-Year Russian
RUSS 200.desc: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students.

RUSS 206.name: Nineteenth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
RUSS 206.desc: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.

RUSS 207.name: Twentieth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
RUSS 207.desc: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.

RUSS 300.name: Third-Year Russian
RUSS 300.desc: Intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition.

RUSS 315.name: Advanced Russian Practice
RUSS 315.desc: Continuation of RUSS 215. May be taken concurrently with RUSS 300.

RUSS 321.name: Imagining Location in Russian Literature (in English)

RUSS 400.name: Fourth-Year Russian
RUSS 400.desc: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition.

SANS 300.name: Introductory Sanskrit
SANS 300.desc: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

SCAN 333.name: Major Works of Scandinavian Literature (in English)
SCAN 333.desc: Selected Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, and Icelandic texts ranging from Old Norse sagas to contemporary literary works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in Scandinavia.

SCAN 335.name: Vikings and Norse Mythology (in English)
SCAN 335.desc: History, literature, and mythology of early Scandinavian societies.

SCAN 414.name: Topics in Danish and Northern European Cultural Studies (in English)
SCAN 414.desc: Selected topics, such as ethnicity, migration, identity, women's issues, Danish and Northern European film.

SCIE 001.name: Science One
SCIE 001.desc: An innovative first-year multidisciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines.  See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca)  for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001.
SCIE 001.prer: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12;  and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12 and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

SCIE 113.name: First-Year Seminar in Science
SCIE 113.desc: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts.  Enrollment limited to students with first-year standing in the B. Sc. program in Science.

SCIE 300.name: Communicating Science
SCIE 300.desc: Effective communication and presentation skills in science. [1-0-3]
SCIE 300.crer: One of BIOL 300, STAT 200, STAT 241 and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.
creq: 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science

SOCI 101.name: Social Interaction and Culture
SOCI 101.desc: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

SOCI 201.name: Ethnic Relations
SOCI 201.desc: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

SOCI 220.name: Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
SOCI 220.desc: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

SOCI 285.name: Citizenship and Identity
SOCI 285.desc: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

SOCI 324.name: Sociology of the Life Course
SOCI 324.desc: Individuals and families through the life course.
SOCI 324.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 342.name: Consumers and Consumption
SOCI 342.desc: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption.

SOCI 364.name: Built Environments
SOCI 364.desc: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning.

SOCI 370.name: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
SOCI 370.desc: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372.

SOCI 372.name: Contemporary Directions in Theory
SOCI 372.desc: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370.

SOCI 381.name: Sociological Methods: Experimental and Mixed Methods
SOCI 381.desc: Experimental methods in sociology integrating quantitative and qualitative approaches. Emphasis is on research design to inform policy and decision making.
SOCI 381.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI 382.name: Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
SOCI 382.desc: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals.
SOCI 382.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI 387.name: Drugs and Society
SOCI 387.desc: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance abuse and addiction from Canadian and international perspectives.

SOCI 416.name: Selected Topics in Sociological Theory
SOCI 416.desc: An in-depth examination of selected sociological theories. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

SOCI 423.name: Sociology of Food
SOCI 423.desc: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender.  Food-related social movements will be included.

SOCI 441.name: Society, Economy and Family
SOCI 441.desc: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440.
SOCI 441.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 442.name: Families and Work
SOCI 442.desc: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442.
SOCI 442.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 444.name: Sociology of Aging
SOCI 444.desc: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations.
SOCI 444.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 490.name: Contemporary Chinese Society
SOCI 490.desc: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations.

SPAN 206.name: Conversational Spanish I
SPAN 206.desc: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

SPAN 207.name: Conversational Spanish II
SPAN 207.desc: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

SPAN 221.name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
SPAN 221.desc: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses.

SPAN 222.name: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
SPAN 222.desc: Media, figures, periods, and genres of Hispanic culture; key concepts, theories, and practices of cultural analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish culture courses.

SPAN 301.name: Advanced Spanish I
SPAN 301.desc: Advanced grammar structures in context, lexical repertoire, fluency and cultural awareness to broaden and develop language skills.

SPAN 302.name: Advanced Spanish II
SPAN 302.desc: Advanced grammar structures in context; students expand lexical repertoire, and gain fluency and flexibility as they deepen cultural awareness through reading, listening, discussion, and writing.

SPAN 321.name: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
SPAN 321.desc: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures.

SPAN 357.name: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN 357.desc: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700.

SPAN 358.name: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
SPAN 358.desc: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism.

SPAN 364.name: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
SPAN 364.desc: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy.

SPAN 365.name: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
SPAN 365.desc: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence.

SPAN 402.name: Advanced Spanish III
SPAN 402.desc: Developing linguistic proficiency and effective and accurate communication in both spoken and written Spanish. Includes close reading of texts, advanced written composition, cross-cultural analysis, and conversational skills.

SPAN 411.name: Hispanic Linguistics
SPAN 411.desc: Spanish as a linguistic system. Includes the structure of Spanish words and sentences, dialectal varieties in both Spain and Latin America, and linguistic theory.

SPAN 495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN 495.desc: Theories and methodologies of the discipline. Consult the Department for this year's offering.

SPPH 300.name: Working in International Health
SPPH 300.desc: This is a tutored, web based Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course on planning/preparing for work in a developing country. Causes of ill health amongst populations living in poverty; analysis of available solutions. Health Science background not essential. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 300 or IHHS 300.

SPPH 302.name: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
SPPH 302.desc: Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 302 or IHHS 302.

SPPH 400.name: Statistics for Health Research
SPPH 400.desc: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples primarily from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Class size may be limited. [3-0]
SPPH 400.prer: Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.
preq: Ability to use high school Algebra

SPPH 406.name: Aging from an Interdisciplinary Perspective
SPPH 406.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers issues associated with aging in our society. For students registered in health and human services programs only. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 406 or IHHS 406.

SPPH 410.name: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
SPPH 410.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course promotes collaborating interprofessionally. Each student team will identify and research a critical public health issue, and develop a detailed practical and effective intervention. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 410 or IHHS 410.

SPPH 411.name: Violence Across the Lifespan
SPPH 411.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers violence in families across the lifespan. Particular emphasis on intersections of race, class, and gender; the long-term impact of childhood exposure to violence; and prevention-focused initiatives. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 411 or IHHS 411.

STAT 203.name: Statistical Methods
STAT 203.desc: Organizing, displaying and summarizing data. Inference estimation and testing for elementary probability models. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-1-0]

STAT 300.name: Intermediate Statistics for Applications
STAT 300.desc: Further topics in statistical inference, including parametric and non-parametric methods, goodness-of-fit methods, analysis of variance and covariance, regression analysis, categorical data analysis, experimental designs, time series, model fitting, and statistical computing. [3-1-0]
STAT 300.prer: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 366.

STAT 302.name: Introduction to Probability
STAT 302.desc: Basic notions of probability, random variables, expectation and conditional expectation, limit theorems. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.) [3-0-0]
STAT 302.prer: One of MATH 200, MATH 226, MATH 217, MATH 253, MATH 263.

STAT 305.name: Introduction to Statistical Inference
STAT 305.desc: Review of probability theory. Sampling distribution theory, large sample theory and methods of estimation and hypothesis testing, including maximum likelihood estimation, likelihood ratio testing and confidence interval construction. [3-0-1]
STAT 305.prer: Either (a) one of STAT 200, BIOL 300, STAT 241, STAT 251, COMM 291, ECON 325, FRST 231, PSYC 218, PSYC 366 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302;  or (b) a score of 65% or higher in one of MATH 302, STAT 302. The Department recommends that students meet the prerequisite through option (a). Note there is credit exclusion between MATH 302, STAT 302 and STAT 241, STAT 251.

STAT 306.name: Finding Relationships in Data
STAT 306.desc: Modeling a response (output) variable as a function of several explanatory (input) variables:  multiple regression for a continuous response, logistic regression for a binary response, and log-linear models for count data.  Finding low-dimensional structure:  principal components analysis.  Cluster analysis.  (Consult the Credit Exclusion List within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1]
STAT 306.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 302, STAT 302.

STAT 321.name: Stochastic Signals and Systems
STAT 321.desc: Stochastic behaviour of signals and systems (e.g., communication systems); discrete and continuous probability; random processes; modeling and identification of linear time-invariant systems; binary hypothesis testing and decision making. [3-0-2]
STAT 321.prer: One of EECE 269, ELEC 221, STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently, with registration assistance from Statistics Student Services.
preq: STAT 305. STAT 305 may be taken concurrently
with registration assistance from Statistics Student Services

STAT 344.name: Sample Surveys
STAT 344.desc: Planning and practice of sample surveys. Random sampling, bias and variance, unequal probability sampling, systematic, multistage and stratified sampling, ratio and regression estimators, post-stratification, establishing a frame, pretesting, pilot studies, nonresponse and additional topics. [3-0-1]

STAT 404.name: Design and Analysis of Experiments
STAT 404.desc: Theory and application of analysis of variance for standard experimental designs, including blocked, nested, factorial and split plot designs. Fixed and random effects, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar). [3-0-1]

STAT 406.name: Methods for Statistical Learning
STAT 406.desc: Flexible, data-adaptive methods for regression and classification models; regression smoothers; penalty methods; assessing accuracy of prediction; model selection; robustness; classification and regression trees; nearest-neighbour methods; neural networks; model averaging and ensembles; computational time and visualization for large data sets. [3-0-1]

STAT 443.name: Time Series and Forecasting
STAT 443.desc: Trend and seasonality, autocorrelation, stationarity, stochastic models, exponential smoothing, Holt-Winters methods, Box-Jenkins approach, frequency domain analysis. [3-0-1]
STAT 443.prer: One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 302 and one of STAT 200, ECON 325.

STAT 450.name: Case Studies in Statistics
STAT 450.desc: Readings and projects in areas of current statistical application including environmental science, industrial statistics, official statistics, actuarial statistics, and medical statistics. [3-0-1]

STAT 460.name: Statistical Inference I
STAT 460.desc: A detailed theoretical development. Statistical models, exponential families, sufficiency, completeness, and detailed properties of point estimation. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0]

STAT 461.name: Statistical Inference II
STAT 461.desc: Detailed development of the theory of testing hypotheses and confidence regions, Bayesian models and inference, elements of decision theory and additional topics. Intended for Honours students. [3-0-0]

THTR 120.name: Introduction to Theatre
THTR 120.desc: Theory and practice of the theatrical arts. Attendance at plays is required.

THTR 150.name: Introduction to Technical Production
THTR 150.desc: Foundation study of production technologies for the performing arts.

THTR 210.name: Drama: Forms and Ideas I
THTR 210.desc: The Anatomy of Drama: Its history, aesthetic principles, performative potential.

THTR 211.name: Drama: Forms and Ideas II
THTR 211.desc: Topics in comparative drama; drama and the other performing arts; dramaturgy.

THTR 250.name: Technical Production
THTR 250.desc: The construction and execution of scenery, costumes, properties, lighting, and sound for the stage.

THTR 271.name: Beginning B.F.A. Acting I
THTR 271.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

THTR 272.name: Beginning B.F.A. Acting II
THTR 272.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 273.name: Beginning Voice and Movement I
THTR 273.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students. An audition is required.

THTR 274.name: Beginning Voice and Movement II
THTR 274.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 305.name: Scenery Design I
THTR 305.desc: Principles and practice of scenery design for the performing arts.

THTR 306.name: Costume Design I
THTR 306.desc: Principles and practice of costume design for the performing arts.

THTR 307.name: Lighting Design I
THTR 307.desc: The optical, distribution, and control systems used in stage lighting design.

THTR 308.name: Sound Design
THTR 308.desc: Audio design and production for theatre and other performance forms.

THTR 352.name: Scene Painting I
THTR 352.desc: Media, techniques, and textural treatments used in scene painting.

THTR 354.name: Stage Management
THTR 354.desc: Principles and procedures of stage management: organizations, systems, and operations.

THTR 356.name: Costume Construction
THTR 356.desc: Advanced assembly and specialized construction methods for producing costume for stage and screen.

THTR 371.name: Intermediate B.F.A. Acting I
THTR 371.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 371.prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR 372.name: Intermediate B.F.A. Acting II
THTR 372.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 373.name: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement I
THTR 373.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 373.prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR 374.name: Intermediate Voice, Speech, and Movement II
THTR 374.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 405.name: Scenery Design II
THTR 405.desc: Exploration of complex scenery design and development of design portfolio.

THTR 406.name: Costume Design II
THTR 406.desc: Complex problems and selected historical studies in costume design.

THTR 407.name: Lighting Design II
THTR 407.desc: Complex design and advanced technologies in stage lighting and scenography.

THTR 420.name: History of Theatre II
THTR 420.desc: Key movements in world theatre history from the nineteenth century to the present.

THTR 450.name: Scenery Production II
THTR 450.desc: Technical direction; complex techniques and problems in scenery production.
