THTR 452.name: Scene Painting II
THTR 452.desc: Study of selected scene painting styles.

THTR 456.name: Costume Construction II
THTR 456.desc: Pattern development and cutting for costume for stage and screen using flat pattern and draping.

THTR 471.name: Advanced B.F.A. Acting I
THTR 471.prer: All of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.

THTR 472.name: Advanced B.F.A. Acting II
THTR 472.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

THTR 473.name: Advanced Speech and Movement I
THTR 473.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 473.prer: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.
preq: Three of THTR 371 THTR 372 THTR 373 THTR 374 THTR 391

THTR 474.name: Advanced Speech and Movement II
THTR 474.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.

UFOR 100.name: Greening the City
UFOR 100.desc: Roles played by urban forestry and greenspace systems in a rapidly changing world; topics include urban ecology, urban forest conservation, urban forest management, climate change, society and human well-being, design and planning, urban/rural interface issues, and urban forest policy. [2-0-2]

UFOR 200.name: Urban Forests and Well-Being
UFOR 200.desc: Basic relationships between urban residents’ mental and physical well-being and their urban forest environment. [2-0-2]

UFOR 300.name: Arboriculture Principles and Practice
UFOR 300.desc: Sustainable practice within the arboricultural discipline with emphasis on a comprehensive understanding of techniques and equipment used in a range of arboricultural operations. [3-1-0]

UFOR 400.name: Urban Forestry Field School
UFOR 400.desc: Development of field skills, professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, and policy. Offered at Malcolm Knapp Research Forest over a 7-day period in April.
UFOR 400.prer: UFOR 200. And third year standing in the B.U.F. program.
preq: third year standing in the B.U.F. program

UFOR 401.name: Integrated Urban Forestry Capstone Studio
UFOR 401.desc: Integration of biophysical and socio-economic components of urban greenspace management and planning through within a collaborative holistic group project linked to a real-world urban forestry situation.
UFOR 401.prer: All of UFOR 300, UFOR 400. And fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program.
preq: fourth year standing in the B.U.F. program

UFOR 402.name: Urban Forestry Administration, Policy and Law
UFOR 402.desc: The administrative, legal, policy, and business environments for urban forestry governance, management, and planning. [3-1-0]

UFOR 403.name: Ecological Restoration
UFOR 403.desc: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
UFOR 403.prer: One of FRST 201, BIOL 230. And third year standing

URST 200.name: Cities
URST 200.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization.  Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

URST 400.name: Seminar in Urban Studies
URST 400.desc: A seminar for senior students who wish to explore some common topics of importance to urban studies from the viewpoints of several disciplines.

VANT 148.name: UBC Vantage College Projects
VANT 148.desc: Projects linked to topics explored in the UBC Vantage College International Program curricula. [1-0-1; 1-0-1]

VANT 150.name: Sustainability and Engineering Design
VANT 150.desc: Topics in sustainability, including the impact of technology on the environment and society, and fundamentals of engineering design. Restricted to students in the UBC Vantage College Engineering Stream. [1-0-1; 1-0-1]

VISA 101.name: BFA Studio Practice
VISA 101.desc: Introduction to a broad range of contemporary studio practice. Intended for first year Bachelor of Fine Arts VISA students.

VISA 110.name: Foundation Studio: Digital Media
VISA 110.desc: Foundation instruction in techniques and approaches to digital practice. The nature of digital technologies and their role in contemporary culture will be examined. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA 180.name: Foundation Studio: Approaches to Media
VISA 180.desc: Drawing, painting, and related media in an introduction to studio practice. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA 183.name: Foundation Studio: Ideas as Practice I
VISA 183.desc: Contemporary art practices, emphasizing the relationship between meanings and materials, art historical contexts and concepts, and non-traditional materials. (This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience.)

VISA 210.name: Digital Arts
VISA 210.desc: Examination of current art practices and issues related to digital technologies and contemporary culture, with an emphasis on the theoretical conceptualization of digital artistic media.
VISA 210.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 220.name: Drawing
VISA 220.desc: Development of skills in drawing including life drawing. Introduction to the development of personal style and concepts.
VISA 220.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 230.name: Painting
VISA 230.desc: Development of a variety of techniques and approaches to painting. Emphasis on developing a strong paint vocabulary as well as acquiring knowledge of historical and contemporary issues in painting.
VISA 230.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 240.name: Photography
VISA 240.desc: Introduction to photography techniques and image-making. Emphasis on camera techniques and film and darkroom production. Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
VISA 240.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 241.name: Digital Photography
VISA 241.desc: Introduction to digital photography image creation in relation to contemporary art. Emphasis on digital camera use, file management, and digital print production.  Only one of VISA 240 or VISA 241 may be used toward requirements for Major, Minor, or Honours programs in Visual Art.
VISA 241.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 250.name: Print Media
VISA 250.desc: Visual print culture, and contemporary and historical technical print practices. Emphasis on hand-drawn intaglio, relief, screen and/or stencil printing, and graphic digital applications.
VISA 250.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 260.name: Sculpture
VISA 260.desc: Contemporary sculpture practice and theory. Various sculpture materials and technologies including machinery use.
VISA 260.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 310.name: Intermediate Digital Arts I
VISA 310.desc: Exploring issues and topics in interactive digital media and culture through the creation of critical contemporary art. Includes technical instruction with a focus on the development of individual and group projects.

VISA 311.name: Intermediate Digital Arts II
VISA 311.desc: Investigation of issues and topics in digital media and visual culture through the production of contemporary video art. Technical instruction in video manipulation software. Individual and/or group projects.

VISA 320.name: Intermediate Drawing I
VISA 320.desc: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art. Emphasis on expanding definitions of the drawing practice while focusing on technical and conceptual development.

VISA 321.name: Intermediate Drawing II
VISA 321.desc: Investigation of drawing as a discipline in the context of contemporary art and theory. Emphasis on self-directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

VISA 330.name: Intermediate Painting I
VISA 330.desc: Development of techniques and personal style in relation to ideas. History and contemporary issues in painting will be introduced  to assist students in conceptualizing their painting practice.

VISA 331.name: Intermediate Painting II
VISA 331.desc: Further investigation of painting in the context of contemporary art.  Emphasis on self directed projects in consultation with the instructor.

VISA 340.name: Intermediate Photography I
VISA 340.desc: An investigation of approaches to photography and its meaning in the context of contemporary art. The term theme will be determined by the instructor. B & W, colour and digital production.

VISA 341.name: Intermediate Photography II
VISA 341.desc: An investigation of contemporary photography production and approaches to the constructed image with emphasis on medium and large format camera use and studio lighting techniques.

VISA 350.name: Intermediate Print Media I: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA 350.desc: Intaglio and relief print applications (i.e., etching, wood and/or lino cut, and collagraph) in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing; discussion of contemporary and historical visual print culture.
VISA 350.prer: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 290, VISA 283, VISA 284, FINA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284.

VISA 351.name: Intermediate Print Media II: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA 351.desc: Screen printing and other print applications in combination with digital and photographic technologies, and drawing, explored within the context of contemporary art.
VISA 351.prer: Either (a) VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

VISA 360.name: Intermediate Sculpture I
VISA 360.desc: Investigation of contemporary practices in sculpture and the use of scale. Emphasis on public sculpture.
VISA 360.prer: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

VISA 370.name: Special Studies I
VISA 370.desc: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

VISA 375.name: Artists in Society
VISA 375.desc: Exploring artistic practice through community-engaged partnerships and critical study.
VISA 375.prer: Restricted to 3rd and 4th year students majoring in Visual Arts or Art History.
preq: 4th year students majoring in Visual Arts

VISA 380.name: Studio Theory
VISA 380.desc: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

VISA 381.name: Studio Seminar
VISA 381.desc: A seminar in problems in contemporary art practice and related theory. Preference given to Visual Art students.

VISA 390.name: Performance Art
VISA 390.desc: Seminar-based studio focusing on performance and actions in the field of contemporary art.
VISA 390.prer: 6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%.
preq: 6 credits of 200-level VISA with an average of at least 72%

VISA 475.name: Exhibition Theory and Practice
VISA 475.desc: Exhibition course focusing on current curatorial practices and theories with an emphasis on contemporary visual art with the aim of preparing students to engage in the active organization of a large exhibition. Restricted to 4th year Majors in either VISA or ARTH, or permission of the instructor.

VISA 479.name: Performance Actions and Approaches
VISA 479.desc: Advanced performance art practices and research methodologies.

VISA 480.name: Advanced Seminar I
VISA 480.desc: Readings in art theory and criticism.

VISA 481.name: Advanced Seminar II
VISA 481.desc: Readings in art theory and criticism.

WOOD 120.name: Introduction to Wood Products and Global Trade
WOOD 120.desc: Introduction to forestry, wood products industry, processes, products, markets and global trade policy issues affecting the wood industry. Not available for credit to students in the B.S.F. degree. [2-3]

WOOD 225.name: Communications Strategies
WOOD 225.desc: Strategies for thinking critically and writing effectively about topics that engage practitioners in Forestry, particularly in Wood Products Processing.  Planning, drafting and editing of professional-quality documents for specialists and other stakeholders. Developing oral presentation skills.

WOOD 244.name: Quantitative Methods in the Wood Industry
WOOD 244.desc: Solving practical problems in the wood industry using computer-based mathematical tools including spreadsheets, visual basic programming and relational database systems. [3-2-0]
WOOD 244.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

WOOD 245.name: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
WOOD 245.desc: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications. [2-4-0]

WOOD 249.name: Contemporary Topics in Forestry and Wood Products
WOOD 249.desc: Seminars on current forestry and wood products topics.

WOOD 276.name: Mechanics of Wood Products
WOOD 276.desc: Introduction to the strength of materials with emphasis on the elastic properties and ultimate strength of wood and wood products. [3-2-0]
WOOD 276.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 117, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

WOOD 280.name: Wood Anatomy and Identification
WOOD 280.desc: Introduction to tree growth; macroscopic and microscopic anatomy and identification of softwoods and hardwoods; descriptions of cell wall ultra-structure, wood variability and wood quality. [3-2-0]

WOOD 282.name: Wood Physics and Mechanics
WOOD 282.desc: Wood-moisture relationships, transport phenomena, acoustical and electrical properties of wood. Effects of wood attributes at macro- and micro-levels on the strength properties of solid wood. [3-2-0]

WOOD 290.name: Secondary Wood Products Manufacturing
WOOD 290.desc: Basic secondary wood products manufacturing. Focus on producing and joining lumber, edging, drilling, veneers and CNC equipment. [2-3-0]

WOOD 292.name: Two-Dimensional and Solid Computer-Aided Graphics
WOOD 292.desc: Computer-aided graphics software used in the wood products sector.  Visualization of product designs and specifications in two and three dimensions. [0-4]

WOOD 310.name: Co-operative Work Placement
WOOD 310.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 311.name: Co-operative Work Placement II
WOOD 311.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 330.name: Industrial Engineering
WOOD 330.desc: Use of industrial engineering concepts and methods to analyze and improve organizations, including operations strategy and competitiveness, quality control, work measurement, inventory management, linear programming, sensitivity analysis, transportation problems, and capacity planning. [3-2-0]

WOOD 335.name: Quality Improvement
WOOD 335.desc: Modern techniques for improving quality in the workplace with particular emphasis on the forest products industry. Topics include quality control management, control charting, continuous improvement and analysis of variance techniques. [2-2-0]

WOOD 356.name: Machine Components
WOOD 356.desc: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs.

WOOD 373.name: Wood Adhesives and Coatings
WOOD 373.desc: Introduction to structure and properties of polymers and wood finishes; chemistry of adhesives and preservatives. [2-3-0]

WOOD 384.name: Wood Sawmilling and Drying
WOOD 384.desc: Introduction to primary log breakdown systems and lumber material flow in modern sawmills and planermills. Lumber drying equipment and methods. [3-2]

WOOD 386.name: Applied Mechanics of Materials
WOOD 386.desc: Beam analysis, shaft analysis, columns, stress/strain transformations, thin-walled pressure vessels, material strength failure, criteria, fatigue, design and sizing, ISO standards. [2-2-0]

WOOD 412.name: Co-operative Work Placement V
WOOD 412.desc: Approved and supervised work experience with a public or private organization for minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final work term assignment required. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in Wood Products Processing.

WOOD 440.name: Engineering Economics
WOOD 440.desc: Use of engineering economics to evaluate investment proposals of an engineering nature, including decision making processes, time value of money, cash flow analysis, comparison methods, depreciation, replacement analysis, taxes, inflation and sensitivity analysis. [3-1]

WOOD 461.name: Globalization and Sustainability
WOOD 461.desc: Examination of globalization and its impact on sustainability, including social, economic, and environmental aspects. [3-1]

WOOD 464.name: Wood Finishing and Protection
WOOD 464.desc: Introduction to polymeric coatings and finishes used in the wood products industry; surface preparation, application equipment and properties of various coatings; wood deterioration and its protection for external applications. [1-3-2]

WOOD 465.name: Wood Industry Business Management
WOOD 465.desc: Business management concepts common in the forest products industry including marketing, customer research, product development and design. [3-0-2]

WOOD 474.name: Wood Properties and Products Manufacturing
WOOD 474.desc: Wood moisture, density and strength properties; manufacturing processes for major forest products. [2-0-0]

WOOD 482.name: CAD/CAM
WOOD 482.desc: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing.

WOOD 485.name: Furniture Construction
WOOD 485.desc: The theory and practice of modern construction techniques used in the manufacture of furniture and cabinets. [3-1]

WOOD 487.name: Wood Composites
WOOD 487.desc: Physical, chemical and mechanical variables involved in adhesive bonding of composite wood products; characteristics of adhesives; plywood, composite wood panels, hardboard, medium density fibreboard, laminated wood and engineered lumber composites manufacturing processes; important physical and chemical properties of products. [2-3-0]

WOOD 491.name: Environmental Facilities Design
WOOD 491.desc: Introduction to pneumatic and hydraulic power, design and selection of waste recycling systems, boilers, energy generation and environmental legislation. [3-2]

WOOD 492.name: Modeling for Decision Support
WOOD 492.desc: Applications of mathematical modeling, optimization, and simulation in forest planning and manufacturing; formulating models and interpreting results for decision support. [3-3]

WOOD 494.name: Principles of Wood Cutting and Tooling
WOOD 494.desc: Wood cutting fundamentals, chip formation, cutting conditions, cutting edge maintenance, sawing, planing and molding, veneer cutting, chipping, turning. [2-3-0]

WOOD 499.name: Wood Products Capstone
WOOD 499.desc: Development of a wood products manufacturing start-up company.  Development of comprehensive business plan, marketing strategy, product design, equipment selection and justification, manufacturing plant layout, and economic analyses.
WOOD 499.prer: All of WOOD 440, WOOD 465 and fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing.
preq: fourth-year standing in Wood Products Processing

CHIN 144.name: Intensive Basic Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN 144.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and in reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 144 or CHIN 114 or both CHIN 111, CHIN 113, or both CHIN 141, CHIN 143..

CHIN 161.name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning Chinese
CHIN 161.desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Mandarin Chinese.

CHIN 244.name: Intensive Basic Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN 244.desc: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 244 or CHIN 118 or both CHIN 115, CHIN 117 or both CHIN 241, CHIN 243.
CHIN 244.prer: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

CHIN 334.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 334.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 334 or CHIN 204 or both CHIN 201, CHIN 203 or both CHIN 331, CHIN 333.
CHIN 334.prer: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

CHIN 338.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 338.desc: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 338 or CHIN 208 or both CHIN 205, CHIN 207 or both CHIN 335, CHIN 337.
CHIN 338.prer: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

CHIN 344.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese I (Heritage)
CHIN 344.desc: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 344 or CHIN 214 or both CHIN 211, CHIN 213 or both CHIN 341, CHIN 343.
CHIN 344.prer: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

CHIN 348.name: Intensive Intermediate Chinese II (Heritage)
CHIN 348.desc: Communication skills. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 348 or CHIN 218 or both CHIN 215, CHIN 217 or both CHIN 345, CHIN 347.
CHIN 348.prer: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

CHIN 380.name: Reading Course in Chinese for Honours Students

CHIN 381.name: Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers I
CHIN 381.desc: Strictly for Cantonese speakers from Hong Kong who cannot speak Mandarin but who have advanced Chinese reading and writing skills (2,000 characters). Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 381 or CHIN 221.

CHIN 383.name: Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers II
CHIN 383.desc: Continuation of CHIN 381. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 383 or CHIN 223.

CHIN 404.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 404.desc: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 408. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 404 or CHIN 304 or both CHIN 301, CHIN 303 or both CHIN 401, CHIN 403.
CHIN 404.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN 408.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 408.desc: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 404. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 408 or CHIN 308 or both CHIN 305, CHIN 307 or both CHIN 405, CHIN 407.
CHIN 408.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN 415.name: Media Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 415.desc: Reading and understanding Chinese as used in newspapers, radio/TV, and the internet news. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 415 or CHIN 309.
CHIN 415.prer: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

CHIN 422.name: Twentieth-Century Chinese Literature
CHIN 422.desc: Selected short stories, novels, plays, essays, and poems from 1917 to the end of the twentieth century.  For students who have a good reading knowledge of modern Chinese.
CHIN 422.prer: 12 credits at CHIN 300 level or above is recommended.

CHIN 444.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing (Heritage)
CHIN 444.desc: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 448. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 444 or CHIN 314 or both CHIN 311, CHIN 313 or both CHIN 441, CHIN 443.
CHIN 444.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN 447.name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Heritage)
CHIN 447.desc: Continuation of CHIN 445. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437and/or CHIN 443. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 447 or CHIN 317 or CHIN 448.

CHIN 448.name: Intensive Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing (Heritage)
CHIN 448.desc: Public-speaking and writing skills at an advanced level. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 438 and/or CHIN 444. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 448 or CHIN 318 or both CHIN 315, CHIN 317 or both CHIN 445, CHIN 447.
CHIN 448.prer: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

CHIN 451.name: Introductory Modern Chinese Literature I (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 451.desc: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1900 to 1949, with a focus on fiction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 451 or CHIN 411.
CHIN 451.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN 453.name: Introductory Modern Chinese Literature II (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 453.desc: A reading-intensive introduction to modern Chinese literature from 1949 to the present, with a focus on fiction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 453 or CHIN 413.

CHIN 455.name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Early Periods) (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 455.desc: Early fiction, including tales of the supernatural and romance, to the Tang Dynasty. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 455 or CHIN 421 or CHIN 458.
CHIN 455.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN 457.name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Later Periods) (Non-Heritage)
CHIN 457.desc: Texts in vernacular Chinese, including drama and fiction, from the Yuan to the Qing Dynasties. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 457 or CHIN 423 or CHIN 458.
CHIN 457.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN 458.name: Introductory Classical Chinese Literature (Intensive)
CHIN 458.desc: Covers a range of stories, fiction, and drama to the Qing Dynasty. Only for students who did not have a good reading knowledge of modern Chinese before entering university. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 458 or CHIN 424 or both CHIN 421, CHIN 423 or both CHIN 455, CHIN 457.
CHIN 458.prer: One of CHIN 303, CHIN 304, CHIN 403, CHIN 404 and one of CHIN 307, CHIN 308, CHIN 407, CHIN 408.

CHIN 480.name: Tutorial in Chinese for Honours Students
CHIN 480.desc: Will require the presentation of at least one research paper. Review the course section information or consult the Department for details. May be taken for up to a total of 12 credits. Restricted to students in the Honours Asian Area Studies or Asian Language and Culture programs.

CHIN 482.name: Supervised Study in the Chinese Language

CHIN 494.name: Intensive Classical Chinese (Heritage)
CHIN 494.desc: A combination of CHIN 491 and 493. Readings on classical philosophy, history, literature, and culture. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 494 or CHIN 434 or both CHIN 431, CHIN 433 or both CHIN 491, CHIN 493.
CHIN 494.prer: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

FIST 332.name: Studies in Genre or Period
FIST 332.desc: A seminar examining one or more genres or periods, such as the Western, Film Noir, Science Fiction, Films of the 1980's. Also includes study of national cinemas.

FIST 430.name: Studies in Auteurism
FIST 430.desc: A seminar examining the work of one or more directors, such as John Ford, Francois Truffaut, Denys Arcand, Margarethe Von Trotta, or of a screenwriter over many films.

FIST 434.name: Studies in Film
FIST 434.desc: A seminar devoted to a topic of current interest in film. Topic will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.

FIST 438.name: Seminar in Canadian Cinema
FIST 438.desc: Topics may include an analysis of the Canadian Governmental agencies supporting Film Production.

CAPS 302.name: Human Physiology Laboratory
CAPS 302.desc: Physiological techniques and principles. Must be taken in conjunction with CAPS 301. Enrolment limited. Available only to students in the Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences. [0-3]

HGSE 310.name: First Nations and Canada: (Re)writing History
HGSE 310.desc: A survey of the history of Indigenous peoples in relation to the Canadian colonial state contrasting the Indigenous historical experience with conventional accounts of Canadian history.
HGSE 310.crer: All of HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

HGSE 311.name: Law and Governance: Indigenous and European Traditions
HGSE 311.desc: Background on sources of Aboriginal and Canadian law; detail on section 35 of the Constitution Act; a review of relevant Canadian case law; insight on the importance of international law; and literature on governance.
HGSE 311.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 312, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

HGSE 312.name: Perspectives on Reconciliation
HGSE 312.desc: Notions of reconciliation and restitution that have emerged in Canada across space and time; key principles, discourses, legal and Constitutional mechanisms, actions and actors.
HGSE 312.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 313, HGSE 314.

HGSE 313.name: Reconciliation and Resource Management
HGSE 313.desc: Relationships and reconciliation processes between First Nations and other governments in the context of land and sea governance.
HGSE 313.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 314.

HGSE 314.name: Reconciliation and Communities
HGSE 314.desc: In-depth exploration of the communities of Haida Gwaii through community-based experiences and community service learning.
HGSE 314.crer: All of HGSE 310, HGSE 311, HGSE 312, HGSE 313.

EOSC 256.name: Earthquakes
EOSC 256.desc: Characteristics, types, plate tectonics, faults, earth stresses and strains, seismic waves, magnitude scales, instrumentation, hazard mapping, prediction, and forecasting. [3-0-0]
EOSC 256.prer: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157;  or (b) SCIE 001.

EOSC 327.name: Geochemical Thermodynamics
EOSC 327.desc: Application of chemical thermodynamics to problem solving in the earth sciences.  Geochemical tools are developed for: low-T aqueous geochemistry, high-T, high-P processes in the lithosphere, ore-deposit formation, and for prediction of geochemical reaction rates in all environments. [2-2-0]

EOSC 355.name: The Planets
EOSC 355.desc: Diversity among the planets and moons of the solar system; integrating concepts across scientific disciplines, including geology, geophysics, and atmospheric science to understand how planets evolve. [3-0]
EOSC 355.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.

EOSC 421.name: Advanced Sedimentology
EOSC 421.desc: Description and interpretation of ancient and modern sediments, with emphasis on the origin, composition, textures, structures, diagenesis and chemistry of biogenic sediments. [2-2-0]

EOSC 426.name: Fundamentals of Geomicrobiology
EOSC 426.desc: Foundational knowledge of the interactions between microorganisms and Earth's surface chemistry.
EOSC 426.prer: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 121, CHEM 111, CHEM 121, EOSC 110, EOSC 112. Third year standing in Science.
preq: EOSC 112. Third year standing in Science

EOSC 431.name: Groundwater Remediation
EOSC 431.desc: Methods for containment and remediation of subsurface contaminants; including groundwater control, groundwater extraction, and in situ treatment. Experience with common design approaches. [2-2-0]

EOSC 432.name: Fossil Fuels
EOSC 432.desc: Origin, geochemistry and distribution of petroleum and coal in the stratigraphic record. Sedimentation of organic matter, organic diagenesis, migration and accumulation of hydrocarbons. Principles of exploration and development. Techniques for measurement of organic maturation and source rock analyses. [2-2-0]

EOSC 448.name: Directed Studies
EOSC 448.desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of an undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

EOSC 490.name: Student Directed Seminars in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences
EOSC 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in earth, ocean and atmospheric sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars (www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/sds/sds_handbook.pdf).

FNEL 111.name: Introduction to an Algonquian Language I
FNEL 111.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 112.name: Introduction to an Algonquian Language II
FNEL 112.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 121.name: Introduction to a  Dene (Athapaskan) Language I
FNEL 121.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures and listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 122.name: Introduction to a Dene (Athapaskan) Language II
FNEL 122.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 131.name: Introduction to a Tsimshianic Language I
FNEL 131.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of the language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 132.name: Introduction to a Tsimshianic Language II
FNEL 132.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 151.name: Introduction to the Haida Language I
FNEL 151.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 152.name: Introduction to the Haida Language II
FNEL 152.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 161.name: Introduction to the Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
FNEL 161.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 162.name: Introduction to the Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language II
FNEL 162.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 191.name: Introduction to an Indigenous Language I
FNEL 191.desc: Emphasis on accurate pronunciation, conversation, basic grammatical structures, listening and literacy skills, and the study of oral traditions in their cultural context. No prior knowledge of this language is assumed. Not offered every year.

FNEL 192.name: Introduction to an Indigenous Language II
FNEL 192.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.
FNEL 192.prer: 3 credits of FNEL 191 in the same language.
preq: 3 credits of FNEL 191 in the same language

FNEL 211.name: Intermediate  Algonquian Language I
FNEL 211.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 212.name: Intermediate Algonquian Language II
FNEL 212.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 221.name: Intermediate Dene (Athapaskan) Language I
FNEL 221.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 222.name: Intermediate Dene (Athapaskan) Language II
FNEL 222.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 231.name: Intermediate Tsimshianic Language I
FNEL 231.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 232.name: Intermediate Tsimshianic Language II
FNEL 232.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 241.name: Intermediate Wakashan Language I
FNEL 241.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 242.name: Intermediate Wakashan Language II
FNEL 242.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 251.name: Intermediate Haida Language I
FNEL 251.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 252.name: Intermediate Haida Language II
FNEL 252.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 261.name: Intermediate Ktunaxa (Kootenay) Language I
FNEL 261.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 262.name: Intermediate Ktunaxa Language II
FNEL 262.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 291.name: Intermediate Indigenous Language I
FNEL 291.desc: Emphasis on increasing fluency in conversational ability, enhancing pronunciation and comprehension skills, expanding vocabulary, extending literacy and grammatical understanding, and further study of oral traditions in their cultural context. Not offered every year.

FNEL 292.name: Intermediate Indigenous Language II
FNEL 292.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 301.name: Advanced Salish Language I
FNEL 301.desc: Emphasis on advanced comprehension and production skills. Extended focus on skills in oral traditions, transcription, literacy, and on deepening the understanding of grammatical structures and dialectal variation. Not offered every year.

FNEL 302.name: Advanced Salish Language II
FNEL 302.desc: Continued focus on the diverse range of language learning skills that advance competency in conversational fluency, pronunciation, comprehension, vocabulary, oral traditions, literacy, grammatical understanding, and the cultural contextualization of language use. Not offered every year.

FNEL 382.name: Lexicography for Endangered Languages
FNEL 382.desc: Foundational concepts in the discipline of compiling, editing, managing and hosting dictionaries, also known as lexicography. Special focus on the technical and ethical considerations for community-based lexicography projects for endangered and BC First Nations languages.

FNEL 389.name: Collaborative Heritage Research in First Nations Languages: Practicum & Workshop
FNEL 389.desc: Hands-on experience planning and producing a Breath of Life Language Reclamation Workshop for endangered BC First Nations languages, during which community-based researchers access and interpret relevant heritage resources at UBC and other local institutions for the revitalization of their languages.
FNEL 389.crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 389.
creq: FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside

FNEL 448.name: Directed Research in First Nations Languages
FNEL 448.prer: Agreement of Supervisor and approval of Chair of FNEL program.
preq: approval of Chair of FNEL program

FNEL 480.name: Endangered Language Documentation and Revitalization
FNEL 480.desc: Critical study of the historical, social, cultural, political, and economic factors impacting on language loss, retention, and revival. Research on and application of methodologies for collaborative, trans-disciplinary, community-based documentation and revitalization of BC's Indigenous linguistic heritage.

FNEL 481.name: Heritage Resources in Endangered First Nations Language Revitalization
FNEL 481.desc: Examines the complementary and intersecting roles of libraries, archives, and museums in collections acquisition, development, curation, preservation, and access traditions pertaining to First Nations languages, to explore how each can contribute to endangered language and cultural heritage sustainability.
FNEL 481.crer: All of FNEL 281, FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside or prior to FNEL 481.
creq: FNEL 282. Corequisites can be taken either alongside

FNEL 489.name: Topics in First Nations and Endangered Languages
FNEL 489.desc: Selected topics will vary. Multiple versions of this course may be taken, under consultation with the FNEL program advisor, for up to a maximum of 12 credits.

THTR 205.name: Graphics for Theatre and Film Design

THTR 245.name: Play-Interpretation and Production-Analysis
THTR 245.desc: Basic methods of interpreting dramatic texts and analyzing plays in performance. The plays presented on the Frederic Wood Stage will be studied in this course.

THTR 301.name: Styles of Decor and Dress
THTR 301.desc: Artistic, decorative, cultural, and social contexts of selected theatrical genres and periods.

THTR 310.name: Theory of Drama Performance
THTR 310.desc: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on dramatic theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

THTR 311.name: Studies in Drama
THTR 311.desc: Topics will vary from year to year.

THTR 317.name: Introduction to Directing
THTR 317.prer: One of THTR 130, THTR 230 and THTR 299.

THTR 320.name: History of Theatre I
THTR 320.desc: Core concepts in world theatre history and the development of theatre prior to the nineteenth century.

THTR 339.name: Creating Theatre I
THTR 339.desc: Study and practice of processes and forms used to create ensemble performance.

THTR 340.name: Studies in Non-Western Theatre
THTR 340.desc: Open to all students in third year and above.

THTR 391.name: Rehearsal and Performance
THTR 391.desc: Open only to  B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 391.prer: All of THTR 271, THTR 272, THTR 273, THTR 274.

THTR 399.name: Production II
THTR 399.desc: Assigned projects in theatre design and production.
THTR 399.crer: One of THTR 305, THTR 306, THTR 307, THTR 308, THTR 350, THTR 352, THTR 354, THTR 356.

THTR 408.name: Advanced Study in Design and Scenography
THTR 408.desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consent of Department required.

THTR 410.name: Dramaturgy
THTR 410.desc: Advanced problems in dramaturgy, both in a historical and a contemporary context.

THTR 417.name: Directing Lab
THTR 417.prer: THTR 317. Permission of the instructor is required for admission to this course.
preq: THTR 317. Permission of the instructor is required for admission to this course

THTR 421.name: History of Theatre from 1900 to the present
THTR 421.desc: The development of Western Theatre from 1900 to the present

THTR 430.name: Theory of Drama and Performance
THTR 430.desc: The basic principles of dramaturgy and theory of performance. Historical and contemporary writing on theatrical theory and criticism and their relation to theatrical practice.

THTR 439.name: Creating Theatre
THTR 439.desc: Ensemble creation culminating in the presentation of a theatrical work. Permission of the instructor is required.

THTR 440.name: Topics in Theatre
THTR 440.desc: An examination in depth of a selected area of theatre history, theory or practice. Topics will change from year to year. May be repeated for credit when topics differ.
THTR 440.prer: 6 credits of THTR at the 300-level or above.

THTR 443.name: Women in Theatre and Film
THTR 443.desc: A course dealing with women's involvement in and contribution to various aspects of Theatre and/or Film Topics will change from year to year.

THTR 448.name: Directed Studies in Theatre Theory and Practice

THTR 454.name: Production and Theatre Management
THTR 454.desc: Production and theatre management with emphasis on budgeting, publicity, scheduling, press relations, special events, legal issues, season selection, resumes and interpersonal skills.

THTR 469.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
THTR 469.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

THTR 491.name: Advanced Rehearsal and Performance
THTR 491.desc: Open only to B.F.A. Acting students.
THTR 491.prer: Three of THTR 371, THTR 372, THTR 373, THTR 374, THTR 391.
preq: Three of THTR 371 THTR 372 THTR 373 THTR 374 THTR 391

THTR 499.name: Production III
THTR 499.desc: Assigned projects in Theatre or Film design and production.
THTR 499.crer: One of THTR 405, THTR 406, THTR 407, THTR 408, THTR 450, THTR 452, THTR 454, THTR 456, THTR 470.

OHS 430.name: Operative Dentistry
OHS 430.desc: The art and science of diagnosing and treating single tooth defects. [0-4.5-0]

OHS 431.name: Orthodontics
OHS 431.desc: Differential diagnosis, treatment planning, biomechanical principles and clinical treatment. [1-2-0]

OHS 435.name: Prosthodontics I
OHS 435.desc: The art and science of restoring and replacing teeth and surrounding tissues.

OHS 440.name: Advanced Operative Dentistry
OHS 440.desc: The art and science of diagnosing and treating single tooth defects. [0-3-0]

OHS 444.name: Practice Management
OHS 444.desc: Ethics, jurisprudence, practice management, intra- and interprofessional relationships. [2-0-0]

OHS 445.name: Prosthodontics II
OHS 445.desc: The art and science of restoring and replacing teeth and surrounding tissues.

FRST 203.name: Silvics of Forest Trees of Western Canada
FRST 203.desc: Ecological and silvical characteristics of forest trees; assessment of ecological site quality and biogeoclimatic classification; application of silvics in silviculture. A plant herbarium of at least 50 species is required. Only available through Distance Education. [3-2]

FRST 403.name: The Sustainability of Production in Managed Forest Ecosystems
FRST 403.desc: Study of the functional and dynamic characteristics of forest ecosystems and their response to forest management using ecosystem-level microcomputer simulation models. [3-2-0]

FRST 404.name: Advances in Silviculture
FRST 404.desc: Fundamental silvicultural problems; the application of research findings to the practice of silviculture. [4-0]

FRST 406.name: Advanced Forest Pathology
FRST 406.desc: Hereditary, physiological, anatomical, environmental, and microbiological factors influencing forest tree diseases. Given in alternate years. [2-2]

FRST 410.name: Introduction to Landscape Ecology and Management
FRST 410.desc: Current concepts, methods, and applications of landscape ecology with emphasis on spatial patterning, spatial heterogeneity, and dynamics; problem-solving approaches to natural resource issues through the application of landscape ecological principles and tools.

FRST 432.name: Molecular Ecology
FRST 432.desc: Use of molecular genetic tools to investigate ecological  processes in natural population; DNA variation and its application in landscape genetics, phylogeography, behavioural ecology, conservation genetics, and association genetics. Emphasis placed on statistical and computational data analysis. [3-0-0]

FRST 436.name: Growth and Yield
FRST 436.desc: Techniques of growth and yield projection and discussion of modelling approaches. Exploration of stand dynamics, quantitative implications of management treatments and environmental limitations to tree and stand growth. [2-2-0]

FRST 449.name: Directed Studies in Forestry
FRST 449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

FRST 470.name: Forests and Society
FRST 470.desc: Social aspects of forestry and forest communities. [3-0-1]

FRST 485.name: Forest Watershed Management
FRST 485.desc: Effects of land management on quality, quantity and timing of water flow. [3-2-0]

FRST 491.name: Visualization and Forest Design
FRST 491.desc: GIS-based spatial planning and 3D landscape visualization for forest management. [3-0-1]

PATH 417.name: Human Bacterial Infections
PATH 417.desc: Students acquire content relating to the virulence factors of the bacteria and the pathophysiology of the host while working through case scenarios on their own and in online groups. Students taking this course must be willing to engage in both self-directed and small-group learning.

PATH 438.name: Medical Laboratory Science: Directed Studies
PATH 438.desc: Investigation of a specific topic in Medical Laboratory Science. Permission of the department head is required.

PATH 447.name: Directed Studies
PATH 447.desc: An elective in clinical infection control, medical microbiology or molecular biology.

PATH 448.name: Introduction to Laboratory Medicine
PATH 448.desc: An elective course open to first-year medical students who spend at least three consecutive hours each week in one of the affiliated hospitals of the Department of Pathology, Vancouver Hospital, under the joint supervision of a Senior Resident in Pathology and the Professional Staff of the following Divisions: anatomical pathology, clinical biochemistry, haematology, paediatric pathology. Enrolment is limited.

PATH 450.name: Systemic Pathology
PATH 450.desc: A series of Pathology discussions in conjunction with various clinical departments designed to illustrate the role of Pathology in the diagnosis and management of various diseases.

PATH 452.name: Clerkship in Anatomic Pathology
PATH 452.desc: An elective course open to third-year medical students, designed to familiarize the student with Anatomic Pathology, including Surgical Pathology, Paediatric Pathology, Autopsy Pathology and Cytology. This elective may involve attendance at one or more affiliated hospitals. Registration requires consent of the Department and enrolment may be limited.

PATH 453.name: Clinical Laboratory Haematology
PATH 453.desc: Correlative seminars based on haematology case studies relating clinical features to laboratory investigations.

PATH 457.name: Clinical Laboratory Microbiology
PATH 457.desc: Selected clinical laboratory exercises plus seminars to illustrate the diagnosis and management of patients with microbial infections. Elective course limited to third- and fourth-year medical students.

MUSC 102.name: Class Strings
MUSC 102.desc: Group instruction in music performance. Restricted to B.Mus. students.

MUSC 108.name: Introduction to Contemporary Art Music
MUSC 108.desc: Contemporary music repertoire, emphasizing music from the past fifty years. Required of undergraduate Composition majors; open to other Bachelor of Music students by permission of instructor.

MUSC 110.name: Intensive Tonal Theory and Form I
MUSC 110.desc: Continuity and form in tonal music, with attention to the development of aural imagery and writing skills. Foundational concepts are first applied cross-historically, then restricted to styles in which functional harmony emerges as a governing feature.  Limited to B.Mus. students with strong preparation (as determined by B.Mus. admissions procedures) and students in other programs with permission of the instructor.

MUSC 111.name: Intensive Tonal Theory and Form II
MUSC 111.desc: Two- and three-voice writing based on a four-part foundation; use of motivic diminution and imitation; dissonant chords; prolonging harmonies within phrases; modulating phrases and sequences; chromatic techniques; small binary and ternary forms, and formal functions of component phrases.

MUSC 128.name: Musical Rhythm and Human Experience
MUSC 128.desc: A multidisciplinary survey of musical rhythm in selected world traditions and genres, connecting it to ideas of time, evolution, history, anthropology, philosophy, and contemporary globalised culture.

MUSC 136.name: Piano Repertoire I
MUSC 136.desc: Performance and discussion of the repertoire for string-keyboard instruments essential to the performer and teacher. Special attention to matters of structure, style, and performance practices. Required of piano performance majors and open to piano concentrators, space permitting. First term prerequisite to second term.

MUSC 150.name: Large Instrumental Ensemble
MUSC 150.desc: Symphony Orchestra, Symphonic Wind Ensemble, or Concert Winds. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 151.name: University Chamber Orchestra
MUSC 151.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 153.name: University Singers
MUSC 153.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 154.name: University Choral Union
MUSC 154.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 156.name: Vocal Chamber Ensembles
MUSC 156.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 157.name: Early Music Ensemble
MUSC 157.desc: Performance of early Western instrumental and vocal ensemble music. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 159.name: University Chamber Strings
MUSC 159.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 160.name: String Chamber Ensembles
MUSC 160.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 161.name: Piano Chamber Ensembles
MUSC 161.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus.

MUSC 162.name: Wind and Percussion Chamber Ensembles
MUSC 162.desc: May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music. Open to other students by audition, with credit, as stipulated by their faculties.

MUSC 165.name: World Music Ensembles
MUSC 165.desc: Training on traditional instruments and their techniques, with emphasis on ensemble performance. Different sections focus on the music of different cultures, e.g., Bali, China, Ghana, Korea. May be repeated for credit in accordance with program requirements for B.Mus. or B.A. in Music, or when permitted in other programs.

MUSC 169.name: Intensive Chamber Ensemble
MUSC 169.desc: Intensive coaching in chamber ensemble for advanced players. Performance of works prepared is expected.
MUSC 169.crer: Any small ensemble (MUSC 156-166) and permission of the instructor.

MUSC 207.name: Composition II
MUSC 207.prer: MUSC 107 and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.
preq: permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores

MUSC 210.name: Intensive Tonal Theory and Form III
MUSC 210.desc: Writing exercises involving chromaticism and modulation. Theme and inter-theme types in Classical and Romantic music.  Techniques of variation and development.  Model-based composition of small forms and analysis of larger forms. Cultivation of score-reading ability.
MUSC 210.prer: MUSC 111. Or MUSC 200 with permission of the instructor.
preq: MUSC 111. Or MUSC 200 with permission of the instructor

MUSC 301.name: Compositional and Analytical Approaches to Music Today
MUSC 301.desc: Technical and stylistic perspectives on contemporary art music and popular and world music idioms. Exercises in composition and production. Training in related listening, sight-singing and score reading skills.

MUSC 307.name: Composition III
MUSC 307.prer: MUSC 207 and permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores.
preq: permission of Composition Division based on submission of scores

MUSC 319.name: Introduction to Electroacoustic Music
MUSC 319.desc: Study of acoustics, audio technology, and electroacoustic composition. Composition of original works using facilities of the UBC Electroacoustic Music Studio.
MUSC 319.prer: MUSC 119 and one of MUSC 100, MUSC 110. Permission of instructor is also required.
preq: MUSC 110. Permission of instructor is also required

MUSC 321.name: Music Appreciation, Twentieth-Century
MUSC 321.desc: Designed for students with little or no musical background. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC 322.name: Topics in Western Music
MUSC 322.desc: Study in one major genre of Western music (e.g., "The Symphony", "Women in Opera", "History of the Song Cycle"). No musical knowledge is required. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC 324.name: The Guitar in History and Practice
MUSC 324.desc: Introduction to guitar performance and repertoire for non-majors. Lectures explore guitar repertoires from selected regions and eras. Not for credit toward the B.Mus. or the Major/Minor in Music (B.A., B.F.A., B.Sc.). Students are expected to provide their own guitars.

MUSC 326.name: Music Appreciation
MUSC 326.desc: An introductory course for which previous musical background is helpful, but not required. Contents include a discussion of musical concepts, evolution of forms, style, and media and detailed study of selected works from the concert repertoire. Popular forms of music (jazz, folk, rock, etc) not included. Not for credit towards the B.Mus. or B.A. in Music.

MUSC 328.name: World Music Cultures
MUSC 328.desc: Introduction to the principles of ethnomusicology and an examination of at least two contrasting musical traditions. May be repeated once for credit if different traditions are covered.

MUSC 330.name: Music in Vancouver's Ethnic Communities
MUSC 330.desc: Examination of music within the ethnic context as found in the urban environment of Vancouver. The musics of several traditions (e.g., Chinese, Jewish, English folk) will be studied together with the social issues surrounding their preservation. For credit toward the B.Mus. and the B.A. in Music, but open to students not majoring in music.

MUSC 331.name: Workshop in World Rhythm
MUSC 331.desc: Theory and practice of selected rhythmic systems of world music cultures, focusing on West African drumming, and including other systems such as Indian Tala and Peking opera percussion.

MUSC 339.name: Opera Workshop I
MUSC 339.desc: Participation in performances by the School. Open also to students outside Music without credit, after audition.

MUSC 340.name: Piano Pedagogy I: Theory and Studio Management
MUSC 340.desc: Basic principles of teaching piano. Business aspects of establishing and maintaining a music studio. For piano majors.

MUSC 345.name: Aesthetics and Practice of Film Music

MUSC 353.name: History of Renaissance Music
MUSC 353.desc: Sacred and secular music, vocal and instrumental.

MUSC 358.name: History of Jazz
MUSC 358.desc: Jazz styles and their cultural contexts; the relationship of performers and audiences; issues of race and gender; non-Western influences.

MUSC 363.name: History and Repertoire of the Guitar and Related Instruments
MUSC 363.desc: A chronological survey, from the Renaissance to the present day, of music for the guitar and related instruments and of the development of the instruments themselves. Instruments considered include Renaissance and Baroque lutes, the vihuela, and early types of guitar as well as the modern six-string guitar. Musical forms and genres, national schools and the works of principal composers of every period are explored and attention is given to national systems, continuo realization, historical ornamentation and pedagogical systems.

MUSC 364.name: Chamber Music Repertoire
MUSC 364.desc: Perspectives on the performance of selected chamber music.  Specific works vary from year to year.  May be repeated for credit.

MUSC 365.name: Song Repertoire I
MUSC 365.desc: An exploration of the solo art song repertoire from 1600 to the Romantic period. Repertoire essential to the performer and teacher will be studied through live and recorded performance with special attention given to poetic content and musical style.

MUSC 402.name: Special Projects
MUSC 402.desc: For fourth-year students who receive permission of the Director of the School of Music to do advanced studies in their major field.

MUSC 403.name: Selected Topics in Music
MUSC 403.desc: See School of Music schedule for description and prerequisites. Restricted to B. Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

MUSC 406.name: Conducting II
MUSC 406.desc: Advanced choral and orchestral conducting techniques and rehearsal practices.
MUSC 406.prer: One of MUSC 311, MUSC 312. Permission of the instructor is required.
preq: MUSC 312. Permission of the instructor is required

MUSC 409.name: Jazz Theory and Arranging
MUSC 409.desc: Jazz scales, chord relationships, substitutions, orchestration, listening, and score analysis. Restricted to B.Mus. and B.A. in Music students.

MUSC 411.name: Analysis of Tonal Music
MUSC 411.desc: Analytical approaches that complement Schenkerian analysis, including motivic construction, harmonic rhythm and phrase rhythm, chromaticism and enharmonicism, features of musical form, aspects of structure and hierarchy at the small and large scale.

MUSC 412.name: Analytical Studies in the Development of Musical Modernism (1860 - 1940)
MUSC 412.desc: Analysis of late- and post-romantic works within a theoretical framework that bridges earlier to later works. Assignments in various formats, emphasizing analysis but possibly including composition.

MUSC 414.name: Counterpoint
MUSC 414.desc: Analysis and comosition of pieces that rely on the control and development of imitative, polyphonic textures. Models to be taken from one or more European historical repertoires.

MUSC 415.name: Imagining Musical Performances
MUSC 415.desc: How performance and analysis engage the musical imagination, as complementary activities; how analytical observations can stimulate performance, and vice versa. Selected topics, with special emphasis on temporal factors.

MUSC 417.name: Musical Scoring for Film
MUSC 417.desc: Addresses the practical aspects of composing music for film through assignments of written scores.
MUSC 417.prer: MUSC 319. Permission of instructor is required.
preq: MUSC 319. Permission of instructor is required

MUSC 428.name: Topics in World Music
MUSC 428.desc: The history, theory, style, organology, and forms of the music of a particular culture in its aesthetic and cultural context. Students should consult the School as to which music culture will be covered in a particular year. May be repeated once for credit if different cultures are covered.

MUSC 430.name: Major Composers
MUSC 430.desc: The musical works of no more than two significant composers will be examined. Specific topics will be announced; may be repeated for credit.
MUSC 430.prer: All of MUSC 120, MUSC 121, MUSC 220, MUSC 221.

MUSC 433.name: Accompanying on the Harpsichord II
MUSC 433.desc: Continuation of MUSC 333 with emphasis on more advanced continuo and obbligato techniques.

MUSC 442.name: Song Interpretation
MUSC 442.desc: Survey of the literature for voice with keyboard accompaniment, with emphasis on performance problems. Open to piano and voice majors, and to others by permission of instructor. May be repeated once for credit.

MUSC 443.name: Opera Coaching
MUSC 443.desc: Principles and practice, focusing on current Opera Workshop repertoire. Reproducing orchestrations on the piano; preparing scores; study of the voice and the rehearsal process; coaching languages; related conducting skills.

MUSC 444.name: Establishing a Career in Music
MUSC 444.desc: Best practices of the contemporary busines of music, focussing on understanding present market conditions, and on targeting specific opportunities through grant-writing, resumés, press kits, publicity, recordings, and marketing. Restricted to fourth-year B.Mus. students.

MUSC 450.name: Selected Topics in Vocal or Instrumental Genres
MUSC 450.desc: Intensive study of one genre of music (e.g., orchestral music 1760–1849; the Lied in Austria and Germany) through analysis and the consideration of cultural milieu and historical development. Specific topics will be announced. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 credits.

MUSC 455.name: History of Opera II
MUSC 455.desc: The development of opera between 1800 and the present.

MUSC 469.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
MUSC 469.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

JAPN 204.name: Basic Japanese Grammar
JAPN 204.desc: Emphasis on grammar, writing and reading Intended for students with a background in spoken Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 204 or JAPN 104.

JAPN 261.name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning Japanese
JAPN 261.desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 261 or JAPN 161.

JAPN 342.name: Reading Course in Japanese for Honours Students

JAPN 403.name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition II
JAPN 403.desc: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on the development of formal presentation skills. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 403 or JAPN 303.

JAPN 422.name: Classical Japanese I
JAPN 422.desc: The grammar, orthography, and literary style of pre-modern Japanese (bungo).  It is strongly recommended that students have 12 credits of JAPN, or equivalent, prior to registration. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 422 or JAPN 311.

JAPN 423.name: Classical Japanese II
JAPN 423.desc: A continuation of JAPN 422.  Focus on reading pre-modern primary sources and producing English translations. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 423 or JAPN 312.

JAPN 424.name: Japanese for Professional Life I
JAPN 424.desc: Technical Japanese as it is used in business, commerce, industry, etc. Emphasis on specialized current vocabulary and on the development of communicative competence relevant for workplaces in these fields. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 424 or JAPN 314.
JAPN 424.prer: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

JAPN 425.name: Japanese for Professional Life II
JAPN 425.desc: Continuation of JAPN 424. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 425 or JAPN 315.

JAPN 451.name: Advanced Oral Communication II
JAPN 451.desc: A continuation of JAPN 450. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 451 or JAPN 411.

JAPN 457.name: Newspaper Japanese II
JAPN 457.desc: A continuation of JAPN 456. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 457 or JAPN 417.

JAPN 459.name: Topics in Japanese Language, Culture, and Society
JAPN 459.desc: Advanced Japanese language course combined with analysis of various media in literary, journalistic, and popular genres drawn from history, sociology, cultural studies, etc. Practice in the use of standard reference tools prepares students for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to JAPN 459. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 459 or JAPN 419.
JAPN 459.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and permission from instructor.

JAPN 460.name: Grammatical Analysis of Japanese I
JAPN 460.desc: Analysis of the grammatical structure of modern Japanese. Contrastive analysis of Japanese and English as well as error analysis. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 460 or JAPN 420.
JAPN 460.prer: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 303, JAPN 403.

JAPN 461.name: Grammatical Analysis of Japanese II
JAPN 461.desc: A continuation of JAPN 460. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 461 or JAPN 421.

JAPN 462.name: Researching Modern Japanese Religions
JAPN 462.desc: Research tools and approaches to the interdisciplinary study of modern Japanese religions (nineteenth century to the present) including state-of-the-field works in English, and locating primary and secondary materials in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 462 or JAPN 452.
JAPN 462.prer: 6 credits of 200- or 300-level courses in Asian religions; 3 credit writing-intensive course in Asian Studies; ability to read modern Japanese or 18 credits of Japanese language courses and permission of instructor.
preq: 300-level courses in Asian religions; 3 credit writing-intensive course in Asian Studies; ability to read modern Japanese

JAPN 470.name: Supervised Study in the Japanese Language
JAPN 470.desc: Primarily for graduate students. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 470 or JAPN 440.

JAPN 472.name: Tutorial in Japanese for Honours Students
JAPN 472.desc: This course will require the presentation of at least one research paper. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 472 or JAPN 442.

CHBE 355.name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
CHBE 355.desc: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models. [3-0-1]

CHBE 401.name: Mechanical Pulping and Papermaking
CHBE 401.desc: Process and unit operations in mechanical pulping and papermaking, emphasizing principles and practice of refining, screening, cleaning, papermaking and properties of paper products, key economic and environmental issues.

CHBE 452.name: Environmental Process Design Project
CHBE 452.desc: 8-month project-based course, concepts from chemical, biological, and environmental science engineering with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations to solve problems related to the protection of the environment. [2-0-8]
CHBE 452.prer: All of CHBE 254, CHBE 344, CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 373.

CHBE 465.name: Rehabilitation and Design of Aquatic Habitat
CHBE 465.desc: Modeling the effects of the environment and nutrient availability on growth and waste production; designing closed and open environments for aquatic organisms; developing prescriptions for habitat rehabilitation.
CHBE 465.prer: BIOL 112 and third-year standing also required.

CHBE 470.name: Transport in Biological Systems
CHBE 470.desc: Mass transport and fluid flow, including physiological tissues and tissue constructs. Mass transport deficiencies that lead to the development of pathological tissue and drug delivery to these tissues. Biological engineering for the design of tissue constructs and artificial organs. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 470 or CHBE 570.

CHBE 479.name: Chemical Engineering Aspects of Occupational Health and Safety
CHBE 479.desc: Relationship between current engineering practice and worker health and safety. Engineering analysis of industrial health and safety problems.

CHBE 480.name: Hazardous Waste Processing Technology
CHBE 480.desc: Characterization, treatment and final disposal of hazardous waste with emphasis upon chemical engineering principles. Topics to include relevant legislation, in-plant minimization, treatment options and clean-up of contaminated sites. Case studies to be used for illustration.
CHBE 480.prer: Third year Chemical and Biological Engineering.

CHBE 489.name: Pollution Control in the Pulp and Paper Industry
CHBE 489.desc: Pollutants of concern in the pulp and paper industry; environmental impact of the industry; technologies used for the control of solid, liquid and gaseous wastes.

CHBE 498.name: Engineering Report
CHBE 498.desc: This should be written on some subject of scientific interest or technical interest, based preferably on personal experience. Specifications are issued by the Department.

DHYG 308.name: Oral Health Sciences III
DHYG 308.desc: An introduction to concepts and principles of pharmacology and local anesthesia, and further study of oral medicine, oral pathology, and radiology.

DHYG 400.name: Policy Analysis and Change
DHYG 400.desc: Critical reviews of oral health care delivery, oral disease processes and dental hygiene. [3-0-0]

DHYG 402.name: Dental Hygiene Practice I
DHYG 402.desc: Dental hygiene concepts, processes, and skills for individuals and communities. [3-0-0; 3-0-0]

DHYG 404.name: Dental Hygiene Practice II
DHYG 404.desc: Advanced dental hygiene concepts, processes and skills in community health, educational or institutional settings.

FNIS 260.name: Applied Learning: Collaborative Place-Based Research
FNIS 260.desc: Topic and community/location of instruction will vary from year to year. Applied, intense delivery experiential learning course designed and implemented in collaboration with faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). Examines the importance of Indigenous place-based research and learning for student and community empowerment.

FNIS 300.name: Writing First Nations
FNIS 300.desc: A writing-intensive course examining approaches to writing Indigenous research: Representation & the Other; Indigenous critiques of research & representation; Indigenous, feminist and cultural studies approaches to writing ethnography, oral history, and related research methods. Credit will be granted for only one of FNIS 300 or FNSP 300.
FNIS 300.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220.

FNIS 360.name: Applied Learning: Collaborative Place-Based Research
FNIS 360.desc: Topic and community/location of instruction will vary from year to year. Applied, intense delivery experiential learning course designed and implemented in collaboration with faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). Examines the importance of Indigenous place-based research and learning for student and community empowerment.
FNIS 360.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220. And Permission of the Instructor.

FNIS 401.name: Special Topics
FNIS 401.desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website: http://fnsp.arts.ubc.ca.
FNIS 401.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or third-year standing.

FNIS 452.name: Indigenous Social Movements
FNIS 452.desc: Draws on Indigenous and non-Indigenous intellectual traditions to explore the theoretical, cultural, political, economic, and historical bases of Indigenous peoples decolonization struggles in Canada. Credit will be granted for only one of FNSP 401A, FNIS 452, or FNSP 452.
FNIS 452.prer: One of FNSP 200, FNIS 210, FNSP 210, FNIS 220, FNSP 220 or third-year standing.

LAW 201.name: Canadian Constitutional Law
LAW 201.desc: Principles of Canadian constitutional law, including Canadian federalism, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and the unique constitutional status and rights of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada.

LAW 211.name: Contracts
LAW 211.desc: Historical development; formation and enforceability of contracts; parties; contractual terms; changes of circumstances; remedies for breach.

LAW 221.name: Criminal Law and Procedure
