LAW 221.desc: Bases of criminal responsibility; principles and objectives of the criminal law and procedure; pre-trial procedure.

LAW 231.name: Property Law
LAW 231.desc: The legal concept of ownership and its changing nature and application, including equitable principles, the acquisition and transfer of interests, the regulation of use, Aboriginal title, and statute-based systems for registering interests in land.

LAW 241.name: Torts
LAW 241.desc: A study of the bases of civil liability for intentionally and accidentally caused harms.

LAW 251.name: Public Law
LAW 251.desc: An overview of the constitutional and statutory law governing the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government in Canada, including an introduction to statutory construction and analysis and the administration of law in Canada.

LAW 261.name: Transnational Law
LAW 261.desc: Introduction to principles of public and private international law and research methods for international legal materials.

LAW 281.name: Legal Research and Writing
LAW 281.desc: Introduction to legal research and writing skills and the use of legal databases.

LAW 301.name: Philosophy of Law
LAW 301.desc: An examination of the principal schools of legal theory, such as legal positivism, legal realism, sociological jurisprudence, and contemporary rights theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 302.name: Fundamental Concepts of Law
LAW 302.desc: A study of some of the fundamental principles and ideas that cut across many areas of the substantive law, including such concepts as fault, intent, legal personality, possession, ownership, justice, and causation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 306.name: Corporate Social Responsibility and the Law

LAW 308.name: Feminist Legal Theory
LAW 308.desc: Recent developments in feminist legal theory. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 309.name: Topics in Feminist Legal Studies
LAW 309.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 310.name: Economic Analysis of Law
LAW 310.desc: Economic analysis used to explore, describe, evaluate and offer prescriptive suggestions for legal decision-making. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 311.name: Property Law and Theory
LAW 311.desc: The idea of property, its origins, its justifications, its uses, its effects, and the rules that surround and create it.

LAW 312.name: Topics in Philosophy of Law and Theoretical Perspectives
LAW 312.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 313.name: Legal History
LAW 313.desc: The relationship between law, society and historical change, normally emphasizing 19th and 20th century issues. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 315.name: Topics in Legal History
LAW 315.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 318.name: Marine Resources Law
LAW 318.desc: Legal regimes governing the protection and exploitation of ocean resources. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 319.name: International Human Rights
LAW 319.desc: The recognition and protection of human rights in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 320.name: Indigenous Peoples in Comparative and International Law
LAW 320.desc: The legal situation of indigenous peoples in various states and in modern international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 321.name: Law of Armed Conflict
LAW 321.desc: The legal basis for armed conflict or military operations; the rights and obligations of combatants and civilians in a region of armed conflict; war crimes.

LAW 322.name: International Law Problems
LAW 322.desc: Selected issues in international law. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 323.name: International Environmental Law
LAW 323.desc: Customary international law and treaties relating to the environment; institutional structures. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 324.name: Topics in International Law and Transactions
LAW 324.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 327.name: International Trade Law
LAW 327.desc: Rules and regulatory systems that govern the international movement of capital, goods and services.

LAW 328.name: International Business Transactions
LAW 328.desc: Legal problems in international financial and commercial transactions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 329.name: International Commercial Disputes
LAW 329.desc: International commercial arbitration and other means for resolving legal disputes relating to international commercial transactions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 330.name: Cultural Property and Art Law
LAW 330.desc: National and international aspects of the law relating to the art trade and the protection and regulation of cultural property and cultural heritage.

LAW 331.name: Topics in Cultural Heritage and Art Law
LAW 331.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 332.name: Maritime Law
LAW 332.desc: Canadian maritime law and admiralty practice.

LAW 333.name: Cultural Law
LAW 333.desc: Relationship of law to cultural activities and phenomena.  International, national, and indigenous laws as they apply to various forms of tangible and intangible cultural expression.

LAW 337.name: Trade and Investment in The People's Republic of China
LAW 337.desc: The legal regime in The People's Republic of China governing trade and foreign investment. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 338.name: Japanese Law
LAW 338.desc: Constitutional foundation and protection of human rights under Japanese law.

LAW 339.name: Human Rights in Asia
LAW 339.desc: Legal issues relating to civil, political, social and cultural rights in particular areas in Asia. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 341.name: European Union Law
LAW 341.desc: The legal system of the European Union as created by the treaties establishing the Union and by the Union's institutions. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 342.name: Topics in Comparative Law
LAW 342.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 343.name: Topics in Public Law
LAW 343.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 344.name: Innovations in Governance and Regulatory Design
LAW 344.desc: Emerging interdisciplinary scholarship on regulation, governance, and institutional design.  Examination of research and experience around both formal and legal regulatory strategies, and other informal, decentred, or non-state-based methods of ordering individual and organizational behaviour.

LAW 348.name: Comparative Constitutional Law
LAW 348.desc: Comparison of the constitutional history, government structure and powers, and protection of individual rights between the United States and Canada.

LAW 349.name: Topics in Constitutional Law
LAW 349.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 350.name: Issues of Equality and Social Justice
LAW 350.desc: Selected topics related to the Charter right to equality and other rights related to social justice. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 351.name: Topics in Human Rights
LAW 351.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 353.name: Aboriginal and Treaty Rights
LAW 353.desc: Rights of Aboriginal people stemming from their aboriginal status and from treaties. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 354.name: First Nations Self-Government
LAW 354.desc: Issues relating to First Nations' assumption of self-government powers. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 355.name: First Nations and the Administration of Justice
LAW 355.desc: The justice system and its operation in relation to First Nations people. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 358.name: Topics in First Nations Law
LAW 358.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 360.name: Children and the Law
LAW 360.desc: The civil and criminal law affecting juveniles; custody, guardianship and adoption.

LAW 362.name: Topics in Family Law
LAW 362.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 363.name: Racism and Law
LAW 363.desc: Legal issues relating to race and racism, including related issues of gender, culture or identity. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 364.name: Topics in Race and Law
LAW 364.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 365.name: Women, Law and Family
LAW 365.desc: Feminist and other critical perspectives on the relationship between unequal gender relations and laws embodying a concept of "family". Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 368.name: Sexuality and Law
LAW 368.desc: Legal issues relating to sexual activity, orientation and identification. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 370.name: Topics in Social Justice
LAW 370.desc: Not offered every year; consult the Faculty.

LAW 371.name: Topics in Law and Social Relations
LAW 371.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 373.name: Topics in Administrative Law
LAW 373.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 375.name: Land Use Planning
LAW 375.desc: The legal and administrative aspects of the regulation of land use and development, especially at the local level. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 376.name: Topics in Municipal and Planning Law
LAW 376.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 378.name: Refugee Law
LAW 378.desc: International and Canadian refugee law; the Refugee Convention and its implementation in Canada; the practice of refugee law in Canadian courts and tribunals. Course content does not duplicate Law 377.

LAW 379.name: Externship
LAW 379.desc: Students work for an approved organization, supervised by a Faculty-approved mentor and a faculty member. Consult the Faculty for full eligibility criteria.
LAW 379.prer: Either (a) one of LAW  280, LAW  476 and either (a) LAW  240 or (b) all of LAW  359, LAW  260 or (c) all of LAW  400, LAW  270 or (d) LAW  469; ;  or (b) one of LAW  387, LAW  392 or (c) one of LAW  230, LAW  459. Or other studies that provide adequate preparation for the program.
preq: LAW 459. Or other studies that provide adequate preparation for the program

LAW 380.name: Externship Reflection
LAW 380.desc: Structured reflective exercises on the LAW 379 Externship experience.

LAW 383.name: Mental Health Law
LAW 383.desc: The law relating to commitment and treatment issues for persons with mental disabilities.

LAW 385.name: Social Welfare Law
LAW 385.desc: Aspects of the law structuring the provision of welfare and other social services in Canada. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 386.name: Sustainable Development Law
LAW 386.desc: The linkages, intersections, and tensions between the legal regulation of the environment and competing social and economic priorities.

LAW 388.name: Environmental Law in Practice
LAW 388.desc: Jurisdiction, remedies and administrative schemes as they apply in practice to selected environmental law problems. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 389.name: Selected Issues in Environmental Law and Policy
LAW 389.desc: Case studies of leading problems in environmental law and regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 391.name: Topics in Environmental Law
LAW 391.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 394.name: Mining Law
LAW 394.desc: Acquisition of mineral interests; development, financing and organization of mining companies; regulation of exploitation industry interests; management taxation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 396.name: Fisheries Law
LAW 396.desc: Legal regimes for the exploitation and regulation of fisheries. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 397.name: Oil and Gas Law
LAW 397.desc: Legal regimes for the disposition of interests in petroleum; government regulation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 398.name: Topics in Natural Resources
LAW 398.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 399.name: Advanced Criminal Law
LAW 399.desc: Selected topics in advanced substantive criminal law and related issues.

LAW 401.name: Penal Policy
LAW 401.desc: Selected legal policy issues relating to punishment for crime. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 402.name: The Law of Sexual Offences
LAW 402.desc: Criminal law relating to sexual offences, including non-consent, evidentiary and procedural rules, and sentencing.  History of sexual offence laws and law reform movements.

LAW 405.name: Topics in Criminal Law
LAW 405.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 406.name: Topics in Criminal Justice
LAW 406.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 411.name: Tax Policy
LAW 411.desc: The policies underlying the creation and implementation of tax laws. Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 411 or LAW 566.

LAW 413.name: Tax Administration and Dispute Resolution
LAW 413.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty. Credit will be granted for only one of LAW 413 or LAW 567.

LAW 417.name: Labour Law and Policy
LAW 417.desc: The role of the law in the operation of the labour market. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 418.name: Resolution of Labour Disputes
LAW 418.desc: Labour arbitration and collective agreement negotiation and interpretation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 419.name: Individual Employment Law
LAW 419.desc: Legal aspects of employment relationships other that those arising by collective bargaining. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 421.name: Topics in Labour Law
LAW 421.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 423.name: Topics in Intellectual Property
LAW 423.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 425.name: Cyberspace Law
LAW 425.desc: Legal issues arising from the development of the Internet and cyberspace.

LAW 426.name: Topics in Law and Technology
LAW 426.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 432.name: Topics in Private Law
LAW 432.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 435.name: Topics in Tort Law
LAW 435.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 436.name: Restitution
LAW 436.desc: Unjust enrichment as the basis of civil liability. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 447.name: Topics in Commercial Law
LAW 447.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 450.name: Topics in Sports, Media, Entertainment or Communications Law
LAW 450.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 454.name: Topics in Trusts and Estates
LAW 454.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 458.name: Topics in Real Property
LAW 458.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 460.name: Advanced Corporate Law
LAW 460.desc: Selected topics such as the nature of shares, equity financing, corporate structure and reorganization, and shareholder squeezeouts.

LAW 467.name: Topics in Corporate Law
LAW 467.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 471.name: Preventing Wrongful Convictions
LAW 471.desc: Substantive legal principles and rules of evidence that can cause or help to prevent wrongful convictions or other miscarriages of justice. Roles of the participants in the criminal justice system. Not offered each year; consult Faculty.

LAW 475.name: Competitive Trial Advocacy Credit
LAW 475.desc: Trial advocacy. Restricted to students participating in one or more faculty approved trial advocacy competitions. Students enrolled in this course must also be enrolled in LAW 474.

LAW 479.name: Mediation
LAW 479.desc: Mediation of legal disputes; negotiation theory and practice as they relate to mediation. Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 481.name: Topics in Litigation, Dispute Resolution and the Administration of Justice
LAW 481.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 482.name: Topics in Procedure and Evidence
LAW 482.desc: Not offered each year, consult Faculty.

LAW 483.name: Competitive Moots and Advocacy Credit A
LAW 483.desc: Appellate and related forms of advocacy. Restricted to students representing the Faculty for the first time in an approved advocacy competition.

LAW 485.name: Client Counselling Competition Credit
LAW 485.desc: Interviewing, counselling and negotiating. Restricted to students representing the Faculty in an approved client counselling competition.

LAW 486.name: Law Review Credit
LAW 486.desc: Editing and business operations by senior editors or the business manager for UBC Law Review, Canadian Journal of Family Law or any other equivalent legal journal based in the Allard School of Law. One time credit only; cannot be repeated.

MINE 395.name: Mineral Deposit Modeling
MINE 395.desc: Types of mineral deposits. Exploration and sampling methods. Methods for data analysis and computer modeling of mineral deposits and their use in production planning and design.

MINE 435.name: Plant and Process Design
MINE 435.desc: Design of unit operations in a mineral processing plant including crushing, grinding, classification, gravity separation, magnetic separation, flotation, thickening and filtration. Equipment selection and sizing, flowsheet design, circuit analysis and processing options.

MINE 497.name: Directed Studies
MINE 497.desc: Requires approval of the department head.

CTLN 301.name: Catalan Language and Culture
CTLN 301.desc: Introduction to the Catalan language and important aspects of the culture of Catalonia. Languages of instruction: English and Catalan.

EDST 400.name: Social and Ethical Considerations in Education

EDST 425.name: Educational Anthropology
EDST 425.desc: Selected concepts from educational anthropology for teachers. Comparative study of school and classroom culture, school teaching, and multicultural education. Pass/Fail.

EDST 426.name: History of Education
EDST 426.desc: An examination of selected topics in the history of Canadian and British Columbian education and of the relationships between historical development and current educational policy. Pass/Fail.

EDST 427.name: Philosophy of Education
EDST 427.desc: An introductory course in which consideration is given to the philosophical foundations of education and to the practical bearing of theory upon curriculum content and classroom practice in our schools. Pass/Fail.

EDST 428.name: The Social Foundations of Education
EDST 428.desc: An application of the social sciences to the study of education. Pass/Fail.

EDST 429.name: Educational Sociology
EDST 429.desc: Selected theories of society and schooling applied to Canadian education. Pass/Fail.

EDST 451.name: Issues and Frameworks in Environmental Education
EDST 451.desc: Competing conceptions of environmental education; the social construction of nature and of science; addressing class, race, culture, and gender in developing sound teaching strategies. Pass/Fail.

EDST 453.name: Moral Education in Elementary and Secondary Schooling
EDST 453.desc: Approaches to moral education; developing educationally and morally justifiable teaching strategies. Pass/Fail.

EDST 454.name: Critical Thinking: Frameworks, Methods, and Challenges
EDST 454.desc: Competing conceptions of critical thinking, including feminist and post-colonial; teaching and evaluation strategies. Pass/Fail.

CNPS 312.name: Career Education for Teachers
CNPS 312.desc: Introduction to career education practices and standards program content, and principles for the design of career education programs. [3-0]

FSCT 201.name: Introduction to Forensic Science
FSCT 201.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7320.

FSCT 202.name: Applied Ethics
FSCT 202.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science. Same as BCIT LIBS 7002.

FSCT 203.name: Report Writing and Communication for Forensic Investigation
FSCT 203.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT COMM 7200.

FSCT 280.name: Introductory Forensic Science I
FSCT 280.desc: Block registration for the introduction to forensic science course taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT 290.name: Introductory Forensic Science II
FSCT 290.desc: Block registration for the applied ethics and report writing and communication for forensic investigation courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT 301.name: Forensic Biology; DNA Typing Theory
FSCT 301.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8150.

FSCT 302.name: Quality Assurance for Forensic Science
FSCT 302.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8370.

FSCT 303.name: Business Management for Forensic Science
FSCT 303.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8371.

FSCT 310.name: Research Methodology and Measurement Models
FSCT 310.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7910.

FSCT 311.name: Forensic Biology: Evidence Recovery
FSCT 311.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8155.

FSCT 312.name: Medico-Legal Aspects of Alcohol
FSCT 312.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8230.

FSCT 313.name: Crime Scene Investigation
FSCT 313.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7310.

FSCT 314.name: The Science of Fingerprints - Theory
FSCT 314.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8320.

FSCT 315.name: Forensic Toxicology I
FSCT 315.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8240.

FSCT 380.name: Intermediate Forensic Science I
FSCT 380.desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing theory, quality assurance, and business management for forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT 390.name: Intermediate Forensic Science II
FSCT 390.desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: evidence recovery, research methodology, and elective courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT 401.name: Forensic Biology: DNA Typing Applications
FSCT 401.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8160.

FSCT 409.name: Law for Forensic Science
FSCT 409.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7009.

FSCT 410.name: The Expert Witness - Prepared for Court
FSCT 410.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 7010. [2-0-0]

FSCT 411.name: Population Genetics
FSCT 411.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8305.

FSCT 412.name: Forensic Chemistry and Toxicology
FSCT 412.desc: Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Same as BCIT FSCT 8156.

FSCT 480.name: Advanced Forensic Science I
FSCT 480.desc: Block registration for the forensic biology: DNA typing applications, law and forensic science courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

FSCT 490.name: Advanced Forensic Science II
FSCT 490.desc: Block registration for the expert witness testimony, population genetics, and forensic chemistry and toxicology courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biochemistry and Forensic Science.  Registration is limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

PSYC 100.name: Introductory Psychology
PSYC 100.desc: Introduction to methods and statistics, biopsychology, learning, perception, memory, cognition, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology.  Credit will be given for either PSYC 100 or PSYC 101 and 102.

PSYC 205.name: Contemporary Issues in Psychology
PSYC 205.desc: Topics include addiction, culture and evolution in social behaviour, personal relationships, pro- and anti-social behaviour, judgment and decision-making, prejudice and discrimination. Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit.

PSYC 263.name: Contemporary Issues in Biopsychology
PSYC 263.desc: Contemporary issues in biopsychology (e.g., neuropsychology, mental illness, brain damage, addiction, hormones and the brain). Consult the Psychology Department for topics offered each term. May be repeated on a different topic once for credit.

PSYC 300.name: Behaviour Disorders
PSYC 300.desc: The definition, history, and scope of deviant behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification.
PSYC 300.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100, or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 303.name: Tests and Measurements I
PSYC 303.desc: Theory and practice of mental measurement, test reliability and validity, uses, administration, scoring, and interpretation of psychological tests.
PSYC 303.crer: May be taken concurrently with PSYC 366.
creq: May be taken concurrently with PSYC 366

PSYC 305.name: Personality Psychology
PSYC 305.desc: Theory and research on individual differences in motivation, emotion, and social behaviour.
PSYC 305.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 306.name: Principles of Animal Behaviour
PSYC 306.desc: Theory of evolution; behavioural genetics; social systems as ecological adaptation; mating and parental strategies; instinct and learning; evolution of human behaviour. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 310 or PSYC 306.
PSYC 306.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 308.name: Social Psychology
PSYC 308.desc: Theory and research of individual social behaviour; social motivation; attitudes; group interaction; socialization; prejudice.
PSYC 308.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 309.name: Cognitive Processes
PSYC 309.desc: Contribution of cognitive processes to perception, attention, and memory; cognitive development, language, thinking, and creativity.
PSYC 309.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 312.name: History of Psychology
PSYC 312.desc: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Open only to Major or Honours students or by permission of the instructor.
PSYC 312.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 320.name: Psychology of Gender and Sex Differences
PSYC 320.desc: Theory and research on gender development and the influence of gender on cognition, emotion, motivation, social behaviour, and health.
PSYC 320.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 323.name: Tests and Measurements II
PSYC 323.desc: A survey of tests for assessing intelligence, abilities, personality, motivation, and interests.

PSYC 325.name: Socialization: Media Content and Effects
PSYC 325.desc: Examines human development in the context of the socializing role of media.
PSYC 325.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 334.name: Memory II
PSYC 334.desc: Organic amnesia; remembering childhood events; the self and memory; and the problem of distinguishing genuine from simulated forgetting.

PSYC 337.name: The Psychology of Language II
PSYC 337.desc: Language and thought; deriving psychological principles from language universals; the psychology of literacy, dyslexia, multilingualism, and natural language processing.
PSYC 337.prer: PSYC 336 or permission of the instructor.

PSYC 340.name: Directed Studies in Psychology
PSYC 340.desc: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 340.prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.
preq: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits
permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation

PSYC 348.name: Directed Studies in Biopsychology
PSYC 348.desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 348.prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.
preq: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits
permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation

PSYC 350.name: Psychological Aspects of Human Sexuality
PSYC 350.desc: Human sexuality from a biopsychological, behavioural, and psychosocial perspective.
PSYC 350.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102 or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 364.name: Animal Cognition
PSYC 364.desc: Investigations of animal cognitive abilities, including spatial learning, timing, counting, concept formation and language use. Experimental findings presented from behavioural and biological approaches with animals and humans.

PSYC 400.name: Clinical Psychology: A Health Profession
PSYC 400.desc: Theory, research, practice, and professional issues in clinical psychology, including a practicum placement. Credit will not be given for both PSYC 400 and 401.

PSYC 402.name: Research in Anxiety Disorders
PSYC 402.desc: Focus on the cognitive, biological, and motivational underpinnings of anxiety disorders. Topics include current research methods, controversies in the research literature, and directions for future research.
PSYC 402.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) all of PSYC 300, PSYC 366.

PSYC 403.name: Human Emotion
PSYC 403.desc: Developmental, cognitive, and social psychological theories and research on human emotion.
PSYC 403.prer: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 305, PSYC 308, PSYC 309, PSYC 315.

PSYC 407.name: Cognition and Culture
PSYC 407.desc: Cultural learning; cultural variation and universality in cognition and emotion; cognitive and emotional bases of cultural phenomena.
PSYC 407.prer: One of PSYC 307, PSYC 308. Or permission of the instructor.
preq: PSYC 308. Or permission of the instructor

PSYC 408.name: Research in Social Psychology
PSYC 408.desc: Representative studies on social psychological topics; emphasis on the formulation of significant questions and the design and execution of relevant research.
PSYC 408.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) one of PSYC 308, PSYC 366.

PSYC 412.name: Cognitive Development
PSYC 412.desc: The development of fundamental cognitive abilities from infancy through adulthood, including traditional approaches to cognitive development as well as new areas of current investigation.
PSYC 412.prer: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

PSYC 413.name: Social and Personality Development
PSYC 413.desc: Comprehensive overview of the psychological processes in the social and personality development of infants, children, and adolescents.
PSYC 413.prer: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

PSYC 414.name: Research in Developmental Psychology
PSYC 414.desc: Advanced study of current research in a specific area of developmental psychology.
PSYC 414.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366;  and one of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

PSYC 415.name: Applied Social Psychology
PSYC 415.desc: The application of social psychological research and theory to the solution of social problems.
PSYC 415.prer: PSYC 308 and either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 or permission of instructor.

PSYC 417.name: Special Topics in Psychology
PSYC 417.desc: Intensive examination of selected topics and issues in psychology.
PSYC 417.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366.

PSYC 418.name: The Self-Concept
PSYC 418.desc: Theory and research on the self: development, knowledge, motivation, emotions, presentation.

PSYC 420.name: Community Psychology
PSYC 420.desc: The relationships between social contexts and wellbeing with a focus on disadvantaged populations.  Students engage in a community service placement to complement academic learning.
PSYC 420.prer: Either (a) PSYC 300 or (b) PSYC 308 or (c) PSYC 314 or (d) PSYC 319.

PSYC 430.name: Forensic Psychology
PSYC 430.desc: The implications of theory and research in psychology for the criminal justice system. Credit will not be granted for both PSYC 331 and PSYC 430.
PSYC 430.prer: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. Or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).

PSYC 431.name: Special Topics in Forensic Psychology
PSYC 431.desc: Selected topics in psychological theory and research applied to the criminal justice system.

PSYC 440.name: Directed Studies in Psychology
PSYC 440.desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 440.prer: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.
preq: At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits
permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation

PSYC 448.name: Directed Studies in Biopsychology
PSYC 448.desc: Directed investigation of an experimental problem requiring a written report of the findings.
PSYC 448.prer: At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.
preq: At least a 72% average in the preceding 30 credits
permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation

PSYC 463.name: Research in Sensation and Perception
PSYC 463.desc: Vision and audition; physical properties and subjective experience of stimuli.
PSYC 463.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 260.

PSYC 466.name: Research in Animal Learning and Cognition
PSYC 466.desc: Examination and evaluation of studies of animal learning and cognition; includes one or more research projects based on material covered.
PSYC 466.prer: Either (a) all of PSYC 217, PSYC 218 or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 304, PSYC 360, PSYC 363, PSYC 365;  or (c) one of BIOL 355, BIOL 455 or (d) one of PHYL 301, PHYL 426.

PSYC 469.name: Psychoneuroimmunology
PSYC 469.desc: Research linking psychological characteristics with the immune system, including implications regarding the onset and course of disease.
PSYC 469.prer: Either (a) one of PSYC 314, PSYC 360 or (b) MICB 302 and either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102.

MICB 430.name: Seminar in Microbiological Literature
MICB 430.desc: Student seminars on selected papers from the microbiological literature. Compulsory for Honours students. Major students may enrol with permission of the department head.

MICB 448.name: Directed Research
MICB 448.desc: A library (3 credits) or laboratory (3 or 6 credits) project. Requires permission of the Undergraduate Advisor. The results are presented in a written report to be reviewed by oral examination.
MICB 448.prer: Either (a) MICB 323 or (b) all of MICB 322, MICB 399.

RUSS 100.name: First-Year Russian
RUSS 100.desc: Introduction to contemporary Russian Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

RUSS 112.name: Russian for Singers
RUSS 112.desc: Study of Russian language and culture for opera students.

RUSS 215.name: Russian Practice
RUSS 215.desc: Emphasis on oral practice and reading. It is recommended that this course be taken concurrently with RUSS 200.

RUSS 305.name: Readings in Russian Literary Texts
RUSS 305.desc: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21st-century sources.

RUSS 306.name: Russian Literature in Translation
RUSS 306.desc: A comprehensive historical and critical presentation with emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

RUSS 316.name: Russian through Film (in Russian)
RUSS 316.desc: Conversation and composition using Russian film.

RUSS 401.name: Russian for Reading Knowledge
RUSS 401.desc: Russian for Reading Knowledge This course provides a reading knowledge of Russian, sufficient to enable students to understand scientific and scholarly material. Basic grammar and practice in the translation into English of texts in the natural sciences, social sciences, and humanities. Intended primarily for upper-year and graduate students.

RUSS 410.name: Women in Russian Literature and Culture
RUSS 410.desc: Analysis of translated texts by and concerning women from folklore to contemporary society.

PCTH 425.name: Medical Pharmacology
PCTH 425.desc: A lecture and laboratory course covering the fundamental pharmacological action of drugs.  Both terms.

PCTH 448.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacology
PCTH 448.desc: Advanced investigation of a specific topic in Pharmacology.

PCTH 449.name: Honours Thesis
PCTH 449.desc: A research problem directed by a faculty member. Restricted to Honours Pharmacology students.

PCTH 451.name: Review of Clinical Pharmacology
PCTH 451.desc: This course has been designed as a basic science elective for third-year medical students.

PCTH 453.name: Advanced Therapeutics
PCTH 453.desc: A lecture, assigned problems, and discussion course dealing with practical aspects of therapeutics. This course is designed to give fourth-year medical students some practical experience in the science of drug prescribing.

GRSJ 201.name: Connecting with Computer Science
GRSJ 201.desc: Fundamentals of computer science and their connections with the arts, psychology, and biology. Historical, cultural, and gender perspectives of important contributions to the field will be discussed. No prior computing background required.

GRSJ 205.name: Gender, Race and Colonialism in Canada
GRSJ 205.desc: The historical foundations of colonialisms in Canada from just prior to the establishment of New France to the end of World War One.

GRSJ 210.name: Gender, Race and Colonialism in the Americas
GRSJ 210.desc: Interdisciplinary exploration of the ways gender, class, sexuality and race shape modern histories in Canada, and transnationally, from 1920 to the present.

GRSJ 224.name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature
GRSJ 224.desc: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

GRSJ 302.name: Pedagogies of Social Justice
GRSJ 302.desc: The intersections of gender, education, and work using sociological and economic frameworks.
GRSJ 302.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 425.name: Special Topics in Gender, Race, and Sexuality
GRSJ 425.desc: Examination in depth of selected topics in gender, race, and sexuality. Consult the Student Service Centre course schedule for course offerings. May be repeated for credit.
GRSJ 425.prer: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102 or third-year standing.

GRSJ 450.name: Directed Studies
GRSJ 450.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

PHAR 303.name: Pharmacy Skills II
PHAR 303.desc: Legal, technical and professional aspects of dispensing prescriptions and providing pharmaceutical care, primarily for community pharmacy practice.

PHAR 315.name: Pharmacokinetics
PHAR 315.desc: Pharmacokinetics and clinical applications of pharmacokinetic principles.

PHAR 321.name: Biophysical Pharmacy I
PHAR 321.desc: Applications of the physical chemical properties of drugs to oral drug delivery systems.

PHAR 323.name: Biophysical Pharmacy II
PHAR 323.desc: Applications of the physical chemical properties of drugs to non-oral drug delivery systems.

PHAR 330.name: Pharmacogenomics: Genetics and Drug Action
PHAR 330.desc: Application of genetic information to drug therapy.

PHAR 341.name: Pharmacology I
PHAR 341.desc: Pharmacological principles and the pharmacology of selected agents.

PHAR 342.name: Pharmacology II
PHAR 342.desc: Principles of chemotherapy and drug resistance and the pharmacology of selected drug classes.

PHAR 351.name: Therapeutics I
PHAR 351.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR 352.name: Therapeutics II
PHAR 352.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR 361.name: Non-Prescription Products and Self-Care of the Patient I
PHAR 361.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR 362.name: Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient II
PHAR 362.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR 369.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience I
PHAR 369.desc: A 160-hour pharmacy clerkship providing exposure to legal, technical, and professional aspects of community practice.

PHAR 399.name: Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences II
PHAR 399.desc: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts. [1-0-3; 1-0-3]

PHAR 401.name: Pharmacy Skills III
PHAR 401.desc: Legal, technical and professional aspects of dispensing prescriptions and providing pharmaceutical care, primarily for community pharmacy practice.

PHAR 404.name: Peer Teaching in Pharmacy Skills II
PHAR 404.desc: Development and delivery of patient counselling role-playing activities in PHAR 303.

PHAR 405.name: Directed Studies in Clinical Pharmacy
PHAR 405.desc: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

PHAR 410.name: Pharmaceutical Research: From Bench to Bedside and Beyond
PHAR 410.desc: Basic, translational, clinical, and community-based research.

PHAR 415.name: Topics in Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics
PHAR 415.desc: A study of selected topics in the field of pharmaceutics and biopharmaceutics. Registration restricted. Permission of instructor required.

PHAR 420.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Education
PHAR 420.desc: Individual assignments involving library and scholarly inquiry related to pharmacy education.

PHAR 430.name: Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry I
PHAR 430.desc: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate enzyme activity.

PHAR 434.name: Essential Medicinal Chemistry Concepts for Pharmacists
PHAR 434.desc: Applying selected chemical concepts to understand drug structure and properties, using frequently encountered drugs as examples. Examining how drugs are used to inhibit enzyme activity.

PHAR 435.name: Biomolecular Pharmaceutical Chemistry II
PHAR 435.desc: Chemical principles and their application to drugs used to regulate receptor activity.

PHAR 441.name: Pharmacology III
PHAR 441.desc: The pharmacology of selected drug classes.

PHAR 442.name: Pharmacology IV
PHAR 442.desc: The pharmacology of selected drug classes.

PHAR 451.name: Therapeutics III
PHAR 451.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR 452.name: Therapeutics IV
PHAR 452.desc: Rational drug therapy, management of patient-specific drug-related problems and therapeutic monitoring of selected disease states.

PHAR 453.name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice
PHAR 453.desc: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice.

PHAR 454.name: Pediatric and Geriatric Drug Therapy
PHAR 454.desc: Drug therapy considerations in pediatric and geriatric patients.

PHAR 458.name: Pharmacotherapy in Oncology
PHAR 458.desc: Common oncological diseases and their drug treatment.

PHAR 460.name: Natural Health Products in Pharmacy Practice
PHAR 460.desc: An evidence-based analysis of the efficacy and safety of natural health products used in pharmacy practice.

PHAR 461.name: Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient III
PHAR 461.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR 462.name: Non-Prescription Drugs and Self-Care of the Patient IV
PHAR 462.desc: The use of non-prescription drugs for selected conditions.

PHAR 498.name: Cases in Pharmaceutical Sciences III
PHAR 498.desc: Case studies and other activities integrating scientific and clinical concepts.

FNH 290.name: Introductory Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
FNH 290.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition, and health. Topics will vary from year to year.

FNH 430.name: Enology and Wine Biotechnology
FNH 430.desc: Yeasts and bacteria involved in wine making, metabolic pathways leading to the production of flavour and spoilage compounds, genetic improvement of wine yeasts, and red and white wine fermentations. Approaches and technologies for the improvement of wine safety. Sensory evaluation of wines.

FNH 454.name: Fish Nutrition
FNH 454.desc: Physiology of digestion and excretion, nutrient requirements, sources of nutrients, diet formulation, feeding management. [3-0-0]

FNH 490.name: Advanced Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
FNH 490.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition and health.

FNH 497.name: Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health

VANT 140.name: Content and Language Enrichment Tutorials
VANT 140.desc: Sustained language support for linked content courses in International Program. Students develop strategies for self-directed learning.

PUNJ 100.name: Introductory Punjabi I
PUNJ 100.desc: Spoken and written Punjabi. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 100 for credit.

PUNJ 101.name: Introductory Punjabi II
PUNJ 101.desc: Continuation of PUNJ 100. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 101 for credit.

PUNJ 201.name: Intermediate Punjabi I
PUNJ 201.desc: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ 202.name: Intermediate Punjabi II
PUNJ 202.desc: Continuation of PUNJ 201. Credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 202 or PUNJ 200.

PUNJ 205.name: Introduction to the Gurmukhi Script
PUNJ 205.desc: The writing system of Punjabi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as PUNJ 200.

PUNJ 401.name: Devotional Literature in Punjabi
PUNJ 401.desc: Emphasis is on reading and written expression. Analytical writing in English and Punjabi required.

PUNJ 403.name: Modern Punjabi Literature
PUNJ 403.desc: Popular and literary works in modern Punjabi, with a focus on short stories and poetry. Emphasis on reading, writing, and vocabulary development.

PUNJ 404.name: The Punjabi Novel (Advanced Punjabi)
PUNJ 404.desc: Study of the modern Punjabi novel to deepen understanding and use of Punjabi, and strengthen analysis in English and Punjabi.

PUNJ 457.name: Punjabi Theatre
PUNJ 457.desc: Punjabi-language theatre, with emphasis on Canadian forms. Reading, writing, and performance of plays; examination of history of Punjabi theatre.

PUNJ 475.name: Oral Histories in Punjabi
PUNJ 475.desc: Develops students' oral expression and listening comprehension in Punjabi through Community Based Learning. Students engage in oral history collection in the Punjabi-speaking community and develop short video or sound projects. Analytical reading and writing required.

HINU 100.name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu I
HINU 100.desc: Spoken Hindi and Urdu, and written Hindi. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100 or 102.

HINU 101.name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu II
HINU 101.desc: Continuation of HINU 100. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 101 or 102.

HINU 200.name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
HINU 200.desc: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 201/202 or HINU 200.

HINU 201.name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I
HINU 201.desc: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 201.

HINU 202.name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II
HINU 202.desc: Continuation of HINU 201. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 200 or 202.

HINU 205.name: Introduction to the Devanagari Script
HINU 205.desc: The writing system of Hindi for those with some background in the spoken language. May be taken at the same time as HINU 200.

HINU 300.name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu
HINU 300.desc: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301/302 or HINU 300.

HINU 301.name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I
HINU 301.desc: Further study of the grammar of Hindi and Urdu; advanced conversation; literary readings in Hindi and Urdu; Hindi film. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 301 or HINU 300.

HINU 302.name: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II
HINU 302.desc: Continuation of HINU 301. Credit will be granted for only one of HINU 302 or HINU 300.

HINU 305.name: Introduction to the Perso-Arabic (Urdu) Script
HINU 305.desc: The writing system of Urdu for those with some background in the spoken language.

HINU 400.name: Introduction to Hindi and Urdu Literature
HINU 400.desc: Readings of various literary genres in Hindi, Urdu and their medieval equivalents. Modern fiction from India and Pakistan; the Urdu ghazal; medieval Hindi bhakti poetry; readings from the Adi Granth of the Sikhs Hindi film. Discussion in Hindi-Urdu of all materials.

HINU 450.name: Hindi Film
HINU 450.desc: Regional, religious, and historical dialects of Hindi and Urdu as repesented in films.

MATH 230.name: Introduction to Finite Mathematics
MATH 230.desc: Difference equations, number theory, counting.  Intended primarily for students not in the Faculty of Science who wish to have some exposure to mathematical thinking.  Students who obtain credit for MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184, or SCIE 001 cannot in the same year or in later years obtain credit for MATH 230. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-0]

MATH 265.name: Linear Differential Equations
MATH 265.desc: Linear ordinary differential equations. Complex numbers, Laplace transforms, frequency reponse, resonance, step response, systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [2-0-1*]
MATH 265.prer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.
MATH 265.crer: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

MATH 267.name: Mathematical Methods for Electrical and Computer Engineering
MATH 267.desc: Fourier series and transforms, wave equation, d'Alembert's solution, modes. Discrete Fourier tranform. Recurrence relations, z-transform, generating functions, applications. [3-0-1*]
MATH 267.prer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

MATH 309.name: Topics in Geometry
MATH 309.desc: Topics chosen by the instructor. These may include conic sections, projective configuration, convexity, non-Euclidean geometries, fractal geometry, combinatorial problems of points in the plane. [3-0-0]
MATH 309.prer: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of MATH 220, MATH 226, CPSC 121.

MATH 361.name: Introduction to Mathematical Biology
MATH 361.desc: Mathematical modeling of basic biological processes in ecology, physiology, neuroscience and genetics. Dynamic behavior of difference equations, differential equations, and partial differential equations, explained with reference to concrete biological examples. [3-0-0]
MATH 361.prer: One of BIOL 301, MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265.

MATH 402.name: Calculus of Variations
MATH 402.desc: Classical variational problems; necessary conditions of Euler, Weierstrass, Legendre, and Jacobi; Erdmann corner conditions, transversality, convex Lagrangians, fields of extremals, sufficient conditions for optimality, numerical methods; applications to classical mechanics, engineering and economics. [3-0-0]
MATH 402.prer: A score of 68% or higher in one of MATH 301, MATH 320.

MATH 424.name: Classical Differential Geometry
MATH 424.desc: The differential geometry of curves and surfaces in three-dimensional Euclidean space. Mean curvature and Gaussian curvature. Geodesics. Gauss's Theorema Egregium. [3-0-0]
MATH 424.prer: Either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 223 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 152, MATH 221;  and either (a) a score of 68% or higher in MATH 227 or (b) a score of 80% or higher in one of MATH 217, MATH 263, MATH 317.

MATH 428.name: Mathematical Classical Mechanics I
MATH 428.desc: Newton's equation, conservation laws, the Euler-Lagrange equation; Hamilton's principle of least action, Hamilton's equations, Lagrangian mechanics on manifolds. [3-0-0]
MATH 428.prer: MATH 215 and one of PHYS 216, PHYS 306.

MATH 430.name: Special Topics in Analysis
MATH 430.desc: The student should consult the Mathematics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]

MATH 432.name: Special Topics in Algebra
MATH 432.desc: The student should consult the Mathematics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year. [3-0-0]

MATH 446.name: Topics in the History of Mathematics I
MATH 446.desc: Historical development of concepts and techniques in areas chosen from Geometry, Number Theory, Algebra, Calculus, Probability, Analysis. The focus is on historically significant writings of important contributors and on famous problems of Mathematics. [3-0-0]

MATH 448.name: Directed Studies in Mathematics
MATH 448.desc: Introduction to the methods of mathematical research through an exploration of a mathematical topic under the supervision of a faculty member.  Written report required. [3-0-0]
MATH 448.prer: Third- or fourth-year standing and permission of the Department Head.

MATH 449.name: Honours Reading
MATH 449.desc: Independent reading by Honours students in Mathematics under the direction of a faculty member. Written report required.

CIVL 404.name: Introduction to Solid Waste Management
CIVL 404.desc: Characteristics of solid wastes; solid waste collection, treatment, and disposal; evaluation and analysis of landfills, composting, combined treatment, recycle, and re-use.

CIVL 447.name: Environmental Engineering Design and Analysis
CIVL 447.desc: Integration and application of previously acquired knowledge and skills to find design solutions.  Extends the conceptual design of CIVL 445 into detailed environmental design projects.

CIVL 492.name: Directed Studies in Civil Engineering
CIVL 492.desc: Independent studies on a special topic.

CIVL 498.name: Topics in Civil Engineering
CIVL 498.desc: Seminar or lecture. Registration will take place on the first day of class by the Instructor.

CPEN 400.name: Topics in Computer Engineering
CPEN 400.desc: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

CPEN 412.name: Microcomputer Systems Design
CPEN 412.desc: Microprocessor and system buses; advanced I/O methods; priority interrupts; event/exception handling; serial I/O; computer networking; memory system design; interaction of hardware and software, microprocessor comparison, testability issues, safety critical systems.
CPEN 412.prer: One of EECE 353, CPEN 311 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211, EECE 355, CPEN 312.

CPEN 422.name: Software Testing and Analysis
CPEN 422.desc: Different levels of testing including unit, integration, system, performance and regression levels. Requirements flowdown. Problem tracking. Coverage criteria. Static methods. Tools support. Specialized techniques. Assessment of correctness, reliability, safety.
CPEN 422.prer: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, EECE 310, CPEN 321, CPSC 210, CPSC 310.

CPEN 423.name: Software Architecture
CPEN 423.desc: Software architecture as a bridge from requirements to implementation. Architectural description and patterns. Iterative development. Use of commercial off-the-shelf products.
CPEN 423.prer: One of EECE 210, CPEN 221, EECE 309, EECE 310, CPEN 321, CPSC 310.

CPEN 499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
CPEN 499.desc: Project in electrical engineering or computer engineering involving design, experimental and/or computer simulation work as selected from topics supplied by faculty members. An individual project thesis is to be prepared according to specifications available from the departmental office.

HEBR 101.name: Elementary Biblical Hebrew Part I
HEBR 101.desc: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew grammar. Includes translation of prose and poetry from the Hebrew Bible.

HEBR 102.name: Elementary Biblical Hebrew Part II
HEBR 102.desc: A continuation of HEBR 101: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew grammar. Includes translation of prose and poetry from the Hebrew Bible.

ARTH 251.name: Asian Arts: From Chinese Warriors to Bollywood Posters
ARTH 251.desc: A thematic examination of Asian arts, such as historic, religious, and secular painting and sculpture to contemporary visual culture.

ARTH 261.name: Pre-Hispanic Arts of Central and South America
ARTH 261.desc: The relevance of various arts to social institutions in ancient societies of Peru and Mesoamerica.

ARTH 262.name: Native Arts of North America
ARTH 262.desc: Men's and women's arts produced by Aboriginal Peoples of North America from pre-contact times to the present.

ARTH 310.name: Art and the Christian Transformation of the Roman Empire
ARTH 310.desc: Visual culture and the rise of Christianity; social, political and religious contexts of art, including diverse viewing practices and cultural frameworks. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 310 or ARTH 330.

ARTH 312.name: Medieval Art in the Age of Monasticism
ARTH 312.desc: Art in Western Europe between 1000 and 1200; the role of monasteries as leading institutions and patrons of art and large scale architecture. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 312 or ARTH 332.

ARTH 313.name: Art, Church, Society and their Margins in the Later Middle Ages
ARTH 313.desc: Diversification of the arts and architecture with the expansion of patronage in late medieval society. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 313 or ARTH 333.

ARTH 319.name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
ARTH 319.desc: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

ARTH 320.name: Art and Architecture in Spain and the New World (1500-1700)
ARTH 320.desc: Role of visual art and culture within Catholic Spain and colonial Latin America is surveyed, with emphasis on transculturation from mudejar to mestizaje.

ARTH 322.name: Early Modern Italian Art and Culture (ca. 1550-1700)
ARTH 322.desc: Focus primarily on Rome as the center of artistic, cultural, economic, and religious power in the seventeenth century.

ARTH 323.name: Northern European Art and Culture I (1400-1600)
ARTH 323.desc: Early Modern painting, sculpture, and the graphic arts from the great devotional triptychs, through the Reformation, to the emergence of a secular art.

ARTH 324.name: Northern European Art and Culture II (1600-1700)
ARTH 324.desc: The role of visual art within Early Modern court cultures, commercial urban centres, and emergent nation states.

ARTH 325.name: Ancient Egypt: The Archaeology of the Land of the Pharaohs
ARTH 325.desc: The material remains of the ancient Egyptians from monumental tombs and temples to the artifacts of daily life; the development of Egyptian civilization from the rise of the first rulers to its incorporation into the Roman Empire.

ARTH 329.name: Greek and Roman Art
ARTH 329.desc: Emphasis on the architecture, sculpture, painting, and decorative arts of Greece and Rome.

ARTH 342.name: Latin American Art: Modern and Contemporary
ARTH 342.desc: Analyses of specific works and texts will emphasize visual inventions and meaning in the light of recent theoretical debates

ARTH 343.name: Art and Photography in Canada to 1920
ARTH 343.desc: Art, artists, and art institutions from the establishment of the French and English colonies to the founding of the Group of Seven: issues of race, wilderness, and colonial expansion.

ARTH 346.name: Architecture in Europe: Building the Fabric of the Modern State (1715-1837)
ARTH 346.desc: The role of architecture within the development of the modern state.  A survey of broad cultural dynamics, particular building projects and design careers.

ARTH 347.name: Architecture in Europe: Modern Paradigms of Design (1837-present)
ARTH 347.desc: An examination of new requirements imposed on architecture by the consolidation of a capitalist economy, industrialization, new technologies and scientific methods.

ARTH 348.name: Architecture in North America: Colonial Projects and Disruptions (1605-1867)
ARTH 348.desc: The role of architecture in the imposition of European governance within North America;  the modification of received conventions in relation to topographical, ethnic-religious and political factors.

ARTH 349.name: Architecture in North America: Independent Design Idioms (1867-present)
ARTH 349.desc: The emergence of a distinctive architecture that superseded British and European agendas; the growth of private and public patronage and the establishment of modern design and practice.

ARTH 350.name: Grounding the Islamic Image
ARTH 350.desc: Contextualizing the complex language of images in the Islamic world.

ARTH 351.name: Art and Architecture in the Islamic World
ARTH 351.desc: A thematic study of visual arts, architecture, and objects from the Islamic world.

ARTH 354.name: Mughal India:  Art, Architecture and the Spectacle of Empire
ARTH 354.desc: The complex relationship of Mughal imperial architecture and painting with those of the Hindu Rajput courts.

ARTH 355.name: Modern and Contemporary India: Art in Colonial and Independent India
ARTH 355.desc: The development of a new Indian art during the colonial period and nationalist movement; the construction of India's contemporary visual culture.

ARTH 357.name: Chinese Art and Architecture: Patronage and Collecting
ARTH 357.desc: The commission, production, preservation, and transmission of Chinese monuments and artworks focusing on the court and questions of cultural policies.

ARTH 360.name: Chinese Painting: Word and Image
ARTH 360.desc: Analyses visual narratives and relationships between painting, calligraphy, and poetry in court and literati painting.

ARTH 361.name: Chinese Modern and Contemporary Art
ARTH 361.desc: Chinese art and its global entanglements from Qing Encounters to the 21st century.

ARTH 362.name: Art in Japan: Objects and Spaces
ARTH 362.desc: Changing relationship between art objects and the built environment in the Japanese archipelago, in its social and historical context.

ARTH 369.name: Art in Japan: Modern Visual Culture
ARTH 369.desc: Self and community in the art and visual culture of modern Japan.

ARTH 370.name: Arts of Mexico's Early Peoples
ARTH 370.desc: Pre-Aztec monumental and portable arts of the Olmec, Zapotec, Teotihuacan and Classic Veracruz peoples.

ARTH 371.name: Arts of the Aztec period in Mexico
ARTH 371.desc: Symbolic meanings and political agendas of Aztec architecture, sculpture and manuscript illustration investigated using Spanish accounts.

ARTH 372.name: Maya Public Ritual Arts
ARTH 372.desc: Architecture, sculpture, costume, and visual productions associated with Maya public ritual, including the ancient ball game and modern cofradía dances.

ARTH 373.name: Maya Arts of Everyday Life
ARTH 373.desc: Social context and meaning of the Maya's elaborate architecture, sculpture, mural paintings, jewelry, ceramics, figurines, and textiles, ancient and modern, of residences from humble to palatial.

ARTH 376.name: Arts of the Northwest Coast Peoples: The North
ARTH 376.desc: The histories, historiography and cultural diversity of the Northern Northwest Coast region; persistence and innovation in the arts in communities, and in cross-cultural and market spheres.

ARTH 382.name: Is Art History Queer?
ARTH 382.desc: Issues in the history of art through the lens of queer theory.

ARTH 410.name: Seminar in African Art
ARTH 410.desc: Key debates in the art of Africa and the African diaspora

ARTH 429.name: Studies in the Art and Archeology of Greece and Rome

ARTH 440.name: Seminar in Modern and Contemporary Art

ARTH 442.name: Seminar in Contemporary Latin American Art

ARTH 445.name: Film and the City
ARTH 445.desc: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

ARTH 450.name: Seminar in Art in the Islamic World
ARTH 450.desc: Key debates in the field of art and architecture in the Islamic World.

ARTH 476.name: Seminar in North American Aboriginal Art

ARTH 490.name: Art History Internship
ARTH 490.prer: ARTH 300 and departmental approval. Interested students may contact the department for details on how to proceed.
preq: departmental approval. Interested students may contact the department for details on how to proceed

ARCL 232.name: Ancient Latin America
ARCL 232.desc: The archaeology of ancient Mexico, Central and South America, highlighting recent discoveries about the emergence and growth of civilizations such as the Aztecs, Maya, Zapotec, Inca, Chimor and their ancestors.

ARCL 319.name: The Emergence of Complex Societies in Eurasia and Africa
ARCL 319.desc: Archaeological evidence and theories for the origins and spread of settled village life, food production systems, and complex social and political organization: Early Neolithic period through to the appearance of the old world civilizations.

ARCL 322.name: Archaeological Foundations of East and Southeast Asia
ARCL 322.desc: Survey of the archaeology of East and Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on the beginnings of the economic, social, political, and artistic traditions and systems of the great civilizations, and the conditions in which they arose. Theories of cultural development emphasizing Neolithic and state-level societies will be discussed.

ARCL 323.name: Archaeological Foundations of Mesoamerica
ARCL 323.desc: The archaeology of Mexico and Central America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization. Seminar format discussing recent research and current discoveries.

ARCL 324.name: Archaeological Foundations of South America
ARCL 324.desc: The archaeology of South America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization, and a primary focus on the Andean region.  Seminar format with lectures discussing recent research and current discoveries.

ARCL 325.name: Paleoanthropology
ARCL 325.desc: Origin and development of the hominins; the hominin fossil record, and theories relating to hominin evolution.

ARCL 406.name: Analytical Techniques in Archaeology
ARCL 406.desc: A survey of methods and techniques in the interpretation of archaeological data; practical experience in processing and analyzing archaeological materials by means of a research project. Students will prepare manuscripts, drawings and photographs for publication and will learn the basics of lithic and faunal analyses.

ARCL 410.name: Archaeology of a Special Area in Africa, Eurasia, or Oceania
ARCL 410.desc: Analysis of the archaeology of one of the listed areas, including a summary of the literature and examination of specific sites and analytical issues.  The area covered will vary according to the instructor's expertise.
ARCL 410.prer: One of ARCL 305, ARCL 318, ARCL 319, ARCL 322.

ARCL 411.name: Prehistory of a Special Area in the New World
ARCL 411.desc: Analysis of the prehistory of a selected New World area, including a summary of the literature and discussion of relevant problems. The course will provide background for students in North, Central, and South American area studies. Typical offerings include the prehistory of Mesoamerica, the Southwest, North America and the Mayan areas.

ARCL 420.name: First Nations Archaeology of British Columbia
ARCL 420.desc: An advanced study of the prehistoric archaeology of coastal and interior Native Peoples. A critical analysis of the archaeological evidence and interpretations of prehistoric cultural developments from the earliest migrations up to historical contact.

ARCL 430.name: Archaeological Survey Methods
ARCL 430.desc: Analytical and practical skills in locating archaeological sites and data leading to spatial patterns and historical interpretation.

NURS 301.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Primary Health Care
NURS 301.desc: Analysis and application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies guiding professional nursing practice in the context of primary health care. Students who take NURS 342 cannot earn credit for NURS 336 or NURS 402.
NURS 301.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 302.name: Foundations for Professional Nursing Practice
NURS 302.desc: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to the discipline and practice of nursing.
NURS 302.crer: All of NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS 303.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: People Living with Mental Health Challenges and Their Families
NURS 303.desc: Theory informing a life course perspective on nursing practice with people living with mental health challenges and their families is introduced. Students who take NURS 303 cannot earn credit for NURS 335 or NURS 424.

NURS 304.name: Introduction to Relational Practice
NURS 304.desc: Introduction to relational theories to guide nursing practice within the socio-political, historical, economic and cultural context of health and health care.
NURS 304.crer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS 305.name: Introduction to Critical Inquiry and Research
NURS 305.desc: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, evidence-based and informed practice, and research utilization in health care.
NURS 305.crer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 306.

NURS 306.name: Introduction to Leadership, Ethics, and Policy in Health Care
NURS 306.desc: Introduction to fundamental theories, concepts, evidence and competencies pertaining to health care leadership, ethics and policy.
NURS 306.crer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305.

NURS 323.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice III
NURS 323.desc: Skills and competencies for clinical practice across the lifespan and health care continuum through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS 323.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 331.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Adults/Older Adults Experiencing Acute Health Challenges and Their Families
NURS 331.desc: Consolidation of fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to acute care nursing practice with adults/older adults and their families. Students who take NURS 331 cannot earn credit for NURS 303, NURS 337 or NURS 420
NURS 331.crer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 360.

NURS 338.name: Relational Nursing Practice Across Diverse Health Experiences
NURS 338.desc: Exploration and analysis of opportunities and challenges of relational practice across multiple diverse health experiences and sites of health care.
NURS 338.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS 339.name: Critical Inquiry and Research in Health Care Practice
NURS 339.desc: Exploration of the application of theories, concepts, evidence and competencies pertaining to scientific inquiry, and the role of evidence informed practice in supporting health care across the range of healthcare disciplines.
NURS 339.prer: All of NURS 302, NURS 303, NURS 304, NURS 305, NURS 306.

NURS 351.name: Leadership, Policy, and Informatics
NURS 351.desc: The enactment of nursing leadership and policy within different health sectors and jurisdictions and the relevance and application of informatics competencies to the delivery of nursing care. Students who take NURS 351 cannot earn credit for NURS 306, NURS 340 or NURS 343.
NURS 351.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 353.name: Promoting the Health of Indigenous People
NURS 353.desc: Foundations to contribute to supporting and providing high quality, ethical, respectful and culturally safe health care in partnership with Indigenous people in Canada and around the globe.

NURS 354.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Complexities in Seniors Care
NURS 354.desc: Research and clinical practice innovations in the care of Seniors and their families (e.g., philosophies of care; age-friendly initiatives) and provide strategies for improving their health through the purposeful integration of such practices in clinical settings.
NURS 354.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 361.name: Nursing Practice with Adults/Older Adults Experiencing Acute Health Challenges and their Families
NURS 361.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the care of adults/older adults experiencing acute health challenges and their families. Students who take NURS 361 cannot earn credit for NURS 303, NURS 337 or NURS 420.
NURS 361.crer: Four of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.
creq: Four of NURS 300 NURS 310 NURS 321 NURS 330 NURS 360

NURS 362.name: Nursing Practice in Primary Health Care Contexts
NURS 362.desc: Clinical practice to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies in the context of primary health care. Students who take NURS 362 cannot earn credit for NURS 336 or NURS 425.
NURS 362.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 363.name: Nursing Practice with People Living with Mental Health Challenges and Their Families
NURS 363.desc: Students will apply theory and concepts from a life course perspective in the provision of nursing care to persons living with mental health challenges and their families. Students who take NURS 363 cannot earn credit for NURS 335 or NURS 424
NURS 363.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 401.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice IV
NURS 401.desc: Students are prepared with the skills and competencies for clinical practice in simulated acute and community settings through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS 401.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 321, NURS 330, NURS 360.

NURS 402.name: Foundational Skills and Competencies for Clinical Practice V
NURS 402.desc: Students are guided to consolidate skills and competencies for clinical practice through a variety of modalities and learning activities.
NURS 402.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 321, NURS 322, NURS 323, NURS 353, NURS 360, NURS 361, NURS 362, NURS 363, NURS 365, NURS 366, NURS 401.

NURS 410.name: Supplemental Guided Study
NURS 410.desc: Supplemental guided study to integrate and consolidate professional nursing knowledge, skills and competencies. For Bachelor of Science Nursing students only. Pass/Fail.

NURS 430.name: Theoretical Perspectives in Nursing: Special Topics in Complex and Urgent Health Challenges across Settings/Populations
NURS 430.desc: Consolidation of fundamental theories, concepts, evidence, and competencies pertaining to nursing practice across the life-span and care context. Students who take NURS 430 cannot earn credit for NURS 420, 422, 423, 424 or 425
NURS 430.prer: All of NURS 300, NURS 301, NURS 303, NURS 310, NURS 321, NURS 322, NURS 323, NURS 330, NURS 331, NURS 344, NURS 345, NURS 346, NURS 350, NURS 351, NURS 352, NURS 353, NURS 354, NURS 360, NURS 361, NURS 362, NURS 363, NURS 365, NURS 366, NURS 401.

LLED 206.name: Language Field Experience
LLED 206.desc: Guided individual and group projects related to concurrent studies. Field-based assignments related to language study.

LLED 210.name: Introduction to Analyzing Meanings of Images in Texts
LLED 210.desc: Systematic analysis of visual and verbal modalities in academic and professional registers through a "grammar" designed for this purpose.

LLED 211.name: Field Research in Social Processes of Inclusion and Exclusion: Discourse Perspectives
LLED 211.desc: Roles that social discourses of inclusion and exclusion play in intercultural integration.

LLED 221.name: Language Maintenance and the Integration of Immigrants in Canada: An Introduction
LLED 221.desc: The concept of societal and individual bilingualism/multilingualism in a variety of settings, including Canada in particular.

LLED 226.name: Introduction to Language Across the Curriculum
LLED 226.desc: Understanding text structure within, and language diversity among, subject areas. Analysis of oral and written language from various curriculum areas in which English is the medium of instruction; implications for learning and instruction. [1.5-3-0]

LLED 300.name: Foundations of Language and Literacy Education: Elementary and Middle Years

LLED 301.name: Language Across the Curriculum in Multilingual Classrooms: Secondary

LLED 310.name: Introduction to Reading and Language Arts Instruction: Elementary and Middle Years

LLED 312.name: Curriculum and Instruction in French: Secondary
LLED 312.prer: A completed concentration in French or permission of the Head.

LLED 313.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Theatre and Drama: Secondary
LLED 313.prer: A completed concentration in theatre or drama or permission of the Head.

LLED 315.name: English as a Second Language - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

LLED 318.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Modern Languages: Secondary
LLED 318.desc: A completed concentration in a modern language (Chinese, German, Italian, Japanese, Russian, Spanish, or Punjabi) or permission of the Head. Pass/Fail.
