LLED 320.name: Curriculum and Instruction in Language and Literacy Education: Elementary and Middle Years

LLED 323.name: Teaching and Learning Modern Languages: Elementary and Middle Years
LLED 323.desc: Curriculum and methods of teaching in modern languages (including Chinese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Punjabi, Russian, and Spanish).

LLED 324.name: Teaching and Learning French: Elementary and Middle Years
LLED 324.desc: An introduction to communicative core French teaching and learning for generalists. Pass/Fail.
LLED 324.prer: French 12, or equivalent prior French experience.

LLED 325.name: Teaching and Learning French in Elementary Schools
LLED 325.desc: Taught in French. Strategies, theoretical foundations, and approaches related to teaching elementary French (Immersion, Core, Intensive) programs. Pass/Fail.
LLED 325.prer: A completed concentration in French or permission of the Head.

LLED 326.name: Introduction to Teaching and Learning Mandarin: Elementary/Secondary
LLED 326.desc: Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students.  Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail.

LLED 336.name: Communication: Voice, Audience, Message
LLED 336.desc: Knowledge and development of skills necessary to create a transactional style of teaching.

LLED 363.name: Teaching and Learning English as an Additional Language: Secondary

LLED 368.name: Multiliteracies in English Language Arts Classrooms

LLED 382.name: Teaching Language and Literacy - Modern Languages: Secondary
LLED 382.desc: Pass/Fail for B.Ed. students.  Non-B.Ed. students are eligible for percentage grading or Credit/D/Fail grading.

LLED 391.name: Theory and Practice in Reading Instruction
LLED 391.desc: Credit may be obtained for only one of LLED 310, 391, 300.

LLED 420.name: Using Canadian Children's Literature in the French Education Classroom
LLED 420.desc: Taught in French. Credit will be given for one of LLED 440, LLED 420.

LLED 421.name: Gramligne: Learning and Teaching Grammar in Text for the Second Language Classroom

LLED 422.name: Language Assessment in the French as a Second/Additional Language Classroom
LLED 422.prer: A completed concentration or major in French or permission of Department Head.

LLED 426.name: Principles and Practice of French Program Development
LLED 426.desc: Taught in French. The development and implementation of French Immersion, Program Cadre, and French as a Second language Programs for preschool, elementary, secondary, or adult.

LLED 428.name: Applied Linguistics for Teachers of French
LLED 428.prer: Either (a) FREN 220 or (b) all of FREN 222, FREN 223.

LLED 429.name: Advanced Studies in Modern Language Education
LLED 429.desc: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and LLED 429.

LLED 435.name: Drama in Education: Community, Inquiry, and Performance

LLED 440.name: Using Canadian Children's Literature in the Classroom

LLED 442.name: Trends and Issues in Teaching Children's Literature

LLED 451.name: Teaching and Learning Language and Literacy: Intermediate and Middle Years
LLED 451.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

LLED 453.name: Materials and Texts of Literacy Instruction: Elementary
LLED 453.prer: An introductory-level reading or language arts education course.

LLED 454.name: Adolescent Literacies: Processes and Practices
LLED 454.prer: or corequisite: an introductory-level reading, language arts, or English education course.

LLED 455.name: Supporting Language and Literacy for First Nations Learners (K-12)

LLED 456.name: Identifying and Supporting Learners with Literacy Difficulties
LLED 456.desc: Individualized assessment, diagnosis, and instructional planning for students with literacy difficulties. Intensive practicum is included in the 6-credit version of this course.
LLED 456.prer: An introductory- level reading or language arts course; successful completion of an extended practicum or one year of teaching experience.
preq: language arts course; successful completion of an extended practicum

LLED 478.name: Introduction to Teaching English as a Second Language

LLED 480.name: Advanced Studies in Language and Literacy Education
LLED 480.desc: Credit will be given for only 6 credits of LLED 480 and 429.

LLED 487.name: Special Topics in English Education
LLED 487.prer: An introductory-level reading, language arts, or English education course.

LLED 493.name: Supervised Study in Modern Languages Education

ADHE 313.name: Organization of Adult Basic Education Programs
ADHE 313.desc: Rationale, structures, and functions of basic education completion. [3-0-0]

ADHE 314.name: Adult Correctional Education
ADHE 314.desc: Planning prison education; methods and techniques as they are affected by historical, philosophical, structural, and organizational contexts of penal institutions. [3-0-0]

ADHE 375.name: Diploma Seminar and Internship in Adult Education

APBI 235.name: Biotechnology in Agricultural Food Production
APBI 235.desc: Genetics, genomics, and biotechnology concepts with applications to agricultural food production and food safety. [3-3]

APBI 316.name: Equine Biology, Health and Welfare
APBI 316.desc: Anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition of the horse; common disease pathology, prevention and treatments; equine behaviour. [3-0]

APBI 326.name: Introductory Plant Pathology
APBI 326.desc: Study of the ecology of plant pathogenic organisms; principles of disease development and control. [3-2-0]

APBI 328.name: Weed Science
APBI 328.desc: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventive, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control. [3-2-0]

APBI 411.name: Reproductive Physiology and Technology
APBI 411.desc: A comparative overview of reproductive physiology and reproductive technologies in domesticated and laboratory animals. [3-2-0]
APBI 411.prer: BIOL 201. Third year standing or higher.

APBI 427.name: Insect Ecology
APBI 427.desc: Behavioural, population, and community ecology of insects. Interaction between insects and plants and the application of the principals of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds. [3-0]
APBI 427.prer: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of BIOL 327, APBI 327.

APBI 461.name: Applied Agroecology
APBI 461.desc: Analysis and solution of problems in agricultural production systems through the integration and application of agroecological knowledge and principles. [1-0-3]

APBI 465.name: Capstone in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
APBI 465.desc: Integrates classroom and applied learning at the UBC Farm with design project. [1-3-0]

APBI 496.name: Applied Animal Biology Practicum
APBI 496.desc: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
APBI 496.prer: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.
preq: higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended

PHYS 102.name: Electricity, Light and Radiation
PHYS 102.desc: Introduction to optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 [3-3*-1*]
PHYS 102.crer: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121.

PHYS 153.name: Elements of Physics
PHYS 153.desc: Thermometry, thermal properties of matter, heat, oscillations, waves, sound, wave optics; geometrical optics, elementary electricity and magnetism, simple DC and AC circuits. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414. [3-0-1; 3-3-1]
PHYS 153.crer: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

PHYS 209.name: Intermediate Experimental Physics
PHYS 209.desc: Use of analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics and analog-to-digital conversion and the use of computers in data analysis and simulations in thermodynamic, electronic and modern physics experiments. [0-3-1*]
PHYS 209.prer: Either (a) all of PHYS 108, PHYS 109 or (b) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 153 or (c) SCIE 001 or (d) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (e) all of PHYS 118, PHYS 119.
PHYS 209.crer: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

PHYS 314.name: Fluids
PHYS 314.desc: Kinetic theory: Diffusion, viscosity and sound waves. Introduction to hydrodynamics: Laminar flow, capillary and gravity waves, convection and turbulence. Dimensional analysis. [3-0-0]

PHYS 318.name: Experimental Acoustics
PHYS 318.desc: Experimental techniques of acoustics: data acquisition hardware and software, microphones, loudspeakers, noise, vibration and modal analysis. [2-3-0]

PHYS 330.name: Modern Physics
PHYS 330.desc: Quantum physics, nuclear energy and particle physics at a level suitable for third- and fourth-year Science students not proceeding to a physics degree. Not for credit towards a B.Sc. in Astronomy, Biophysics or Physics. [3-0-0]
PHYS 330.prer: Either (a) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157;  or (b) SCIE 001.

PHYS 343.name: Physical Science by Inquiry
PHYS 343.desc: A guided sequence of hands-on science modules intended primarily for prospective elementary schoolteachers, to help them to work constructively in a science teaching role. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. [0-6-0]

PHYS 354.name: Electric and Magnetic Fields
PHYS 354.desc: Applications of electricity and magnetism. Maxwell's equations. [3-0-1]
PHYS 354.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317.

PHYS 409.name: Experimental Physics
PHYS 409.desc: A laboratory course with a wide choice of experiments for fourth year Honours and Major students. Topics include solid state, nuclear, classical, quantum, electromagnetic and low temperature physics. For six credits, two weekly laboratory periods and completion of a project in second term are required. [0-3-0]

PHYS 412.name: Quantum Physics
PHYS 412.desc: Fundamentals of atomic, nuclear, particle, and condensed matter physics. [3-0-0]
PHYS 412.prer: MATH 215 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 200.

PHYS 420.name: Physics Demonstrations
PHYS 420.desc: The students will prepare, under the supervision of a faculty member, a demonstration or series of demonstrations intended to illustrate physical principles to diverse audiences. Intended for third- or fourth-year Physics Majors and Math/Science Education students.

PHYS 437.name: Physics of Biocellular Structure and Machinery
PHYS 437.desc: Molecular structure and architecture of biological cells, interactions of molecules in aqueous solution and at interfaces, physical properties of polymers and surfactants, mechanisms of cell membranes and cytoplasmic structures, thermodynamics of molecular machines and mechanical enzymes. Credit can not be given for both PHYS 437 and 537. [3-0-0]
PHYS 437.prer: One of PHYS 313, PHYS 403, PHYS 455, CHEM 304.

PHYS 447.name: Advanced Topics in Physics
PHYS 447.desc: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

PHYS 450.name: Quantum Mechanics
PHYS 450.desc: Postulates of quantum mechanics, expectation values, hermitian operators, commuting observables, applications to one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, applications in three dimensions, hydrogen atom, time dependent perturbations. Credit will be given for only one of PHYS 304, 450 or CHEM 312. [3-0-0]

PHYS 454.name: Applied Electromagnetic Theory
PHYS 454.desc: Wave propagation and related phenomena in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas. Wave guides, radiation, antennae, special relativity. [3-0-0]

PHYS 455.name: Statistical Mechanics
PHYS 455.desc: Introduction to quantum statistical mechanics and its application to systems of varying complexity from the simple ideal gas to the degenerate gas. Quantum fluids, phase transitions and simulation methods will also be introduced. Credit cannot be given for both PHYS 403 and 455. [3-0-0]
PHYS 455.prer: One of PHYS 257, PHYS 203, PHYS 313 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450.

PHYS 458.name: Applied Optics
PHYS 458.desc: Basic applications of lasers, geometrical optics, fibre optics, diffraction, and Fourier optics. [3-3-0]

ARCH 407.name: Research Methods
ARCH 407.desc: Motivations and techniques which underpin environmental design research.

ARCH 410.name: Design Methods
ARCH 410.desc: Techniques for environmental design, including architecture.

GERM 213.name: Refresher I
GERM 213.desc: Grammar-based course for students with previous untutored  exposure to German and students with a first-year knowledge in need of grammar review.

GERM 305.name: The Culture of Nazism (in English)
GERM 305.desc: Literature, film and ideology in the Third Reich.

GERM 318.name: Introduction to German Linguistics
GERM 318.desc: Basic theories and methodologies of modern German linguistics.

GERM 319.name: Canadian German Cultural Dialogues
GERM 319.desc: Analysis of intercultural theory; examination of Canadian and German print and video materials.  Includes direct audio/visual intercultural online discussion with German-speaking students at the University of Kiel.

GERM 370.name: Reason and Revolution: Studies in the 18th Century
GERM 370.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of eighteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM 390.name: Progress and Disaster: Studies in the 20th and 21st Centuries
GERM 390.desc: Masterpieces and major trends of 20th and 21st-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

GERM 401.name: The Cult of the Hero and its Parody in German Literature
GERM 401.desc: The glorification and satirization of heroes and heroism in a variety of genres and periods. Works and authors to be studied might include Nibelungenlied, Faust, Gryphius, Kleist, Fontane, Brecht, Remarque.

GERM 403.name: Studies in Modern German Culture (in English)
GERM 403.desc: Topics of special interest, varying from year to year.

GERM 405.name: The Literature of Growing Social Consciousness
GERM 405.desc: Concentrates on the late 18th to the early 20th century. This course traces the reflections in German literature of changes in social, political, cultural and gender concepts. Readings are drawn from a variety of genres.

GERM 406.name: Selected Topics in German Literature
GERM 406.desc: A study in depth of one topic of special interest, varying from year to year depending on interests of faculty and students. Possible topics: literature and film, the image of the outside world in German literature, individualism and conformism.

GERM 407.name: The German Lyric from Goethe to the Present
GERM 407.desc: Reading and discussion of selected texts against their cultural, social and political background.

GERM 408.name: Selected Issues in German Culture
GERM 408.desc: In depth study of one topic from German cultural history, varying from year to year. Possible topics: Germany of the New Europe; Gender and nation in German culture; topics from theory, such as the Frankfurt School.

GERM 409.name: Special Topics in German Cinema (in English)
GERM 409.desc: Themes, traditions and techniques specific to German cinema.

GERM 420.name: Advanced German III
GERM 420.desc: Near-native competence and an advanced and transferable understanding of contemporary issues.

GERM 430.name: Advanced German IV
GERM 430.desc: Near-native competence and an advanced and transferable understanding of contemporary issues, intercultural comparisons and analyses in a variety of fields using German as the focus and means of communication.

CDST 250.name: Introduction to Canada
CDST 250.desc: Approaches to the study of Canada from an interdisciplinary perspective, including cultural, political, historical, and economic dimensions.

CDST 350.name: Canadian Studies
CDST 350.desc: An interdisciplinary introduction to Canadian studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

CDST 450.name: Senior Seminar in Canadian Studies
CDST 450.desc: The Canadian experience from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Offered by the McLean Chair in Canadian Studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

ENDS 211.name: Introduction to Environmental Design
ENDS 211.desc: Survey of the visual, cultural, ecological and spatial literacies in environmental design and planning.

ENDS 281.name: Architecture in Context and Across Cultures: A History
ENDS 281.desc: A world survey of architecture, from prehistory to postmodernity, which relates architecture to landscape and city, design principles and cultural values, formal and vernacular practices. It explores the different ways in which history has been conveyed and the purposes it serves. [2-0-1]

ENDS 404.name: Environmental Design History
ENDS 404.desc: A survey of environmental influences in architecture and landscape architecture design across time, geographies, and cultures, from neolithic settlements to nineteenth-century urbanization. Restricted to students in the Environmental Design program.

KORN 100.name: Basic Korean I
KORN 100.desc: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100 or KORN 102.

KORN 101.name: Basic Korean II
KORN 101.desc: Continuation of KORN 100. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 101 or KORN 102.

KORN 104.name: Basic Korean Grammar
KORN 104.desc: Emphasis on grammar, writing, and reading. For heritage learners and students with prior background in spoken Korean.

KORN 161.name: Enriched Summer Intensive Beginning
KORN 161.desc: An integrated language course developing communicative competence in speaking, listening to, reading, and writing modern Korean.

KORN 201.name: Intermediate Korean I
KORN 201.desc: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201 or KORN 200.

KORN 202.name: Intermediate Korean II
KORN 202.desc: Continuation of KORN 201. Credit will be granted for only one of KORN 202 or KORN 200.

KORN 300.name: Readings in Korean Topics
KORN 300.desc: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

KORN 351.name: Introduction to Sino-Korean Readings
KORN 351.desc: Chinese characters in their Korean pronunciations and shapes. Students learn approximately 600 characters, related vocabulary, and do structured readings in mixed scripts on aspects of Korean culture and contemporary life.

KORN 410.name: Modern Korean Short Fiction
KORN 410.desc: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.
KORN 410.prer: Either (a) KORN 300 or (b) all of KORN 301, KORN 302.

KORN 411.name: Advanced Readings in Korean Non-Fiction
KORN 411.desc: Guided readings on contemporary affairs from the Korean press and/or selected readings in Korean academic prose.

KORN 412.name: Korean-to-English Translation
KORN 412.desc: Translation into English of Korean writing in various literary genres, including short story, poetry, personal essay, and academic essay. Supplementary readings in translation studies and translation theory.

KORN 415.name: Korean Conversation and Composition
KORN 415.desc: Structured conversation practice and weekly composition assignments based on viewing one designated Korean television program per week.

KORN 420.name: Readings in Middle and Early Modern Korean
KORN 420.desc: History and structure of the Korean language through targeted close readings in different editions of an illustrated text from the 15th and 18th centuries.
KORN 420.prer: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome.
preq: Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410

KORN 440.name: Supervised Study in the Korean Language
KORN 440.desc: Primarily for students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

LFS 301.name: Aquaculture Field Studies
LFS 301.desc: An orientation to the aquaculture system in BC. Participating students are assessed a fee.

LFS 302.name: International Field Studies
LFS 302.desc: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

LFS 490.name: Topics in Land and Food Systems
LFS 490.desc: Analysis and interpretation of current issues related to land and food systems.

LFS 496.name: Career Development Internship
LFS 496.desc: Technical work experience appropriate to students' career goals. Enrolment subject to competition and availability of work placements.

LATN 401.name: Latin Prose
LATN 401.desc: Studies in history, oratory and/or philosophy. May be repeated for up to 12 credits. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to LATN 401.

LATN 402.name: Latin Verse
LATN 402.desc: Studies in narrative verse, comedy, satire, elegiac and lyric poetry. May be repeated for up to 12 credits. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to LATN 402.

SLAV 105.name: Introduction to Russian and Slavic Culture
SLAV 105.desc: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present.

SLAV 307.name: Literature and Film in Eastern Europe
SLAV 307.desc: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

LIBE 477.name: Special Topics in Teacher Librarianship
LIBE 477.desc: In-depth study of selected topics in library education. [3-0-0]

WOOD 241.name: Programming for Wood Products Manufacturing Applications
WOOD 241.desc: Practical computer and problem solving cases taken from wood products manufacturing industrial applications. [2-4-0]

WOOD 271.name: Wood Products Chemistry I
WOOD 271.desc: Chemistry relating to wood and wood products: chemistry of lignin, cellulose, hemicelluloses, extractives, and biological degradation of lignocellulosics; wood pressure impregnation procedures. [3-3-0]
WOOD 271.prer: WOOD 280 and one of CHEM 113, CHEM 123.

WOOD 430.name: Plant Layout and Design
WOOD 430.desc: Techniques for developing a plan,setting goals, and evaluating the impact of changes in the design, layout and operation of the factory with an emphasis on computer simulation.

WOOD 449.name: Directed Studies in Wood Products Processing
WOOD 449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in wood products processing.

WOOD 475.name: Wood Properties, Identification and Uses
WOOD 475.desc: Elementary chemical, physical and mechanical properties of wood and their variations in relation to structure; identification by hand lens features; manufacture of lumber, pulp and composite wood products. Not available for credit to Wood Products Processing students. [3-2]

WOOD 476.name: Design of Timber Structures
WOOD 476.desc: Design of timber structural elements using limit states design principles; joints and fasteners, sawn lumber and engineered wood products, light frame systems and shear walls.

WOOD 478.name: Building Science
WOOD 478.desc: Building enclosure design considering heat and moisture transmission, air flow and ventilation, condensation, acoustics; roofing systems; diagnostic evaluations; fire protection. [3-0-0]

BUSI 290.name: Introduction to Quantitative Decision Analysis
BUSI 290.desc: Introduction to decision models in business, including basic optimization, linear programming, probability, decision analysis, random variables, simulation, and solving decision problems using spreadsheet tools.

BUSI 295.name: Managerial Economics
BUSI 295.desc: Economic foundations of managerial decision making.

BUSI 299.name: Business Communications
BUSI 299.desc: Basic communication theory, communications in organizations.  Includes written and oral practice in lab sessions.

BUSI 391.name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
BUSI 391.desc: Overview of computer technology and terminology; use of computers as managerial and administrative tools; the management of computer resources and the influence of information technology within the organization.

BUSI 399.name: Logistics and Operations Management
BUSI 399.desc: The design and management of systems to make products, provide services and deliver them to the end user.
BUSI 399.prer: All of BUSI 290, BUSI 291 or equivalents.

BUSI 454.name: Accounting for Management Control and Incentives
BUSI 454.desc: Design of accounting systems for facilitating and influencing management decisions, with emphasis on performance evaluation in organizations.

BUSI 485.name: Taxes and Decision Making
BUSI 485.desc: Analysis of business and financial decisions in the presence of taxes.

BUSI 498.name: International Business Management
BUSI 498.desc: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems.
BUSI 498.prer: BUSI 293 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 309.
BUSI 498.crer: Two of BUSI 294, BUSI 329, BUSI 370, BUSI 465.
creq: Two of BUSI 294 BUSI 329 BUSI 370 BUSI 465

CENS 303.name: Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
CENS 303.desc: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

SANS 301.name: Introductory Sanskrit I
SANS 301.desc: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.

SANS 302.name: Introductory Sanskrit II
SANS 302.desc: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300.

SANS 401.name: Intermediate Sanskrit I
SANS 401.desc: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400.

SANS 402.name: Intermediate Sanskrit II
SANS 402.desc: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400.

SANS 450.name: Further Readings in Sanskrit
SANS 450.desc: Study of selected texts belonging to a particular period (e.g., Vedic) or representing a specific branch of kavya (poetic literature) or sastra (technical-philosophical literature).
SANS 450.prer: One of SANS 200, SANS 202, SANS 400, SANS 402.

CONS 415.name: Land, Trees, and Property Institutions
CONS 415.desc: Exploration of the forces that gave rise to the global variety of systems of property for trees and forestlands; evolution in the governance of property. [3-0-0]

CONS 440.name: Conservation Policy
CONS 440.desc: Contemporary issues are used to examine conservation policies designed to achieve conservation objectives. [3-0]

CONS 449.name: Directed Studies in Natural Resources Conservation
CONS 449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies of specific problems in natural resources conservation.

MRNE 400.name: Directed Studies
MRNE 400.desc: A research project approved by the supervisor in the field of interest of the student designed to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. Note: the supervisor may be teaching at the Marine Centre; or a member of faculty of WCUMSS whether at the Marine Centre as a research investigator or as one of the members of WCUMSS.

MRNE 401.name: Special Topics in Marine Biology
MRNE 401.desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. It is expected that the course will generally be of a specialized nature and be at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.

MRNE 402.name: Special Topics in Marine Biology
MRNE 402.desc: This course will be offered, as opportunities arise, by distinguished scientists visiting at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre. This course will be of a specialized nature and at a level appropriate to graduate or senior undergraduate students.

MRNE 411.name: Comparative Invertebrate Embryology
MRNE 411.desc: A comprehensive study of development of marine invertebrates available at the Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre, including all major phyla and most of the minor phyla.

MRNE 420.name: Marine Phycology
MRNE 420.desc: A survey of the marine algae, with emphasis on the benthic forms in the vicinity of the Marine Centre. The course includes lectures, laboratory periods, field collection, identification and observation. Emphasis is placed on the study of living specimens in the laboratory and in the field.

MRNE 430.name: Marine Ecology
MRNE 430.desc: An analytical approach to biotic associations in the marine environment. Opportunities are provided for study of the intertidal realm in exposed and protected areas, and of beaches and estuaries in the vicinity of the Marine Centre; plankton studies and investigations of the subtidal and benthic environments by diving and dredging are envisaged.

MRNE 435.name: Introduction to Biological Oceanography
MRNE 435.desc: An introduction to the biology of oceans, with supporting coverage of relevant physics and chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on plankton biology, community structure and life histories, and influencing environmental factors. Collections will be made from sheltered inlets, through Barkely Sound to offshore waters. The course will involve both field and laboratory.

MRNE 440.name: Biology of Marine Birds
MRNE 440.desc: Study of interrelationship of birds and the marine environment. Census techniques and observation of birds in the field will be emphasized.
MRNE 440.prer: Completion of a course in vertebrate zoology or permission of the instructor.
preq: Completion of a course in vertebrate zoology

MRNE 445.name: Biology of Marine Mammals
MRNE 445.desc: Survey course covering systematics and distribution of marine mammals, their sensory capabilities and physiology, with special emphasis on the Cetacea. The course will involve an independent field study.

MEDD 439.name: Flexible Enhanced Learning III
MEDD 439.desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, life-long learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 441.name: Senior Elective
MEDD 441.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 442.name: Senior Elective
MEDD 442.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 443.name: Senior Elective
MEDD 443.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 444.name: Senior Elective
MEDD 444.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 445.name: Senior Elective
MEDD 445.desc: A senior clinical elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 446.name: Senior Elective
MEDD 446.desc: A senior clinical or academic elective for fourth-year students. Students will participate in all relevant clinical and/or academic activities associated with the particular elective. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 448.name: Transition into Postgraduate Education and Practice
MEDD 448.desc: Enables students to effectively transition from medical school to residency and medical practice. Complex clinical presentations that integrate foundational sciences and practice themes. Prepares students for practice as residents and physicians. Pass/Fail.

MEDD 449.name: Flexible Enhanced Learning III
MEDD 449.desc: Opportunity to build on scholarly activities initiated in MEDD 419 and 429, or start new ones. Emphasizes social accountability and fosters innovation and critical thought to prepare graduates for roles as scholars, life-long learners, and leaders. Pass/Fail.

CSIS 300.name: Introduction to Critical Studies in Sexuality
CSIS 300.desc: A multidisciplinary, team-taught course which provides an introduction to the study of sexuality, including  lesbian, gay, bisexual, heterosexual, and transgender issues and related topics.

CSIS 450.name: Topics in Critical Studies in Sexuality
CSIS 450.desc: A thematic course, which explores current questions and issues in relation to the study of sexuality. Topics may vary from year to year.

CSIS 490.name: Directed Topics
CSIS 490.desc: Designed to allow a student to develop an individual course of study in a specific area as approved by a faculty member affiliated with the CSIS program.

RELG 102.name: Introduction to the Major Eastern Religions
RELG 102.desc: An introduction to the major Asian religious traditions (Hinduism, Sikhism, Jainism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, Shintoism, and Shamanism; including religious life in South Asia – devotionalism in Islam, Hinduism, Sikhism) which employs theoretical models drawn from religious studies.

RELG 204.name: Introduction to Asian Religions
RELG 204.desc: The religions of India, China, and Japan in their interactions and cultural contexts, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Shinto.

RELG 206.name: Introduction to Judaism and its Texts
RELG 206.desc: What is Judaism? An overview of the key texts that have defined the Jewish religion, from the Hebrew Bible through works of contemporary thinkers. Recommended as a basis for upper-level courses in religious studies.

RELG 210.name: History of Christianity I (1st C. C.E. - 14th C. C.E.)
RELG 210.desc: An introduction to the history of Christianity from the post-Biblical period to the colonial expansion of Christianity under Spain and Portugal.

RELG 211.name: History of Christianity II (15th C. C.E. - present)
RELG 211.desc: The history of Christianity from the Reformation to the present day. Provides an historical overview of Christian thought and its institutions and significant people during the rise of the Reformation in various locales of Europe and beyond (Germany, France, Great Britain, Switzerland, and Scandinavia).

RELG 302.name: Death and Afterlife in Western Religious Tradition
RELG 302.desc: A survey of traditional attitudes toward death and beliefs regarding human existence after death in Western religions.

RELG 305.name: The Prophetic Personality in Ancient Israel
RELG 305.desc: An exploration of the unique phenomenon of the biblical prophet in its wider Near Eastern context.

RELG 308.name: Talmud, Midrash and the Rabbinic Imagination
RELG 308.desc: The Talmud, Midrash, and other late-antique (3rd - 7th centuries) rabbinic writings, focusing on biblical interpretation and narratives.

RELG 309.name: Jews and Christians
RELG 309.desc: Aspects of Jewish-Christian relations from the beginnings of Christianity to the present day. Emphasis on the study of Christian and Jewish texts in translation.

RELG 310.name: Jewish Responses to Catastrophe
RELG 310.desc: Topics include the destruction of the Second Temple, the Crusades, the expulsions from Spain and Portugal, and the Holocaust. A study of texts in translation.

RELG 311.name: Jewish Literature in Translation
RELG 311.desc: A survey of Jewish literature in medieval and modern times.

RELG 312.name: Jews and Judaism in Canada
RELG 312.desc: The history of the Jewish community in Canada, from New France to the present. Emphasis on the relationship between immigration and religious transformation, Jewish-Christian relations, the development of community structures.

RELG 313.name: Modern Jewish Ethics in Historical Perspective
RELG 313.desc: Readings from key texts in English translation, tracing how Jewish approaches to ethical issues evolved from biblical times to the present.

RELG 315.name: History of Christian Thought
RELG 315.desc: Selected topics with special emphasis on doctrinal change and development, orthodoxy and heresy, tradition and authority, and Church and State in the Patristic, Medieval, Reformation, and Modern periods.

RELG 316.name: The Origins of Christianity: Literary Contexts
RELG 316.desc: The origins of Christianity as reflected in the New Testament and contemporaneous literature.

RELG 321.name: Prophetic Figures in the Christian Tradition
RELG 321.desc: Examined in their historical context and in terms of their continuing significance. Selection will vary from year to year, but may include Augustine, Thomas Aquinas, Martin Luther, and Teresa of Avila.

RELG 323.name: Christianity in the Modern World
RELG 323.desc: The interaction between Christianity and the major intellectual, social, and cultural developments since 1648 with special attention to the expansion of Christianity and its encounter with urban industrial society.

RELG 328.name: Medieval Philosophy
RELG 328.desc: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the fourteenth century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham.

RELG 331.name: Medieval Jewish History
RELG 331.desc: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

RELG 332.name: Modern Jewish History
RELG 332.desc: The political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present, with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, and social and cultural transformations.

RELG 335.name: Jewish Law
RELG 335.desc: History, sources, theoretical issues and current state of research about early Jewish legal traditions, focusing on close readings of classic primary texts in English translations.

RELG 341.name: Art and Architecture in the Islamic World
RELG 341.desc: A thematic study of visual arts, architecture, and objects from the Islamic world.

RELG 365.name: Daoist (Taoist) Religion and Its Philosophical Background
RELG 365.desc: A study of the Daoist religious traditions from their beginnings in the second century C.E. in cultural, intellectual and social contexts.

RELG 366.name: Buddhism in China
RELG 366.desc: History, thought and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century.

RELG 370.name: Concepts and Methods in the Study of Religion
RELG 370.desc: Required of Major and Honours students in their third year. Open to others by permission of the instructor.

RELG 385.name: Mystical Traditions: Jewish and Christian
RELG 385.desc: Methodology, textual study and scholarly analysis of selected texts from these traditions.

RELG 407.name: Topics in Early Judaism
RELG 407.desc: Judaism and Hellenism, the rise of the synagogue, Jewish sects, the development of Mishnah and Talmud.

RELG 408.name: Topics in Medieval Judaism
RELG 408.desc: The work of Maimonides and other Jewish philosophers, early developments in Jewish mysticism, the Jews as a minority culture in Islamic and Christian lands.

RELG 409.name: Topics in Modern Judaism
RELG 409.desc: The Jews in the ghetto culture, Hasidism, the Emancipation, Reform, Orthodox, and Conservative Movements.

RELG 420.name: Religion in Canada
RELG 420.desc: An examination of Canadian religious development with special reference to the separation of church and state, the rise of denominationalism and religious pluralism, secularization and ecumenicity, and the emergence of new religious movements.

RELG 452.name: Readings in Hindu Religious Texts
RELG 452.desc: Representative texts, in translation, of the Vedic, Epic, Puranic, Classical, Medieval, and Modern periods. Emphasis in the second term on texts of particular periods, movements, or sects, depending on the students' needs and interests. Those with the necessary preparation may read some texts in the original languages.

RELG 475.name: Topics in Religion
RELG 475.desc: Consult the course registration information each year for offered topics.

RELG 479.name: Directed Studies
RELG 479.desc: Reading and, where appropriate, other research on a topic arising in the discipline, arranged by agreement between the student and the instructor.

RELG 480.name: Women and Religion
RELG 480.desc: A study of the roles of women in the literature of one or more religious traditions.

RELG 485.name: Images of Eve
RELG 485.desc: The story of Adam and Eve, and its influence on the role and image of women in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

ECED 380.name: Selected Topics in Infant Development and Supported Child Development

ECED 405.name: Foundations of Curriculum and Instruction in Early Childhood Education

ECED 415.name: Supporting Learning in The Primary Years
ECED 415.desc: Designing environments, experiences, activities, instruction, and assessment to foster children's learning in the primary years (grades 1-3).
ECED 415.prer: ECED 405 or teaching experience or successful completion of the extended practicum.
preq: successful completion of the extended practicum

ECED 425.name: Advanced Studies in Early Childhood Education
ECED 425.prer: One of ECED 405, or an introductory level early childhood education course, or teaching experience, or successful completion of extended practicum.
preq: an introductory level early childhood education course

ECED 480.name: Selected Topics in Early Childhood Education

COHR 302.name: Critical Evaluation of Information, Evidence, and Arguments
COHR 302.desc: Strategies to critically evaluate information relevant to Human Resource Managers. This course will examine common errors in logic, decision biases, and cause and effect relationships.
COHR 302.prer: All of COMM 291, COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 307.name: Introduction to Organizational Consulting
COHR 307.desc: Frameworks from the social sciences useful for understanding organizational processes and how to apply these frameworks to particular organizational consulting challenges.
COHR 307.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 308.name: Labour Relations
COHR 308.desc: Integrated coverage of union-management relations including labour law, collective bargaining, and collective agreement administration.
COHR 308.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 310.name: Industrial Relations in an Era of Globalization
COHR 310.desc: Comprehensive examination of the Canadian industrial relations system, and its legal foundations, in the context of a global economy.
COHR 310.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 311.name: Organizational Analysis
COHR 311.desc: An analysis of organizational structures and intraorganizational processes; effects of organizational factors on individual behaviour.
COHR 311.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 403.name: Managing Diversity
COHR 403.desc: Explores the business and legal cases for diversity in the workplace. Examines how to effectively manage a diverse work force.
COHR 403.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 405.name: Managing the Family Business
COHR 405.desc: Managing and working in a family business presents unique challenges: family issues can conflict with business issues. This course examines governance structures and tools to manage the interface between the family and the business.
COHR 405.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 406.name: International Human Resource Management
COHR 406.desc: Application of human resource management practices to multinational enterprises. Comparative analysis of national human resource management systems.
COHR 406.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 407.name: Advanced Organizational Consulting
COHR 407.desc: Methods and techniques to diagnose and solve a broad range of organizational problems from the perspective of an organizational consultant.
COHR 407.prer: All of COMM 292, COHR 307 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 409.name: Creativity and Innovation
COHR 409.desc: Techniques and approaches to managing creativity and innovation in organizations.
COHR 409.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 410.name: Knowledge Management
COHR 410.desc: Techniques and approaches to managing knowledge and learning in organizations.
COHR 410.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 412.name: Advanced Topics in Organizational Behaviour
COHR 412.desc: Understanding, critiquing, and analyzing behaviour and social processes in organizations. This course focuses on provocative and current topics that could not be covered in depth in the introductory course.
COHR 412.prer: COMM 292 and one of COMM 203, COMM 392.

COHR 486.name: Special Topics in Organizational Behaviour and Human Resources

STAT 100.name: Statistical Thinking
STAT 100.desc: Explores the development and use of statistical thinking in the modern world. The aim is to develop statistical literacy and demonstrate applications of statistics in research and society. Students who obtain credit for any of STAT 306, 307, 308, 344 cannot in the same or later term gain credit for STAT 100. [3-0-1]

STAT 307.name: Statistics Laboratory I
STAT 307.desc: Implementing theory in applications. Problem based learning. Generation and analysis of case data. Modelling, computation and reporting. [0-4-0]

STAT 335.name: Statistics in Quality Assurance
STAT 335.desc: Philosophy of quality improvement and total quality control. Definitions of quality. Deming's principles, Ishikawa's tools, control charts, acceptance sampling, continuous improvement, quality design. Credit cannot be obtained for both STAT 335 and WOOD 335. [3-0-1]
STAT 335.prer: One of STAT 200, STAT 241, STAT 251, BIOL 300.

STAT 445.name: Introduction to Exploratory Data Analysis
STAT 445.desc: Methods for exploring and presenting the structure of data: one group of numbers, several groups, bivariate data, time series data and two-way tables. Data displays, outlier identification, transformations, resistant regression, several types of data smoothing, comparisons with standard statistical methods. [3-0-1]

STAT 447.name: Special Topics in Statistics
STAT 447.desc: Students should consult the Statistics Department for the particular topics offered in a given year.
STAT 447.prer: STAT 305. Permission of the instructor is required.
preq: STAT 305. Permission of the instructor is required

ASTU 204.name: Topics in Interdisciplinary Arts Studies
ASTU 204.desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in Arts studies.  For upcoming offerings including course descriptions and possible enrolment restrictions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule.

ASTU 210.name: Global Citizenship, Part 1: Introduction
ASTU 210.desc: Themes of global citizenship, sustainability, and civil society, and barriers and bridges to global thinking.

ASTU 211.name: Global Citizenship, Part 2: Community Service Learning and Capstone Conference

ASTU 400.name: Interdisciplinary Studies in Arts
ASTU 400.desc: For upper-division students in the Faculty of Arts. Topics announced annually.

ASTU 401.name: Special Topics in Arts Studies
ASTU 401.desc: Selected topics offered by a distinguished visitor to the campus. For upcoming offerings including course descriptions and possible enrolment restrictions, please see section information in the UBC course schedule.

DES 101.name: Introductory Workshop
DES 101.desc: Week long orientation to the School community, the City and the study of design one week prior to the start of Winter Session Term 1. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 101 or DES 101.

DES 110.name: Measured Architectural Drawing
DES 110.desc: Techniques applicable to analytic and technical drawing used in architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design with focus primarily on analog drawing techniques. Open to all UBC students regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 110 or DES 110.

DES 200.name: Design Thinking
DES 200.desc: Design thinking through the analysis of architecture, landscape architecture and urban design and through hands-on design projects. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will granted for only one of ENDS 231 or DES 200.

DES 201.name: Design Studio I - Context and Site
DES 201.desc: Design within the context of various analytical lenses including ecological, climatic, social, political, cultural and historical influences.

DES 202.name: Design Studio II - Form
DES 202.desc: Essential processes and methods for thinking in three-dimensional spatial terms.
DES 202.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  201.

DES 211.name: Design Media I
DES 211.desc: Techniques in architectural drawing, two-dimensional representation, three-dimensional representation and general visual literacy. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 320, ARCH 515 or DES 211.

DES 212.name: Design Media II
DES 212.desc: Advanced techniques in architectural representation and discourse in digital representation and digital making. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 437, ARCH 517 or DES 212.

DES 220.name: Architecture in Context: Vancouver and its Region
DES 220.desc: The unfolding architecture and urbanism of Metro Vancouver. Using Vancouver as a laboratory to examine the historical transformation of the built environment, and how this has affected particular activities, land uses, and social groups within the region. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 220 or DES 220.

DES 230.name: Sustainability by Design
DES 230.desc: Interactions between human and natural urban systems using local and international examples of successful sustainable community designs. This course is open to all UBC students, regardless of prior experience. Credit will be granted for only one of ENDS 221 or DES 230.

DES 231.name: Site Analysis and Planning
DES 231.desc: Analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Credit will be given for only one of DES 231, LARC 440, or LARC 540.

DES 232.name: Material Culture
DES 232.desc: An investigation of building materials and associated design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 232 or ARCH 411.

DES 301.name: Design Studio III - Building Scale Synthesis
DES 301.desc: Design at the architectural scale through the medium of program and site.
DES 301.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  202.

DES 302.name: Design Studio IV - Vancouver
DES 302.desc: Vancouver as a laboratory for design at the architectural and urban scale with a focused view into how design is implicated in the social, political, and environmental transformation of the city.
DES 302.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  301.

DES 321.name: Architectural History I
DES 321.desc: A global history of architecture pre-20th century. Credit will be granted for only one of  DES 321, ARCH 404 or ARCH 505.

DES 322.name: Architectural History II
DES 322.desc: A global history of architecture, 20th and 21st century. Credit will be granted for only one of DES 322, ARCH 405, or ARCH 505.

DES 323.name: Histories in Landscape Architecture
DES 323.desc: Landscapes from medieval times to the present studied synchronically across design elements as well as chronologically with the development of several key historical concepts.

DES 330.name: Structural Systems and Supports
DES 330.desc: Basic structural systems in the built world including wood, steel, concrete, composite systems and essential structural logics of soil retention systems and drainage.

DES 341.name: Co-operative Education I
DES 341.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Experiential Report required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES 350.name: Design Build
DES 350.desc: Direct hands-on confrontation with the realities of design and construction, engaging in both conventional and unconventional building processes.

DES 401.name: Design Studio V - Urban Systems Scale Synthesis
DES 401.desc: Relationships between communities and environment, urban infrastructure and ecological systems.

DES 402.name: Design Studio VI - Away
DES 402.desc: A design project engaged with an international context and site. Emphasis placed on mapping, interpretation of the international context as well as methods of construction, notions of program, and policies, regulations and codes that relate to the site.
DES 402.prer: A score of 60% or higher in DES  401.

DES 403.name: Senior Design Project
DES 403.desc: Final design project in the Honours Option with an independently conceived methodology allowing a student the opportunity to pursue his/her own set of interests and concerns.
DES 403.prer: A score of 80% or higher in DES  401.

DES 421.name: Design Theory
DES 421.desc: Introduction to a broad range of theories in architecture and design as they relate to the built environment.

DES 422.name: Urbanism by Design
DES 422.desc: A history of the planning, landscape architecture and urban design of cities, and of how ideas have influenced the design of the city.

DES 430.name: Environment, Urban Form, and Infrastructure
DES 430.desc: Relationships between, and integration of, the natural environment and the physical form, spatial structure, and infrastructure of livability of cities.

DES 442.name: Co-operative Education II
DES 442.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Career Development Report required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES 443.name: Co-operative Education III
DES 443.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Oral Presentation required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES 444.name: Co-operative Education IV
DES 444.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Oral Presentation required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Bachelor of Design and the Co-operative Education Program.

DES 445.name: Entrepreneurship and Ethics in Design
DES 445.desc: Core business skills, building on students' design capabilities to pursue ethical and sustainable design-based business goals.

GEOB 304.name: Synoptic Meteorology and Climatology
GEOB 304.desc: Analysis of meteorological fields, diagnostic analysis of synoptic weather systems, applications of synoptic meteorology. Requires participation in weekly weather map discussion. [2-2-0]

GEOB 308.name: Quaternary and Applied Geomorphology
GEOB 308.desc: Quaternary landscape development emphasizing the history of glaciation with special reference to western North America; applications of geomorphology in resource development and land management; interpretation of quaternary materials. Weekend field trips required. [3-2*-0]

GEOB 401.name: Urban Meteorology
GEOB 401.desc: The impact of urbanization upon atmospheric processes and climates. The energy and water balances of cities. Meteorological effects (urban heat island, precipitation modification, etc.) and their significance. Models of the urban atmosphere. [3-0-0]
GEOB 401.prer: One of GEOG 204, GEOB 204, GEOG 300, GEOB 300, AGRO 244, APBI 244.

GEOB 403.name: Catchment Hydrology
GEOB 403.desc: Hydrometeorology; runoff processes; streamwater chemistry in relation to runoff processes; effects of climate variations and land cover change on streamflow regimes; models of catchment hydrology. [3-0-0]
GEOB 403.prer: One of GEOB 200, GEOB 204 and one of GEOB 305, FRST 385 and one of STAT 200, FRST 231, BIOL 300.

GEOB 405.name: Fluvial Geomorphology
GEOB 405.desc: Introduction to open channel flow and sediment transport. River morphology and channel types. Palaeohydrology. The development of channel networks. [2-3-0]

GEOB 408.name: Snow and Ice Processes
GEOB 408.desc: Formation of snow and ice masses and their evolution including snowpacks, glaciers, and ice sheets. Relationships between snow, ice, and climate including glacier dynamics and avalanche forecasting. Weekend field trip. [3-0-0]
GEOB 408.prer: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 153, SCIE 001 and one of GEOB 305, GEOB 308.

GEOB 409.name: Self-Directed Field Studies in Physical Geography
GEOB 409.desc: Advanced research design, field sampling methods, instrumentation, surveying, mapping techniques, data analysis and management; self-directed fieldwork; 1 lecture per week during term and a multi-day field camp in April or May. [2-0-0]
GEOB 409.prer: GEOB 309. Third-year standing in Geographical Biogeosciences Major.
preq: GEOB 309. Third-year standing in Geographical Biogeosciences Major

GEOB 448.name: Directed Studies in Geographical Sciences
GEOB 448.desc: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required. Credit will be given for only one of GEOB 448 and GEOG 448.

GEOB 449.name: Undergraduate Thesis
GEOB 449.desc: Original research on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a faculty member. Open to 4th year students in Geographical Biogeosciences with appropriate background courses related to the research topic, and permission of the directing faculty member. The 3-credit option is only available to students who complete GEOB 449 in tandem with GEOB 409.

GEOB 490.name: Student Directed Seminar in Geographical Sciences
GEOB 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in physical geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars." This course carries science credit. Credit will not be granted for both GEOG 442 and GEOB 490.

POLS 200.name: Beginner's Polish
POLS 200.desc: Introduction to contemporary Polish. Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

POLS 345.name: Introduction to Twentieth-Century Polish Literature
POLS 345.desc: Readings and discussion of selected works of representative writers.

POLS 424.name: Polish Literature and Film in Translation
POLS 424.desc: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

GRS 397.name: Regional Directed Field Studies
GRS 397.desc: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

GRS 497.name: Regional Directed Field Studies
GRS 497.desc: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

TIBT 100.name: Introduction to Tibetan I
TIBT 100.desc: Concepts, grammar, syntax of spoken and written Tibetan for beginners. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

TIBT 101.name: Introduction to Tibetan II
TIBT 101.desc: Focus on grammar, syntax, and structures to improve comprehension and communication skills. Also covers aspects of Tibetan worldview.

FRE 402.name: Market Research and Analysis in Agri-Food Industries
FRE 402.desc: Macro and micro aspects of agri-food market and industry analysis, market strategy, consumer behaviour, secondary market research, quantitative and qualitative market research. [3-0-0]

MECH 356.name: Machine Components
MECH 356.desc: Machines used for wood products manufacturing, design, maintenance, purchasing. Selection of components including drives, bearings, brakes, clutches, fasteners, springs. Not open to students in the Faculty of Applied Science.

MECH 405.name: Acoustics and Noise Control
MECH 405.desc: Wave properties; the decibel; hearing, deafness, and hearing protectors; noise criteria and regulations; sound measurement; sound-source characterization; real noise sources, sound propagation outdoors, in ducts and pipes and in rooms; sound transmission; silencers; sound absorbers; partitions.

MECH 410.name: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering
MECH 410.desc: Lectures and readings on specialized topics of current interest in Mechanical Engineering.

MECH 422.name: Introduction to Microelectromechanical Systems
MECH 422.desc: Fundamentals of MEMS (MicroElectroMechanical Systems). Microfabrication of MEMS with solid-state technology. LIGA and micro injection molding. Physics of MEMS. Operational principles of various MEMS devices.
MECH 422.prer: One of ELEC 302, EECE 363, ELEC 344, EECE 365 and all of MECH 360, MECH 463.

MECH 430.name: Engineering Data Analysis
MECH 430.desc: The use of probability and statistical methods for engineering applications.

MECH 475.name: Heat Transfer II
MECH 475.desc: Unsteady heat conduction. Radiative heat exchange between gray surfaces. Gas radiation. Free convection from plates and cylinders. Boiling. Mass transfer. Simultaneous heat and mass transfer. Heat exchanger design. Boilers, condensers, and cooling towers. Building heat transfer.

MECH 492.name: CAD/CAM
MECH 492.desc: Introduction to computer assisted design and manufacturing with a focus on the fundamental issues of geometry and machine tools including an understanding of standard computer tools. Applications to secondary wood products manufacturing. Not open to students in the Faculty of Applied Science.

ARBC 420.name: Supervised Study in Classical Arabic
ARBC 420.desc: Religious and literary Arabic texts pertaining to the early and medieval Islamic world.

ITST 333.name: Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
ITST 333.desc: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age.

ITST 414.name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages in Translation
ITST 414.desc: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITAL 404.

ITST 415.name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance in Translation
ITST 415.desc: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Precludes credit for ITAL 405.

ITST 416.name: Classics of Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITST 416.desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 416 or ITAL 406.

ITST 417.name: Classics of Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITST 417.desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITST 417 or ITAL 407.

ITST 418.name: Topics in Nineteenth-century Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
ITST 418.desc: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 408.

ITST 421.name: Special Topics in Italian Studies
ITST 421.desc: Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

ITST 495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Italian Literature and Culture
ITST 495.desc: Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 495 or ITST 495.

CPSC 101.name: Connecting with Computer Science
CPSC 101.desc: Fundamentals of computer science and their connections with the arts, psychology, and biology.  Historical, cultural, and gender  perspectives of important contributions to the field will be discussed.  No prior computing background required. [3-3-0]

CPSC 189.name: Systematic Program Design in Python
CPSC 189.desc: Systematic design of small programs using the Python programming language. [1-1-0]
CPSC 189.prer: CPSC 110 and one of Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

CPSC 260.name: Data Structures and Algorithms for Computer Engineers
CPSC 260.desc: Design and analysis of object-oriented programs, emphasizing data structures. Topics include: classes, interfaces, fundamental data structures, algorithmic complexity, basic debugging and testing techniques. [3-1-0]

CPSC 402.name: Numerical Linear Algebra
CPSC 402.desc: Investigation of the practical techniques of computational linear algebra. Orthogonal transformations and their application to the solution of linear equations, the eigenproblem, and linear least squares. Complete solution of the symmetric eigenproblem, including bisection and the QR method. Refinements of these techniques for sparse matrices. [3-0-0]

CPSC 417.name: Computer Networking
CPSC 417.desc: Network protocols and architecture including internetworking, the Internet, layered communication protocols, routing, flow and congestion control, network performance, wired and wireless data communication. [3-0]
CPSC 417.prer: All of CPSC 313, CPSC 317 and one of STAT 200, STAT 241.

CPSC 425.name: Computer Vision
CPSC 425.desc: Introduction to the processing and interpretation of images.  Image sensing, sampling, and filtering.  Algorithms for colour analysis, texture description, stereo imaging, motion interpretation, 3D shape recovery, and recognition. [3-0-0]
CPSC 425.prer: All of MATH 200, MATH 221 and either (a) CPSC 221 or (b) all of CPSC 260, EECE 320.

CPSC 426.name: Computer Animation
CPSC 426.desc: Motion in computer graphics for characters and their environments. Keyframing, inverse kinematics, particle systems, rigid body dynamics, contact and collision, controller-based active motion, motion capture. [3-0-0]

CPSC 430.name: Computers and Society
CPSC 430.desc: Impact of computer technology on society; historical perspectives; social and economic consequences of large-scale information processing systems and automatic control; legal and ethical problems in computer applications. Computers and the individual: machine versus human capabilities, fact and fancy; problematic interface between man and machine. [3-0-0]
CPSC 430.prer: 3 credits of Computer Science and at least third-year standing.

CPSC 436.name: Topics in Computer Science
CPSC 436.desc: Selected topics in a specific area within Computer Science. May be taken more than once for credit with permission of the department.
CPSC 436.prer: Third-year standing in a Computer Science or Computer Engineering specialization, and permission of the department.
preq: Third-year standing in a Computer Science

CPSC 448.name: Directed Studies in Computer Science
CPSC 448.desc: Open ordinarily to students in Computer Science with at least a 72% average and the permission of the head of the department or designate. The course may consist of supervised reading, participation in a seminar, and one or more programming projects.

HIST 107.name: Global Indigenous Histories
HIST 107.desc: An introduction to the experiences of Indigenous peoples and the nature of colonialisms around the world since 1500, and an introduction to historical practices and perspectives.

HIST 108.name: Global History of Capitalism
HIST 108.desc: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization.  An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era.

HIST 109.name: Cultural Histories of Media: From Writing to Tweeting
HIST 109.desc: The history of different forms of media in global perspective, with particular attention to audiovisual electronic media.

HIST 200.name: Asia and the World
HIST 200.desc: The political, economic, social, cultural, and human interactions between Asia and the world, inter-Asian relations, Asian diaspora, colonialism, war and the social consequences of conflict, decolonization, industrial growth, and developing world issues.

HIST 202.name: Gateway to the Middle Ages
HIST 202.desc: Problems and themes of medieval European History through the close study of the people and cultures that produced them.

HIST 205.name: Introduction to Historical Archaeology
HIST 205.desc: An introduction to the study of medieval and modern material culture, with special emphasis on Canada, using archaeological evidence to illustrate the principles, aims, and techniques of historical archaeology and related disciplines.

HIST 220.name: History of Europe
HIST 220.desc: Selected themes and historical approaches in European history; may include Europe's history of religious conflict, state formation, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, revolution, total war, globalization, genocide, or environmental change.

HIST 237.name: History of the United States
HIST 237.desc: Survey from colonial period to present examining political system, slavery, Civil War, race relations and civil rights, westward expansion, industrialization, feminism, expanding international presence, Cold War, and modern culture.

HIST 250.name: Latin American History
HIST 250.desc: Exploring themes of colonialism, indigenous life, national imaginaries, dictatorships and transitions to democracy through different forms of telling Latin American history. Includes epistolary writing, maps, eyewitness accounts, chronicles, actions, novels, films, built environment and city plans, testimonios, and plays.

HIST 252.name: Modern Caribbean History
HIST 252.desc: A survey of social, cultural and political history of Anglophone, Francophone and Spanish Caribbean from the Haitian Revolution to the present.

HIST 259.name: Science, Medicine, and Technology in the Ancient and Medieval Worlds
HIST 259.desc: The history of science, medicine, and technology, emphasizing networks, exchanges, and encounters in a global context.

HIST 270.name: China in World History
HIST 270.desc: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

HIST 273.name: History of India
HIST 273.desc: Societies, cultures, and politics of the Indian subcontinent from its ancient civilizations to the formation of the modern nation-states of South Asia.

HIST 303.name: History of the Canadian West
HIST 303.desc: Selected topics in the history of the Canadian West with an emphasis on the prairie west: the Indian and the fur trade, Louis Riel, prairie settlement, and western social and political protest.

HIST 304.name: Researching Local History from the Ground Up
HIST 304.desc: Sources and methods for reconstructing local history that can be used by Social Studies teachers in B.C. The aim is to develop an appreciation of the formative processes and past experiences that created one's familiar community.

HIST 305.name: British Columbia
HIST 305.desc: Selected themes in the history of the region, primarily during the post-confederation years. Topics will emphasize changes in the economic, social, and institutional structures of the province. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 305 or 404, if 404 was taken before 2007W.

HIST 306.name: History of France, 1461-1715
HIST 306.desc: The development of absolute monarchy in France, with emphasis on change and conflict in French society; spiritual and intellectual "crisis"; the place of France in the emerging European state system; and opposition to the monarchy.

HIST 307.name: French North America to 1803
HIST 307.desc: Historical background for understanding the French-speaking peoples of North America: Acadians, Franco-Quebecois, French-Canadians and Cajuns. It also deals extensively with French-Indigenous relations and introduces the student to the historiography of French North America.

HIST 308.name: Quebec from the End of the 18th Century to the Present
HIST 308.desc: Relations between the English and the Canadians prior to the Rebellions of 1837-38, the emergence of French Canadian nationalism after 1840, the impact of State formation and  industrialization in Quebec, the Quiet Revolution, and the independence movement.

HIST 309.name: Topics in Sub-Saharan African History
HIST 309.desc: Examination of a major theme in the history of Sub-Saharan Africa.

HIST 310.name: The British Empire to 1850
HIST 310.desc: Rise of the British imperial system within a global context from its beginnings to 1850. Focuses on economic and social themes with emphasis on settlements in the southern hemisphere as well as the West Indies.

HIST 314.name: Early Modern Britain
HIST 314.desc: The social, economic, political, religious, cultural, and intellectual history of Britain between the Reformation and the Industrial Revolution, emphasizing the rise of modern industrial society.

HIST 315.name: Britain 1750-1850
HIST 315.desc: Emergence of the world's first industrial society, and the political, economic, and cultural struggles accompanying this transformation.

HIST 317.name: Britain, 1850-1918
HIST 317.desc: Britain from the Great Exhibition to the Great War: the creation of a mass electorate, the "New Imperialism," the "New Woman," and the ways that class, race, gender, and sexuality shaped modern Britain.

HIST 327.name: Colonial America: Encounter and Settlement, 1607 - 1763
HIST 327.desc: Encounters between European, African, and Indigenous North American peoples as well as the history of the colonies within the Atlantic world, from the late sixteenth century to the eve of the American Revolution.

HIST 328.name: Rebels in America: Revolution to Civil War, 1763 - 1865
HIST 328.desc: Issues in U.S. history from the colonial era through the Civil War,  including the causes of the American Revolution; slavery; aboriginal peoples; labour, gender, and industrialization.

HIST 329.name: Canadian Lives: A Social and Cultural History
HIST 329.desc: A survey of Canadian society from colonial times to post-industrialization through the lenses of race, class, and gender. Topics include colonialism, slavery, immigration, religion, industrialization, citizenship, sexuality, social movements, and moral regulation.

HIST 338.name: American Modernity: The United States, 1890-1945
HIST 338.desc: U.S. emergence as an industrial powerhouse and, eventually, a global superpower; responses to industrial society, meaning of "modern times," economic upheaval and social change, U.S.'s role as a world power, and politics of race, ethnicity, and gender.

HIST 341.name: Medieval Jewish History
HIST 341.desc: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

HIST 342.name: Modern Jewish History
HIST 342.desc: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the beginning of the sixteenth century to the present with special emphasis on changing attitudes to Jews and Judaism, social and cultural transformations.

HIST 344.name: Ancien Regime France
HIST 344.desc: The political, social and/or cultural history of early modern France before the Revolution.  Topics may include: the changing significance of the monarchy; the Enlightenment critique of the Catholic Church and religion; the 'pre-revolution'. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 344 or 406.

HIST 346.name: France Since the Revolution
HIST 346.desc: The political, social and/or cultural history of France after the Revolution, possibly including nation building and regional identities; the Dreyfus affair; France as a colonial power; decolonization; the two world wars; the EU.

HIST 347.name: Medieval and Imperial Russian History, 998 to 1800
HIST 347.desc: Russian politics, society, culture, and empire, beginning with the medieval period extending through the era of Peter the Great's modernization efforts and the Enlightenment.

HIST 349.name: Imperial Russian History, 1800 to 1917
HIST 349.desc: History of Russia from the time of Catherine the Great to the Russian Revolution with particular focus on social and cultural history.

HIST 351.name: East Central Europe in the 19th and 20th Centuries
HIST 351.desc: Covers the region between Germany and Russia as well as Southeast Europe. Emphasis on comparisons with Western Europe and features that make the area significant to Europe as a whole.

HIST 358.name: State and Society in 20th century Cuba
HIST 358.desc: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life.

HIST 359.name: A History of Brazil: From Colony to Nation
HIST 359.desc: The cultural and political history of Brazil, from the earliest arrival of the Portuguese to Brazil’s emergence as one of the economic powerhouses of the twenty-first century.

HIST 379.name: History of Later Imperial China
HIST 379.desc: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understant the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

HIST 380.name: The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution
HIST 380.desc: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.

HIST 381.name: Imperialism and Nationalism in Southeast Asia
HIST 381.desc: The history of European imperial rule, the forms of resistance to it, and the formation of nationalist movements in Southeast Asia. The countries studied include Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Burma, and Thailand.

HIST 386.name: Korea Since 1860
HIST 386.desc: An examination of the political, economic, social, and cultural transformations of Korea since the late nineteenth century. Topics include the end of the Choson Dynasty, the history of Japanese colonial rule, the Korean war, and the two Koreas in the international system.

HIST 389.name: The Sikhs: History, Religion and Society
HIST 389.desc: A historical study of the social and cultural forces that helped shape Sikh religious beliefs and ritual practices over the past four centuries. In dealing with the evolution of Sikh identity, attention will be given to Sikh ideals, social organization, religious institutions and sacred literature.

HIST 390.name: Topics in History
