HIST 390.desc: Small-group instruction in a seminar format on a variety of historical topics. Check with the department for course offerings. This course does not satisfy the History Majors Research Seminar (490) requirement.

HIST 392.name: Scientific Revolution: Circulation of Knowledge in the Early Modern World
HIST 392.desc: The profound transformation of knowledge about the world in the context of the first global encounter of civilizations between 1450 and 1800. Explores the foundations for modern science.

HIST 395.name: The Nuclear Century: Scientists, Atoms, and the World Order Since 1900
HIST 395.desc: Science and the military-industrial complex; quantum and relativistic revolutions in physics; nuclear energy and weapons of mass destruction; international tensions, environmental damage, and global perils.

HIST 396.name: Environmental History of North America
HIST 396.desc: Overview of land use and environmental change in Canada and the United States; examines ideas and practices that shaped indigenous and non-indigenous resource exploitation, management, and activism to the end of the twentieth century.

HIST 398.name: The History of Modern Medicine
HIST 398.desc: The history of health and disease in the modern world, focusing in particular on the emergence and history of modern biomedicine.

HIST 399.name: Theory and Practice of History
HIST 399.desc: Approaches to the history of historical inquiry, with particular attention to theoretical and methodo-logical debates among historians. Recommended for history majors. Not open to Department of History honours students.

HIST 401.name: Seafaring in the Age of Sail
HIST 401.desc: Humankind’s encounter with its ocean frontier through exploration, trading, fishing, whaling, piracy, and naval warfare from 1400 to 1850.

HIST 402.name: Problems in International Relations
HIST 402.desc: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

HIST 403.name: Seminar in the History of International Relations
HIST 403.desc: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Priority for registration will be given to fourth-year majors in the International Relations and History programs.

HIST 411.name: Development of Canadian External Policy Since Confederation
HIST 411.desc: Examines the history of Canada's external relations since Confederation with particular emphasis on Canada's changing international status and role in the twentieth century.

HIST 414.name: Constitutions in Canadian History: From Pre-Contact to the Charter of Rights
HIST 414.desc: European precedents, Colonial self-government, Canadian Confederation, and issues such as gay rights, abortion, and First Nations land rights.

HIST 419.name: Crime and Punishment in Canadian History
HIST 419.desc: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada.

HIST 420.name: Topics in Canadian History
HIST 420.desc: May include immigration, French-English relations, the growth of the state, health and welfare, or the family.

HIST 423.name: Economic and Business History of Modern Japan
HIST 423.desc: From 1800 to the present; emphasis on the business strategies of Japan's largest companies; attention also to broader economic topics such as international trade, government policy, social impact of industry, business and politics, labour, and post-1971 multi-nationalism.

HIST 424.name: Economic History of Pre-Modern Europe
HIST 424.desc: This course traces the roots of the “Rise of the West” through long-term economic, social, and political developments in European and global history.

HIST 435.name: Gender and Sexuality in the Modern U. S
HIST 435.desc: Gender roles and gender relations from the Gilded Age to the present day. Topics include political movements such as suffrage and feminism; labour and recreation; marriage, family, and children's socialization; sexuality; and popular culture.

HIST 436.name: European Social History
HIST 436.desc: A study of the changes in economic activity, social structure, family life, religious attitudes, and popular behaviour which accompanied the transformation of Europe from a pre-industrial to an industrial society.

HIST 439.name: Politics and Culture in Fin-de-Siècle Europe (1890-1914)
HIST 439.desc: Explores relationships between politics, culture, and social change in Europe. Topics include the changing role of intellectuals: literary aestheticism, painting, design and the city, origins of psychology.

HIST 440.name: History of Health in the Modern West
HIST 440.desc: Changing conditions of health in Europe and North America from the beginning of the modern mortality decline to the recent past.

HIST 443.name: History of North American Children and Youth
HIST 443.desc: Children’s history from settler days to the present. Topics include education, work and play, ideologies of childhood and adolescence, children’s material and popular culture, and differences of identity based on region, class, race, and gender.

HIST 447.name: Selected Topics in United States History
HIST 447.desc: Examines in depth a significant period, theme, or topic in the history of the United States. Possible subjects include The West, the Great Depression, the Sixties, and Class, Race, and Gender.

HIST 450.name: Selected Topics in Latin American History
HIST 450.desc: A study in depth of one major topic (such as the Cuban Revolution or Peronismo) in the recent history of Latin America.

HIST 451.name: Family and Community in Latin America
HIST 451.desc: The role of family and community from the colonial period to the present. Emergence of the nation state as it affected community and family structures.

HIST 453.name: Class and Culture in Latin America
HIST 453.desc: The relationship between culture and class formation from the late colonial period to the present.

HIST 456.name: Race in the Americas
HIST 456.desc: Legacies of African, European, and Asian migrations, and colonial encounters with indigenous peoples in the Americas. Includes the creation of racial categories, the making of transnational and transracial families, and the emergence of race-based social and cultural movements.

HIST 460.name: Revolution and Resistance in the Third World
HIST 460.desc: Revolutionary movements in the Third World during the second half of the twentieth century; the radicalisation of anticolonial nationalism; the impact of anticolonial radicalism in the developed world; the decline of Marxism as a revolutionary inspiration.

HIST 464.name: First Contacts in the Pacific
HIST 464.desc: An interdisciplinary history of early European contact with the Indigenous peoples of the northwest coast of  North America and the Pacific Islands.

HIST 466.name: Topics in Indigenous History of Canada
HIST 466.desc: Selected interdisciplinary topics in the history of Canada's Indigenous peoples after European contact, including historical demography, economic interdependency, missionary encounters, gender relations, and interactions with colonial powers and the nation state. Recommended: HIST 302 or other background in the field.

HIST 467.name: Topics in Indigenous History of the United States
HIST 467.desc: Interdisciplinary topics in the history of the United States' Indigenous peoples from before European contact. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended.

HIST 468.name: Topics in Comparative Indigenous History
HIST 468.desc: Comparative  interdisciplinary analysis of selected topics in Indigenous history in North America and beyong. HIST 302 or other background in the field is recommended.

HIST 470.name: Seminar in Medieval History
HIST 470.desc: Annually changing topics of medieval studies with special attention to research methods on primary sources.

HIST 473.name: Women in the Middle Ages
HIST 473.desc: A study of women's roles in the family, society, law, religion, the economy, and literature from about 500 to 1500 CE.

HIST 474.name: Ideas and Religions of the Middle Ages
HIST 474.desc: A survey and exploration of the development, interpenetration, conflict, and transformation of various intellectual and religious traditions during the Middle Ages.

HIST 476.name: Law and Society in the Middle Ages
HIST 476.desc: The history of law in the Middle Ages, including English common law, civil (Roman) law, and canon law, and how changes in both medieval law and society affected the development of each.

HIST 477.name: Constitutional History of Medieval Europe
HIST 477.desc: The evolution of political institutions, the emergence of royal governments as well as representative assemblies and urban republic and conflicts within and among them leading to the emergence of modern structures.

HIST 478.name: Medieval Portraits and Personalities
HIST 478.desc: The lives of leading and controversial figures in the Middle Ages and the means by which they have portrayed themselves and been portrayed by others.

HIST 479.name: Cultural History of Imperial China
HIST 479.desc: An in-depth examination of the construction, transmission, and transformation of Chinese culture(s) prior to 1800. Credit will be granted for only one of HIST 479 or ASIA 440.

HIST 480.name: Social History of Modern China
HIST 480.desc: Changes and continuities in Chinese society and culture from the late imperial period to the present; rural and urban life, social stratification, social movements and ideology, family and community, popular beliefs and cultural values.

HIST 481.name: Education and Society in Modern China
HIST 481.desc: The relationship between education and society in China since 1600; classical learning and the civil service examination system; popular literacy; sino-foreign interactions in education; education and gender; nationalism and education; the education revolution in China after 1949.

HIST 485.name: Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver
HIST 485.desc: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities.

HIST 487.name: History of Alternative and Complementary Medicine: Acupuncture to Yoga
HIST 487.desc: Alternative and complementary healing in history, including Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), yoga, meditation, and alternative drug therapies. Specific themes may vary from year to year.

HIST 490.name: Seminar for Majors in History
HIST 490.desc: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

HIST 491.name: Science and the Enlightenment
HIST 491.desc: Examines the relationship between science and society in the long eighteenth century. Topics include empiricism, classification, academies, print culture, and voyages of exploration.

HIST 493.name: History and Social Relations of Modern Sciences
HIST 493.desc: Science and society in the 19th to 21st Centuries. [3-0-0]

HIST 494.name: Machines, Media, and Modernity: Frankenstein to Cinema
HIST 494.desc: The cultural contexts and consequences of science and nineteenth century technology. European and North American developments.

HIST 495.name: Evolution and the Sciences of Mind, Brain, and Behaviour
HIST 495.desc: Examines how Darwin's theory of evolution changed the investigation of human nature. Questions will be historical and scientific, but will also concern the social, ethical, and existential stakes raised by the human mind as a product of evolution.

EDCP 302.name: Art - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 302.prer: A concentration in art or permission of the Head.

EDCP 316.name: Contemporary Methods of Instruction in Ear Training, Music Reading, and Musicianship I

EDCP 317.name: Contemporary Methods of Instruction in Ear Training, Music Reading, and Musicianship II

EDCP 318.name: Canadian Music in the Classroom: Elementary/Secondary

EDCP 322.name: Physical Education - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 322.prer: A completed concentration in physical education or permission of the head.
preq: A completed concentration in physical education

EDCP 332.name: Social Studies - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 341.name: Mathematics across the Curriculum: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 342.name: Mathematics - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy
EDCP 342.prer: A completed concentration in mathematics or permission of the Head.

EDCP 350.name: Biological Sciences - Elementary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EDCP 352.name: General Science - Secondary: Curriculum and Pedagogy

EPSE 171.name: Education in the Adolescent Years
EPSE 171.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EPSE 271.name: Teaching Adolescents with Special Learning Needs
EPSE 271.desc: For Dadaab, Kenya teacher education students.

EPSE 306.name: Education during the Adolescent Years
EPSE 306.desc: Developmental characteristics of persons from pre-school age through adulthood. Physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional growth of both normal and exceptional children in grades 8-12. The teacher's role in assisting such students to deal with major developmental issues and problems.  Pass/Fail.

EPSE 307.name: Applying Developmental Theories in the Classroom

EPSE 310.name: Assessment and Learning in the Classroom

EPSE 313.name: Educational Application of Developmental Theories
EPSE 313.desc: Theories of human development; physical, social, cognitive, moral, and emotional developmental characteristics from infancy to adolescence; implications for educational practice with students of different age and developmental status during the elementary school years.  Pass/Fail.

EPSE 314.name: Introduction to the Education of the Visually Impaired
EPSE 314.desc: An introductory course reviewing the identification and education of blind and partially sighted children. Designed to aid teachers to accommodate visually impaired children in the regular class setting. [3-0]

EPSE 315.name: Language Disorders of Exceptional Children
EPSE 315.desc: The course deals with severe language disabilities in children. Emphasis is placed on theories of language acquisition as applied to assessment. [3-0]

EPSE 342.name: Field Experiences with Individual Atypical Children
EPSE 342.desc: Supervised experience working with several atypical children in a community setting. Diagnosing needs, planning programs and integrating instruction and materials on an individual basis. [1-9]
EPSE 342.prer: Permission of the department is required.
preq: Permission of the department is required

EPSE 344.name: Programming in Special Education: Developing Perspective
EPSE 344.desc: An examination of the range of educational methodologies and teaching procedures and a discussion of their implications for the establishment of programs useful in working with exceptional children. The course comprises a practical examination and a detailed comparison of the major special educational methodologies. [3-1]

EPSE 390.name: Special Topics
EPSE 390.desc: A study of innovative practices, ideas, and theories in special education. The specific topics may change yearly to reflect changing priorities and interests in special education, and the specific interest and competencies of visiting and regular faculty. [3-0]
EPSE 390.prer: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. Permission of the instructor is required.
preq: EPSE 317. Permission of the instructor is required

EPSE 399.name: Education and Culture in the Deaf Community
EPSE 399.desc: Designed for students intending to work with deaf persons.

EPSE 404.name: Principles of Applied Behaviour Analysis
EPSE 404.desc: Credit will be given for only one of EPSE 404 or 405. [3-0-0]
EPSE 404.prer: One of EPSE 312, EPSE 317. Or permission of instructor.

EPSE 410.name: Assistive Technologies in Special Education
EPSE 410.desc: The use of microcomputers, adaptive technology, and software across age levels and areas of exceptionality in special education and health care settings. [2-1]

EPSE 415.name: Technology for the Visually Impaired
EPSE 415.desc: Preparation of teachers to work with a variety of technological devices designed for students who are blind or visually impaired, e.g., computers, electronic reading devices, and closed circuit television. This course is restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children. [2-2]

EPSE 425.name: Provisions in the Education of the Visually Handicapped
EPSE 425.desc: Provisions, procedures and methodology in the teaching of specific curriculum for the blind and visually impaired. Life skills and adjustment to blindness. This course is restricted to students in a program of Education of Visually Impaired Children. [3-0]

EPSE 426.name: Principles of Teaching the Hearing Impaired
EPSE 426.desc: An introductory course reviewing methods of teaching, administration, and organization of the educational program for the hearing impaired. Pre or corequisite: EPSE 312 or 317. [3-0]
EPSE 426.prer: EPSE 312. May be taken as a corequisite.
preq: EPSE 312. May be taken as a corequisite

EPSE 455.name: Introduction to Orientation and Mobility for the Blind
EPSE 455.desc: Understanding the process of teaching independent travel to blind students, including orientation and mobility skills in school. Restricted to students enrolled in a program for Education of Visually Impaired Children or those who hold the Diploma or the equivalent. [2-2]

EPSE 461.name: Educational Diagnosis and Remedial Instruction
EPSE 461.desc: Interpretation of informal and standardized test scores in educational diagnosis; estimates of actual and optimum levels of individual achievement; individual differences as factors affecting performance; methods of encouraging the optimum achievement of individuals; methods and practice materials for remedial teaching.

EPSE 462.name: Human Development in Education
EPSE 462.desc: Investigates selected concepts of developmental theory in terms of their influence upon instructional practice. Particular emphasis is placed on social and intellectual development.

EPSE 484.name: Nonparametric and Related Statistics
EPSE 484.desc: Distribution-free statistical techniques for analysis of ranked data, and analysis of discrete observations. [3-0]

UFOR 449.name: Directed Studies in Urban Forestry
UFOR 449.desc: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry out directed studies on a specific topic/problems in Urban Forestry and related greenspace planning, management, or governance.

ENGL 009.name: Preparation for University Writing
ENGL 009.desc: Practice-based course in communication skills. Develops university-level skills in composition, critical analysis, grammar, and documentation.  Can be taken to fulfill the prerequisite for UBC Okanagan first-year ENGL courses. Cannot be taken after successful completion of any first-year ENGL course.  Cannot be counted for credit toward the B.A., B.A.Sc., B.Ed., B.F.A., B.H.K., B.Mgt., B.M.S., B.Sc., or B.S.N. degrees. Pass/ Fail. [3-1-0]

ENGL 121.name: Introduction to Literary Theory
ENGL 121.desc: Enriched study of various theories of literature. Open to students with a BC-equivalent mark of A in English 12 or B+ in English Literature 12. Essays are required.

ENGL 228.name: Topics in Literary and/or Cultural Studies
ENGL 228.desc: Current research interests in English studies.
ENGL 228.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 229.name: Topics in the Study of Language and/or Rhetoric
ENGL 229.desc: For an up to date listing of available topics, please see the English Department (http://english.ubc.ca/undergraduate/undergraduate-courses/2016-winter-session/ ).
ENGL 229.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of classes or students will be withdrawn). One of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 and 3 credits of 100-level English, or (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.
preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

preq: 6 credits of ASTU 100 OR 3 credits of ASTU 100

ENGL 302.name: Advanced Practical Writing
ENGL 302.desc: Library research in the student's professional field; the writing of articles and research papers; detailed preparation of term or graduating essays required in a number of departments and faculties. Attention will be given to appropriate style. Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
ENGL 302.prer: ENGL 301. Permission of the course chair is also acceptable.
preq: ENGL 301. Permission of the course chair is also acceptable

ENGL 303.name: Intermediate Composition
ENGL 303.desc: Study of the principles and extensive practice in the writing of effective prose, from arrangement and punctuation to various stylistic strategies. May be taken in the second year. Not for credit towards the English Major or Minor.
ENGL 303.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 304.name: Advanced Composition
ENGL 304.desc: Special emphasis on rhetoric, with a focus on audience, authorial voice, and range of style.
ENGL 304.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 307.name: Studies in Rhetoric
ENGL 307.desc: Topics in rhetorical theories and their application.

ENGL 308.name: Rhetorical Criticism
ENGL 308.desc: A study of literary texts from a rhetorical perspective.

ENGL 312.name: Discourse and Society
ENGL 312.desc: Introduction to theories of language and culture, and to techniques for analysing discourses in their social contexts.

ENGL 322.name: Stylistics
ENGL 322.desc: Application of linguistic theory and method to stylistic analysis.

ENGL 323.name: Varieties of English
ENGL 323.desc: Study of geographical, social, and/or urban dialects of English.

ENGL 326.name: Studies in the English Language
ENGL 326.desc: Topics in the history or structure of the English language.

ENGL 330.name: The Structure of Modern English: Sounds and Words
ENGL 330.desc: An introduction to phonology, morphology, and lexical semantics.

Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 472.name: American Studies
ENGL 472.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 472.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 474.name: Studies in Contemporary Literature
ENGL 474.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 474.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 476.name: Indigenous Studies
ENGL 476.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 476.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ENGL 478.name: Post-colonial Studies
ENGL 478.desc: Please see the Department website for further information on topics offered in the current session.
ENGL 478.prer: (Pre-requisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn). Third year standing and, one of (a) 6 credits of 100-level English; or, (b) WRDS 150 or ASTU 150 plus 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (c) 6 credits of ASTU 100 or 3 credits of ASTU 100 and 3 credits of 100-level English; or, (d) ARTS 001.

ISCI 322.name: Science of Measurement and Instrumentation
ISCI 322.desc: Interactive course integrating diverse aspects of science: semi-quantitative overview of physical principles underlying modern measurement technology; philosophy of measurement; accuracy and limits to measurement, and resultant scientific, sociological and economic consequences. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
ISCI 322.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 330.name: Topics in Integrated Sciences
ISCI 330.desc: Interactive examination of a theme common to all areas of science. Themes will change from year to year. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [3-0-0]
ISCI 330.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 344.name: Theory and Practice of Games in Economics and Evolution
ISCI 344.desc: Exploration of human and animal interactions: integrating evolutionary and economic perspectives to investigate individual and social behaviour.  Credit will be given for only one of ECON 221 or ISCI 344. [3-0-0]

ISCI 345.name: Integrative Bioinformatics
ISCI 345.desc: Storage and processing of information in biological systems. Computational methods for recovering and interpreting stored genetic information. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program. [2-0-2]
ISCI 345.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science

ISCI 448.name: Directed Studies
ISCI 448.desc: Permission of the Director is required.

SPAN 280.name: Revolution! (in English)
SPAN 280.desc: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings.

SPAN 303.name: Conversational Spanish for Advanced Speakers
SPAN 303.desc: Expands the comprehension and communicative skills of upper-level students and heritage speakers through  topics drawn from Hispanic culture and current events.
SPAN 303.prer: One of SPAN 207, SPAN 302. Or placement test for heritage speakers.
preq: SPAN 302. Or placement test for heritage speakers

SPAN 308.name: Spanish for Business
SPAN 308.desc: Language of commerce, finance, marketing, and economics. Competence in business practices of the Hispanic world.

SPAN 309.name: Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
SPAN 309.desc: Language of international commerce through real world business practices in the Hispanic world; key issues concerning business practices, engaging with real-world materials, and interacting with professionals specializing in trade with the Hispanic world.

SPAN 312.name: Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature (in English)
SPAN 312.desc: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation.

SPAN 322.name: Dependency and Revolution in Latin American History and Culture
SPAN 322.desc: Continuities and changes in the Americas from before Columbus to the present. Includes the first modern global empire and its ambivalent legacies.

SPAN 401.name: Translation
SPAN 401.desc: Purpose, practice, and methodologies of translation from Spanish into English and back. Includes translation theory, translation from a variety of sources (i.e. literary, journalistic, legal, technical).

SPAN 403.name: History of the Spanish Language
SPAN 403.desc: Major features of the development of the Spanish language, from its origins to the present. Includes the history of Spanish phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and dialectology.

SPAN 404.name: From World to Screen: Topics in Hispanic Cinema
SPAN 404.desc: Selected areas of study relating to Hispanic Cinema. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 405.name: Celebrating Diversity: Topics in Peninsular and Latin-American Culture
SPAN 405.desc: Selected topics relating to the diversity of cultural production in Peninsular and Latin American Culture.  Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 406.name: Breaking the Mold: Gender Representation(s) in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN 406.desc: Gender and sexuality in Spain and Latin America.

SPAN 410.name: Multicultural Beginnings: Topics in Medieval Literature and Culture
SPAN 410.desc: Selected areas of study relating to literature and culture of the Iberian Peninsula to the 15th century. Consult the Department for this year'ss offerings.

SPAN 420.name: Ascent and Decline: Topics in Golden-Age Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN 420.desc: Selected areas of study relating to sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 430.name: Modernization and Autonomy: Topics in Peninsular Literature and Culture since the 18th Century
SPAN 430.desc: Selected areas of study relating to the literature and culture of modern Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 450.name: Discourse and Dialect: Topics in Spanish Language
SPAN 450.desc: Selected areas of study relating to Spanish linguistics or its relation to other languages spoken in the Hispanic world. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 470.name: Imperial Eyes and Foundational Fictions: Topics in Spanish-American Colonial and Nineteenth-Century Culture
SPAN 470.desc: Selected areas of study relating to colonial and/or nineteenth-century Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 490.name: Peoples and Nations: Topics in Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century Spanish-American Culture
SPAN 490.desc: Selected areas of study relating to modern and/or contemporary Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SPAN 498.name: Directed Reading
SPAN 498.desc: Focus on a topic agreed on by both Faculty Supervisor and student. Restricted to students with 4th year standing and permission from both the Department Head and Faculty Supervisor.

CHEM 113.name: Principles of Chemistry II
CHEM 113.desc: General and ionic equilibrium, solubility, thermodynamics. Introductory organic chemistry: stereochemistry; substitution, elimination and oxidation-reduction reactions. Can be used as prerequisite to subsequent CHEM courses. [3-3-1]
CHEM 113.prer: CHEM 111 and Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12 and Not open to students with credit for CHEM 121.
preq: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12
Not open to students with credit for CHEM 121

CHEM 201.name: Introduction to Physical Chemistry
CHEM 201.desc: Principles of chemical kinetics, reaction mechanisms and chemical thermodynamics. Credit will be given for only one of CHEM 201 and 205. [2-3*-1]
CHEM 201.prer: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123 or (c) CHEM 154. MATH 200 or MATH 217 or MATH 226 or MATH 253 or MATH 263 is recommended.

CHEM 202.name: Coordination Chemistry
CHEM 202.desc: Coordination chemistry of the transition elements. [2-3*1]
CHEM 202.prer: Either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123 or (c) one of SCIE 001, CHEM 154.

CHEM 309.name: s- and p-Block Elements: Chemistry and Applications
CHEM 309.desc: Synthesis, structures, bonding and characterization of compounds of the s- and p-block elements. Industrial uses discussed include: hydrogen-based fuels, materials and high performance polymers. [3-0-0]

CHEM 310.name: d- and f-Block Elements: Chemistry and Applications
CHEM 310.desc: Representative chemistry of d- and f-block elements interpreted in terms of structure, mechanisms, and theoretical principles.  Applications discussed include: organometallic catalysis, bioinorganic chemistry and materials. [3-0-0]

CHEM 333.name: Spectroscopic Techniques in Organic Chemistry
CHEM 333.desc: Application of mass spectrometry, and NMR, UV/visible, and IR spectroscopies to organic chemical problems. [3-0-0]
CHEM 333.prer: Either (a) all of CHEM 203, CHEM 204 or (b) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 205 or (c) CHEM 213.

CHEM 404.name: Computational Chemistry
CHEM 404.desc: Application of numerical techniques to study chemical systems; molecular simulation. Computer programming experience is not required.
CHEM 404.prer: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and Third-year standing.

CHEM 408.name: Chemical Dynamics
CHEM 408.desc: Macroscopic and microscopic kinetics; photochemistry; theory of reaction rates; reaction cross sections, energy distributions, experimental methods. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 408 and CHEM 508. [3-0-0]
CHEM 408.prer: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

CHEM 414.name: Coordination Chemistry of the Transition Elements
CHEM 414.desc: Molecular and electronic structures and reactivities of coordination compounds of the transition elements. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 414 and CHEM 525. [3-0-0]

CHEM 416.name: Physical and Theoretical Organic Chemistry
CHEM 416.desc: Energetics and catalysis in organic reactions. Pericyclic reactions. Substituent effects. Linear free energy relationships. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 416 and CHEM 563. [3-0-0]

CHEM 430.name: Developments in Contemporary Chemistry
CHEM 430.desc: A review of modern developments in general chemistry for teachers of Secondary School chemistry (Not for credit in the Faculty of Science). Course is offered periodically in extra-sessional sessions.

CHEM 435.name: Bio-Inorganic Chemistry
CHEM 435.desc: A discussion of the involvement of inorganic chemistry in biological systems. Chemistry of cations, metalloenzymes, and simpler model systems. Reactions of coordinated ligands, chemistry of sulphur and phosphorus. Credit will not be given for both CHEM 435 and CHEM 526. [3-0-0]
CHEM 435.prer: CHEM 304 and one of CHEM 218, CHEM 309.

CHEM 445.name: Projects in Experimental Chemistry
CHEM 445.desc: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting. [0-8-0]
CHEM 445.prer: CHEM 345 or CHEM 335 and fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.
preq: fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization

CHEM 448.name: Directed Studies in Chemistry
CHEM 448.desc: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

PHRM 170.name: Community Service Learning I
PHRM 170.desc: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 270.name: Community Service Learning II
PHRM 270.desc: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 371.name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient III
PHRM 371.desc: Direct patient care activities in an outpatient setting. Building on existing pharmaceutical knowledge and problem solving ability. Increased involvement in diverse patient care situations. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 441.name: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Pharmacy Practice
PHRM 441.desc: Roles and skills for pharmacists as preceptors, teachers and mentors; emerging issues in pharmacy practice.

PHRM 450.name: Pharm.D. Seminar
PHRM 450.desc: Seminar course about current and potential roles for pharmacists. Students will also deliver an individual and a group seminar. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 451.name: Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature
PHRM 451.desc: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 452.name: Patient Assessment Skills
PHRM 452.desc: Principles and practices of patient assessment, applied to the monitoring of drug efficacy and toxicity. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 453.name: Applied Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacogenomics
PHRM 453.desc: Pharmacokinetic monitoring of drug therapy in common clinical situations with foundations for application to other drugs.  Pharmacogenomics and personalized medicine principles and applications to practice. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 454.name: Practice Management
PHRM 454.desc: Values, concepts, issues and responsibilities of individuals exercising leadership and management roles in pharmacy practice and health care settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 462.name: Pharmacotherapeutics 2
PHRM 462.desc: Respirology, dermatology, and ears, eyes, nose, and throat. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 467.name: Pharmacotherapeutics 7
PHRM 467.desc: GU, OBS/GYN, endocrine, and renal. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 469.name: Pharmacotherapeutics 9
PHRM 469.desc: Acute/critical care, neurology, cardiac, GI, infectious diseases, and respiratory. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 471.name: Outpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRM 471.desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 472.name: Inpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRM 472.desc: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in inpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 473.name: Selected Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
PHRM 473.desc: Diverse options available in such domains as patient care (various settings), research, health policy, education, and others. The available placement options will vary from year to year depending on site/preceptor availability. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 481.name: Healthcare Quality Improvement
PHRM 481.desc: Builds on the foundation of patient care and management learning with knowledge about healthcare system improvement. Focuses on principles of quality measurement and quality improvement in health.

PHRM 491.name: Experiential Rotation I Community
PHRM 491.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve inceasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of community settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 492.name: Experiential Rotation II Inpatient
PHRM 492.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 493.name: Experiential Rotation III Advanced Practice
PHRM 493.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in specialized (advanced practice) settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 494.name: Experiential Rotation IV Ambulatory/Primary Care
PHRM 494.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of ambulatory or primary care settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 495.name: Experiential Rotation V Community or Inpatient
PHRM 495.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in community or inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 496.name: Experiential Rotation VI Elective
PHRM 496.desc: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience with application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in community, inpatient, primary care, ambulatory care, or specialized (advanced practice) settings. This elective rotation requires Program Director approval. Pass/Fail.

PHRM 499.name: Comprehensive Examination
PHRM 499.desc: Assessment of skills in the clinical problem-solving process. Pass/Fail.
PHRM 499.prer: Successful completion of all other coursework
preq: Successful completion of all other coursework

CNTO 403.name: Intermediate Cantonese II
CNTO 403.desc: Intermediate lower level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 401.

CNRS 335.name: Practicum in Classical or Near Eastern Archaeology
CNRS 335.desc: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks; it may be repeated once.

MDVL 301.name: European Literature from the 5th to the 14th Century
MDVL 301.desc: Selected works from the 5th to the 14th centuries in their cultural and social contexts.
MDVL 301.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts

MDVL 302.name: European Literature from the 14th to the 16th Century
MDVL 302.desc: Selected works of the Late Middle Ages and Renaissance in their cultural and social contexts.
MDVL 302.prer: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts.
preq: Third-year standing in the Faculty of Arts

MDVL 310.name: Topics in Medieval Studies
MDVL 310.desc: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

MDVL 490.name: Research Seminar in Medieval Studies
MDVL 490.desc: An intensive research seminar in a specific period, area, or issue integrating topics in medieval history, literature, and the arts; topics vary from year to year; interested students should consult the Medieval Studies advisor.

EECE 265.name: Circuits and Electronics
EECE 265.desc: Introduction to circuit analysis and electronic circuits; topics chosen for applicability to systems involving signal acquisition, amplification, low/high pass filtering and power control. Not open to students in the Faculty of Applied Science.

EECE 280.name: Electrical and Computer Engineering Laboratory I
EECE 280.desc: Introduction to oscilloscopes, signal generators and electrical measuring instruments.  Design projects in analog and digital logic circuits.

EECE 283.name: Electro-Mechanical Laboratory
EECE 283.desc: Experiments in analog and digital electronics, including microcomputers. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

EECE 301.name: Topics in Nanotechnology and Microsystems
EECE 301.desc: Guest lectures and preparatory theory will highlight emerging devices and systems. Restricted to students admitted to the Nanotechnology and Microsystems Option in the Electrical Engineering.

EECE 320.name: Discrete Structures and Algorithms
EECE 320.desc: Discrete structures, such as trees and graphs, and their properties; introduction to algorithms and algorithmic complexity. Proof of correctness; design techniques such as greedy algorithms and dynamic programming. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 320 or CPSC 320.

EECE 321.name: Languages and Translation
EECE 321.desc: Principles and practice of automated language translation. Language syntax and semantics, typing, binding and parameter passing. Syntactic and lexical analysis. Language automata, parsing. Compilers and compiler-compilers.

EECE 359.name: Signals and Communications
EECE 359.desc: Review of Fourier analysis of signals; convolution and correlation; filtering, sampling, multiplexing and modulation of signals; introduction to probability with applications in communications.  Credit will only be given for one of EECE 359 or EECE 369, although EECE 359 is not equivalent to EECE 369.
EECE 359.prer: One of EECE 253, ELEC 202, EECE 269, ELEC 221.

EECE 362.name: Communications Systems and Networks
EECE 362.desc: Transceiver architectures; link budget analysis; elements of analog and digital communications methods; packet switched networks; multiple access; Internet architecture and protocols.

EECE 370.name: Electrical Machines and Power Transmission
EECE 370.desc: Electric power, three-phase systems, transmission/distribution; transformers, motors, generators. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering. Credit will only be given for one of EECE 365, 370, 373, 374 or 376.

EECE 374.name: Electronics and Electromechanics
EECE 374.desc: BJT and MOSFET amplifiers; cascode and differential amplifiers; nonideal OP amps; feedback; active filters; permanent magnet. DC motors; variable voltage control; software control of variable frequency; mechanical power, torque and speed. Credit will be granted for only one of EECE 356, 365, 370, 373, 374, or 376.
EECE 374.prer: EECE 251 and one of EECE 253, EECE 263.

EECE 375.name: Computer-Based Instrumentation Design Laboratory
EECE 375.desc: Theory and practice of electronic instrumentation for software engineers. Computer-based data acquisition and control techniques. Design project.

EECE 400.name: Nanotechnology and Microsystems Capstone Design Project
EECE 400.desc: Design, analysis, and implementation of solutions in response to a real world nanotechnology and microsystems engineering problem.  Projects are provided by industry, research laboratories, or other suitable entities.  Includes coverage of topics such as project management.

EECE 415.name: Requirements Engineering for Software-Intensive Systems
EECE 415.desc: Elicitation, analysis, validation, description, management and traceability of functional and non-functional requirements. Specialized techniques. Emphasis on software-intensive systems but also applicable to other kinds of engineered systems.

EECE 423.name: Software Systems for Modeling and Simulation
EECE 423.desc: Discrete, continuous and hybrid approaches to modeling and simulating natural and artificial systems.  Credit will not be given for both EECE 423 and CPSC 405.
EECE 423.prer: Either (a) CPSC 260 or (b) all of CPSC 211, CPSC 221;  and one of STAT 251, MATH 318.

EECE 451.name: Engineering Product Development and Management
EECE 451.desc: Product development cycle: generation of ideas and market requirements for new products, economic and quality considerations, the team approach, relationships with suppliers and evaluation of proposed products. Cases involving North American and Japanese firms.

EECE 467.name: Real-time Implementation of DSP Algorithms
EECE 467.desc: Review of sampling, digital filter design, convolution, transforms; DSP systems and architecture; programming DSP boards in "C" and assembly, fixed-point vs. floating point arithmetic; testing; DSP solutions in audio and telecommunications.

EECE 468.name: Digital Process Control
EECE 468.desc: Discrete systems, z-transform; sampled data systems; process control algorithms; multivariable control; state space methods; response to stochastic inputs, Wiener and Kalman filtering; least squares parameter identification.

EECE 470.name: Microwave Circuits
EECE 470.desc: Transmission lines; microwave integrated circuit lines; passive microstrip devices; microwave solid state control devices and circuits, amplifiers, oscillators and frequency conversion circuits.

EECE 474.name: Instrumentation and Design Laboratory
EECE 474.desc: Theory and practice of electrical measurements and electronic instrumentation.

EECE 478.name: Computer Graphics
EECE 478.desc: Physical and virtual graphics I/O devices. The GKS standard Interactive graphics. Transformations, modelling, rendering algorithms for 2-D and 3-D graphics. Curves and surfaces. Credit will not be given for both CPSC 314 and EECE 478.

EECE 485.name: Digital Instrumentation for Mechanical Systems
EECE 485.desc: Design of microcomputer-based controllers and instrumentation; basics of digital and analog computer interface hardware; processor structure and function; high-level and low-level languages and system design-related issues. Laboratory experiments in basic logic elements, computer interface control, and sensor-based software control of various devices. Credit will be given for only one of EECE 485 or APSC 380. Not open to students in Electrical and Computer Engineering.
EECE 485.prer: One of EECE 365, PHYS 253 and one of CPSC 152, CPSC 122, APSC 160 or APSC 171.

FOPR 261.name: Basic Geomatics for Natural Resources
FOPR 261.desc: Techniques of measuring and surveying as they are applied in assessing and managing natural resources. [2-2-0]

FOPR 262.name: Forest Access and Transportation
FOPR 262.desc: Introduction to the physical attributes of forest access and transportation and how they best integrate with the objectives of resource sustainability. [2-3-0]

SPPH 301.name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
SPPH 301.desc: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200. [3-0-0]

SPPH 381.name: Selected Topics
SPPH 381.desc: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

SPPH 404.name: First Nations Health: Historical and Contemporary Issues
SPPH 404.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) covers an epistemological approach that considers the determinants of health and spiritual-environmental-cultural perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 404 or IHHS 404. [3-0-0]

SPPH 408.name: Topics in Aboriginal Health: Community-based Learning Experience
SPPH 408.desc: In-depth cultural and interprofessional learning experience that enables students to live and study in BC First Nations communities while learning about health, wellness, and community strengths from a local perspective. Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 408 or IHHS 408.

SPPH 409.name: International Indigenous Experiences of Colonization
SPPH 409.desc: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course is an online, interprofessional, comparative inquiry of indigenous experiences of global colonization and the manifestations of that experience in the contemporary socio-cultural environment. Informed and guided by indigenous knowledge and drawing upon a range of disciplines such as public health, history, sociology and public policy. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 409 or IHHS 409.

SPPH 481.name: Special Topics in Population and Public Health
SPPH 481.desc: Selected topics will vary.  Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.

COEC 126.name: Data: Description, Display, and Inference
COEC 126.desc: Use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 126 or COMM 126.

COEC 298.name: Introduction to Finance
COEC 298.desc: Basic principles of financial valuation, including the time-value of money and the risk/return tradeoff. Develops tools for the quantitative analysis of corporate and/or individual financing and saving decisions, and of capital budgeting decisions. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 298.

COEC 394.name: Government and Business
COEC 394.desc: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 394 or COMM 394.

SCIE 120.name: Topics in Sustainability Science
SCIE 120.desc: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses. [1-0-0]
SCIE 120.crer: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.
creq: CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science

SCIE 420.name: Sustainability for Community and the World
SCIE 420.desc: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations. [3-0-0]
SCIE 420.prer: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW  386, LFS  250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, SCIE 120. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

MIDW 200.name: Introduction to Midwifery Clinical Care
MIDW 200.desc: Clinical care of women experiencing normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium.  Clinical education experiences in preventative and therapeutic midwifery care with emphasis on prenatal and postnatal midwifery care.  Clinical practice education opportunities within the province.  Pass/Fail.

MIDW 201.name: Clinical Skills for Midwifery Practice
MIDW 201.desc: Online situation-based learning tutorials occurring simultaneously with MIDW 200 clinical placement.

MIDW 210.name: Evidence-Informed Midwifery
MIDW 210.desc: Principles of evidence-informed midwifery, what counts as evidence? Making sense of the evidence, applying the evidence in practice.

MIDW 230.name: Midwifery Theory for Primary Care
MIDW 230.desc: Care of normal pregnancy, labour, birth, and puerperium with an empahsis on the intrapartum period and assessment and management skills.  Inludes a four-week intensive session in Vancouver, a series of online tutorials, and simulation and skills lab practice.

MIDW 322.name: Midwifery Primary Care
MIDW 322.desc: Clinical course focusing on consolidation of skills and knowledge of all aspects of midwifery care.

MIDW 380.name: Midwifery in Special Contexts
MIDW 380.desc: Clinical course providing opportunity to study midwifery in contexts beyond those usually offered on the program. Students select context and provide rationale for how the context will enhance their learning.

MIDW 435.name: Comprehensive Midwifery Theory and Practice
MIDW 435.desc: Theoretical principles and evidence basis for comprehensive midwifery care. Tutorials are carried out in an online live classroom setting.

ENVR 410.name: Energy, Environment, and Society
ENVR 410.desc: The role of energy in human societies throughout history and the environmental and social implications of energy use.  Coverage of both the science and policy of energy use.  Energy supply and demand, energy transitions, analytical tools, impacts, and alternatives. [3-0-0]
ENVR 410.prer: Fourth-year standing in B.Sc., B.A.Sc. or related programs.

ENVR 448.name: Directed Studies in Environmental Science
ENVR 448.desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of an ENSC advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required prior to registration.
ENVR 448.prer: Third year standing in the Faculty of Science.
preq: Third year standing in the Faculty of Science

ENVR 490.name: Student Directed Seminars in Environmental Sciences
ENVR 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in environmental sciences, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars (www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/sds/sds_handbook.pdf).

LARC 421.name: Creativity and Design Applied
LARC 421.desc: An exploration of creativity and design and their application to a number of design disciplines. Web based. [3-0-0]

DENT 407.name: Special Oral Care in the Community
DENT 407.desc: Provision of special oral health services in community settings.
DENT 407.prer: All of DHYG 405, DHYG 435. Prerequisites may be waived for non-program dental hygienists and others.
preq: DHYG 435. Prerequisites may be waived for non-program dental hygienists

FHIS 333.name: Short Fiction in Romance Literatures
FHIS 333.desc: A study of the genres of the "novella" and the short story within and across Romance cultures.

FHIS 334.name: Afterlife of the Text: Rewritings and Adaptations
FHIS 334.desc: How stories travel across media and across national and linguistic boundaries in the Romance-speaking world. Dialogue between different versions and inter-media translations. Questions of authorship and reception.

PHIL 313.name: Medieval Philosophy
PHIL 313.desc: Survey of Western European thought from Augustine to the 14th century. Possible topics and authors include: Augustine; Abelard; the influence of Islam; the rediscovery of Aristotle; Aquinas; Scotus; Ockham.

PHIL 322.name: Modal Logic
PHIL 322.desc: Logic of the modal operators "It is necessary that" and "It is possible that." Possible-world semantics and a method of derivation for this logic.

PHIL 323.name: Non-Classical Logics
PHIL 323.desc: One or more of conditional logic, deontic logic, epistemic logic, many-valued logic, systems of belief dynamics.

PHIL 324.name: Philosophy of Logic
PHIL 324.desc: Fundamental concepts and methods of logic; the logistic method, syntax and semantics; the conditional; entailment; consequence; modal logic; problems concerning extensionality and intentionality. Frege's distinction between sense and reference; Russell's theory of definite descriptions; Tarski's definition of truth.

PHIL 371.name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
PHIL 371.desc: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

PHIL 378.name: Philosophical Wisdom of Early India
PHIL 378.desc: Epistemological and ontological thought from the Vedic Period to the period of the rise of philosophical schools or systems.  Philosophy in the Mahabharata, Gita; early Buddhist and Jain views on knowledge and reality; views on language.

PHIL 400.name: Morals, Politics and the Individual
PHIL 400.desc: Introduction to major themes in moral and political philosophy. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 400, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

PHIL 401.name: Knowledge, Explanation, and the Nature of Things
PHIL 401.desc: Introduction to major themes in epistemology and metaphysics. Primarily for fourth-year and graduate students who have had no previous course in Philosophy. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 401, PHIL 100 or PHIL 101 and 102.

PHIL 410.name: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
PHIL 410.desc: Advanced study of the Presocratics, or of a philosopher such as Plato, or of a school such as the Sceptics or Stoics. Topics vary from year to year.

PHIL 412.name: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
PHIL 412.desc: Advanced study of a medieval philosopher such as Aquinas, or school.

PHIL 414.name: Topics in the History of Modern Philosophy
PHIL 414.desc: Intensive study of a major philosopher or school such as Descartes, Hume, Empiricism, Rationalism, or the British utilitarians.

PHIL 416.name: Topics in 19th-Century Philosophy
PHIL 416.desc: Study of a major 19th-century philosopher such as Hegel, Mill or Nietzsche, or school, such as German Idealism.
PHIL 416.prer: One of PHIL 314, PHIL 315, PHIL 316, PHIL 340.

PHIL 419.name: Philosophy of History
PHIL 419.desc: Concepts of history and historical explanation, historical progress, purpose, necessity, law and causation. Hegel, Marx, Vico, Spengler, Pareto, Collingwood, Croce, and Toynbee, as well as contemporary figures. Students will be expected to have an adequate knowledge of ancient or modern history.

PHIL 420.name: Topics in Symbolic Logic
PHIL 420.desc: Formal semantics, proof theory, incompleteness and decidability, axiomatic set theory, independence results. Consult the Department as to which topics are offered in a given year.

PHIL 426.name: Topics in Philosophy of Language
PHIL 426.desc: Advanced topics in the philosophy of language.
PHIL 426.prer: PHIL 326. And 6 credits of PHIL/LING at the 200-level or above.

PHIL 427.name: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL 427.desc: Logicism, formalism and constructivism, implications of metatheorems such as those of Gödel and Church, mathematical truth, mathematics and mental construction, mathematics and the physical world.
PHIL 427.prer: Philosophy or mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level or above.
preq: mathematics courses totaling 9 credits at the 200-level

PHIL 431.name: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
PHIL 431.desc: Central concepts and problems in political life and thought including obligation, citizenship, representation, justice; equality; civil rights and liberty; disobedience.
PHIL 431.prer: 9 credits of PHIL/POLI at the 200-level or above.

PHIL 440.name: Topics in Epistemology
PHIL 440.desc: Analysis of the concept of knowledge; problems of justifying ordinary and basic empirical beliefs.

PHIL 450.name: Topics in Metaphysics
PHIL 450.desc: Topics including ontology, universals and particulars, substance, determinism and indeterminism, identity over time, and theories of truth.
PHIL 450.prer: 9 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above. PHIL 340 is recommended.

PHIL 452.name: Philosophy of Action
PHIL 452.desc: Explanation of human actions; the conditions of responsibility; freedom of the will; the domains of rational and moral appraisal; the category of action and the individuation of actions.

PHIL 455.name: Topics in the Philosophy of Cognitive Science
PHIL 455.desc: Philosophical topics in the cognitive sciences, such as empiricism vs. nativism, consciousness, mental representation, cognitive architecture, language & thought, and situated cognition.
PHIL 455.prer: PHIL 240 or COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.  Recommended: PHIL 441 or PHIL 451.
preq: COGS 200 if accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level

PHIL 462.name: Space and Time
PHIL 462.desc: Such topics as: Are space and time continuous? Is motion always relative to another body? Does time flow? Is time irreversible?
PHIL 462.prer: PHIL 340 or 12 credits of mathematics or science.

PHIL 464.name: Philosophy of Biology
PHIL 464.desc: Methodological, historical, philosophical and social science questions about biology. Credit will be given for only one of PHIL 464 or BIOL 446.
PHIL 464.prer: Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.
preq: Fourth-year standing in any degree program

PHIL 469.name: Topics in Philosophy of Science
PHIL 469.desc: Topics such as probability and induction; foundations of measurement; theory construction.

PHIL 470.name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
PHIL 470.desc: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsün-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

COMM 126.name: Data: Description, Display, and Inference
COMM 126.desc: Introduction to the use of data and statistics to convey information on important issues of the world economy. Credit will be granted for only one of COMM 126 or COEC 126.

COMM 201.name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
COMM 201.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

COMM 300.name: Study Abroad, Commerce
COMM 300.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

COMM 301.name: Study Abroad, Commerce
COMM 301.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between the Sauder School of Business and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.  Pass/Fail.

COMM 302.name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
COMM 302.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between UBC Faculty of Commerce and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.

COMM 303.name: Study Abroad, Non-Commerce
COMM 303.desc: A study abroad program developed in cooperation between the Sauder School of Business and another institution offering a set of courses tailored to a particular field of study.  Pass/Fail.

COMM 310.name: Simulation Models in Business Decision-Making
COMM 310.desc: Computer simulation, simulation languages. Typical business applications in financial planning, waiting line problems and other operating problems.

COMM 342.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management I - Study Abroad

COMM 343.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management II - Study Abroad

COMM 344.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management III - Study Abroad

COMM 345.name: Global Supply Chain & Logistics Management IV - Study Abroad

COMM 349.name: Logistics Services Management
COMM 349.desc: Overview of the characteristics and commercial environment of logistics and transportation services; service operations planning and design, costing, pricing and quality management.
COMM 349.crer: One of COMM 204, COMM 296, COMM 396, COMM 399.

COMM 376.name: Financial Institutions I
COMM 376.desc: The financial systems in Canada; the practices of the major financial institutions; and theories of financial processes.

COMM 379.name: Introduction to Pensions and Insurance
COMM 379.desc: Financial dimensions and institutional structure of the pension and insurance industry; calculation of annuities and other aspects of actuarial science based on probability distributions and asset returns. Suitable for students in mathematics who have taken basic finance and for commerce students in finance, accounting and related areas.

COMM 411.name: Intermediate Business Statistics
COMM 411.desc: Statistical techniques useful in business environments. Includes regression analysis, analysis of variance, forecasting, and logit and probit analysis. Credit may be obtained for only one of STAT 300, 306, and COMM 411.

COMM 425.name: Research Methods for Human Resource Management
COMM 425.desc: Techniques for collection and analysis of data in organizations to support adoption and administration of human resource management.

COMM 428.name: Selected Topics in Human Resource Management

COMM 441.name: Advanced Business Logistics
COMM 441.desc: Analysis of logistics systems within firms and across supply chains. The formulation of corporate logistics strategies.

COMM 446.name: Transportation Economics
COMM 446.desc: Economic characteristics of passenger and freight transportation services; market structure of the transportation industry; economic impact of public regulation and promotion and the role of economic analysis in resolving problems of Canadian policy. Credit may be obtained for only one of COMM 446, ECON 480.
COMM 446.prer: One of COMM 295, ECON 201, ECON 301, ECON 206.

COMM 448.name: Business Logistics and Logistics Services Management
COMM 448.desc: General services management including warehousing, transportation, intermodal, order-fulfillment, dispatching, and more.

COMM 456.name: Information Technology Risks, Protection and Audit
COMM 456.desc: Business risks associated with the use of information technology. Controls for integrity, security safety, and privacy of hardware, software, data and communications. Methods for auditing information systems and their controls.

COMM 463.name: Special Topics in Marketing
COMM 463.desc: An investigation of current developments in both retailing and wholesaling fields and their application to marketing institutions.

COMM 488.name: Public Sector Management
COMM 488.desc: This course focuses on some of the distinctive aspects of managing in the public sector.

COMM 490.name: Directed Studies in Commerce
COMM 490.desc: An investigation and report on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and a senior student.

COMM 492.name: Management Simulation
COMM 492.desc: Student teams manage hypothetical firms in a complex simulation, coordinating production, finance, marketing and strategic planning in competition with other teams.
COMM 492.prer: All of COMM 390, COMM 395. Fourth-year standing.

COMM 495.name: Business and Sustainable Development
COMM 495.desc: An overview of environmental issues, focusing on corporate strategy, government policy and interactions between these two sectors of the economy.

ITAL 103.name: Intensive First-Year Italian
ITAL 103.desc: An accelerated course. Grammar, reading, writing, comprehension. This course is equivalent to ITAL 101 plus 102 offered in the same semester.

ITAL 203.name: Intensive Second-Year Italian
ITAL 203.desc: An accelerated course. Grammar review, reading, composition, comprehension. This course is equivalent to ITAL 201 plus 202 offered in the same semester.

ITAL 342.name: Introduction to Italian for Senior Students I
ITAL 342.desc: An intensive course in spoken and written Italian. Grammar, conversation, reading of literary texts. Prerequisite: proficiency in another Romance language or Latin. Not considered a third-year course for purposes of satisfying Italian program requirements.
ITAL 342.prer: Proficiency in another Romance Language or in Latin

ITAL 343.name: Introduction to Italian for Senior Students II
ITAL 343.desc: An intensive course in spoken and written Italian. Grammar, conversation, progressive reading of various texts. Prerequisite: Proficiency in another Romance language or Latin. Not considered a third-year course for purposes of satisfying Italian program requirements.

ITAL 402.name: Advanced Studies in Italian Language and Style II
ITAL 402.desc: Advanced reading, writing, speaking, comprehension. Special emphasis on composition. Alternates with ITAL 401.

ITAL 404.name: Italian Literature of the Middle Ages
ITAL 404.desc: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITST 414.

ITAL 405.name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance
ITAL 405.desc: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other Arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 405 or ITAL 415.

ITAL 406.name: Topics in Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITAL 406.desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 406 or ITST 416.

ITAL 407.name: Topics in Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITAL 407.desc: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context.  Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 407 or ITST 417.

ITAL 408.name: Topics in Nineteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
ITAL 408.desc: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITST 418.

ITAL 420.name: Special Topics in Italian Language, Literature and Culture
ITAL 420.desc: Course content will vary. May be taken twice for a total of 6 credits.

ITAL 430.name: Italian Cinema in its Cultural Background
ITAL 430.desc: A survey of major films in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Auteurs may range from De Sica, Rossellini, Pasolini, and Visconti to Bertolucci, Rosi, the Tavianis, and Moretti. Precludes credit for ITST 432.

ITAL 495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Italian Literature and Culture
ITAL 495.desc: Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL 495 or ITST 495.

NEST 310.name: History of Women in Early to Late Medieval Muslim Societies
NEST 310.desc: Realities of Muslim Women's lives are reconstructed through a critical examination of a variety of literary and material sources.

NEST 311.name: Prehistoric Egypt
NEST 311.desc: A survey of the development and evolution of prehistoric humans and their material culture in Egypt from the Lower Paleolithic to the Chalcolithic.

NEST 315.name: Introduction to Akkadian
NEST 315.desc: The basic grammar and introduction to the cuneiform writing system of the Akkadian language of the Ancient Near East.

NEST 317.name: Introduction to Coptic
NEST 317.desc: An introduction to Coptic, the language of Christian Egypt from 100 AD.

NEST 318.name: Egyptomania
NEST 318.desc: The adaptation and appropriation of ancient Egypt in ancient and modern art, architecture, film, and music; the development of Egyptology since the 19th century.

NEST 319.name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
NEST 319.desc: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

NEST 400.name: Materials and Technologies of the Ancient Near East and Egypt
NEST 400.desc: The natural resources and production technologies of the ancient Near East and Egypt.  Credit will be  granted for only one of NEST 400 or 504.

NEST 401.name: Literature of Ancient Egypt or the Ancient Near East
NEST 401.desc: The main genres and texts of Egyptian and Ancient Near Eastern Literature and their modern Interpretation. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 401 or 505.

NEST 402.name: The Archaeology of the City in the Ancient Near East
NEST 402.desc: The material manifestations of urbanism in the ancient Near East, from the 4th millennium BC up to the 1st millennium BC. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 402 or 506.

ATSC 212.name: Earth and Atmospheric Science Introductory Computing Laboratory
ATSC 212.desc: Computing tools, including Unix/Linux, Web page creation, programming languages used for numerical calculation, database programs. [0-2]

ATSC 301.name: Atmospheric Radiation and Remote Sensing
ATSC 301.desc: Energy transfer at infrared, visible, and microwave wavelengths. Analysis of satellite measurements of the atmosphere and surface. [3-0-0]
ATSC 301.prer: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158 and familiarity with a programming language.

ATSC 303.name: Methods in Atmospheric Science
ATSC 303.desc: An introduction to instrumentation used in monitoring the state of the atmosphere; a brief survey of methods of analysis of meteorological data. [2-2-0]
ATSC 303.prer: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, GEOB 200.

ATSC 406.name: Operational Meteorology
ATSC 406.desc: Introduction to meteorological prediction, meteorological data analysis, prognosis of weather systems, motion and development, satellite imagery, Doppler radar, numerical weather prediction, synoptic and mesoscale forecasting, applied laboratory exercises. [2-2-0]

ATSC 448.name: Directed Studies
ATSC 448.desc: Investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.  Permission of the undergraduate advisor and of the supervising faculty member is required before registration.

ATSC 490.name: Student Directed Seminars in Atmospheric Science
ATSC 490.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in atmospheric science, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars (www.vpacademic.ubc.ca/sds/sds_handbook.pdf).

GEOG 210.name: Vancouver and Its Region
GEOG 210.desc: An integrated approach to the physical and human geography of the Lower Mainland of British Columbia. Field trips.

GEOG 315.name: Human and Environmental Geography Field Course
GEOG 315.desc: Engage in primary field-based research in British Columbia on important issues concerning intercultural understanding, engagement with local communities and sustainability. Focus will shift on a bi-annual basis in accordance with location and available community partners. Special fees and liability insurance are required. Third year standing is recommended.

GEOG 317.name: The Physical Environment of British Columbia
GEOG 317.desc: The biophysical processes which are shaping and have shaped British Columbia; characteristic associations between landforms, climate, soil, and vegetation; biophysical constraints on air, land and water use.
GEOG 317.prer: 6 credits from GEOG 102 (or GEOG 200 or 204) or GEOB 102 (or GEOB 200 or 204), GEOG 101, 103, 205, 207 or GEOB 103, 205, 207.

GEOG 362.name: Geography of Economic Development
GEOG 362.desc: Geographical approaches to economic development; models of economic development and spatial change; influences on spatial economic change; case studies from the developed, third, and socialist worlds.

GEOG 379.name: Field Course in Human Geography
GEOG 379.desc: As announced by the department a year in advance.

GEOG 390.name: Geography of Selected Regions
GEOG 390.desc: A geographical analysis of selected regions not regularly included in the Department's offerings in regional geography (e.g., tropical Africa, Oceania). Students should consult the Department regarding regions to be covered.

GEOG 419.name: Research in Environmental Geography
GEOG 419.desc: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
GEOG 419.prer: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.
preq: Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits

GEOG 426.name: Historical Geography of British Columbia, I
GEOG 426.desc: Colonialism, resistance, and land use in early British Columbia.

GEOG 429.name: Research in Historical Geography
GEOG 429.desc: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
GEOG 429.prer: Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor.
preq: Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits
