GEOG 442.name: Student Directed Seminar in Human Geography
GEOG 442.desc: Self-directed, collaborative studies in human geography, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars."  Credit will not be granted for both Geog 442 and Geog 443.

GEOG 446.name: Topics in Geography
GEOG 446.desc: See the departmental undergraduate adviser for details.

GEOG 461.name: Political-Economic Geographies
GEOG 461.desc: Principal theories and debates in contemporary political-economic geography, with particular emphasis on global and regional transformations.

GEOG 468.name: Geography of International Economic Systems: Canada and the Pacific Basin
GEOG 468.desc: An introduction to the study of international economic systems illustrated by the study of Canada's relations with the countries located in the Pacific Basin. Normally alternates with GEOG 481.

GEOG 484.name: Geography of Southeast Asia
GEOG 484.desc: A critical analysis of significant features of political, economic, and cultural development in the region from pre-colonial times to the present.

GEOG 485.name: Geography of China
GEOG 485.desc: An introduction to the changing cultural, social and economic geography of China. Normally alternates with GEOG 425.

GEOG 493.name: Contemporary Europe: Identity and Geopolitics
GEOG 493.desc: Political, economic, and social geographies of post Cold War Europe with a special emphasis on east-central Europe: societal transformations in the formerly socialist states; European Union and NATO enlargement; the external relations of these two organizations.

GEOG 496.name: Geography of Africa
GEOG 496.desc: A critical introduction to social, political and economic geographies of Africa from pre-colonial times to the present, with a focus on contemporary environmental and development issues.
GEOG 496.prer: One of GEOG 329, GEOG 350. GEOG 362 is recommended.

APSC 122.name: Introduction to Engineering
APSC 122.desc: Non-credit course designed to introduce students to Engineering. Information on the Faculty, the profession and the particular skills and type of work done by practising engineers in different disciplines. [1-0-0]

APSC 150.name: Engineering Case Studies
APSC 150.desc: Application of scientific principles and technical knowledge to practical problems. Introduction to the engineering design process and to engineering graphics.

APSC 151.name: Computer-Aided Engineering Graphics
APSC 151.desc: Orthographic projection, technical sketching, development of the ability to visualize in three dimensions. Standards and conventions of engineering drawing, graphical presentation of engineering data. Micro-computer based graphics aids. Engineering geometry and the solution of space problems.

APSC 202.name: Technical Communication Engineering Physics I
APSC 202.desc: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Engineering Physics Program.
APSC 202.prer: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121.

APSC 203.name: Technical Communication Engineering Physics II
APSC 203.desc: Continuation of written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation and oral presentations of technical material. Restricted to students in second year of the Engineering Physics Program.

APSC 211.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 211.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 212.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 212.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 263.name: Technology and Development
APSC 263.desc: Environmental, economic, political, and social aspects of appropriate technologies in the developing world. Appropriate technology and infrastructure, trade and finance, transportation, energy, water access, communication, health, and gender.

APSC 311.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 311.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 312.name: Co-operative Work Placement
APSC 312.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an approved company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 331.name: Intermediate Engineering Design I
APSC 331.desc: Intermediate level engineering design project involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program. For students in the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 332.name: Intermediate Engineering Design II
APSC 332.desc: Intermediate level engineering design project involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program. For students in the Co-operative Education Program.

APSC 364.name: Applied Sustainability: UBC as a Living Laboratory
APSC 364.desc: The role and function of common infrastructures, and the impact of various technological solutions on people, the economy, and the environment.

APSC 380.name: Introduction to Microcomputers
APSC 380.desc: An introductory course intended for potential users of microcomputers in real time or non-computational engineering applications. Topics include: perspective on applications and costs; basic microcomputer hardware; principles of microcomputer operation; introduction to microcomputer programming and software design tools; input-output devices including transducers, analog-to-digital converters, digital-to-analog converters; input-output methods and interface characteristics; selected case studies such as direct digital controllers and sensor-based systems. Limited enrolment. Restricted to engineering students not taking Electrical or Computer Engineering.

APSC 496.name: Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project
APSC 496.desc: Projects involving students from several departments.

APSC 498.name: Directed Studies
APSC 498.desc: Requires approval of a Department Head or Program Director.

KIN 115.name: Performance Analysis of Selected Individual Sports and Activities
KIN 115.desc: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order. [2-2]

KIN 215.name: Performance Analysis of Selected Team Sports and Activities
KIN 215.desc: Specific topics to be announced each year. KIN 115 and 215 can be taken in any order. [2-2]

KIN 343.name: Biology of Human Athletic Performance
KIN 343.desc: Basics of exercise physiology and related issues pertaining to sports and athletic performance for non-Kinesiology students.  Not for credit in the B.Kin. Program. [3-0]

KIN 353.name: Human Body Composition
KIN 353.desc: Examination of techniques for measuring the amounts of adipose tissue, muscle and bone in the body, and factors affecting body composition, with particular emphasis on physical activity. [3-0]

KIN 392.name: The Leisure and Sport Industry
KIN 392.desc: Economic and financial issues in the leisure and sport industry. Topics include entrepreneurship, economic impact, commercialization, patterns of ownership and control, and selected financial practices. [3-0]

KIN 403.name: Co-operative Work Placement
KIN 403.desc: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.

KIN 454.name: Field Experience
KIN 454.desc: Students have the opportunity to develop their leadership, instruction, and professional skills in a variety of supervised fieldwork settings. Students should select the section of the course (A, B) most relevant to their program of study and career goals.

KIN 455.name: Field Work and Field Research Practicum
KIN 455.desc: Field work and a field research project will be undertaken concurrently in a cooperating leisure, sport or other agency over one term in fourth year (30 hours per week). Students will also attend weekly seminars to discuss field work and the field research projects. Limited enrolment.
KIN 455.prer: One of KIN  371, HKIN 371. Fourth-year standing and approval from KIN Program Coordinator.

KIN 469.name: Chronic Health Issues, Physical Activity, and Community Practice
KIN 469.desc: Issues related to physical activity and public health. Focus on community interventions.  Creation of activity plans that promote physical, mental, and/or social well-being in persons dealing with chronic health issues. Community service-learning component. [3-0]

KIN 489.name: Seminar
KIN 489.desc: Current topics and research in specific areas. [3-0-0]
KIN 489.prer: Fourth-year standing. Consult with Advisor for specific prerequisites.
preq: Fourth-year standing. Consult with Advisor for specific prerequisites

SOCI 210.name: Canadian Social Structure
SOCI 210.desc: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

SOCI 240.name: Introduction to Social Interaction
SOCI 240.desc: A general introduction to research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour. Topics include: status, power and prestige, distributive justice, marginality and social control, authority relations, and group structure and membership, all to be studied in the context of a variety of groups (such as families, formal organizations, communities and friendship groups) and cultures.

SOCI 250.name: Crime and Society
SOCI 250.desc: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies. The scope and nature of the crime problem, the growth of criminology as a science and profession, and relationships between components of state criminal justice systems.

SOCI 260.name: Technology, Work and Society
SOCI 260.desc: The social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work and the labour force. Topics may include division of labour, professionalization, labour movements, management techniques and bureaucracy, the social context of research and development initiatives, the effects of new technologies (e.g., automation) on the work place and social aspects of technological development in the Third World.

SOCI 301.name: Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
SOCI 301.desc: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Major themes stress the relationship between urbanization and industrialization; modernization and ethnic conflict; imperialism, neo-colonialism, and foreign aid; and intra-national modernization problems such as regional underdevelopment in industrial societies.

SOCI 302.name: Ethnic and Racial Inequality
SOCI 302.desc: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels.

SOCI 303.name: Sociology of Migration
SOCI 303.desc: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time.

SOCI 310.name: Canadian Society
SOCI 310.desc: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class.

SOCI 344.name: Sociology of Aging
SOCI 344.desc: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444.
SOCI 344.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 352.name: Organization of Work
SOCI 352.desc: The meaning of work and leisure. Properties of work organization: division of labour and specialization; technology and working knowledge; means of coordinating work, such as cooperation, authority, and exchange. Research problems concerning work in households, offices, and industry, division of labour by gender, industrial democracy and the relation of work and social inequality.

SOCI 354.name: Community Studies
SOCI 354.desc: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks.

SOCI 360.name: Sociology and Natural Resources
SOCI 360.desc: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. May also include examination of social aspects of resource development in the Third World.

SOCI 361.name: Social Inequality
SOCI 361.desc: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies.

SOCI 369.name: Sociology of Sexualities
SOCI 369.desc: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century.
SOCI 369.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 383.name: Sociological Methods: Historical Research
SOCI 383.desc: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history.
SOCI 383.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

SOCI 410.name: Selected Topics in Canadian Society
SOCI 410.desc: Selected areas of study relating to Canadian society such as BC Studies; French Canada's demographic problems; rural communities; social welfare and community programs in Canada. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

SOCI 414.name: Feminist Theory
SOCI 414.desc: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. The social basis and development of feminist thought from critiques of scholarship and research to contemporary debates will be addressed.

SOCI 415.name: Theories of Family and Kinship
SOCI 415.desc: Theoretical approaches to the study of the family and family forms.
SOCI 415.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

SOCI 418.name: Social Statistics II
SOCI 418.desc: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology.
SOCI 418.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

SOCI 420.name: Sociology of the Environment
SOCI 420.desc: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment.

SOCI 425.name: Urban Sociology
SOCI 425.desc: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods.

SOCI 430.name: Global Citizenship
SOCI 430.desc: Sociology approaches to global citizenship, including its contested nature and intellectual lineage.

SOCI 433.name: Directed Studies
SOCI 433.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
SOCI 433.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. And permission of the Department.

SOCI 435.name: International Service Learning
SOCI 435.desc: International field placement normally for eight to ten weeks; pre-departure seminars (eight to twelve seminars or equivalent) with student presentation seminars upon return from the field.

SOCI 440.name: Economic Sociology
SOCI 440.desc: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology.

SOCI 449.name: Honours Tutorial
SOCI 449.desc: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program.

SOCI 461.name: Political Sociology
SOCI 461.desc: The social and economic bases of political power. May include studies of the state and interstate relations, ideology and control, alienation and anomie, political movements and social revolutions, political violence and terrorism, and the political economy of world conflict.

SOCI 464.name: Social Movements
SOCI 464.desc: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies.

SOCI 465.name: Sociology of the Arts
SOCI 465.desc: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured.

SOCI 466.name: Sociology of Education
SOCI 466.desc: Examines the role of schooling in modern society including links with inequality, knowledge production, socialization and the economy.

SOCI 469.name: Queer Theory and Politics
SOCI 469.desc: Empirical expressions and political possibilities of queer theory.
SOCI 469.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.

SOCI 470.name: Sociology of Crime and Justice
SOCI 470.desc: Critical examination of specific forms of crime and delinquency in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Issues selected for study will be further scrutinized within the cultural framework of ethics, morality, and social justice.

SOCI 473.name: Sociology of Mental Illness
SOCI 473.desc: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population.

SOCI 479.name: Social Determinants of Health
SOCI 479.desc: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations.

SOCI 480.name: Urban Ethnographic Field School (UEFS)
SOCI 480.desc: Approximately 50 hours of volunteering and fieldwork based in community organizations with theoretical approaches to urban spaces. Students will engage in collaborative research while considering a range of theoretical and methodological approaches.
SOCI 480.prer: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. Or permission of the instructor(s)
preq: SOCI 102. Or permission of the instructor(s)

SOCI 484.name: Sociology of Health and Illness
SOCI 484.desc: Sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care as represented in classic and contemporary sociological studies of selected topics such as illness experience, social aspects of the practice of health professionals, training of health professionals, and the social organization of health delivery systems.

SOCI 495.name: Advanced Studies in Sociology
SOCI 495.desc: An intensive examination of selected topics in Sociology. Consult the department for this year's offerings.

HESO 400.name: Sociocultural Determinants of Health
HESO 400.desc: Methods for analyzing population health data and medical research reporting.

ANAT 393.name: Human Anatomy for Physical Therapy Students
ANAT 393.desc: Microscopic systems anatomy and regional anatomy of the nervous system. [3-0-0]
ANAT 393.prer: Registration in Rehabilitation Sciences (RSPT) is required.

ANAT 400.name: Human Anatomy
ANAT 400.desc: A correlated course of study for medical and dental students of the structure of the human body including gross and radiological anatomy and embryology. Clinics are held in cooperation with the Departments of Medicine, Orthopaedics, Surgery and Family Practice. Both terms.

ANAT 401.name: Microscopic Human Anatomy
ANAT 401.desc: A survey course for medical and dental students of the microscopic structure of the human body as studied by light and electron microscopy. Lectures and laboratory sessions. Both terms.

ANAT 425.name: Elements of Neuroanatomy
ANAT 425.desc: An introduction to the structure of the human nervous system. Given only in conjunction with PHYL 425.  (Open to Medical and Dental students only.)

ANAT 448.name: Directed Studies in Anatomy
ANAT 448.desc: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

ELEC 361.name: Molecules to Mechanisms
ELEC 361.desc: Forces, scaling, thermal, fluidic, and mechanical properties relevant to the design of emerging devices and systems whose basic structures are at micrometer and nanometer scales.

ELEC 400.name: Topics in Electrical Engineering
ELEC 400.desc: Lectures or projects on subjects of current interest.

ELEC 416.name: Quantum Dots and Device Applications
ELEC 416.desc: Theory and modeling techniques of 0-dimensional structures. Electronic, magnetic, and optical properties of quantum dots. Current and future applications of quantum dots including: single electron transistors, quantum dot lasers, optical detectors.

ELEC 452.name: Industrial Drives
ELEC 452.desc: Typical mechanical loads; dynamic and static characteristics and analysis of DC and AC drives; microprocessor-based controllers; commercial choices of drives for various applications.
ELEC 452.prer: One of EECE 373, ELEC 342, EECE 376, ELEC 343.

ELEC 464.name: Nanotechnology and Nature
ELEC 464.desc: Examples of nature's fabrication methods, sensors, actuators, energy harvesting, signaling and information processing, and comparisons with artificial methods.

ELEC 472.name: Biomechatronics
ELEC 472.desc: Design of mechatronic systems to measure and manipulate biological materials and processes; compliant structures; bioelectronic circuits; biomedical embedded systems and BioMEMS.  Example applications from clinical medicine and biomedical research.  Credit will be granted for only one of MECH 423 or EECE 424.
ELEC 472.prer: One of EECE 251, ELEC 201 and one of EECE 253, ELEC 202 and one of EECE 259, CPEN 211 and one of EECE 360, ELEC 341.

ELEC 499.name: Undergraduate Thesis
ELEC 499.desc: Project in electrical engineering or computer engineering involving design, experimental and/or computer simulation work as selected from topics supplied by faculty members. An individual project thesis is to be prepared according to specifications available from the departmental office.

ACAM 300.name: Dis/Orienting Asian Canada
ACAM 300.desc: The histories, cultures, social dynamics, and life experiences of Asian communities in Canada in the context of global migrations. Restricted to students with second year status or higher.

ACAM 320.name: Selected Topics in ACAM Studies
ACAM 320.desc: Selected Asian Canadian Asian Migration topics. Consult acam.arts.ubc.ca for this year's offerings.
ACAM 320.prer: Restricted to students with at least Second year standing; a previous course in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies is recommended.
preq: Restricted to students with at least Second year standing; a previous course in Asian Canadian

ACAM 447.name: Directed Studies in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration
ACAM 447.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking within the scope of Asian Canadian and Asian Migration.
ACAM 447.prer: Permission of the Chair of the ACAM program.
preq: Permission of the Chair of the ACAM program

FIPR 235.name: Image Concepts for Filmmakers
FIPR 235.desc: The theory and practice involved in creating images for film and media.

FIPR 269.name: Special Topics in Film Production
FIPR 269.desc: A topic of current interest in film production.  Topic will change from year to year.

FIPR 299.name: Directed Studies: On-Campus Research
FIPR 299.desc: On-campus film production field research. Based on film project work on campus productions. Restricted to Film Production students except with permission. Contact department.

FIPR 399.name: Directed Studies: Off-Campus Research
FIPR 399.desc: Off-campus film production field research. Based on film project work outside the university.

FIPR 435.name: Alternative Cinema Production
FIPR 435.desc: Experimental approaches to content, structure, technology and style in film and media production. Students who have not yet completed FIPR 233, 234, 337, 339, must complete them at the same time as FIPR 333.
FIPR 435.crer: All of FIPR 233, FIPR 234, FIPR 337, FIPR 339.

FIPR 436.name: Documentary Development and Production
FIPR 436.desc: Documentary concept development, essential production techniques, and marketing.

FIPR 469.name: Special Projects
FIPR 469.desc: Advanced film production, including interdisciplinary projects.

CLST 308.name: Roman Law
CLST 308.desc: The development of Roman private law during the classical period with special attention to family law, contract and delict.

CLST 311.name: Women in the Bronze Age, Classical Greek and Hellenistic Cultures
CLST 311.desc: The images projected in mythology, literature, and art are compared with realities of women's lives insofar as they can be reconstructed from historical, legal, and archaeological records.

CLST 314.name: Latin Epic
CLST 314.desc: The development of the epic genre in Latin, with detailed study of Vergil's

CLST 318.name: Classical Comedy
CLST 318.desc: The plays of the Greek and Roman comic dramatists: Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence, in translation.

CLST 319.name: The Roman Army
CLST 319.desc: Rome's military from the early Republic to the Imperial period. Topics range from those of a military nature such as equipment and strategy to social topics such as policing and marriage of soldiers.

CLST 320.name: Slavery in the Ancient Greek and Roman World
CLST 320.desc: The study and history of slavery in the Greek and Roman worlds as a political, legal, economic, social, and cultural phenomenon.

CLST 334.name: Roman Religion
CLST 334.desc: Roman religions between the ninth century BC and the second century AD, including mystery religions, love magic, emperor worship, and early Christianity, with particular attention devoted to the primary sources. Some knowledge of ancient Rome is recommended.

CLST 352.name: The Roman Republic
CLST 352.desc: Rome from the foundation to the Augustan settlement. Constitutional development; the workings and failure of the Republican political system; acquisition and growth of Empire; the political, social, and economic consequences of imperialism.

CLST 360.name: Life and Society in Classical Antiquity
CLST 360.desc: Topics in Greek and Roman life and society.

CLST 401.name: Seminar in Classical History
CLST 401.desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman history, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

CLST 402.name: Seminar in Classical Literature
CLST 402.desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman literature, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

CLST 403.name: Seminar in Classical Art and Archaeology
CLST 403.desc: Selected topics in Greek or Roman art and archaeology, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

CLST 404.name: Seminar in the Reception of the Classical World
CLST 404.desc: Selected topics in the reception of the classicial world in its own time and in later eras, with an emphasis on research. Prerequisite: at least one 3-credit upper-level course of content appropriate for the topic of the seminar (to be established by individual instructors). Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

GREK 401.name: Greek Prose
GREK 401.desc: Studies in history, philosophy and/or oratory. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 401.

GREK 402.name: Greek Verse
GREK 402.desc: Studies in epic, tragedy and/or comedy. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 402.

SCAN 332.name: Topics in Scandinavian Studies (in English)
SCAN 332.desc: Selected issues and topics in Scandinavian cultural studies.

SCAN 334.name: Contemporary Scandinavian Fiction (in English)
SCAN 334.desc: Study of texts, topics, or genres against the background of current Scandinavian literary, social, and political developments.

SCAN 337.name: Scandinavian Cinema (in English)
SCAN 337.desc: An introduction to the cinemas of the Scandinavian region.

SCAN 411.name: Scandinavian Drama and Film in Translation
SCAN 411.desc: Traces the explosive development of a provincial theatre into one of the seminal forces of twentieth-century drama and film. Emphasis on Ibsen, Strindberg, and Bergman.

SCAN 412.name: The Northern European Epic in Translation
SCAN 412.desc: Major prose works of the Scandinavian literatures with emphasis on the stylistic qualities of the Old Icelandic sagas and their transformation in the novels of modern Icelandic, Danish, Swedish, and Norwegian writers. Possible authors: Laxness, Blixen, Hamsun, Lindgren.

SCAN 413.name: The Literatures of the Baltic in English Translation
SCAN 413.desc: An examination through literature of the historical, cultural, and ethnic elements that have made the Baltic area the crossroads of northeastern Europe. The emphasis is on literature from the Germanic  and Finno-Ugric languages. Authors to be studied include Strindberg, Tikkanen, Transtromer, Kaplinski, Grass, Bobrowski, Lenz.

SCAN 415.name: The World of the Sagas (in English)
SCAN 415.desc: Scandinavian contributions to medieval and early modern world literature, culture and history.

EDUC 141.desc: For students in the Indigenous Teacher Education Program (NITEP) only.

EDUC 442.desc: Post-practicum students will explore how a school program may need to be modified in order to integrate more fully First Nations history, content, and world views.

EDUC 449.name: Supervised Research Investigation
EDUC 449.desc: Available only to outstanding students approved by the Associate Dean (Teacher Education).

AUDI 400.desc: Frameworks from linguistics, psychology, and speech and hearing sciences as applied to communication disorders, clinical populations and practices. [3-0]

CRWR 417.name: Play Development Workshop
CRWR 417.desc: An interdisciplinary course, in cooperation with the Theatre program, emphasizing script development through scene work, character development and stagecraft.
CRWR 417.prer: Manuscript submission or equivalent theatre experience.

CRWR 440.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
CRWR 440.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

CRWR 455.name: Writing Creative Nonfiction II
