CRWR 476.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR 477.name: Special Projects in Writing Drama for the Stage
CRWR 477.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR 479.name: Special Projects in Writing Fiction
CRWR 479.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in this genre.

CRWR 480.name: Special Projects in Literary Translation
CRWR 480.desc: For students who receive departmental permission to do advanced work in translation.

CRWR 490.name: Directed Reading
CRWR 490.desc: The course will emphasize current trends and techniques rather than critical evaluation. Not offered every year.

RMST 420.name: Studies in Romance Languages and Literature

RMST 468.name: Romance Linguistics
RMST 468.desc: The Indo-European background; Classical and Vulgar Latin; the origin, development and spread of the Romance languages; their vocabulary, phonology, morphology, syntax; vernacular Latin texts and Romance texts.
RMST 468.prer: Two years study of each of two Romance languages or two years of one Romance language and one year of Latin.
preq: Two years study of each of two Romance languages
two years of one Romance language

RMST 495.name: Research Intensive Seminar in Romance Studies

POLI 301.name: Canadian Political Parties
POLI 301.desc: The organization and operation of party politics and the systems of party competition in Canada. The focus is on national-level politics.

POLI 302.name: Public Administration
POLI 302.desc: The structure and organization of the administrative branch of government in theory and practice. Administrative powers and policy-making in the modern state. Examples of the administrative processes are drawn from Canada and other countries.

POLI 305.name: Canadian Political Ideas
POLI 305.desc: Political theories and ideologies in Canada.

POLI 306.name: Local Government and Politics in Canada
POLI 306.desc: Local and regional political institutions and processes in Canada, with particular attention to those of Vancouver and other British Columbia localities.

POLI 307.name: Quebec Government and Politics
POLI 307.desc: The nature of politics and the conduct of government in contemporary Quebec. The course is open to students from fields other than political science.

POLI 308.name: Issues in Canadian Politics
POLI 308.desc: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 316.name: Global Indigenous Politics
POLI 316.desc: The political dynamics of Indigenous peoples’ politics on the global level; the legal and practical realities of colonization as a global Indigenous experience; current global Indigenous political issues and avenues of Indigenous resistance.

POLI 320.name: Government and Politics of the United States of America
POLI 320.desc: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.

POLI 321.name: Chinese Politics and Development
POLI 321.desc: The course will explore various aspects of Chinese politics and the dynamics of China’s development since 1949.  Topics include: the Cultural Revolution, political reform and protest, and economic reform policies and their consequences.

POLI 322.name: Japanese Government and Politics
POLI 322.desc: A general introduction to modern Japanese politics from various theoretical and comparative perspectives.

POLI 323.name: South Asian Government and Politics
POLI 323.desc: Comparative analysis of politics and government in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. Imperial legacies and nationalist movements; political institution-building amidst socio-cultural diversity; parties and interest groups; elections and leadership crises; military intervention; ethnic and class conflicts; foreign policy.

POLI 324.name: Southeast Asian Government and Politics
POLI 324.desc: The political systems of contemporary Southeast Asia.

POLI 325.name: Communist and Post-Communist Politics
POLI 325.desc: An examination of the origins, development, and demise of Communist political systems, as well as the nature of post-Communist politics, with special emphasis on the Soviet Union and its successor states.

POLI 328.name: Topics in Comparative Politics
POLI 328.desc: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 329.name: Gender and Politics
POLI 329.desc: Relations between gender and political processes and institutions, including the impact of globalization and economic development.

POLI 330.name: Japanese Political Economy
POLI 330.desc: Issues in contemporary Japanese political economy, including industrial policy, the Keiretsu groupings, the main-bank system, trends toward deregulation, and business-labour relations.

POLI 331.name: Korean Government and Politics
POLI 331.desc: An introduction to the politics of Korea. The evolution of Korean politics from authoritarian rule to democratic transition, focusing on present and future political, economic and social issues.

POLI 333.name: Issues in Comparative Politics
POLI 333.desc: An examination of a major issue in comparative politics (e.g., the media, gender, nationalism, ethnic conflict). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 334.name: Comparative Democratization
POLI 334.desc: Literatures and theories on regime democratization around the world; the roles of political, economic, social, and international factors in encouraging or impeding democratization.

POLI 335.name: Comparative Federalism
POLI 335.desc: An empirical and normative analysis of federalism as a way of structuring political life in industrialized democracies, investigating explanations for the design, persistence and operation of federal systems.

POLI 336.name: Associations and the State in Comparative Perspective
POLI 336.desc: How organised groups (civil society organizations, NGOs, interest groups) interact with governments in a variety of countries.

POLI 337.name: The U.S. Presidency in Comparative Perspective
POLI 337.desc: Executive leadership of the U.S. presidency in comparison to the leadership of other Anglo-American systems, including the U.K., Canada, and Australia.

POLI 340.name: History of Political Ideas
POLI 340.desc: An introduction to the political ideas of leading political philosophers from Ancient Greece to the 19th century.

POLI 341.name: Contemporary Political Theory
POLI 341.desc: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

POLI 342.name: Modern Political Theory: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
POLI 342.desc: A detailed examination of an acknowledged masterpiece of modern political theory. The text and attendant literature vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 343.name: Theories of State and Society
POLI 343.desc: Classical origins of contemporary theories of the state, market, and civil society, focused on the relationship between social order, politics, and democracy. Readings from Smith, Toqueville, Weber, and contemporary sources.

POLI 344.name: Social and Political Thought
POLI 344.desc: An examination of some of the major concepts in political philosophy such as justice, equality, rights, obligation, liberty in the context of both classical and contemporary political thought.

POLI 346.name: Democratic Theory
POLI 346.desc: An examination of both classical and contemporary theories of democracy. Representative democratic theory, participatory democratic theory, and their relationship to twentieth century concepts of democracy.

POLI 347.name: Law and Political Theory
POLI 347.desc: An examination of law and political theory that considers topics such as sovereignty, constitutionalism, civil disobedience, rights and the political role of judges.

POLI 348.name: Political Theory and Public Policy
POLI 348.desc: Application of frameworks to policy questions that factor in debates about citizenship and social inclusion, and an examination of contemporary normative frameworks that fall along, and transcend, the left-right political spectrum.

POLI 350.name: Public Policy
POLI 350.desc: An introduction to public policy: rationales for government intervention, the influence of interest groups and political institutions on policy outcomes, and the various stages in the policy process.

POLI 351.name: Environmental Politics and Policy
POLI 351.desc: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments.

POLI 352.name: Comparative Politics of Public Policy
POLI 352.desc: Policy making across industrialized democracies, with a focus on North America and Europe.

POLI 360.name: Security Studies
POLI 360.desc: The contemporary international security context: reorientation of the study of security, patterns of inter- and intrastate conflict and communal violence, dilemmas of international response and conflict management.

POLI 361.name: International Violence and Its Control
POLI 361.desc: A study of the nature of international violence from guerrilla to nuclear war; a survey of theories of the causes of interstate war; recent research findings on the causes of war and conditions for peace; a comparative analysis of strategies for controlling violence through disarmament and the promotion of alternative means of conflict resolution.

POLI 362.name: The Great Powers and International Politics
POLI 362.desc: An examination of the changing nature of Great Power relations, including procedures and institutions for managing their conflicts, in the pre-Cold War, Cold War, and post-Cold War international systems.

POLI 363.name: Canadian Foreign Policy
POLI 363.desc: An analysis of Canadian foreign policy on important international issues since the 1960s and of the policy-making process. Issues may include defence commitments, economic relations, activities of international organizations, and relations with the US, Europe, USSR, Asia and the Third World.

POLI 364.name: International Organizations
POLI 364.desc: Analysis of the activities and influence of modern international organizations in international security, economic, and social issue areas. The course will focus on organizations associated with the United Nations, but other world and regional bodies will be analysed as well.

POLI 365.name: Asian International Relations
POLI 365.desc: Analysis of the foreign policies of one or more of the states of East, Southeast, and South Asia; their relations with other states in the region as well as with major outside powers.

POLI 367.name: International Relations Theory and the International System
POLI 367.desc: The evolution of the international system and empirical and normative theories of international relations such as realism, liberalism, and Marxism.

POLI 368.name: Japan's Foreign Relations
POLI 368.desc: Japan's security policy, aid policy, relations with the United States and with neighbouring Asian nations, role in the United Nations and other international institutions.

POLI 369.name: Issues in International Security
POLI 369.desc: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 370.name: Issues in International Conflict Management
POLI 370.desc: Problems of managing conflict in the international system (e.g., intervention, mediation, sanctions). Topics will vary from year to year.

POLI 374.name: International Peacekeeping
POLI 374.desc: The development of peacekeeping within and outside the United Nations system and as an instrument of conflict management.

POLI 375.name: Global Environmental Politics
POLI 375.desc: Ecological consequences of the global political economy.

POLI 376.name: International Law
POLI 376.desc: The nature, sources, and sanctions of international law; the notion of nationhood with particular reference to the status of the British Dominions; territorial and extra-territorial jurisdiction; diplomatic and sovereign immunities; international delinquency; treaties; settlement of disputes; international organizations. This course  may not be taken for credit in both Arts and Law.

POLI 381.name: Topics in Quantitative Analysis
POLI 381.desc: Application of quantitative techniques to selected topics in Political Science. Topics vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 385.name: Public Opinion and Elections
POLI 385.desc: Psychological and social foundations of public opinion; quality of democratic decision-making; how voters make up their minds; impact of electoral systems; social bases of party systems; campaigns and the mass media. The Canadian experience in comparative context.

POLI 401.name: Canadian Provincial and Regional Politics
POLI 401.desc: Seminar examines political parties, processes, and institutions in the provincial political systems and regional arrangements between provinces.
POLI 401.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI 402.name: Law and Politics of the Canadian Constitution
POLI 402.desc: Seminar on the origins and development of the Canadian Constitution: the political aspects of federalism and the legal consequences of the Charter of Rights.
POLI 402.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI 403.name: The Political Economy of Canada
POLI 403.desc: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the interplay of economic and social factors in the shaping of Canadian politics: the major issues and strains in the functioning of the Canadian polity.
POLI 403.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI 404.name: Public Policy and Its Administration
POLI 404.desc: Political and administrative aspects of public policy, particularly in Canada.
POLI 404.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308, POLI 350, POLI 351, POLI 352.

POLI 405.name: Topics in Canadian Politics
POLI 405.desc: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
POLI 405.prer: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

POLI 406.name: Aboriginal Peoples and Canadian Politics
POLI 406.desc: Seminar in political structures, activities, and demands of aboriginal peoples; policies of federal, provincial, and territorial governments; relations between these governments and aboriginal peoples; role of the courts and the Constitution.
POLI 406.prer: POLI 101 and at least 3 credits from POLI 301–308.

POLI 420.name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics
POLI 420.desc: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 420.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.
preq: Two of POLI 220 POLI 320 POLI 321 POLI 322 POLI 323 POLI 324 POLI 325 POLI 326 POLI 327 POLI 328 POLI 329 POLI 330 POLI 331 POLI 332 POLI 333 POLI 350 POLI 351

POLI 421.name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics: Non-Western
POLI 421.desc: A seminar devoted to comparative analysis of politics in non-western states. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 421.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.
preq: Two of POLI 220 POLI 320 POLI 321 POLI 322 POLI 323 POLI 324 POLI 325 POLI 326 POLI 327 POLI 328 POLI 329 POLI 330 POLI 331 POLI 332 POLI 333 POLI 350 POLI 351

POLI 422.name: Selected Problems in Comparative Politics
POLI 422.desc: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 422.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.
preq: Two of POLI 220 POLI 320 POLI 321 POLI 322 POLI 323 POLI 324 POLI 325 POLI 326 POLI 327 POLI 328 POLI 329 POLI 330 POLI 331 POLI 332 POLI 333 POLI 350 POLI 351

POLI 423.name: Issues in Comparative Politics
POLI 423.desc: Seminar in comparative analysis of constitutionalism, authoritarianism, democracy, etc. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 423.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.
preq: Two of POLI 220 POLI 320 POLI 321 POLI 322 POLI 323 POLI 324 POLI 325 POLI 326 POLI 327 POLI 328 POLI 329 POLI 330 POLI 331 POLI 332 POLI 333 POLI 350 POLI 351

POLI 426.name: Seminar on Comparative Parties and Party Systems
POLI 426.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.
preq: Two of POLI 220 POLI 320 POLI 321 POLI 322 POLI 323 POLI 324 POLI 325 POLI 326 POLI 327 POLI 328 POLI 329 POLI 330 POLI 331 POLI 332 POLI 333 POLI 350 POLI 351

POLI 427.name: Issues in Chinese Politics and Development
POLI 427.desc: Seminar examines one issue in Chinese politics (e.g., environmental politics, local government, state-society relations) from a broadly comparative perspective.

POLI 429.name: Seminar in Issues in Gender and Politics
POLI 429.prer: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 345, POLI 350, POLI 351.
preq: Two of POLI 220 POLI 320 POLI 321 POLI 322 POLI 323 POLI 324 POLI 325 POLI 326 POLI 327 POLI 328 POLI 329 POLI 330 POLI 331 POLI 332 POLI 333 POLI 345 POLI 350 POLI 351

POLI 440.name: Contemporary Political Theory
POLI 440.desc: This seminar examines the political ideas of leading political philosophers of the twentieth century. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 441.name: Interpretation and Criticism in Political Theory
POLI 441.desc: Approaches to political criticism: Critical Theory, Foucauldian genealogy, critical realism, and feminism, including forms of domination, which shape people's beliefs and self-conceptions.

POLI 442.name: Contemporary Political Theorists: Analysis of a Selected Theorist
POLI 442.desc: This seminar examines in detail the political ideas of an important political philosopher of the twentieth century. The theorist studied varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

POLI 443.name: MODERN WESTERN POLITICAL THOUGHT
POLI 443.desc: Seminar: Texts in the history of modern Western political thought, such as works by Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Karl Marx, Alexis de Tocqueville, John Stuart Mill, Friedrich Nietzsche, Max Weber, and Sigmund Freud.

POLI 445.name: Critical Theory: Policitical Theory and the Problems of Race
POLI 445.desc: Traditions of critical social theory, broadly construed, to examine the modern politics of 'race,' racism, and racialized identities.

POLI 446.name: Multiculturalism and Identity Politics
POLI 446.desc: Seminar will examines how "identity" is theorized in contemporary political thought, beginning with the role that identity plays in the "western" canon and proceeding to examine feminist, multicultural, queer, and post-colonial theories of citizenship along with their critics.

POLI 448.name: Democratic Theory
POLI 448.desc: Overview of traditional democratic theory with close readings of several contemporary theories, such as those of Habermas, Rawls, and Arendt. Readings are drawn from complete original texts, and assessment is based on a research essay.

POLI 450.name: Policy Analysis
POLI 450.desc: Practical skills for generating written and oral analysis for a client or supervisor.
POLI 450.prer: Either (a) POLI 101 and one of POLI 302, POLI 306, POLI 350;  or (b) all of POLI 350, POLI 352.

POLI 460.name: Foreign Policy Analysis
POLI 460.desc: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the foreign policies of one or more states, as well as to the study of literature pertaining to foreign policy analysis. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
POLI 460.prer: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.
preq: Two of POLI 260 POLI 360 POLI 361 POLI 362 POLI 363 POLI 364 POLI 365 POLI 366 POLI 367 POLI 368 POLI 369 POLI 370

POLI 464.name: Problems in International Relations
POLI 464.desc: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

POLI 466.name: The Politics of International Law
POLI 466.desc: Seminar on the origins and politics of international law, and its impact on international affairs; the laws of war, human rights, environment, law of the sea, and international criminal law.

ANTH 200.name: Introduction to Problems in Method and Theory in Anthropology
ANTH 200.desc: A survey of basic concepts and procedures in the cross-cultural study of human societies.

ANTH 201.name: Ethnic Relations
ANTH 201.desc: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

ANTH 202.name: Contemporary Social Problems
ANTH 202.desc: Cultural background to contemporary events; problems of nationalism and regional conflicts, economic and social development, gender, religion and social change. Course may stress a different region of the world in different years.

ANTH 214.name: The Family in Cross-Cultural Perspective
ANTH 214.desc: A cross-cultural comparison of family and kinship to provide an understanding of variations in the structure and meaning of marriage relations; forms of domestic organization; and the sexual division of labour, property, and inheritance.

ANTH 221.name: Contemporary Indigenous Cultural Expressions
ANTH 221.desc: Forms and styles of indigenous expressive arts, and their current place in the lives of Indigenous Peoples.

ANTH 300.name: Contemporary Anthropological Theory
ANTH 300.desc: Contemporary approaches to society and culture in anthropology.

ANTH 303.name: Ethnography of Special Areas
ANTH 303.desc: A specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems in one area. Different culture areas or regions may be selected each term. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

ANTH 304.name: Ethnography of the Northwest Coast
ANTH 304.desc: Specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems of the region.

ANTH 307.name: Ethnography of Korea
ANTH 307.desc: An exploration of ethnographic, topical, and theoretical issues.

ANTH 316.name: Political Anthropology
ANTH 316.desc: Comparative study of political organization; leadership and non-centralized and centralized political systems.

ANTH 317.name: Linguistic Anthropology
ANTH 317.desc: A survey of the ethnographic uses of language data and the techniques of linguistic analysis.

ANTH 329.name: Contemporary First Nations Issues
ANTH 329.desc: Anthropological perspectives on contemporary issues of public policy, law, and political activity, as they affect the place of First Nations people in British Columbia and Canada.

ANTH 330.name: Anthropology of Rural Peoples and the Global Economy
ANTH 330.desc: A comparative study of rural peoples (such as small-scale horticulturists, artisans and craft workers, peasants, fisherfolk, or industrial/manufacturing workers) in the global economy.

ANTH 331.name: Art, Aesthetics and Anthropology
ANTH 331.desc: Anthropological perspectives on art, aesthetics, and expressive culture.

ANTH 333.name: Language and Power
ANTH 333.desc: A sociolinguistic examination of the role of language in articulating, maintaining, and subverting power relations in society.

ANTH 341.name: Museums, Heritage and Memory
ANTH 341.desc: Museums, galleries, monuments, and other cultural institutions' relations to our perception of history and geography.

ANTH 350.name: Ethnography of the Pacific Islands: Polynesia and Micronesia
ANTH 350.desc: Major cultural groupings in Polynesia and Micronesia, emphasizing both traditional cultures and the incorporation of the region into modern international institutions.

ANTH 351.name: Ethnography of the Pacific Islands: Melanesia
ANTH 351.desc: Major cultural groupings in Melanesia, emphasizing both traditional cultures and the incorporation of the region into modern international institutions.

ANTH 353.name: Ethnography of Latin America
ANTH 353.desc: Indigenous peoples of Latin America, emphasizing both pre-Columbian cultural traditions and socioeconomic and cultural changes from the Colonial period to the present.

ANTH 400.name: History of Anthropology
ANTH 400.desc: The development of anthropological theory and practice in institutional contexts.

ANTH 402.name: Ethnography of China
ANTH 402.desc: Advanced studies in the ethnography of China, premodern and contemporary. Topics may include kinship, rural and urban social structure, stratification and mobility, religion, national power structures, and social change in Chinese society.

ANTH 403.name: Ethnography of Special Areas
ANTH 403.desc: An advanced study of ethnographic and theoretical problems. A different region may be studied each term.

ANTH 404.name: Ethnography in Circumpolar North: Comparative Perspectives
ANTH 404.desc: An examination of relationships between indigenous people and nation states in Greenland, Canada, Alaska and Siberia, using ethnographic methods.

ANTH 408.name: Field Methods
ANTH 408.desc: Intensive examination and application of selected methods of ethnographic data-collection, e.g., visual anthropology, anthropological interviewing, genealogies, ethnographic semantics, life histories, oral traditions. Consult department for current description.

ANTH 409.name: Topics in Applied Anthropology
ANTH 409.desc: Advanced study of the theory and practice of applied, action, and consultancy anthropology. Topics may include the application of anthropology to questions of aboriginal rights and title, education, medicine, development, women and development, tourism, and other social issues.

ANTH 412.name: Advanced Topics in the Anthropology of Gender
ANTH 412.desc: Contemporary theory employed in the anthropological study of gender.

ANTH 413.name: Relatedness: Family, Kinship, and Social Relations
ANTH 413.desc: A cross-cultural survey of the social and cultural bases of relatedness including changing family relationships, kinship, and social organization, based on theoretical analysis and case studies.

ANTH 414.name: Anthropology of Globalization
ANTH 414.desc: Theories on the global flow of people, commodities, images, and ideas with critical ethnographic attention to the different ways people respond to globalization.

ANTH 415.name: Religion and Society
ANTH 415.desc: Comparative study of religious beliefs, practices, and movements; relations between religious, social, and political institutions; religion as a force for stability and change; anthropological/sociological theories of religion.

ANTH 416.name: The Ethnography of Japan
ANTH 416.desc: Ethnographies about Japan and processes of conducting fieldwork on Japan, covering topics such as work, leisure, identity, tradition, popular culture, rural/urban lifestyles, gender, sexuality, internationalization.

ANTH 417.name: Language, Culture, and Cognition
ANTH 417.desc: The relationships between linguistic and cultural phenomena; how language affects normative and cognitive systems of thought and behaviour.
ANTH 417.prer: One of ANTH 100, LING 200. May be taken as co-requisites.
preq: LING 200. May be taken as co-requisites

ANTH 421.name: The Anthropology of Place and Space
ANTH 421.desc: An anthropological understanding of the spatial dimensions of social practice, and the relationships of space to culture, history, and power.

ANTH 422.name: Modes of Subsistence
ANTH 422.desc: The nature of subsistence systems antedating or alternative to modern commercial systems. Introductory survey with basic readings; focus on problems such as the development of complex cultures without agriculture, the ambiguity of hunting and gathering, agricultural and other "intensification", "orchestration" of the use of adjacent microenvironments. Of interest to students of archaeology, anthropology and cultural geography.

ANTH 423.name: Ethnography of East Africa and the Swahili Coast
ANTH 423.desc: The everyday lives of people who inhabit East Africa and the Swahili Coast, and consideration of slave trade, long distance migration, colonialism, nationalism, independence movements, religion, identity politics, music, gender, sexuality, health, ecotourism and conservation.

ANTH 427.name: Topics in Medical Anthropology
ANTH 427.desc: Anthropological perspectives on health, illness, and disability as represented by classic and contemporary research in selected topics in medical anthropology including disease and human evolution, illness and human ecology, culture and epidemiology, ethnomedical systems, the relationship between folk and biomedicine and the cultural construction and social organization of health care, illness and disability. Specific content will vary from year to year. Consult the Department brochure.

ANTH 431.name: Museum Practice and Curatorship
ANTH 431.desc: Management of museum collections and their public presentation, addressing questions of access, collaboration, and cultural property. The public interpretation of anthropological concepts and materials utilizing the programs and facilities of the Museum of Anthropology.

ANTH 432.name: The Anthropology of Public Representation
ANTH 432.desc: The public presentation and interpretation of anthropological concepts and materials utilizing the programs and facilities of the Museum of Anthropology.
ANTH 432.prer: ANTH 341. Permission of the department is also acceptable.
preq: ANTH 341. Permission of the department is also acceptable

ANTH 433.name: Directed Studies
ANTH 433.desc: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student. No more than six credits of Directed Studies may be taken for credit toward the Major or Honours program.

ANTH 435.name: The Japanese Tea Ceremony: Ethnography of Performance, Practice, and Ritual
ANTH 435.desc: An exploration of Chanoyu, Japanese Tea Practice, as a culturally embedded ritual, performance, and aesthetic form, and as a way of understanding underlying elements of Japanese culture. This course has a studio component and a nominal fee may be charged.

ANTH 449.name: Honours Tutorial
ANTH 449.desc: Will usually require the presentation of at least one research paper.

ANTH 452.name: Conservation of Inorganic Materials
ANTH 452.desc: Conservation of inorganic materials within a museum environment; the nature of materials, mechanisms of deterioration and principles of preventive conservation. Recommended for students intending to work with cultural materials.

ANTH 461.name: Anthropological Study of Local Ecological Knowledge
ANTH 461.desc: Analysis of the concepts of ecological anthropology via the medium of local ecological knowledge. ANTH 360 is recommended as background.

ANTH 462.name: Special Topics in Ecological Anthropology
ANTH 462.desc: May include environmental discourse and social movements, anthropological contributions to ecological management systems, or examination of emerging issues in the field.  ANTH 360 is recommended as background.

ANTH 470.name: Topics in Contemporary Theory
ANTH 470.desc: Selected topics in contemporary social and cultural theory which contribute to anthropological analyses. Topics may include Marxist anthropology, critical theory, theories of culture, phenomenology, behavioural ecology, structuralism, hermeneutics, formal theory and examination of specific social theorists.

ANTH 472.name: Anthropological Study of Social Inequality
ANTH 472.desc: An anthropological perspective on the historical origins and theoretical explanations of social inequality.

ANTH 478.name: Ethnographic Film Methods
ANTH 478.desc: Ethnographic digital video production, including methods of ethnographic fieldwork, creation of field notes, and research design; basics of digital video planning, production, and editing. Production fees are charged for this course. Prerequisite: ANTH 378 is recommended.

ANTH 480.name: Urban Ethnographic Field School (UEFS)
ANTH 480.desc: A combination of approximately 50 hours of volunteering and fieldwork based in community organizations with theoretical approaches to urban spaces.  Students will engage in collaborative research while considering a range of theoretical and methodological approaches.

ANTH 495.name: Advanced Studies in Anthropology
ANTH 495.desc: An intensive examination of selected topics in Anthropology. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

AFST 250.name: Introduction to African Studies
AFST 250.desc: Cultural, historical, and geographical issues of African Studies.

AFST 351.name: Perspectives in African Studies: Literary and Theoretical Approaches
AFST 351.crer: AFST 250. Credit will not be given for both AFST 350 and 351
creq: AFST 250. Credit will not be given for both AFST 350

AFST 352.name: Perspectives in African Studies: A Social Science Approach
AFST 352.crer: AFST 250. Credit will not be given for both AFST 350 and 352
creq: AFST 250. Credit will not be given for both AFST 350

AFST 380.name: Study of Sociolinguistics of a Selected African Language
AFST 380.desc: Selected African language with emphasis on major syntactic structures, vocabulary, conversation patterns, reading short texts, and the cultural and historical contexts of language use.

AFST 450.name: African Diasporic Culture in African Canadian Communities
AFST 450.desc: African diasporic culture in Canadian society, fostering dialogue with members of African Canadian communities on cultural values, traditions, memory, adaptation and change.

VISA 270.name: Special Studies
VISA 270.desc: Introduction to various aspects of contemporary studio practice. Not offered every year.
VISA 270.prer: A score of 72% or higher in one of VISA 110, VISA 180, VISA 183.

VISA 280.name: Contemporary Art: Ideas as Practice II
VISA 280.desc: Development and history of contemporary art practice, with a focus on how artists realize and exchange ideas. Intended for second year BFA VISA students.
VISA 280.prer: A score of 72% or higher in VISA 183.

VISA 352.name: Intermediate Print Media III: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Image Production
VISA 352.desc: Lithographic printing; suitable for students interested in drawing and print media interface in context of contemporary art; related digital and photographic technologies employed.
VISA 352.prer: Either (a) one of VISA 220, VISA 250 or (b) one of VISA 281, FINA 281, VISA 283, VISA 284, VISA 290, FINA 283, FINA 284, FINA 290.

VISA 361.name: Intermediate Sculpture II
VISA 361.desc: Development of personal concerns in three-dimensional work. Emphasis on the integration of diverse materials and techniques.
VISA 361.prer: One of VISA 260, VISA 285, VISA 286, FINA 285, FINA 286.

VISA 371.name: Special Studies II
VISA 371.desc: Intermediate tutorial. Not offered every year.

VISA 401.name: Advanced Open Studio
VISA 401.desc: Research-based studio with thematic or disciplinary focus.  Intended for senior Visual Art undergraduate students.
VISA 401.prer: Three of VISA 310, VISA 311, VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331, VISA 340, VISA 341, VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361, VISA 370, VISA 390.
preq: Three of VISA 310 VISA 311 VISA 320 VISA 321 VISA 330 VISA 331 VISA 340 VISA 341 VISA 350 VISA 351 VISA 360 VISA 361 VISA 370 VISA 390

VISA 410.name: Advanced Digital Arts I
VISA 410.desc: Development of contemporary art works utilizing digital technologies including 3-dimensional applications, spatial, interactive and time-based installations. Focus on student-generated projects, either individual or group.
VISA 410.prer: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.
preq: VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA

VISA 411.name: Advanced Digital Arts II: Video
VISA 411.desc: Contemporary practices in video media examined through individual projects and directed study.
VISA 411.prer: One of VISA 310, VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.
preq: VISA 311. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA

VISA 430.name: Advanced Drawing and Painting I
VISA 430.desc: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media.
VISA 430.prer: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331.
preq: Two of VISA 320 VISA 321 VISA 330 VISA 331

VISA 431.name: Advanced Drawing and Painting II
VISA 431.desc: Interdisciplinary studio practice with emphasis on drawing, painting, and related media.
VISA 431.prer: Two of VISA 320, VISA 321, VISA 330, VISA 331.
preq: Two of VISA 320 VISA 321 VISA 330 VISA 331

VISA 440.name: Advanced Photography I
VISA 440.desc: Photography practice in the context of contemporary art. Interdisciplinary connections to other media will be encouraged.

VISA 441.name: Advanced Photography II
VISA 441.desc: The production of self-directed projects investigating photography as art. Focus on integrative approaches including conventional, digital and multi-media.

VISA 450.name: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture I
VISA 450.desc: Studies in contemporary trends in studio practice and theory. Emphasis on advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media.
VISA 450.prer: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.
preq: VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA

VISA 451.name: Advanced Print Media and Sculpture II
VISA 451.desc: Further studies in advanced two and three-dimensional work developed out of experimental approaches to sculpture, installation art and print-based media.
VISA 451.prer: One of VISA 350, VISA 351, VISA 360, VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA.
preq: VISA 361. Plus an additional 3 credits of 300-level VISA

VISA 469.name: Interdisciplinary Projects
VISA 469.desc: Group projects and workshops with students majoring in other creative arts.

VISA 470.name: Advanced Special Studies I
VISA 470.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Not offered every year.

VISA 471.name: Advanced Special Studies II
VISA 471.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Not offered every year.

VISA 490.name: Advanced Tutorial in Studio I
VISA 490.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required. Not offered every year.
VISA 490.prer: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.

VISA 491.name: Advanced Tutorial in Studio II
VISA 491.desc: Advanced work in contemporary and historical aspects of studio practice. Permission of instructor required.
VISA 491.prer: 6 credits of 300-level VISA and 3 credits of 400-level VISA.

CLCH 399.name: Introduction to Classical Chinese II (Non-Heritage)
CLCH 399.desc: Practice and expansion of the grammar skills learned in CLCH 389; reading of additional and longer passages from the classical canon. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 399 or ASIA 399.

CLCH 401.name: Advanced Readings in Classical Chinese
CLCH 401.desc: Focus on reading longer texts in Classical Chinese, producing careful and polished translation, using appropriate reference works and appreciating nuances of style and genre. Transition from textbook-based study to independent reading and scholarly translation necessary for advanced study and research.

SOAL 100.name: Khichri: The South Asian Languages of Vancouver
SOAL 100.desc: A systematic introduction to the grammars and scripts of Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi and Sanskrit, primarily through the media of Indo-Canadian popular culture (film, radio, bhangra, etc.)

SOAL 440.name: Supervised Study in South Asian Languages

PORT 308.name: Portuguese for Business (in Portuguese)
PORT 308.desc: Communicative Portuguese for students studying Commerce or otherwise preparing for a career in business.

FMST 441.name: Social Context of Child Development
FMST 441.desc: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

FREN 280.name: Introduction to Québécois Literature in Translation
FREN 280.desc: An overview of the novel and theatre of Quebec in the 1960s, 70s, and 80s.

FREN 328.name: Selected Works of African and Caribbean Literature
FREN 328.desc: Representative works from different genres, viewed in their historical, social, and cultural contexts.

FREN 333.name: French Civilization I
FREN 333.desc: A historically based approach to French civilization and culture from their origins to the Third Republic (1875).
FREN 333.prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223. Or permission of the instructor.
preq: FREN 223. Or permission of the instructor

FREN 335.name: French-Canadian Civilization
FREN 335.desc: A thematic approach to selected topics in French-Canadian culture and civilization.
FREN 335.prer: One of FREN 220, FREN 221, FREN 223 or permission of the instructor.

FREN 336.name: The Francophone World in Images
FREN 336.desc: A socio-cultural study of francophone communities of Canada, the Caribbean, Europe, and North and Sub-Saharan Africa as seen through their films and other visual forms.

FREN 344.name: Techniques of Oral Expression in French I
FREN 344.desc: Training in formal oral presentation in French. Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward a Major or Honours Program in French.
FREN 344.prer: One of FREN 215, FREN 225. 68% or better in FREN 215 is recommended.

FREN 345.name: Techniques of Oral Expression in French II
FREN 345.desc: Further training in formal oral presentation in French.  Emphasis on structured expression and oral delivery. Not available for credit toward the Honours Program in French.

FREN 346.name: French at Work
FREN 346.desc: Communicative French for students preparing for a career in the francophone world. Not available for credit toward a Minor, Major, or Honours degree in French. Language of instruction is French.

FREN 348.name: French Literatures in Translation I
FREN 348.desc: Literary works from the Middle Ages to the French Revolution. Not available for credit towards a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.
FREN 348.prer: Second year standing or higher. At least 6 credits of English, or equivalent, is strongly recommended.
preq: higher. At least 6 credits of English

FREN 349.name: French Literatures in Translation II
FREN 349.desc: Literary works since the French Revolution.  Topics may include literature from France, Quebec, Africa, the Caribbean.  Not available for credit towards a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.
FREN 349.prer: Second year standing or higher. At least 6 credits of English, or equivalent, is strongly recommended.
preq: higher. At least 6 credits of English

FREN 357.name: Translation I
FREN 357.desc: Comparative study of French and English through translation.

FREN 360.name: Introduction to Old French
FREN 360.desc: The phonetics, grammar, and vocabulary of major Old French dialects; corpus of various literary texts (842-1300).

FREN 380.name: Foundations of French Cultural Identity (in English)
FREN 380.desc: Aspects of French culture through a set of key concepts that cut across French history, politics, and social structures. Not available for credit toward a Minor, Major or Honours program in French.

FREN 407.name: Studies in Medieval French Literature
FREN 407.desc: Literary texts from the eleventh to the fifteenth century. Topics may include the epic, Tristan texts, Arthurian texts, the short narrative, satirical texts, religious drama, secular drama, lyric poetry, didactic poetry, François Villon.
FREN 407.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 408.name: Studies in French Literature of the Sixteenth Century
FREN 408.desc: Topics may include works by Rabelais, Montaigne, Scève, Labé, Ronsard, and DuBellay.
FREN 408.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 409.name: Studies in French Literature of the Seventeenth Century
FREN 409.desc: Topics may include works by Corneille, Racine, Molière, Descartes, Pascal, La Fontaine, and Mme de la Fayette.
FREN 409.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 410.name: Studies in French Literature of the Eighteenth Century
FREN 410.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 413.name: Studies in French Literature of the Nineteenth Century
FREN 413.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 416.name: Studies in French Literature since 1900
FREN 416.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 418.name: Studies in African and/or Caribbean Literatures of French Expression
FREN 418.desc: An introduction to representative works. Topics include Negritude, the evolution of post-colonial literature, and the socio-historical context of each work.
FREN 418.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 419.name: Studies in Women's Writing
FREN 419.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 420.name: Selected Topics in French Literature and Culture
FREN 420.desc: Course content will vary. May be taken up to 3 times, with different content, for a maximum of 9 credits.
FREN 420.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 423.name: Studies in Theatre
FREN 423.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 424.name: Studies in Prose Fiction
FREN 424.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 425.name: Studies in French Autobiography
FREN 425.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 427.name: Studies in Cinema
FREN 427.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 429.name: Studies in Non-fiction Prose
FREN 429.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 430.name: Studies in Quebecois Literature
FREN 430.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330, FREN 335.

FREN 460.name: Studies in Historical French Linguistics
FREN 460.desc: Topics may include historical phonetics and phonology, morphology and syntax, lexicology.

FREN 470.name: Studies in Modern French Linguistics
FREN 470.crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 470.
creq: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 470

FREN 472.name: Morphology of the French Language
FREN 472.desc: The morphological markings of French (gender, number, tense, mode, person, etc) and their underlying semantic systems.
FREN 472.crer: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
creq: FREN 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor

FREN 473.name: Syntactic Description of the French Language
FREN 473.desc: The syntactic markings of French (word order, agreement, pronominalisation, etc) and their underlying semantic systems.
FREN 473.crer: FREN 353 and 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
creq: 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor

FREN 474.name: Synchronic Lexicology
FREN 474.desc: An introduction to the study of the vocabulary of modern French, focusing on basic principles in lexical semantics, lexicology, phraseology, lexicography, terminology and new technologies, neology.
FREN 474.crer: FREN 353 and 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 474.
creq: 370 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor of FREN 474

FREN 475.name: Canadian French: A Descriptive Approach
FREN 475.desc: The phonetics, phonology, lexicon, and syntax of spoken and written Canadian French.
FREN 475.crer: FREN 351 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor.
creq: FREN 351 may be taken concurrently with the permission of the instructor

FREN 481.name: Studies in Literature and the Arts
FREN 481.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 482.name: Studies in Literature and Philosophy
FREN 482.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 483.name: Studies in Literature and History
FREN 483.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 484.name: Studies in Book Culture
FREN 484.desc: A historical approach to the social transformations of the book trade in France.
FREN 484.crer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 495.name: Research Seminar in French
FREN 495.desc: Research on critical topics related to selected literary works. Limited enrolment: required of honours, but open to majors students in French.
FREN 495.prer: One of FREN 320, FREN 321, FREN 328, FREN 329, FREN 330.

FREN 498.name: Directed Reading
FREN 498.desc: For fourth-year students. Focus on a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student. Permission of the department head and of a supervisory faculty member is required.
